column4: IT WAS SO USED FOR THE DATE OF THE ABOLITION OF THE STAR CHAMBER IN THE SIXTEENTH CHARLES THE FIRST
column5: it was so used for the date of the abolition of the star chamber in the sixteenth charles the first

column4: THE SHAMEFUL MALPRACTICES OF BAMBRIDGE
column5: the shameful malpractices of bambridge

column4: THE WARDEN OF THE FLEET AT THE COMMENCEMENT OF THE EIGHTEENTH CENTURY ARE TOO WELL KNOWN TO NEED MORE THAN A PASSING REFERENCE
column5: the warden of the fleet at the commencement of the eighteenth century are too well known to need more than a passing reference

column5: a committee of the house of commons investigated the charges against bambridge who was proved to have connived at the escape of some debtors

column4: AND TO HAVE BEEN GUILTY OF EXTORTION TO OTHERS ONE SIR WILLIAM RICH BART HE HAD LOADED WITH HEAVY IRONS
column5: and to have been guilty of extortion to others one sir william rich bart he had loaded with heavy irons

column5: in consequence of these disclosures both bambridge and huggin his predecessor in the office were committed to newgate

column4: AND MANY REFORMS INSTITUTED BUT THE CONDITION OF THE PRISON AND ITS INMATES REMAINED UNSATISFACTORY TO THE LAST
column5: and many reforms instituted but the condition of the prison and its inmates remained unsatisfactory to the last

column4: IT CONTAINED GENERALLY FROM SIX TO SEVEN HUNDRED INMATES WHILE ANOTHER HUNDRED MORE OR LESS RESIDED IN THE RULES OUTSIDE
column5: it contained generally from six to seven hundred inmates while another hundred more or less resided in the rules outside

column4: THE PRINCIPLE OF CHUMMAGE PREVAILED AS IN THE KING'S BENCH
column5: the principle of chummage prevailed as in the king's bench

column4: BUT A NUMBER OF ROOMS FIFTEEN MORE OR LESS WERE RESERVED FOR POOR DEBTORS UNDER THE NAME OF BARTHOLOMEW FAIR
column5: but a number of rooms fifteen more or less were reserved for poor debtors under the name of bartholomew fair

column4: THE RENTALS OF ROOMS AND FEES WENT TO THE WARDEN WHOSE INCOME WAS TWO THOUSAND THREE HUNDRED SEVENTYTWO POUNDS
column5: the rentals of rooms and fees went to the warden whose income was two thousand three hundred seventytwo pounds

column4: THE SAME EVILS OF OVERCROWDING UNCLEANLINESS WANT OF MEDICAL ATTENDANCE
column5: the same evils of overcrowding uncleanliness want of medical attendance

column4: ABSENCE OR NEGLECT OF DIVINE SERVICE WERE PRESENT AS IN THE KING'S BENCH BUT IN AN EXAGGERATED FORM
column5: absence or neglect of divine service were present as in the king's bench but in an exaggerated form

column4: THE COMMITTEE ON JAILS REPORTED THAT QUOTE ALTHOUGH THE HOUSE OF THE WARDEN LOOKED INTO THE COURT
column5: the committee on jails reported that quote although the house of the warden looked into the court

column4: AND THE TURNKEYS SLEPT IN THE PRISON YET SCENES OF RIOT DRUNKENNESS AND DISORDER WERE MOST PREVALENT END QUOTE
column5: and the turnkeys slept in the prison yet scenes of riot drunkenness and disorder were most prevalent end quote

column4: THE STATE OF MORALS WAS DISGRACEFUL ANY WOMAN OBTAINED ADMISSION IF SOBER AND IF SHE GOT DRUNK SHE WAS NOT TURNED OUT
column5: the state of morals was disgraceful any woman obtained admission if sober and if she got drunk she was not turned out

column4: THERE WAS NO DISTINCT PLACE FOR THE FEMALE DEBTORS WHO LIVED IN THE SAME GALLERIES AS THE MEN
column5: there was no distinct place for the female debtors who lived in the same galleries as the men

column4: DISTURBANCES WERE FREQUENT OWING TO THE RIOTOUS CONDUCT OF INTOXICATED WOMEN
column5: disturbances were frequent owing to the riotous conduct of intoxicated women

column4: TWICE A WEEK THERE WAS A WINE AND BEER CLUB HELD AT NIGHT WHICH LASTED TILL TWO OR THREE IN THE MORNING
column5: twice a week there was a wine and beer club held at night which lasted till two or three in the morning

column4: IN THE YARD BEHIND THE PRISON
column5: in the yard behind the prison

column4: WERE PLACES SET APART FOR SKITTLES FIVES AND TENNIS WHICH STRANGERS FREQUENTED AS ANY OTHER PLACE OF PUBLIC AMUSEMENT
column5: were places set apart for skittles fives and tennis which strangers frequented as any other place of public amusement

column4: MATTERS WERE RATHER BETTER AT THE MARSHALSEA
column5: matters were rather better at the marshalsea

column4: THIS VERY ANCIENT PRISON WHICH STOOD IN THE HIGH STREET SOUTHWARK
column5: this very ancient prison which stood in the high street southwark

column4: WAS USED FOR DEBTORS ARRESTED FOR THE LOWEST SUMS WITHIN TWELVE MILES OF THE PALACE OF WHITEHALL
column5: was used for debtors arrested for the lowest sums within twelve miles of the palace of whitehall

column4: ALSO FOR PRISONERS COMMITTED BY THE ADMIRALTY COURT
column5: also for prisoners committed by the admiralty court

column5: at one time the marshalsea was the receptacle of pirates but none were committed to it after seventeen eightynine

column5: the court of the marshalsea was instituted by charles the first in the sixth year of his reign

column4: TO BE HELD BEFORE THE STEWARD OF THE ROYAL HOUSEHOLD THE KNIGHT MARSHAL AND THE STEWARD OF THE COURT
column5: to be held before the steward of the royal household the knight marshal and the steward of the court

column5: with jurisdiction to hold pleas in all actions within the prescribed limits the court was chiefly used for the recovery of small debts under ten pounds

column4: BUT ITS BUSINESS WAS MUCH REDUCED BY THE EXTENSION OF THE COURTS OF CONSCIENCE
column5: but its business was much reduced by the extension of the courts of conscience

column4: THE PRISON WAS A NEST OF ABUSES LIKE ITS NEIGHBOR THE KING'S BENCH
column5: the prison was a nest of abuses like its neighbor the king's bench

column4: AND CAME UNDER THE STRONG ANIMADVERSION OF THE JAIL COMMITTEE OF SEVENTEEN TWENTYNINE
column5: and came under the strong animadversion of the jail committee of seventeen twentynine

column4: AS THE BUSINESS OF THE MARSHALSEA COURT DECLINED THE NUMBERS IN ITS PRISON DIMINISHED
column5: as the business of the marshalsea court declined the numbers in its prison diminished

column4: THE POPULATION AS REPORTED BY THE COMMITTEE IN EIGHTEEN FOURTEEN AVERAGED ABOUT SIXTY
column5: the population as reported by the committee in eighteen fourteen averaged about sixty

column4: AND THE PRISON ALTHOUGH WIVES AND CHILDREN RESIDED WITHIN THE WALLS WAS NOT OVERCROWDED
column5: and the prison although wives and children resided within the walls was not overcrowded

column4: THEIR CONDUCT TOO WAS ORDERLY ON THE WHOLE
column5: their conduct too was orderly on the whole

column4: DRUNKENNESS WAS NOT COMMON CHIEFLY BECAUSE LIQUOR WAS NOT TO BE HAD FREELY ALTHOUGH THE TAPSTER PAID A RENT OF TWO GUINEAS A WEEK FOR PERMISSION TO SELL IT
column5: drunkenness was not common chiefly because liquor was not to be had freely although the tapster paid a rent of two guineas a week for permission to sell it

column5: the inmates who euphemistically styled themselves collegians

column4: WERE GOVERNED BY RULES WHICH THEY THEMSELVES HAD FRAMED AND UNDER WHICH SUBSCRIPTIONS WERE LEVIED
column5: were governed by rules which they themselves had framed and under which subscriptions were levied

column4: AND FINES IMPOSED FOR CONDUCT DISAPPROVED OF BY THE COLLEGE
column5: and fines imposed for conduct disapproved of by the college

column5: a court of the collegians was held every monday to manage its affairs at which all prisoners were required to attend

column5: a committee of collegians was elected to act as the executive also a secretary or accountant to receive monies and keep books

column4: AND A MASTER OF THE ALEROOM WHO KEPT THIS THE SCENE OF THEIR REVELS CLEAN AND SAW THAT BOILING WATER WAS PROVIDED FOR GROG
column5: and a master of the aleroom who kept this the scene of their revels clean and saw that boiling water was provided for grog

column4: BAD LANGUAGE QUARRELING THROWING WATER OVER ONE ANOTHER WAS FORBIDDEN ON PAIN OF FINE AND BEING SENT TO COVENTRY
column5: bad language quarreling throwing water over one another was forbidden on pain of fine and being sent to coventry

column4: BUT THE PREVAILING MORAL TONE MAY BE GUESSED FROM THE PENALTY INFLICTED UPON PERSONS SINGING OBSCENE SONGS BEFORE NINE PM
column5: but the prevailing moral tone may be guessed from the penalty inflicted upon persons singing obscene songs before nine pm

column4: YET THE PUBLIC OPINION OF THE WHOLE BODY SEEMS TO HAVE CHECKED DISSIPATION
column5: yet the public opinion of the whole body seems to have checked dissipation

column4: THE POORER PRISONERS WERE NOT IN ABJECT WANT AS IN OTHER PRISONS
column5: the poorer prisoners were not in abject want as in other prisons

column4: OWING TO MANY CHARITABLE GIFTS AND BEQUESTS WHICH INCLUDED ANNUAL DONATIONS FROM THE ARCHBISHOP OF CANTERBURY
column5: owing to many charitable gifts and bequests which included annual donations from the archbishop of canterbury

column4: THE LORD STEWARD OF THE HOUSEHOLD THE STEWARD AND OFFICERS OF THE MARSHALSEA COURT AND OTHERS
column5: the lord steward of the household the steward and officers of the marshalsea court and others

column5: legacies had also been left to free a certain number of debtors notably that of one hundred pounds per annum

column4: LEFT BY A MR HENRY ALLNUTT WHO WAS LONG A PRISONER IN THE MARSHALSEA AND CAME INTO A FORTUNE WHILE THERE
column5: left by a mr henry allnutt who was long a prisoner in the marshalsea and came into a fortune while there

column4: HIS BEQUEST WHICH WAS CHARGED UPON HIS MANOR AT GORING OXON AND HENCE CALLED THE OXFORD CHARITY
column5: his bequest which was charged upon his manor at goring oxon and hence called the oxford charity

column4: WAS APPLIED ONLY TO THE RELEASE OF POOR DEBTORS WHOM FOUR POUNDS EACH COULD FREE
column5: was applied only to the release of poor debtors whom four pounds each could free

column4: THE SUPREME CONTROL OF THE MARSHALSEA WAS VESTED IN THE MARSHAL OF THE ROYAL HOUSEHOLD BUT ALTHOUGH HE DREW A SALARY OF FIVE HUNDRED POUNDS A YEAR
column5: the supreme control of the marshalsea was vested in the marshal of the royal household but although he drew a salary of five hundred pounds a year

column5: he did nothing beyond visiting the prison occasionally and left the administration to the deputy marshal

column4: THE LATTER'S SALARY WITH FEES THE RENT OF THE TAP AND OF THE CHANDLER'S SHOP AMOUNTED TO ABOUT SIX HUNDRED POUNDS A YEAR
column5: the latter's salary with fees the rent of the tap and of the chandler's shop amounted to about six hundred pounds a year

column4: THE COMPTERS OF LUDGATE GILTSPUR STREET AND THE BOROUGH WERE DISCONTINUED AS DEBTORS' PRISONS AS WAS NEWGATE ALSO
column5: the compters of ludgate giltspur street and the borough were discontinued as debtors' prisons as was newgate also

column4: ON THE OPENING OF WHITECROSS PRISON FOR DEBTORS IN EIGHTEEN FIFTEEN
column5: on the opening of whitecross prison for debtors in eighteen fifteen

column4: LUDGATE TO THE LAST WAS THE DEBTORS' PRISON FOR FREEMEN OF THE CITY OF LONDON
column5: ludgate to the last was the debtors' prison for freemen of the city of london

column4: CLERGYMEN PROCTORS ATTORNEYS AND PERSONS SPECIALLY SELECTED BY THE CORPORATION
column5: clergymen proctors attorneys and persons specially selected by the corporation

column4: AT ONE TIME THE LUDGATE DEBTORS ACCOMPANIED BY THE KEEPER
column5: at one time the ludgate debtors accompanied by the keeper

column5: went outside and beyond the prison to call on their creditors and try to arrange their debts but this practice was discontinued

column4: THERE WERE FIFTEEN ROOMS OF VARIOUS SIZES AND AS THE NUMBERS IMPRISONED RARELY EXCEEDED FIVEANDTWENTY THE PLACE WAS NEVER OVERCROWDED
column5: there were fifteen rooms of various sizes and as the numbers imprisoned rarely exceeded fiveandtwenty the place was never overcrowded

column5: while the funds of several bequests and charities were applied in adding to the material comfort of the prisoners

column5: the giltspur street compter received sheriffs' debtors also felons vagrants and night charges

column4: IT WAS GENERALLY CROWDED AS DEBTORS WHO WOULD HAVE GONE TO THE POULTRY COMPTER WERE SENT TO GILTSPUR STREET WHEN THE FORMER WAS CONDEMNED AS UNFIT TO RECEIVE PRISONERS
column5: it was generally crowded as debtors who would have gone to the poultry compter were sent to giltspur street when the former was condemned as unfit to receive prisoners

column5: the demands for fees were excessive in giltspur street

column5: those who could not pay were thrown into the wards with the night charges

column4: AND DENIED ADMISSION TO THE CHARITY WARDS WHICH PARTOOK OF ALL THE BENEFITS OF BEQUESTS AND DONATIONS TO POOR DEBTORS
column5: and denied admission to the charity wards which partook of all the benefits of bequests and donations to poor debtors

column5: the borough compter was in a disgraceful state to the last the men's ward had an earth or rather a mud floor

column5: and was so unfit to sleep on that it had not been used for many years so that the men and women associated together indiscriminately

column4: THE ROOMS HAD NO FIREPLACES SO IT MATTERED LITTLE THAT NO COALS WERE ALLOWED
column5: the rooms had no fireplaces so it mattered little that no coals were allowed

column4: THERE WERE NO BEDS OR BEDDING NO STRAW EVEN
column5: there were no beds or bedding no straw even

column5: in one room mr neild found a woman ill of a flux shut up with three men

column5: the latter raised eighteen pence among them to pay for a truss of straw for the poor woman to lie on

column4: NEILD FOUND THE PRISONERS IN THE BOROUGH COMPTER RAGGED STARVING AND DIRTY
column5: neild found the prisoners in the borough compter ragged starving and dirty

column4: I COME NOW TO THE DEBTORS IN NEWGATE THE QUARTERS THEY OCCUPIED WERE DIVIDED AS I HAVE SAID INTO THREE PRINCIPAL DIVISIONS
column5: i come now to the debtors in newgate the quarters they occupied were divided as i have said into three principal divisions

column5: the master's side the cabin side and the common side payment of a fee of three shillings gained the debtor admission to the two first named

column5: those who could pay nothing went as a matter of course to the common side

column4: A FURTHER FEE WAS HOWEVER DEMANDED FROM THE NEWCOMER BEFORE HE WAS MADE FREE OF EITHER THE MASTER'S OR THE CABIN SIDE
column5: a further fee was however demanded from the newcomer before he was made free of either the master's or the cabin side

column4: THIS WAS THE REPREHENSIBLE CLAIM FOR GARNISH WHICH HAD ALREADY BEEN ABOLISHED IN ALL WELLCONDUCTED PRISONS BUT WHICH STILL WAS DEMANDED IN NEWGATE
column5: this was the reprehensible claim for garnish which had already been abolished in all wellconducted prisons but which still was demanded in newgate

column5: garnish on the cabin side was a guinea at entrance for coals candles brooms etc and a gallon of beer on discharge

column4: ON THE MASTER'S SIDE IT WAS THIRTEEN AND FOURPENCE AND A GALLON OF BEER ON ENTRANCE ALTHOUGH MR NEWMAN
column5: on the master's side it was thirteen and fourpence and a gallon of beer on entrance although mr newman

column4: IN HIS EVIDENCE IN EIGHTEEN FOURTEEN SAID IT WAS MORE
column5: in his evidence in eighteen fourteen said it was more

column4: AND GAVE THE GARNISH FOR THE COMMON SIDE AT THAT SUM WHICH IS FIVE SHILLINGS MORE THAN MR NEILD SAYS WAS EXTORTED ON THE COMMON SIDE
column5: and gave the garnish for the common side at that sum which is five shillings more than mr neild says was extorted on the common side

column5: numerous tyrannies were practiced on all who would not and could not pay the garnish

column5: they were made to wash and swab the ward or they were shut out from the ward fireplace and forbidden to pass a chalked line drawn on the floor

column5: and so were unable either to warm themselves or to cook their food

column5: besides these fees legitimate and illegitimate there were others which must be paid before release

column5: the sheriff demanded four shillings six pence for his liberate the jailer six shillings ten pence more and the turnkey two shillings

column4: AND THUS WHEN THE DEBTOR'S DEBT HAD BEEN ACTUALLY PAID OR WHEN HE HAD ABANDONED HIS PROPERTY TO THE CREDITORS AND ALMOST DESTITUTE
column5: and thus when the debtor's debt had been actually paid or when he had abandoned his property to the creditors and almost destitute

column4: LOOKED FORWARD TO HIS LIBERTY HE WAS STILL DELAYED UNTIL HE HAD PAID A NEW DEBT ARISING QUOTE
column5: looked forward to his liberty he was still delayed until he had paid a new debt arising quote

column4: ONLY OUT OF A SATISFACTION OF ALL HIS FORMER DEBTS END QUOTE THE FEES WERE NOT ALWAYS EXTORTED IT IS TRUE
column5: only out of a satisfaction of all his former debts end quote the fees were not always extorted it is true

column5: nor was nonpayment made a pretext for further imprisonment thanks to the humanity of the jailer or the funds provided by various charities

column5: there was this much honest forbearance in newgate in these days

column5: that debtors who could afford the cabin and master's side were not permitted to share in the prison charities

column4: THESE WERE LUMPED TOGETHER INTO A GENERAL FUND
column5: these were lumped together into a general fund

column5: and a calculation made as to the amount that might be expended per week from the whole sum so that the latter might last out the year

column4: IT GENERALLY RAN TO ABOUT SIX POUNDS PER WEEK THE MONEY WHICH AT ONE TIME HAD BEEN DISTRIBUTED QUARTERLY AND ALL WENT IN DRINK
column5: it generally ran to about six pounds per week the money which at one time had been distributed quarterly and all went in drink

column5: was after eighteen oh seven through the exertions of the keeper of the jail spent in the purchase of necessaries

column4: BUT THIS WEEKLY PITTANCE DID NOT GO FAR WHEN THE DEBTORS' SIDE WAS CROWDED AS IT OFTEN WAS

column5: notably as when numbers filled newgate in anticipation of lord redesdale's bill for insolvent debtors

column5: and there were as many as three hundred and fifty prisoners in at one time

column5: the city also allowed the poor debtors fourteen ounces of bread daily and their share of eight stone of meat an allowance which never varied

column5: issued once a week and divided as far as it would go  a very precarious and uncertain ration

column5: others who arrived just after the time of distribution were often fortyeight hours without food the latter might also be six days without meat

column5: share in the weekly allowance of meat might also be denied to debtors who had not paid garnish as well as in the weekly grant from the charitable fund

column4: HENCE STARVATION STARED MANY IN THE FACE UNLESS FRIENDS FROM OUTSIDE CAME TO THEIR ASSISTANCE
column5: hence starvation stared many in the face unless friends from outside came to their assistance

column5: or the sixpenny allowance was claimed for the creditors which seldom happened owing to the expense the process entailed

column5: sometimes rugs were urgently required and not forthcoming

column5: a severe winter set in the new stock had not been supplied by the contractors and the poor debtors perished of cold

column5: again there was no regular allowance of fuel coals were purchased out of the garnish money and the charitable fund

column4: SO WERE CANDLES SALT PEPPER MOPS AND BROOMS BUT THE LATTER COULD HAVE BEEN OF LITTLE SERVICE DIRT PREVAILED EVERYWHERE

column4: INDEED THE PLACE WITH ITS OAK FLOORS CAULKED WITH PITCH AND SMOKED CEILINGS
column5: indeed the place with its oak floors caulked with pitch and smoked ceilings

column5: could not be made even to look clean while there was no obligation of personal cleanliness on individuals who often came into the prison in filthy rags

column5: only now and again in extreme cases an unusually nasty companion was stripped haled to the pump

column5: the chronicles of newgate volume two by arthur griffiths section five newgate down to eighteen eighteen part two

column4: THE SQUALOR AND UNCLEANNESS OF THE DEBTORS' SIDE WAS INTENSIFIED BY CONSTANT OVERCROWDING
column5: the squalor and uncleanness of the debtors' side was intensified by constant overcrowding

column4: PRISONERS WERE COMMITTED TO IT QUITE WITHOUT REFERENCE TO ITS CAPACITY
column5: prisoners were committed to it quite without reference to its capacity

column4: NO REMONSTRANCE WAS ATTENDED TO
column5: no remonstrance was attended to

column4: NO STEPS TAKEN TO REDUCE THE NUMBER OF COMMITTALS AND THE GOVERNOR WAS OBLIGED TO UTILIZE THE CHAPEL AS A DAY AND NIGHT ROOM
column5: no steps taken to reduce the number of committals and the governor was obliged to utilize the chapel as a day and night room

column4: BESIDES THIS ALTHOUGH THE FAMILIES OF DEBTORS WERE NO LONGER PERMITTED TO LIVE WITH THEM INSIDE THE JAIL
column5: besides this although the families of debtors were no longer permitted to live with them inside the jail

column4: HUNDREDS OF WOMEN AND CHILDREN CAME IN EVERY MORNING TO SPEND THE DAY THERE AND THERE WAS NO LIMITATION WHATEVER TO THE NUMBERS OF VISITORS ADMITTED TO THE DEBTORS' SIDE
column5: hundreds of women and children came in every morning to spend the day there and there was no limitation whatever to the numbers of visitors admitted to the debtors' side

column4: FRIENDS ARRIVED ABOUT NINE AM AND WENT OUT AT NINE PM WHEN AS MANY AS TWO HUNDRED VISITORS HAVE BEEN OBSERVED LEAVING THE DEBTORS' YARDS AT ONE TIME
column5: friends arrived about nine am and went out at nine pm when as many as two hundred visitors have been observed leaving the debtors' yards at one time

column4: THE DAY PASSED IN REVELRY AND DRUNKENNESS ALTHOUGH SPIRITUOUS LIQUORS WERE FORBIDDEN
column5: the day passed in revelry and drunkenness although spirituous liquors were forbidden

column4: WINE AND BEER MIGHT BE HAD IN ANY QUANTITY THE ONLY LIMITATION BEING
column5: wine and beer might be had in any quantity the only limitation being

column4: THAT NOT MORE THAN ONE BOTTLE OF WINE OR ONE QUART OF BEER COULD BE ISSUED AT ONE TIME NO ACCOUNT WAS TAKEN OF THE AMOUNT OF LIQUORS ADMITTED IN ONE DAY
column5: that not more than one bottle of wine or one quart of beer could be issued at one time no account was taken of the amount of liquors admitted in one day

column4: AND DEBTORS MIGHT PRACTICALLY HAVE AS MUCH AS THEY LIKED IF THEY COULD ONLY PAY FOR IT
column5: and debtors might practically have as much as they liked if they could only pay for it

column4: NO ATTEMPT WAS MADE TO CHECK DRUNKENNESS BEYOND THE PENALTY OF SHUTTING OUT FRIENDS FROM ANY WARD IN WHICH A PRISONER EXCEEDED
column5: no attempt was made to check drunkenness beyond the penalty of shutting out friends from any ward in which a prisoner exceeded

column4: QUARRELING AMONG THE DEBTORS WAS NOT UNFREQUENT BLOWS WERE STRUCK AND FIGHTS OFTEN ENSUED
column5: quarreling among the debtors was not unfrequent blows were struck and fights often ensued

column4: FOR THIS AND OTHER ACTS OF MISCONDUCT THERE WAS THE DISCIPLINE OF THE REFRACTORY WARD OR STRONG ROOM ON THE DEBTORS' SIDE
column5: for this and other acts of misconduct there was the discipline of the refractory ward or strong room on the debtors' side

column4: BAD CASES WERE REMOVED TO A CELL ON THE FELONS' SIDE AND HERE THEY WERE LOCKED IN SOLITARY CONFINEMENT FOR THREE DAYS AT A TIME
column5: bad cases were removed to a cell on the felons' side and here they were locked in solitary confinement for three days at a time

column4: ORDER THROUGHOUT THE DEBTORS' SIDE WAS PRESERVED
column5: order throughout the debtors' side was preserved

column4: AND DISCIPLINE MAINTAINED BY A SYSTEM OPEN TO GRAVE ABUSES AND WHICH HAD THE PRESCRIPTION OF LONG USAGE
column5: and discipline maintained by a system open to grave abuses and which had the prescription of long usage

column4: AND WHICH WAS NEVER WHOLLY ROOTED OUT FOR MANY YEARS TO COME
column5: and which was never wholly rooted out for many years to come

column4: THIS WAS THE PERNICIOUS PLAN OF GOVERNING BY PRISONERS OR OF SETTING A FAVORED FEW IN AUTHORITY OVER THE MANY
column5: this was the pernicious plan of governing by prisoners or of setting a favored few in authority over the many

column4: THE HEAD OF THE DEBTORS' PRISON WAS A PRISONER CALLED THE STEWARD WHO WAS CHOSEN BY THE WHOLE BODY FROM SIX WHOM THE KEEPER NOMINATED
column5: the head of the debtors' prison was a prisoner called the steward who was chosen by the whole body from six whom the keeper nominated

column4: THIS STEWARD WAS PRACTICALLY SUPREME
column5: this steward was practically supreme

column4: ALL THE ALLOWANCES OF FOOD PASSED THROUGH HIS HANDS HE HAD THE CONTROL OF THE POORBOX FOR CHANCE CHARITIES
column5: all the allowances of food passed through his hands he had the control of the poorbox for chance charities

column4: HE COLLECTED THE GARNISH MONEY AND DISTRIBUTED THE WEEKLY GRANT FROM THE PRISON CHARITABLE FUND
column5: he collected the garnish money and distributed the weekly grant from the prison charitable fund

column4: IN THE LATTER DUTIES HE WAS HOWEVER SUPERVISED BY THREE AUDITORS FREELY CHOSEN BY THE PRISONERS AMONG THEMSELVES
column5: in the latter duties he was however supervised by three auditors freely chosen by the prisoners among themselves

column4: THE AUDITORS WERE PAID A SHILLING EACH FOR THEIR SERVICES EACH TIME THE POORBOX WAS OPENED THE STEWARD WAS ALSO REMUNERATED FOR HIS TROUBLE
column5: the auditors were paid a shilling each for their services each time the poorbox was opened the steward was also remunerated for his trouble

column4: HE HAD A DOUBLE ALLOWANCE OF BREAD DEDUCTED OF COURSE FROM THE ALREADY TOO LIMITED PORTION OF THE REST
column5: he had a double allowance of bread deducted of course from the already too limited portion of the rest

column4: AND NO DOUBT MADE THE MEAT ALSO PAY TOLL
column5: and no doubt made the meat also pay toll

column4: UNDER THE STEWARD THERE WERE CAPTAINS OF WARDS CHOSEN IN THE SAME WAY AND PERFORMING ANALOGOUS DUTIES
column5: under the steward there were captains of wards chosen in the same way and performing analogous duties

column4: THESE SUBORDINATE CHIEFS WERE ALSO REWARDED OUT OF THE SCANTY PRISON RATIONS
column5: these subordinate chiefs were also rewarded out of the scanty prison rations

column4: THE SAME SYSTEM WAS EXTENDED TO THE CRIMINAL SIDE AND CASES WERE ON RECORD OF THE PLACE OF WARDSMAN BEING SOLD FOR CONSIDERABLE SUMS
column5: the same system was extended to the criminal side and cases were on record of the place of wardsman being sold for considerable sums

column4: SO VALUABLE WERE THEY DEEMED THAT AS MUCH AS FIFTY GUINEAS WAS OFFERED TO THE KEEPER FOR THE POST
column5: so valuable were they deemed that as much as fifty guineas was offered to the keeper for the post

column4: ENOUGH HAS BEEN SAID PROBABLY TO PROVE THAT THERE WAS ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT IN THE CONDITION AND TREATMENT OF DEBTORS IN THE PRISONS OF THE CITY OF LONDON
column5: enough has been said probably to prove that there was room for improvement in the condition and treatment of debtors in the prisons of the city of london

column4: THIS GRADUALLY WAS FORCED UPON THE CONSCIOUSNESS OF THE CORPORATION
column5: this gradually was forced upon the consciousness of the corporation

column4: AND ABOUT EIGHTEEN TWELVE APPLICATION WAS MADE TO PARLIAMENT FOR FUNDS TO BUILD A NEW DEBTORS' PRISON
column5: and about eighteen twelve application was made to parliament for funds to build a new debtors' prison

column4: AUTHORITY WAS GIVEN TO RAISE MONEY ON THE ORPHANS' FUND TO THE EXTENT OF NINETY THOUSAND POUNDS
column5: authority was given to raise money on the orphans' fund to the extent of ninety thousand pounds

column4: A SITE WAS PURCHASED BETWEEN RED LION AND WHITE CROSS STREETS AND A NEW PRISON PLANNED
column5: a site was purchased between red lion and white cross streets and a new prison planned

column4: WHICH WOULD ACCOMMODATE THE INMATES OF NEWGATE AND OF THE THREE COMPTERS LUDGATE
column5: which would accommodate the inmates of newgate and of the three compters ludgate

column4: GILTSPUR STREET AND THE POULTRY OR ABOUT FOUR HUNDRED AND SEVENTYSIX IN ALL
column5: giltspur street and the poultry or about four hundred and seventysix in all

column4: THE EVILS OF ASSOCIATION FOR THESE DEBTORS WERE PERPETUATED ALTHOUGH THE PLAN PROVIDED FOR THE SEPARATION OF THE VARIOUS CONTINGENTS COMMITTED TO IT
column5: the evils of association for these debtors were perpetuated although the plan provided for the separation of the various contingents committed to it

column4: THERE WAS NO LACK OF AIR AND LIGHT FOR THE NEW JAIL AND SEVERAL EXERCISING YARDS
column5: there was no lack of air and light for the new jail and several exercising yards

column4: THE COMPLETION OF THIS VERY NECESSARY BUILDING WAS HOWEVER MUCH DELAYED FOR WANT OF FUNDS
column5: the completion of this very necessary building was however much delayed for want of funds

column4: AND IT WAS NOT READY TO RELIEVE NEWGATE TILL LATE IN EIGHTEEN FIFTEEN
column5: and it was not ready to relieve newgate till late in eighteen fifteen

column4: THE REFORMS WHICH WERE TO BE ATTEMPTED IN THAT PRISON
column5: the reforms which were to be attempted in that prison

column4: MORE PARTICULARLY AS REGARDED THE CLASSIFICATION OF PRISONERS AND WHICH WERE DEPENDENT ON THE SPACE TO BE GAINED BY THE REMOVAL OF THE DEBTORS
column5: more particularly as regarded the classification of prisoners and which were dependent on the space to be gained by the removal of the debtors

column4: COULD NOT BE CARRIED OUT TILL THEN IT IS TO BE FEARED THAT LONG AFTER THE OPENING OF WHITE CROSS STREET PRISON
column5: could not be carried out till then it is to be feared that long after the opening of white cross street prison

column4: NEWGATE CONTINUED TO BE A REPROACH TO THOSE RESPONSIBLE FOR ITS MANAGEMENT
column5: newgate continued to be a reproach to those responsible for its management

column4: I PASS NOW TO THE CRIMINAL SIDE OF NEWGATE WHICH CONSISTED OF THE SIX QUARTERS OR YARDS ALREADY ENUMERATED AND DESCRIBED
column5: i pass now to the criminal side of newgate which consisted of the six quarters or yards already enumerated and described

column4: THE INMATES OF THIS PART AS DISTINGUISHED FROM THE DEBTORS WERE COMPRISED IN FOUR CLASSES
column5: the inmates of this part as distinguished from the debtors were comprised in four classes

column4: ONE THOSE AWAITING TRIAL
column5: one those awaiting trial

column4: TWO PERSONS UNDER SENTENCE OF IMPRISONMENT FOR A FIXED PERIOD OR UNTIL THEY SHALL HAVE PAID CERTAIN FINES
column5: two persons under sentence of imprisonment for a fixed period or until they shall have paid certain fines

column4: THREE TRANSPORTS AWAITING REMOVAL TO THE COLONIES AND FOUR CAPITAL CONVICTS CONDEMNED TO DEATH AND AWAITING EXECUTION
column5: three transports awaiting removal to the colonies and four capital convicts condemned to death and awaiting execution

column4: AT ONE TIME THE WHOLE OF THESE DIFFERENT CATEGORIES WERE THROWN TOGETHER PELLMELL YOUNG AND OLD THE UNTRIED WITH THE CONVICTED
column5: at one time the whole of these different categories were thrown together pellmell young and old the untried with the convicted

column4: AN IMPERFECT ATTEMPT AT CLASSIFICATION WAS HOWEVER MADE IN EIGHTEEN TWELVE AND A YARD WAS AS FAR AS POSSIBLE SET APART FOR THE UNTRIED
column5: an imperfect attempt at classification was however made in eighteen twelve and a yard was as far as possible set apart for the untried

column4: OR CLASS ONE WITH WHOM UNDER THE IMPERIOUS DEMAND FOR ACCOMMODATION WERE ALSO ASSOCIATED THE MISDEMEANANTS OR CLASS TWO
column5: or class one with whom under the imperious demand for accommodation were also associated the misdemeanants or class two

column4: THIS WAS THE CHAPEL YARD WITH ITS FIVE WARDS WHICH WERE CALCULATED TO HOLD SEVENTY PRISONERS BUT OFTEN HELD MANY MORE
column5: this was the chapel yard with its five wards which were calculated to hold seventy prisoners but often held many more

column4: A FURTHER SUBCLASSIFICATION WAS ATTEMPTED BY SEPARATING AT NIGHT THOSE CHARGED WITH MISDEMEANORS FROM THOSE CHARGED WITH FELONY
column5: a further subclassification was attempted by separating at night those charged with misdemeanors from those charged with felony

column4: BUT ALL MINGLED FREELY DURING THE DAY IN THE YARD
column5: but all mingled freely during the day in the yard

column4: THE SLEEPING ACCOMMODATION IN THE CHAPELYARD WARDS AND INDEED THROUGHOUT THE PRISON CONSISTED OF A BARRACK BED
column5: the sleeping accommodation in the chapelyard wards and indeed throughout the prison consisted of a barrack bed

column4: WHICH WAS A WOODEN FLOORING ON A SLIGHTLY INCLINED PLANE WITH A BEAM RUNNING ACROSS THE TOP TO SERVE AS A PILLOW
column5: which was a wooden flooring on a slightly inclined plane with a beam running across the top to serve as a pillow

column4: NO BEDS WERE ISSUED ONLY TWO RUGS PER PRISONER
column5: no beds were issued only two rugs per prisoner

column4: WHEN EACH SLEEPER HAD THE FULL LATERAL SPACE ALLOTTED TO HIM IT AMOUNTED TO ONE FOOT AND A HALF ON THE BARRACK BED
column5: when each sleeper had the full lateral space allotted to him it amounted to one foot and a half on the barrack bed

column4: BUT WHEN THE WARD WAS OBLIGED TO ACCOMMODATE DOUBLE THE ORDINARY NUMBER AS WAS FREQUENTLY THE CASE
column5: but when the ward was obliged to accommodate double the ordinary number as was frequently the case

column4: THE SLEEPERS COVERED THE ENTIRE FLOOR WITH THE EXCEPTION OF A PASSAGE IN THE MIDDLE
column5: the sleepers covered the entire floor with the exception of a passage in the middle

column4: ALL THE MISDEMEANANTS WHATEVER THEIR OFFENSE WERE LODGED IN THIS CHAPEL WARD
column5: all the misdemeanants whatever their offense were lodged in this chapel ward

column4: AS MANY VARIOUS AND ACCORDING TO OUR IDEAS HEINOUS CRIMES CAME UNDER THIS HEAD
column5: as many various and according to our ideas heinous crimes came under this head

column4: IN THE THEN EXISTING STATE OF THE LAW
column5: in the then existing state of the law

column4: THE MAN GUILTY OF A COMMON ASSAULT FOUND HIMSELF SIDE BY SIDE WITH THE FRAUDULENT OR OTHERS WHO HAD ATTEMPTED ABOMINABLE CRIMES
column5: the man guilty of a common assault found himself side by side with the fraudulent or others who had attempted abominable crimes

column4: IN THIS HETEROGENEOUS SOCIETY WERE ALSO THROWN THE UNFORTUNATE JOURNALISTS TO WHOM I HAVE ALREADY REFERRED AND ON WHOM IMPRISONMENT IN NEWGATE
column5: in this heterogeneous society were also thrown the unfortunate journalists to whom i have already referred and on whom imprisonment in newgate

column4: WAS FREQUENTLY ADJUDGED FOR SOCALLED LIBELS OR TOO OUTSPOKEN COMMENTS IN PRINT
column5: was frequently adjudged for socalled libels or too outspoken comments in print

column4: IT WAS PARTICULARLY RECOMMENDED BY THE COMMITTEE ON JAILS IN EIGHTEEN FOURTEEN
column5: it was particularly recommended by the committee on jails in eighteen fourteen

column4: THAT SOME OTHER AND LESS MIXED PRISON SHOULD BE USED FOR THE CONFINEMENT OF PERSONS CONVICTED OF LIBELS BUT THIS SUGGESTION WAS IGNORED
column5: that some other and less mixed prison should be used for the confinement of persons convicted of libels but this suggestion was ignored

column4: INDEED THE PARTIAL CLASSIFICATION ATTEMPTED SEEMS TO HAVE BEEN ABANDONED WITHIN A YEAR OR TWO
column5: indeed the partial classification attempted seems to have been abandoned within a year or two

column4: THE HON H G BENNET WHO VISITED NEWGATE IN EIGHTEEN SEVENTEEN SAW IN ONE YARD IN A TOTAL OF SEVENTYTWO PRISONERS
column5: the hon h g bennet who visited newgate in eighteen seventeen saw in one yard in a total of seventytwo prisoners

column4: THIRTYFIVE TRIED AND THIRTYSEVEN UNTRIED OF THE FORMER THREE WERE TRANSPORTS FOR LIFE
column5: thirtyfive tried and thirtyseven untried of the former three were transports for life

column4: FOUR FOR FOURTEEN YEARS AND THREE OF THEM PERSONS SENTENCED TO FINES OR SHORT IMPRISONMENT  ONE FOR LITTLE MORE THAN A MONTH
column5: four for fourteen years and three of them persons sentenced to fines or short imprisonment  one for little more than a month

column4: TWO OF THE UNTRIED WERE FOR MURDER AND SEVERAL FOR HOUSEBREAKING AND HIGHWAY ROBBERY
column5: two of the untried were for murder and several for housebreaking and highway robbery

column4: NOR WERE THE MISDEMEANANTS AND BAIL PRISONERS ANY LONGER SEPARATED FROM THOSE WHOSE CRIMES WERE OF A MORE SERIOUS CHARACTER
column5: nor were the misdemeanants and bail prisoners any longer separated from those whose crimes were of a more serious character

column4: MR BENNET REFERS TO A GENTLEMAN CONFINED FOR WANT OF BAIL WHO OCCUPIED A ROOM WITH FIVE OTHERS
column5: mr bennet refers to a gentleman confined for want of bail who occupied a room with five others

column4: TWO COMMITTED BY THE BANKRUPTCY COMMISSIONER ONE FOR PERJURY AND TWO TRANSPORTS
column5: two committed by the bankruptcy commissioner one for perjury and two transports

column4: PERSONS CONVICTED OF PUBLISHING LIBELS WERE STILL IMMURED IN THE SAME ROOMS WITH TRANSPORTS AND FELONS
column5: persons convicted of publishing libels were still immured in the same rooms with transports and felons

column4: THE MIDDLE YARD AS FAR AS ITS LIMITS WOULD PERMIT WAS APPROPRIATED TO FELONS AND TRANSPORTS THE WARDS HERE WERE GENERALLY VERY CROWDED
column5: the middle yard as far as its limits would permit was appropriated to felons and transports the wards here were generally very crowded

column4: EACH WARD WAS CALCULATED TO HOLD TWENTYFOUR ALLOWING EACH INDIVIDUAL ONE FOOT AND A HALF
column5: each ward was calculated to hold twentyfour allowing each individual one foot and a half

column4: QUOTE A COMMONSIZED MAN SAYS THE KEEPER MR NEWMAN CAN TURN IN NINETEEN INCHES END QUOTE
column5: quote a commonsized man says the keeper mr newman can turn in nineteen inches end quote

column4: THESE TWENTYFOUR COULD JUST SLEEP ON THE BARRACK BED WHEN THE NUMBER WAS HIGHER AND IT OFTEN ROSE TO FORTY THE SURPLUS HAD TO SLEEP ON THE FLOOR
column5: these twentyfour could just sleep on the barrack bed when the number was higher and it often rose to forty the surplus had to sleep on the floor

column4: THE CROWDING WAS IN CONSEQUENCE OF THE DELAY IN REMOVING TRANSPORTS
column5: the crowding was in consequence of the delay in removing transports

column4: THESE OFTEN REMAINED IN NEWGATE FOR SIX MONTHS SOMETIMES A YEAR IN SOME CASES LONGER
column5: these often remained in newgate for six months sometimes a year in some cases longer

column4: IN ONE FOR SEVEN YEARS  THAT OF A MAN SENTENCED TO DEATH FOR WHOM GREAT INTEREST HAD BEEN MADE BUT WHOM IT WAS NOT THOUGHT RIGHT TO PARDON
column5: in one for seven years  that of a man sentenced to death for whom great interest had been made but whom it was not thought right to pardon

column4: OCCASIONALLY THE TRANSPORTS MADE THEMSELVES SO USEFUL IN THE JAIL THAT THEY WERE PASSED OVER
column5: occasionally the transports made themselves so useful in the jail that they were passed over

column4: MR NEWMAN ADMITTED THAT HE HAD PETITIONED THAT CERTAIN TRUSTY MEN MIGHT BE LEFT IN THE JAIL
column5: mr newman admitted that he had petitioned that certain trusty men might be left in the jail

column4: CONSTANTLY ASSOCIATED WITH THESE CONVICTED FELONS WERE NUMBERS OF JUVENILES INFANTS OF TENDER YEARS
column5: constantly associated with these convicted felons were numbers of juveniles infants of tender years

column4: THERE WERE FREQUENTLY IN THE MIDDLE YARD SEVEN OR EIGHT CHILDREN THE YOUNGEST BARELY NINE
column5: there were frequently in the middle yard seven or eight children the youngest barely nine

column4: THE OLDEST ONLY TWELVE OR THIRTEEN EXPOSED TO ALL THE CONTAMINATING INFLUENCES OF THE PLACE
column5: the oldest only twelve or thirteen exposed to all the contaminating influences of the place

column4: MR BENNET MENTIONS ALSO THE CASE OF YOUNG MEN OF BETTER STAMP CLERKS IN CITY OFFICES AND YOUTHS OF GOOD PARENTAGE
column5: mr bennet mentions also the case of young men of better stamp clerks in city offices and youths of good parentage

column4: QUOTE IN THIS DREADFUL SITUATION END QUOTE WHO HAD BEEN RESCUED FROM THE HULKS THROUGH THE KINDNESS AND ATTENTION OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE
column5: quote in this dreadful situation end quote who had been rescued from the hulks through the kindness and attention of the secretary of state

column4: QUOTE YET THEY HAD BEEN LONG ENOUGH HE GOES ON TO SAY IN THE PRISON ASSOCIATED WITH THE LOWEST AND VILEST CRIMINALS
column5: quote yet they had been long enough he goes on to say in the prison associated with the lowest and vilest criminals

column4: WITH CONVICTS OF ALL AGES AND CHARACTERS TO RENDER IT NEXT TO IMPOSSIBLE BUT THAT WITH THE OBLITERATION OF ALL SENSE OF SELFRESPECT
column5: with convicts of all ages and characters to render it next to impossible but that with the obliteration of all sense of selfrespect

column4: THE INEVITABLE CONSEQUENCE OF SUCH A SITUATION THEIR MORALS MUST HAVE BEEN DESTROYED
column5: the inevitable consequence of such a situation their morals must have been destroyed

column4: AND THOUGH DISTRESS OR THE SEDUCTION OF OTHERS MIGHT HAVE LED TO THE COMMISSION OF THIS THEIR FIRST OFFENSE
column5: and though distress or the seduction of others might have led to the commission of this their first offense

column4: YET THE SOCIETY THEY WERE DRIVEN TO LIVE IN THE LANGUAGE THEY DAILY HEARD AND THE LESSONS THEY WERE TAUGHT IN THIS ACADEMY
column5: yet the society they were driven to live in the language they daily heard and the lessons they were taught in this academy

column4: MUST HAVE HAD A TENDENCY TO TURN THEM INTO THE WORLD HARDENED AND ACCOMPLISHED IN THE WAYS OF VICE AND CRIME END QUOTE
column5: must have had a tendency to turn them into the world hardened and accomplished in the ways of vice and crime end quote

column4: MR BUXTON IN THE WORK ALREADY QUOTED INSTANCES ANOTHER GRIEVOUS CASE OF THE HORRORS OF INDISCRIMINATE ASSOCIATION IN NEWGATE
column5: mr buxton in the work already quoted instances another grievous case of the horrors of indiscriminate association in newgate

column4: IT WAS THAT OF A PERSON QUOTE WHO PRACTICED IN THE LAW AND WHO WAS CONNECTED BY MARRIAGE WITH SOME VERY RESPECTABLE FAMILIES
column5: it was that of a person quote who practiced in the law and who was connected by marriage with some very respectable families

column4: HAVING BEEN COMMITTED TO CLERKENWELL
column5: having been committed to clerkenwell

column4: HE WAS SENT ON TO NEWGATE IN A COACH HANDCUFFED TO A NOTED HOUSEBREAKER WHO WAS AFTERWARDS CAST FOR DEATH
column5: he was sent on to newgate in a coach handcuffed to a noted housebreaker who was afterwards cast for death

column4: THE FIRST NIGHT IN NEWGATE AND FOR THE SUBSEQUENT FORTNIGHT
column5: the first night in newgate and for the subsequent fortnight

column4: HE SLEPT IN THE SAME BED WITH A HIGHWAYMAN ON ONE SIDE AND A MAN CHARGED WITH MURDER ON THE OTHER
column5: he slept in the same bed with a highwayman on one side and a man charged with murder on the other

column4: SPIRITS WERE FREELY INTRODUCED AND ALTHOUGH HE AT FIRST ABSTAINED
column5: spirits were freely introduced and although he at first abstained

column4: HE FOUND HE MUST ADOPT THE MANNERS OF HIS COMPANIONS OR THAT HIS LIFE WOULD BE IN DANGER
column5: he found he must adopt the manners of his companions or that his life would be in danger

column4: THEY VIEWED HIM WITH SOME SUSPICION AS ONE OF WHOM THEY KNEW NOTHING
column5: they viewed him with some suspicion as one of whom they knew nothing

column4: HE WAS IN CONSEQUENCE PUT OUT OF THE PROTECTION OF THEIR INTERNAL LAW END QUOTE THEIR CODE WAS A SUBJECT OF SOME CURIOSITY
column5: he was in consequence put out of the protection of their internal law end quote their code was a subject of some curiosity

column4: WHEN ANY PRISONER COMMITTED AN OFFENSE AGAINST THE COMMUNITY OR AGAINST AN INDIVIDUAL HE WAS TRIED BY A COURT IN THE JAIL
column5: when any prisoner committed an offense against the community or against an individual he was tried by a court in the jail

column4: A PRISONER GENERALLY THE OLDEST AND MOST DEXTEROUS THIEF
column5: a prisoner generally the oldest and most dexterous thief

column4: WAS APPOINTED JUDGE AND A TOWEL TIED IN KNOTS WAS HUNG ON EACH SIDE IN IMITATION OF A WIG
column5: was appointed judge and a towel tied in knots was hung on each side in imitation of a wig

column4: THE JUDGE SAT IN PROPER FORM HE WAS PUNCTILIOUSLY STYLED MY LORD
column5: the judge sat in proper form he was punctiliously styled my lord

column4: A JURY HAVING BEEN SELECTED AND DULY SWORN THE CULPRIT WAS THEN ARRAIGNED JUSTICE HOWEVER WAS NOT ADMINISTERED WITH ABSOLUTE INTEGRITY
column5: a jury having been selected and duly sworn the culprit was then arraigned justice however was not administered with absolute integrity

column4: A BRIBE TO THE JUDGE WAS CERTAIN TO SECURE ACQUITTAL AND THE NEGLECT OF THE FORMALITY WAS AS CERTAINLY FOLLOWED BY CONDEMNATION
column5: a bribe to the judge was certain to secure acquittal and the neglect of the formality was as certainly followed by condemnation

column4: VARIOUS PUNISHMENTS WERE INFLICTED THE HEAVIEST OF WHICH WAS STANDING IN THE PILLORY
column5: various punishments were inflicted the heaviest of which was standing in the pillory

column4: THIS WAS CARRIED OUT BY PUTTING THE CRIMINAL'S HEAD THROUGH THE LEGS OF A CHAIR AND STRETCHING OUT HIS ARMS AND TYING THEM TO THE LEGS
column5: this was carried out by putting the criminal's head through the legs of a chair and stretching out his arms and tying them to the legs

column4: THE CULPRIT WAS THEN COMPELLED TO CARRY THE CHAIR ABOUT WITH HIM
column5: the culprit was then compelled to carry the chair about with him

column4: BUT ALL PUNISHMENTS MIGHT READILY BE COMMUTED INTO A FINE TO BE SPENT IN GIN FOR JUDGE AND JURY
column5: but all punishments might readily be commuted into a fine to be spent in gin for judge and jury

column4: THE PRISONER MENTIONED ABOVE WAS CONTINUALLY PERSECUTED BY TRIALS OF THIS KIND
column5: the prisoner mentioned above was continually persecuted by trials of this kind

column4: THE MOST TRIFLING ACTS WERE MAGNIFIED INTO OFFENSES
column5: the most trifling acts were magnified into offenses

column4: HE WAS CHARGED WITH MOVING SOMETHING WHICH SHOULD NOT BE TOUCHED WITH LEAVING A DOOR OPEN OR COUGHING MALICIOUSLY TO THE DISTURBANCE OF HIS COMPANIONS
column5: he was charged with moving something which should not be touched with leaving a door open or coughing maliciously to the disturbance of his companions

column4: THE EVIDENCE WAS INVARIABLY SUFFICIENT TO CONVICT AND THE JUDGE NEVER HESITATED TO INFLICT THE HEAVIEST PENALTIES
column5: the evidence was invariably sufficient to convict and the judge never hesitated to inflict the heaviest penalties

column4: THE UNFORTUNATE MAN WAS COMPELLED AT LENGTH TO ADOPT THE HABITS OF HIS ASSOCIATES
column5: the unfortunate man was compelled at length to adopt the habits of his associates

column4: QUOTE BY INSENSIBLE DEGREES HE BEGAN TO LOSE HIS REPUGNANCE TO THEIR SOCIETY
column5: quote by insensible degrees he began to lose his repugnance to their society

column4: CAUGHT THEIR FLASH TERMS AND SUNG THEIR SONGS WAS ADMITTED TO THEIR REVELS AND ACQUIRED IN PLACE OF HABITS OF PERFECT SOBRIETY
column5: caught their flash terms and sung their songs was admitted to their revels and acquired in place of habits of perfect sobriety

column4: A TASTE FOR SPIRITS END QUOTE
column5: a taste for spirits end quote

column4: HIS WIFE VISITED HIM IN NEWGATE AND WROTE A PITIABLE ACCOUNT OF THE STATE IN WHICH SHE FOUND HER HUSBAND
column5: his wife visited him in newgate and wrote a pitiable account of the state in which she found her husband

column4: HE WAS AN INMATE OF THE SAME WARD WITH OTHERS OF THE MOST DREADFUL SORT QUOTE
column5: he was an inmate of the same ward with others of the most dreadful sort quote

column4: WHOSE LANGUAGE AND MANNERS WHOSE FEMALE ASSOCIATES OF THE MOST ABANDONED DESCRIPTION AND THE SCENES CONSEQUENT WITH SUCH LOST WRETCHES
column5: whose language and manners whose female associates of the most abandoned description and the scenes consequent with such lost wretches

column4: PREVENTED ME FROM GOING INSIDE BUT SELDOM AND I USED TO COMMUNICATE WITH HIM THROUGH THE BARS FROM THE PASSAGE END QUOTE
column5: prevented me from going inside but seldom and i used to communicate with him through the bars from the passage end quote

column4: ONE DAY HE WAS TOO ILL TO COME DOWN AND MEET HER
column5: one day he was too ill to come down and meet her

column4: SHE WENT UP TO THE WARD AND FOUND HIM LYING DOWN QUOTE
column5: she went up to the ward and found him lying down quote

column4: PALE AS DEATH VERY ILL AND IN A DREADFULLY DIRTY STATE THE WRETCHES MAKING GAME OF HIM AND ENJOYING MY DISTRESS
column5: pale as death very ill and in a dreadfully dirty state the wretches making game of him and enjoying my distress

column4: AND I LEARNED HE HAD BEEN UP WITH THE OTHERS THE WHOLE NIGHT
column5: and i learned he had been up with the others the whole night

column4: THOUGH THEY COULD NOT FORCE HIM TO GAMBLE HE WAS COMPELLED TO DRINK
column5: though they could not force him to gamble he was compelled to drink

column4: AND I WAS OBLIGED AFTERWARDS TO LET HIM HAVE FIVE SHILLINGS TO PAY HIS SHARE
column5: and i was obliged afterwards to let him have five shillings to pay his share

column4: OTHERWISE HE WOULD HAVE BEEN STRIPPED OF HIS CLOTHES END QUOTE
column5: otherwise he would have been stripped of his clothes end quote

column4: FELONS WHO COULD PAY THE PRICE WERE PERMITTED IRRESPECTIVE OF THEIR CHARACTER OR OFFENSES
column5: felons who could pay the price were permitted irrespective of their character or offenses

column4: TO PURCHASE THE GREATER EASE AND COMFORT OF THE MASTER'S SIDE
column5: to purchase the greater ease and comfort of the master's side

column4: THE ENTRANCE FEE WAS AT LEAST THIRTEEN SHILLINGS SIX PENCE A HEAD WITH HALFACROWN A WEEK MORE FOR BED AND BEDDING
column5: the entrance fee was at least thirteen shillings six pence a head with halfacrown a week more for bed and bedding

column4: THE WARDS BEING FURNISHED WITH BARRACK BEDSTEADS UPON WHICH EACH PRISONER HAD THE REGULATION ALLOWANCE OF SLEEPING ROOM
column5: the wards being furnished with barrack bedsteads upon which each prisoner had the regulation allowance of sleeping room

column4: OR ABOUT A FOOT AND A HALF LATERALLY THESE FEES WERE IN REALITY A SUBSTANTIAL CONTRIBUTION TOWARDS THE EXPENSES OF THE JAIL
column5: or about a foot and a half laterally these fees were in reality a substantial contribution towards the expenses of the jail

column4: WITHOUT THEM THE KEEPER DECLARED THAT HE COULD NOT PAY THE SALARIES OF TURNKEYS AND SERVANTS NOR KEEP THE PRISON GOING AT ALL
column5: without them the keeper declared that he could not pay the salaries of turnkeys and servants nor keep the prison going at all

column4: BESIDES THE JAIL FEES THERE WAS GARNISH OF HALFAGUINEA COLLECTED BY THE STEWARD
column5: besides the jail fees there was garnish of halfaguinea collected by the steward

column4: AND SPENT IN PROVIDING COALS CANDLES PLATES KNIVES AND FORKS WHILE ALL THE OCCUPANTS OF THIS PART OF THE PRISON
column5: and spent in providing coals candles plates knives and forks while all the occupants of this part of the prison

column4: SUPPORTED THEMSELVES THEY HAD THE RATION OF PRISON BREAD ONLY
column5: supported themselves they had the ration of prison bread only

column4: BUT THEY HAD NO SHARE IN THE PRISON MEAT OR OTHER CHARITIES AND THEY OR THEIR FRIENDS FOUND THEM IN FOOD
column5: but they had no share in the prison meat or other charities and they or their friends found them in food

column4: ALL WHO COULD SCRAPE TOGETHER THE CASH SEEM TO HAVE GLADLY AVAILED THEMSELVES OF THE PRIVILEGE OF ENTERING THE MASTER'S SIDE
column5: all who could scrape together the cash seem to have gladly availed themselves of the privilege of entering the master's side

column4: IT WAS THE ONLY WAY TO ESCAPE THE HORRORS THE DISTRESS PENURY AND RAGS OF THE COMMON YARDS
column5: it was the only way to escape the horrors the distress penury and rags of the common yards

column4: IDLENESS WAS NOT SO UNIVERSALLY THE RULE IN THIS PART OF THE JAIL
column5: idleness was not so universally the rule in this part of the jail

column4: ARTISANS AND OTHERS WERE AT LIBERTY TO WORK AT THEIR TRADES PROVIDED THEY WERE NOT DANGEROUS
column5: artisans and others were at liberty to work at their trades provided they were not dangerous

column4: TAILORING AND SHOEMAKING WAS PERMITTED BUT IT WAS DEEMED UNSAFE TO ALLOW A CARPENTER OR BLACKSMITH TO HAVE HIS TOOLS
column5: tailoring and shoemaking was permitted but it was deemed unsafe to allow a carpenter or blacksmith to have his tools

column4: ALL THE MONEY EARNED BY PRISONERS WAS AT THEIR OWN DISPOSAL AND WAS SPENT ALMOST HABITUALLY IN DRINK CHAMBERING AND WANTONNESS
column5: all the money earned by prisoners was at their own disposal and was spent almost habitually in drink chambering and wantonness

column4: THE BEST ACCOMMODATION THE JAIL COULD OFFER WAS RESERVED FOR THE PRISONERS ON THE STATE SIDE
column5: the best accommodation the jail could offer was reserved for the prisoners on the state side

column4: FROM WHOM STILL HIGHER FEES WERE EXACTED WITH THE SAME DISCREDITABLE IDEA OF SWELLING THE REVENUES OF THE PRISON
column5: from whom still higher fees were exacted with the same discreditable idea of swelling the revenues of the prison

column4: TO CONSTITUTE THIS THE ARISTOCRATIC QUARTER UNWARRANTABLE DEMANDS WERE MADE UPON THE SPACE PROPERLY ALLOTTED TO THE FEMALE FELONS
column5: to constitute this the aristocratic quarter unwarrantable demands were made upon the space properly allotted to the female felons

column4: AND NO LODGER WAS REJECTED WHATEVER HIS STATUS WHO OFFERED HIMSELF AND COULD BRING GRIST TO THE MILL
column5: and no lodger was rejected whatever his status who offered himself and could bring grist to the mill

column4: THE LUXURY OF THE STATE SIDE WAS FOR A LONG TIME OPEN TO ALL WHO COULD PAY
column5: the luxury of the state side was for a long time open to all who could pay

column4: THE CONVICTED FELON THE TRANSPORT AWAITING REMOVAL THE LUNATIC WHOSE CASE WAS STILL UNDECIDED
column5: the convicted felon the transport awaiting removal the lunatic whose case was still undecided

column4: THE MISDEMEANANT TRIED OR UNTRIED THE DEBTOR WHO WISHED TO AVOID THE DISCOMFORT OF THE CROWDED DEBTORS' SIDE THE OUTSPOKEN NEWSPAPER EDITOR
column5: the misdemeanant tried or untried the debtor who wished to avoid the discomfort of the crowded debtors' side the outspoken newspaper editor

column4: OR THE DARING REPORTER OF PARLIAMENTARY DEBATES
column5: or the daring reporter of parliamentary debates

column4: THE BETTER CLASS OF INMATE COMPLAINED BITTERLY OF THIS ENFORCED COMPANIONSHIP WITH THE VILE
column5: the better class of inmate complained bitterly of this enforced companionship with the vile

column4: ASSOCIATION AT ONE TIME FORBIDDEN BY CUSTOM BUT WHICH GREED AND RAPACITY LONG MADE THE RULE
column5: association at one time forbidden by custom but which greed and rapacity long made the rule

column4: THE FEE FOR ADMISSION TO THE STATE SIDE AS FIXED BY THE TABLE OF FEES WAS THREE GUINEAS BUT MR NEWMAN DECLARED THAT HE NEVER TOOK MORE THAN TWO
column5: the fee for admission to the state side as fixed by the table of fees was three guineas but mr newman declared that he never took more than two

column4: TEN AND SIXPENCE A WEEK MORE WAS CHARGED AS RENT FOR A SINGLE BED WHERE TWO OR MORE SLEPT IN A BED THE RENT WAS SEVEN SHILLINGS A WEEK EACH
column5: ten and sixpence a week more was charged as rent for a single bed where two or more slept in a bed the rent was seven shillings a week each

column4: PRISONERS WHO COULD AFFORD IT SOMETIMES PAID FOR FOUR BEDS AT THE RATE OF TWENTYEIGHT SHILLINGS AND SO SECURED THE LUXURY OF A PRIVATE ROOM
column5: prisoners who could afford it sometimes paid for four beds at the rate of twentyeight shillings and so secured the luxury of a private room

column4: A MR LUNDY CHARGED WITH FORGERY WAS THUS ACCOMMODATED ON THE STATE SIDE FOR UPWARDS OF FIVE YEARS
column5: a mr lundy charged with forgery was thus accommodated on the state side for upwards of five years

column4: BUT THE KEEPER PROTESTED THAT NO SINGLE PRISONER COULD THUS MONOPOLIZE SPACE IF THE STATE SIDE WAS CROWDED
column5: but the keeper protested that no single prisoner could thus monopolize space if the state side was crowded

column4: THE KEEPER WENT STILL FURTHER IN HIS EFFORTS TO MAKE MONEY
column5: the keeper went still further in his efforts to make money

column4: HE CONTINUED THE ANCIENT PRACTICE OF LETTING OUT A PORTION OF HIS OWN HOUSE AND BY A POETICAL FICTION TREATED IT AS AN ANNEX OF THE STATE SIDE
column5: he continued the ancient practice of letting out a portion of his own house and by a poetical fiction treated it as an annex of the state side

column4: MR DAVISON SENT TO NEWGATE FOR EMBEZZLEMENT AND WHOSE CASE IS GIVEN IN THE PRECEDING CHAPTER
column5: mr davison sent to newgate for embezzlement and whose case is given in the preceding chapter

column4: WAS ACCOMMODATED WITH A ROOM IN MR NEWMAN'S HOUSE AT THE EXTRAVAGANT RENTAL OF THIRTY GUINEAS PER WEEK
column5: was accommodated with a room in mr newman's house at the extravagant rental of thirty guineas per week

column4: MR COBBETT WAS ALSO A LODGER OF MR NEWMAN'S AND SO WERE ANY MEMBERS OF THE ARISTOCRACY
column5: mr cobbett was also a lodger of mr newman's and so were any members of the aristocracy

column4: IF THEY HAPPENED TO BE IN FUNDS  AMONG WHOM WAS THE MARQUIS OF SLIGO IN EIGHTEEN ELEVEN
column5: if they happened to be in funds  among whom was the marquis of sligo in eighteen eleven

column4: THE FEMALE FELONS' WARDS I SHALL DESCRIBE AT LENGTH IN THE NEXT CHAPTER
column5: the female felons' wards i shall describe at length in the next chapter

column4: WHICH WILL DEAL WITH MRS FRY'S PHILANTHROPIC EXERTIONS AT THIS PERIOD IN THIS PARTICULAR PART OF THE PRISON
column5: which will deal with mrs fry's philanthropic exertions at this period in this particular part of the prison

column4: THESE WARDS WERE ALWAYS FULL TO OVERFLOWING SOMETIMES DOUBLE THE NUMBER THE ROOMS COULD ACCOMMODATE WERE CROWDED INTO THEM
column5: these wards were always full to overflowing sometimes double the number the rooms could accommodate were crowded into them

column4: THERE WAS A MASTER'S SIDE FOR FEMALES WHO COULD PAY THE USUAL FEES BUT THEY ASSOCIATED WITH THE REST IN THE ONE NARROW YARD COMMON TO ALL
column5: there was a master's side for females who could pay the usual fees but they associated with the rest in the one narrow yard common to all

column4: THE TRIED AND THE UNTRIED YOUNG AND OLD WERE HERDED TOGETHER
column5: the tried and the untried young and old were herded together

column4: SOMETIMES GIRLS OF THIRTEEN TWELVE EVEN TEN OR NINE YEARS OF AGE WERE EXPOSED TO QUOTE
column5: sometimes girls of thirteen twelve even ten or nine years of age were exposed to quote

column4: ALL THE CONTAGION AND PROFLIGACY WHICH PREVAILED IN THIS PART OF THE PRISON END QUOTE
column5: all the contagion and profligacy which prevailed in this part of the prison end quote

column4: THERE WAS NO SEPARATION EVEN FOR THE WOMEN UNDER SENTENCE OF DEATH WHO LIVED IN A COMMON AND PERPETUALLY CROWDED WARD
column5: there was no separation even for the women under sentence of death who lived in a common and perpetually crowded ward

column4: ONLY WHEN THE ORDER OF EXECUTION CAME DOWN WERE THOSE ABOUT TO SUFFER PLACED APART IN ONE OF THE ROOMS IN THE ARCADE OF THE MIDDLE WARD
column5: only when the order of execution came down were those about to suffer placed apart in one of the rooms in the arcade of the middle ward

column4: I HAVE KEPT TILL THE LAST THAT PART OF THE PRISON WHICH WAS USUALLY THE LAST RESTINGPLACE OF SO MANY
column5: i have kept till the last that part of the prison which was usually the last restingplace of so many

column4: THE OLD PRESS YARD HAS BEEN FULLY DESCRIBED IN A PREVIOUS CHAPTER
column5: the old press yard has been fully described in a previous chapter

column4: THE NAME STILL SURVIVED IN THE NEW PRESS YARD WHICH WAS THE RECEPTACLE OF THE MALE CONDEMNED PRISONERS IT WAS GENERALLY CROWDED LIKE THE REST OF THE PRISON
column5: the name still survived in the new press yard which was the receptacle of the male condemned prisoners it was generally crowded like the rest of the prison

column4: EXCEPT IN MURDER CASES WHERE THE EXECUTION WAS GENERALLY VERY PROMPTLY PERFORMED
column5: except in murder cases where the execution was generally very promptly performed

column4: STRANGE AND INCONCEIVABLE DELAY OCCURRED IN CARRYING OUT THE EXTREME SENTENCE
column5: strange and inconceivable delay occurred in carrying out the extreme sentence

column4: HENCE THERE WAS A TERRIBLE ACCUMULATION OF PRISONERS IN THE CONDEMNED CELLS
column5: hence there was a terrible accumulation of prisoners in the condemned cells

column4: ONCE DURING THE LONG ILLNESS OF GEORGE THE THIRD AS MANY AS ONE HUNDRED WERE THERE WAITING THE REPORT AS IT WAS CALLED
column5: once during the long illness of george the third as many as one hundred were there waiting the report as it was called

column4: AT ANOTHER TIME THERE WERE FIFTY ONE OF WHOM HAD BEEN UNDER SENTENCE A COUPLE OF YEARS
column5: at another time there were fifty one of whom had been under sentence a couple of years

column4: MR BENNET SPEAKS OF THIRTYEIGHT CAPITAL CONVICTS HE FOUND IN THE PRESS YARD IN FEBRUARY EIGHTEEN SEVENTEEN
column5: mr bennet speaks of thirtyeight capital convicts he found in the press yard in february eighteen seventeen

column4: FIVE OF WHOM HAD BEEN CONDEMNED THE PREVIOUS JULY FOUR IN SEPTEMBER AND TWENTYNINE IN OCTOBER
column5: five of whom had been condemned the previous july four in september and twentynine in october

column4: THIS PROCRASTINATION BRED CERTAIN CALLOUSNESS
column5: this procrastination bred certain callousness

column4: FEW REALIZING THAT THE DREADFUL FATE WOULD OVERTAKE THEM DISMISSED THE PROSPECT OF DEATH
column5: few realizing that the dreadful fate would overtake them dismissed the prospect of death

column4: AND UNTIL THE DAY WAS ACTUALLY FIXED SPENT THE TIME IN ROISTERING SWEARING GAMBLING OR PLAYING AT BALL
column5: and until the day was actually fixed spent the time in roistering swearing gambling or playing at ball

column4: VISITORS WERE PERMITTED ACCESS TO THEM WITHOUT STINT
column5: visitors were permitted access to them without stint

column4: UNLIMITED DRINK WAS NOT DENIED THEM PROVIDED IT WAS OBTAINED IN REGULATED QUANTITIES AT ONE TIME
column5: unlimited drink was not denied them provided it was obtained in regulated quantities at one time

column4: THESE CAPITAL CONVICTS SAYS MR BENNET QUOTE LESSENED THE ENNUI AND DESPAIR OF THEIR SITUATION BY UNBECOMING MERRIMENT
column5: these capital convicts says mr bennet quote lessened the ennui and despair of their situation by unbecoming merriment

column4: OR SOUGHT RELIEF IN THE CONSTANT APPLICATION OF INTOXICATING STIMULANTS
column5: or sought relief in the constant application of intoxicating stimulants

column4: I SAW CASHMAN A FEW HOURS BEFORE HIS EXECUTION SMOKING AND DRINKING WITH THE UTMOST UNCONCERN AND INDIFFERENCE END QUOTE
column5: i saw cashman a few hours before his execution smoking and drinking with the utmost unconcern and indifference end quote

column4: THOSE WHO WERE THUS RECKLESS REACTED UPON THE PENITENT WHO KNEW THEIR DAYS WERE NUMBERED
column5: those who were thus reckless reacted upon the penitent who knew their days were numbered

column4: AND THEIR GIBES AND JOLLITY COUNTERACTED THE ORDINARY'S COUNSELS OR THE INDEPENDENT PREACHER'S EARNEST PRAYERS
column5: and their gibes and jollity counteracted the ordinary's counsels or the independent preacher's earnest prayers

column4: FOR WHILE ROMAN CATHOLICS AND DISSENTERS WERE ENCOURAGED TO SEE MINISTERS OF THEIR OWN PERSUASION
column5: for while roman catholics and dissenters were encouraged to see ministers of their own persuasion

column4: A NUMBER OF AMATEURS WERE EVER READY TO GIVE THEIR GRATUITOUS MINISTRATIONS TO THE CONDEMNED
column5: a number of amateurs were ever ready to give their gratuitous ministrations to the condemned

column4: THE PRISONERS IN THE PRESS YARD HAD FREE ACCESS DURING THE DAY TO THE YARD AND LARGE DAY ROOM
column5: the prisoners in the press yard had free access during the day to the yard and large day room

column4: AT NIGHT THEY WERE PLACED IN THE FIFTEEN CELLS TWO THREE OR MORE TOGETHER ACCORDING TO THE TOTAL NUMBER TO BE ACCOMMODATED
column5: at night they were placed in the fifteen cells two three or more together according to the total number to be accommodated

column4: THEY WERE NEVER LEFT QUITE ALONE FOR FEAR OF SUICIDE AND FOR THE SAME REASON THEY WERE SEARCHED FOR WEAPONS OR POISONS
column5: they were never left quite alone for fear of suicide and for the same reason they were searched for weapons or poisons

column4: BUT THEY NEVERTHELESS FREQUENTLY MANAGED TO SECRETE THE MEANS OF MAKING AWAY WITH THEMSELVES AND ACCOMPLISHED THEIR PURPOSE
column5: but they nevertheless frequently managed to secrete the means of making away with themselves and accomplished their purpose

column4: CONVICTED MURDERERS WERE KEPT CONTINUOUSLY IN THE CELLS ON BREAD AND WATER
column5: convicted murderers were kept continuously in the cells on bread and water

column4: IN COUPLES FROM THE TIME OF SENTENCE TO THAT OF EXECUTION WHICH WAS ABOUT THREE OR FOUR DAYS GENERALLY
column5: in couples from the time of sentence to that of execution which was about three or four days generally

column4: FROM FRIDAY TO MONDAY SO AS TO INCLUDE ONE SUNDAY ON WHICH DAY THERE WAS A SPECIAL SERVICE FOR THE CONDEMNED IN THE PRISON CHAPEL
column5: from friday to monday so as to include one sunday on which day there was a special service for the condemned in the prison chapel

column4: THIS LATTER WAS AN ORDEAL WHICH ALL DREADED AND MANY AVOIDED BY DENYING THEIR FAITH
column5: this latter was an ordeal which all dreaded and many avoided by denying their faith

column4: THE CONDEMNED OCCUPIED AN OPEN PEW IN THE CENTER OF THE CHAPEL HUNG WITH BLACK IN FRONT OF THEM UPON A TABLE WAS A BLACK COFFIN IN FULL VIEW
column5: the condemned occupied an open pew in the center of the chapel hung with black in front of them upon a table was a black coffin in full view

column4: THE CHAPEL WAS FILLED WITH A CURIOUS BUT CALLOUS CONGREGATION WHO CAME TO STARE AT THE MISERABLE PEOPLE THUS PUBLICLY EXPOSED
column5: the chapel was filled with a curious but callous congregation who came to stare at the miserable people thus publicly exposed

column4: WELL MIGHT MR BENNET WRITE THAT THE CONDITION OF THE CONDEMNED SIDE WAS THE MOST PROMINENT OF THE MANIFOLD EVILS IN THE PRESENT SYSTEM OF NEWGATE
column5: well might mr bennet write that the condition of the condemned side was the most prominent of the manifold evils in the present system of newgate

column4: QUOTE SO DISCREDITABLE TO THE METROPOLIS END QUOTE
column5: quote so discreditable to the metropolis end quote

column4: YET IT MUST HAVE BEEN ABUNDANTLY PLAIN TO THE READER THAT THE OTHER EVILS EXISTING WERE GREAT AND GLARING A BRIEF SUMMARY OF THEM WILL BEST PROVE THIS
column5: yet it must have been abundantly plain to the reader that the other evils existing were great and glaring a brief summary of them will best prove this

column4: THE JAIL WAS NEITHER SUITABLE NOR SUFFICIENTLY LARGE IT WAS NOT EVEN KEPT WEATHERTIGHT
column5: the jail was neither suitable nor sufficiently large it was not even kept weathertight

column4: THE ROOF OF THE FEMALE PRISON SAYS THE GRAND JURY IN THEIR PRESENTMENT IN EIGHTEEN THIRTEEN LET IN THE RAIN
column5: the roof of the female prison says the grand jury in their presentment in eighteen thirteen let in the rain

column4: SUPPLIES OF COMMON NECESSARIES SUCH AS HAVE NOW BEEN PART OF THE FURNITURE OF EVERY BRITISH JAIL FOR MANY YEARS
column5: supplies of common necessaries such as have now been part of the furniture of every british jail for many years

column4: WERE MEAGER OR ALTOGETHER ABSENT
column5: were meager or altogether absent

column4: THE RATIONS OF FOOD WERE NOTORIOUSLY INADEQUATE AND SO CARELESSLY DISTRIBUTED THAT MANY WERE LEFT TO STARVE
column5: the rations of food were notoriously inadequate and so carelessly distributed that many were left to starve

column4: SO UNJUST AND UNEQUAL WAS THE SYSTEM THAT THE ALLOWANCE TO CONVICTED CRIMINALS WAS BETTER THAN THAT OF THE INNOCENT DEBTOR
column5: so unjust and unequal was the system that the allowance to convicted criminals was better than that of the innocent debtor

column4: AND THE GENERAL INSUFFICIENCY WAS SUCH
column5: and the general insufficiency was such

column4: THAT IT MULTIPLIED BEYOND ALL REASON THE NUMBER OF VISITORS MANY OF WHOM CAME MERELY AS THE PURVEYORS OF FOOD TO THEIR FRIENDS
column5: that it multiplied beyond all reason the number of visitors many of whom came merely as the purveyors of food to their friends

column4: THE PRISON ALLOWANCES WERE EKED OUT BY THE BROKEN VICTUALS GENEROUSLY GIVEN BY SEVERAL EATINGHOUSE KEEPERS IN THE CITY
column5: the prison allowances were eked out by the broken victuals generously given by several eatinghouse keepers in the city

column4: SUCH AS MESSRS BIRCH OF CORNHILL AND MESSRS LEACH AND DOLLIMORE OF LUDGATE HILL
column5: such as messrs birch of cornhill and messrs leach and dollimore of ludgate hill

column4: THESE WERE FETCHED AWAY IN A LARGE TUB ON A TRUCK BY A TURNKEY
column5: these were fetched away in a large tub on a truck by a turnkey

column4: AMONGST THE HEAP WAS OFTEN THE MEAT THAT HAD MADE TURTLE SOUP WHICH WHEN HEATED AND STIRRED TOGETHER IN A SAUCEPAN WAS SAID TO BE VERY GOOD EATING
column5: amongst the heap was often the meat that had made turtle soup which when heated and stirred together in a saucepan was said to be very good eating

column4: THE BEDDING WAS SCANTY FUEL AND LIGHT HAD TO BE PURCHASED OUT OF PRISONERS' PRIVATE MEANS CLOTHING WAS ISSUED BUT RARELY
column5: the bedding was scanty fuel and light had to be purchased out of prisoners' private means clothing was issued but rarely

column4: EVEN TO PRISONERS ALMOST IN NAKEDNESS AND AS A SPECIAL CHARITABLE GIFT EXTORTION WAS PRACTICED RIGHT AND LEFT
column5: even to prisoners almost in nakedness and as a special charitable gift extortion was practiced right and left

column4: GARNISH CONTINUED TO BE DEMANDED LONG AFTER IT HAD DISAPPEARED IN OTHER AND BETTERREGULATED PRISONS
column5: garnish continued to be demanded long after it had disappeared in other and betterregulated prisons

column4: THE FEES ON RECEPTION AND DISCHARGE MUST BE DEEMED EXORBITANT WHEN IT IS REMEMBERED THE IMPOVERISHED CLASS WHO USUALLY CROWDED THE JAIL
column5: the fees on reception and discharge must be deemed exorbitant when it is remembered the impoverished class who usually crowded the jail

column4: AND THEY WERE EXACTED TO RELIEVE A RICH CORPORATION FROM PAYING FOR THE MAINTENANCE OF THEIR OWN PRISON
column5: and they were exacted to relieve a rich corporation from paying for the maintenance of their own prison

column4: THIS IMPOSITION OF FEES LEFT PRISONERS DESTITUTE ON THEIR DISCHARGE WITHOUT FUNDS TO SUPPORT THEM IN THEIR FIRST STRUGGLE TO RECOMMENCE LIFE
column5: this imposition of fees left prisoners destitute on their discharge without funds to support them in their first struggle to recommence life

column4: WITH RUINED CHARACTER BAD HABITS AND OFTEN BAD HEALTH CONTRACTED IN THE JAIL
column5: with ruined character bad habits and often bad health contracted in the jail

column4: A FURTHER AND A MORE INIQUITOUS METHOD OF EXTORTING MONEY
column5: a further and a more iniquitous method of extorting money

column4: WAS STILL PRACTICED THAT OF LOADING NEWLYARRIVED PRISONERS UNTIL THEY PAID CERTAIN FEES
column5: was still practiced that of loading newlyarrived prisoners until they paid certain fees

column4: IRONING WAS STILL THE RULE NOT ONLY FOR THE CONVICTED BUT FOR THOSE CHARGED WITH FELONIES ONLY THE MISDEMEANANTS ESCAPED
column5: ironing was still the rule not only for the convicted but for those charged with felonies only the misdemeanants escaped

column4: AT THE COMMENCEMENT OF EVERY SESSIONS SUCH OF THE UNTRIED AS HAD PURCHASED EASEMENT OF IRONS WERE CALLED UP AND REFETTERED
column5: at the commencement of every sessions such of the untried as had purchased easement of irons were called up and refettered

column4: PREPARATORY TO THEIR APPEARANCE IN THE OLD BAILEY IRONS WERE SELDOM REMOVED FROM THE CONVICTED UNTIL DISCHARGE
column5: preparatory to their appearance in the old bailey irons were seldom removed from the convicted until discharge

column4: SOMETIMES THE WEARER WAS DECLARED MEDICALLY UNFIT OR HE OBTAINED RELEASE BY LONG GOOD CONDUCT
column5: sometimes the wearer was declared medically unfit or he obtained release by long good conduct

column4: OR THE FAITHFUL DISCHARGE OF SOME PETTY OFFICE SUCH AS GATESMAN OR CAPTAIN OF A WARD
column5: or the faithful discharge of some petty office such as gatesman or captain of a ward

column4: THE IRONS WEIGHED FROM THREE TO FOUR POUNDS BUT HEAVIER IRONS SEVEN OR EIGHT POUNDS' WEIGHT
column5: the irons weighed from three to four pounds but heavier irons seven or eight pounds' weight

column4: WERE IMPOSED IN CASE OF MISCONDUCT AND WHEN THERE HAD BEEN AN ATTEMPT AT ESCAPE
column5: were imposed in case of misconduct and when there had been an attempt at escape

column4: THE CULPRIT WAS CHAINED DOWN TO THE FLOOR BY RUNNING A CHAIN THROUGH HIS IRONS WHICH PREVENTED HIM FROM CLIMBING TO THE WINDOW OF HIS CELL
column5: the culprit was chained down to the floor by running a chain through his irons which prevented him from climbing to the window of his cell

column4: AMONG OTHER EXCUSES OFFERED FOR THUS MANACLING ALL ALMOST WITHOUT EXCEPTION WAS THAT IT WAS THE BEST AND SAFEST METHOD
column5: among other excuses offered for thus manacling all almost without exception was that it was the best and safest method

column4: OF DISTINGUISHING A PRISONER FROM A STRANGER AND TEMPORARY VISITOR
column5: of distinguishing a prisoner from a stranger and temporary visitor

column4: CLOTHES OR PRISON UNIFORM WOULD NOT HAVE SERVED THE PURPOSE FOR A DISGUISE CAN BE RAPIDLY AND SECRETLY PUT ON
column5: clothes or prison uniform would not have served the purpose for a disguise can be rapidly and secretly put on

column4: WHEREAS IRONS CANNOT WELL BE EXCHANGED WITHOUT LOSS OF TIME AND ATTRACTING MUCH ATTENTION
column5: whereas irons cannot well be exchanged without loss of time and attracting much attention

column4: THE UNCHECKED ADMISSION OF CROWDS OF VISITORS TO THE FELONS' AS WELL AS THE DEBTORS' SIDE WAS ANOTHER UNMIXED EVIL
column5: the unchecked admission of crowds of visitors to the felons' as well as the debtors' side was another unmixed evil

column4: BY THIS MEANS SPIRITS OTHERWISE UNATTAINABLE AND STRICTLY PROHIBITED WERE SMUGGLED INTO THE JAIL
column5: by this means spirits otherwise unattainable and strictly prohibited were smuggled into the jail

column4: SEARCHES WERE MADE CERTAINLY BUT THEY WERE TOO OFTEN SUPERFICIAL OR THEY MIGHT BE EVADED BY A TRIFLING BRIBE
column5: searches were made certainly but they were too often superficial or they might be evaded by a trifling bribe

column4: HENCE THE FREQUENT CASES OF DRUNKENNESS OF WHICH NO NOTICE WAS TAKEN UNLESS PEOPLE GREW RIOTOUS IN THEIR CUPS
column5: hence the frequent cases of drunkenness of which no notice was taken unless people grew riotous in their cups

column4: AND ATTRACTED ATTENTION BY THEIR DISORDERLY BEHAVIOR
column5: and attracted attention by their disorderly behavior

column4: ANOTHER FRIGHTFUL CONSEQUENCE OF THIS INDISCRIMINATE ADMISSION WAS THE INFLUX OF NUMBERS OF ABANDONED WOMEN
column5: another frightful consequence of this indiscriminate admission was the influx of numbers of abandoned women

column4: ONLY A FEW OF WHOM HAD THE COMMENDABLE PRUDERY TO PASS THEMSELVES OFF AS THE WIVES OF PRISONERS
column5: only a few of whom had the commendable prudery to pass themselves off as the wives of prisoners

column5: any reputed and indeed any real wife might spend the night in newgate if she would pay the shilling fee commonly known as the bad money

column5: which might have done something towards increasing the prison receipts had it not been appropriated by the turnkey who winked at this evasion of the rules

column5: among the daily visitors were members of the criminal classes still at large

column5: the thieves and burglars who carried on the active business of their profession from which their confederates were temporarily debarred

column5: this delectable society enticed into their set a clerk who had been imprisoned for fraud

column5: and offered him half the booty if he would give full information as to the transactions and correspondence of his late employers

column5: owing to the facility of intercourse between inside and outside many crimes were doubtless hatched in newgate

column5: these malpractices were fostered by the absence of all supervision and the generally unbroken idleness

column5: there was fear as to the unrestricted use of tools

column5: and the danger of losing material raw or manufactured

column5: many years were to elapse before these objections should be fairly met and universally overcome

column5: it was not strange therefore that the inmates of newgate should turn their unoccupied brains and idle hands to all manner of mischief

column5: that when they were not carousing plotting or scheming

column5: they should gamble with dice or cards and play at bumble puppy or some other disreputable game of chance

column5: the report of the committee of the house of commons painted so black a picture of newgate as then conducted that the corporation were roused in very shame

column5: to undertake some kind of reform

column5: the abovementioned report was ordered to be printed upon the ninth may

column5: upon the twentyninth july the same year

column5: the court of aldermen appointed a committee of its own body assisted by the town clerk mr dance city surveyor son to the architect of newgate

column5: and mr addison keeper of newgate to make a visitation of the jails supposed to be the best managed including those of petworth and gloucester

column5: this committee was to compare allowances examine rules and certify as to the condition of prisoners

column5: also to make such proposals as might appear salutary and calculated to improve newgate and the rest of the city jails

column5: this committee made its report in september the following year and an excellent report it is so far as its recommendations are concerned

column4: THE COMMITTEE SEEMS TO HAVE FULLY REALIZED EVEN AT THIS EARLY DATE EIGHTEEN FIFTEEN
column5: the committee seems to have fully realized even at this early date eighteen fifteen

column4: MANY OF THE INDISPENSABLE CONDITIONS OF A MODEL PRISON ACCORDING TO MODERN IDEAS
column5: many of the indispensable conditions of a model prison according to modern ideas
