column5: it admitted the paramount necessity

column4: FOR GIVING EVERY PRISONER A SLEEPING CELL TO HIMSELF AN AMOUNT OF ENLIGHTENMENT WHICH IS HARDLY GENERAL AMONG EUROPEAN NATIONS AT THIS
column5: for giving every prisoner a sleeping cell to himself an amount of enlightenment which is hardly general among european nations at this

column4: THE LATTER END OF THE NINETEENTH CENTURY SEVERAL OF WHICH STILL FALL FAR SHORT OF OUR ENGLISH IDEAL
column5: the latter end of the nineteenth century several of which still fall far short of our english ideal

column4: THAT ALL PRISONERS SHOULD ALWAYS BE IN SEPARATE CELLS BY NIGHT AND THOSE OF SHORT SENTENCES BY DAY
column5: that all prisoners should always be in separate cells by night and those of short sentences by day

column5: it recommended day cells or rooms for regular labor which should be compulsory upon all transports and prisoners sentenced to hard labor

column4: THE WORK BEING CONSTANT AND SUITABLE WITH CERTAIN HOURS OF RELAXATION AND FOR FOOD AND EXERCISE
column5: the work being constant and suitable with certain hours of relaxation and for food and exercise

column4: THE PERSONAL CLEANLINESS OF ALL PRISONERS WAS TO BE INSISTED UPON THEY SHOULD BE MADE TO WASH AT LEAST ONCE A DAY
column5: the personal cleanliness of all prisoners was to be insisted upon they should be made to wash at least once a day

column4: WITH THE PENALTY OF FORFEITING THE DAY'S ALLOWANCE OF FOOD AN INCREASE OF WHICH THE COMMITTEE HAD RECOMMENDED

column4: THE PROVISION OF MORE BATHS WAS ALSO SUGGESTED AND THE DAILY SWEEPING OUT OF THE PRISON
column5: the provision of more baths was also suggested and the daily sweeping out of the prison

column5: the clothes of prisoners arriving dirty or in rags should be fumigated before worn in the jail

column5: but as yet no suggestion was made to provide prison uniform

column5: a laundry should be established and a matron appointed on the female side where all the prisoners' washing could be performed

column4: PROPER HOURS FOR LOCKING AND UNLOCKING PRISONERS SHOULD BE INSISTED UPON
column5: proper hours for locking and unlocking prisoners should be insisted upon

column4: A BELL SHOULD GIVE NOTICE THEREOF AND OF MEALHOURS WORKINGHOURS OR OF ESCAPES
column5: a bell should give notice thereof and of mealhours workinghours or of escapes

column5: the committee took upon itself to lay down stringent rules for the discipline of the prison

column5: the jailer should be required to visit every part and see every prisoner daily the chaplain should perform service visit the sick

column4: INSTRUCT THE PRISONERS QUOTE GIVE SPIRITUAL ADVICE AND ADMINISTER RELIGIOUS CONSOLATION END QUOTE TO ALL WHO MIGHT NEED THEM
column5: instruct the prisoners quote give spiritual advice and administer religious consolation end quote to all who might need them

column4: THE SURGEON SHOULD SEE ALL PRISONERS WHETHER ILL OR WELL ONCE A WEEK AND TAKE GENERAL CHARGE OF THE INFIRMARIES
column5: the surgeon should see all prisoners whether ill or well once a week and take general charge of the infirmaries

column4: ALL THREE GOVERNOR CHAPLAIN AND SURGEON SHOULD KEEP JOURNALS WHICH SHOULD BE INSPECTED PERIODICALLY BY THE VISITING MAGISTRATES
column5: all three governor chaplain and surgeon should keep journals which should be inspected periodically by the visiting magistrates

column4: IT SHOULD BE PEREMPTORILY FORBIDDEN TO THE KEEPER OR ANY OFFICER TO MAKE A PECUNIARY PROFIT OUT OF THE SUPPLIES OF FOOD FUEL OR OTHER NECESSARIES
column5: it should be peremptorily forbidden to the keeper or any officer to make a pecuniary profit out of the supplies of food fuel or other necessaries

column4: NO PRISONER SHOULD BE ALLOWED TO OBTAIN SUPERIOR ACCOMMODATION ON THE PAYMENT OF ANY FEES FEES INDEED SHOULD BE GENERALLY ABOLISHED GARNISH ALSO
column5: no prisoner should be allowed to obtain superior accommodation on the payment of any fees fees indeed should be generally abolished garnish also

column5: no prisoners should in future be ironed except in cases of misconduct

column4: PROVIDED ONLY THAT THEIR SECURITY WAS NOT JEOPARDIZED AND DEPENDENT UPON THE ENFORCEMENT OF ANOTHER NEW RULE
column5: provided only that their security was not jeopardized and dependent upon the enforcement of another new rule

column4: WHICH RECOMMENDED RESTRICTIONS UPON THE NUMBER OF VISITORS ADMITTED
column5: which recommended restrictions upon the number of visitors admitted

column5: no wine or beer should be in future admitted into or sold in the jail

column4: EXCEPT FOR THE USE OF THE DEBTORS OR AS MEDICAL COMFORTS FOR THE INFIRMARY
column5: except for the use of the debtors or as medical comforts for the infirmary

column4: DRUNKENNESS IF IT EVER OCCURRED SHOULD BE VISITED WITH SEVERE PUNISHMENT
column5: drunkenness if it ever occurred should be visited with severe punishment

column5: gaming of all sorts should be peremptorily forbidden under heavy pains and penalties

column5: the feelings of the condemned prisoners should no longer be outraged by their exposure in the chapel and the chapel should be rearranged

column4: SO THAT THE VARIOUS CLASSES MIGHT BE SEATED SEPARATELY AND SO AS NOT TO SEE EACH OTHER
column5: so that the various classes might be seated separately and so as not to see each other

column5: it will hardly be denied that these proposals went to the root of the matter

column5: in common justice to them it must be admitted that immediate effect was given to all that could be easily carried out

column5: but here the recommendations touched at once upon the delicate subject of expense and it is clear that the committee hesitated on this score

column5: the committee did not deny the superior advantages offered by such prisons as gloucester and petworth

column5: but it at once deprecated the idea that the city could follow the laudable example thus set in the provinces quote

column5: were a metropolitan prison erected on the same lines with all the space not only for air and exercise but for day rooms and sleeping cells

column5: end quote it would cover some thirty acres and cost a great deal more than the city with the example of whitecross street prison before it

column4: COULD POSSIBLY AFFORD
column5: could possibly afford

column5: the committee does not seem to have yet understood that newgate could be only and properly replaced

column5: by a new jail built on the outskirts as holloway eventually was and permitted itself to be altogether countered

column5: the pleadings however eloquent of a single individual were unable to more than partially remedy the widespread and colossal evils of british prisons

column5: howard's energy and devotion were rewarded by lively sympathy but the desire to improve which followed his exposures was but shortlived

column5: was in several places merely temporary

column5: in order to give greater value to the pamphlet

column5: mr buxton's small work on prison discipline gave a new aspect to the question he had so much at heart

column5: the untried and in the eyes of the law still innocent could claim pure air wholesome and sufficient food and opportunities for exercise

column5: they had a right mr buxton affirmed to be employed in their own crafts provided it could be safely followed in prison

column4: YOU HAVE NO RIGHT HE SAYS ADDRESSING THE AUTHORITIES TO SUBJECT A PRISONER TO SUFFERING FROM COLD

column5: by want of bedclothing by night or firing by day

column4: AND THE REASON IS PLAIN YOU HAVE TAKEN HIM FROM HIS HOME AND HAVE DEPRIVED HIM OF THE MEANS OF PROVIDING HIMSELF WITH THE NECESSARIES OR COMFORTS OF LIFE
column5: and the reason is plain you have taken him from his home and have deprived him of the means of providing himself with the necessaries or comforts of life

column4: AND THEREFORE YOU ARE BOUND TO FURNISH HIM WITH MODERATE INDEED BUT SUITABLE ACCOMMODATION
column5: and therefore you are bound to furnish him with moderate indeed but suitable accommodation

column5: his morals by compelling him to mix with a promiscuous assemblage of hardened and convicted criminals

column5: or his health by forcing him at night into a damp unventilated cell with such crowds of companions as very speedily render the air foul and putrid

column5: or amidst the noxious effluvia of dirt and corruption

column5: in short attention to his feelings mental and bodily a supply of every necessary abstraction from evil society

column5: nor even when found guilty and his liberty forfeited did his privileges cease the law appointed a suitable punishment for the offense

column4: TO SEE THAT NO CIRCUMSTANCES OF SEVERITY ARE FOUND IN HIS TREATMENT WHICH ARE NOT FOUND IN HIS SENTENCE

column5: who ever heard of a criminal being sentenced to catch the rheumatism or the typhus fever

column5: the convicted delinquent has his rights said mr buxton authoritatively

column5: of poor and needy prisoners committed to the common jail for felony and other misdemeanors who many times perish before their trial

column5: in distinct rooms on pain of forfeiting his office and treble damages to the party aggrieved

column5: were to be kept in every jail and the prisoners directed to wash in them before release these provisions were almost a dead letter

column5: yet another act passed in seventeen ninetyone if properly observed should have insured proper attention to them

column5: two or more justices were appointed visitors of prisons and directed to visit and inspect three times every quarter

column4: A PRICE WHICH IN THOSE DAYS FLUCTUATED ENORMOUSLY  AS MUCH AS A HUNDRED PERCENT IN A COUPLE OF YEARS
column5: a price which in those days fluctuated enormously  as much as a hundred percent in a couple of years

column4: BUT AS NO SIMILAR VARIATION OCCURRED IN THE PRISONER'S APPETITE HIS RATION WAS SOMEWHAT PRECARIOUS
column5: but as no similar variation occurred in the prisoner's appetite his ration was somewhat precarious

column4: AS FOR THE DEBTORS THEY HAD NO ALLOWANCE WHATEVER AND WERE OFTEN IN IMMINENT DANGER OF STARVATION
column5: as for the debtors they had no allowance whatever and were often in imminent danger of starvation

column4: WITH ALL THIS THE INMATES WERE CROWDED TOGETHER AT NIGHT TO SUCH A DEGREE AS TO EXCITE SURPRISE THAT THEY SHOULD ESCAPE SUFFOCATION
column5: with all this the inmates were crowded together at night to such a degree as to excite surprise that they should escape suffocation

column4: THERE REIGNED THROUGH THE WHOLE EDIFICE A CHILLY DAMP UNWHOLESOME ATMOSPHERE AND THE EFFLUVIA FROM THE PRISONERS WAS SO NAUSEOUS
column5: there reigned through the whole edifice a chilly damp unwholesome atmosphere and the effluvia from the prisoners was so nauseous

column4: THAT THE CHAPLAIN FOUND IT NECESSARY TO TAKE HIS PLACE BEFORE THEY ENTERED CHAPEL AS HE COULD NOT OTHERWISE HAVE FACED THE SMELL
column5: that the chaplain found it necessary to take his place before they entered chapel as he could not otherwise have faced the smell

column4: IT IS CONSOLING TO KNOW THAT THERE WERE A FEW BRILLIANT EXCEPTIONS TO THIS CRUEL CALLOUS NEGLECT
column5: it is consoling to know that there were a few brilliant exceptions to this cruel callous neglect

column4: ALREADY AS EARLY AS EIGHTEEN EIGHTEEN A PRISON EXISTED AT BURY ST EDMUNDS WHICH WAS A MODEL FOR IMITATION TO OTHERS AT THAT TIME
column5: already as early as eighteen eighteen a prison existed at bury st edmunds which was a model for imitation to others at that time

column4: AND WHICH EVEN FULFILLED MANY OF THE EXACTING REQUIREMENTS OF MODERN DAYS
column5: and which even fulfilled many of the exacting requirements of modern days

column4: THE GREAT PRINCIPLES OF CLASSIFICATION CLEANLINESS AND EMPLOYMENT WERE CLOSELY OBSERVED
column5: the great principles of classification cleanliness and employment were closely observed

column4: THERE WERE EIGHTYFOUR SEPARATE SLEEPINGCELLS AND UNLESS THE JAIL WAS OVERCROWDED EVERY INMATE PASSED THE NIGHT ALONE
column5: there were eightyfour separate sleepingcells and unless the jail was overcrowded every inmate passed the night alone

column4: AND IN COMPARATIVE COMFORT WITH A BED AND PROPER BEDDING
column5: and in comparative comfort with a bed and proper bedding

column4: THE PRISON STOOD ON A DRY AIRY SITUATION OUTSIDE THE TOWN
column5: the prison stood on a dry airy situation outside the town

column4: PRISONERS ON RECEPTION WERE TREATED AS THEY ARE NOWADAYS  BATHED DRESSED IN PRISON CLOTHES AND INSPECTED BY THE SURGEON
column5: prisoners on reception were treated as they are nowadays  bathed dressed in prison clothes and inspected by the surgeon

column4: NO IRONS WERE WORN EXCEPT AS A PUNISHMENT
column5: no irons were worn except as a punishment

column4: PERSONAL CLEANLINESS WAS INSISTED UPON AND ALL PARTS OF THE PRISON WERE KEPT SCRUPULOUSLY CLEAN
column5: personal cleanliness was insisted upon and all parts of the prison were kept scrupulously clean

column4: THERE WAS AN INFIRMARY PROPERLY FOUND AND DULY LOOKED AFTER
column5: there was an infirmary properly found and duly looked after

column4: NO IDLENESS WAS PERMITTED AMONG THE INMATES TRADES WERE TAUGHT OR PRISONERS WERE ALLOWED TO FOLLOW THEIR OWN IF SUITABLE
column5: no idleness was permitted among the inmates trades were taught or prisoners were allowed to follow their own if suitable

column4: THERE WAS BESIDES A MILL FOR GRINDING CORN SOMEWHAT SIMILAR TO A TURNSPIT WHICH PRISONERS TURNED BY WALKING IN ROWS
column5: there was besides a mill for grinding corn somewhat similar to a turnspit which prisoners turned by walking in rows

column4: THIS MADE EXERTION COMPULSORY AND IMPOSED HARD LABOR AS A PROPER PUNISHMENT
column5: this made exertion compulsory and imposed hard labor as a proper punishment

column4: ANOTHER JAIL THAT OF ILCHESTER WAS ALSO WORTHY OF ALL COMMENDATION IT EXHIBITED ALL THE GOOD POINTS OF THAT AT BURY
column5: another jail that of ilchester was also worthy of all commendation it exhibited all the good points of that at bury

column4: AT ILCHESTER THE RULE OF EMPLOYMENT HAD BEEN CARRIED FURTHER
column5: at ilchester the rule of employment had been carried further

column4: A SYSTEM NOT ADOPTED GENERALLY TILL NEARLY HALF A CENTURY LATER HAD ALREADY PREVAILED AT ILCHESTER
column5: a system not adopted generally till nearly half a century later had already prevailed at ilchester

column5: the new jail had been in a great measure constructed by the prisoners themselves

column5: masons bricklayers carpenters painters had been employed upon the buildings and the work was pronounced excellent by competent judges

column5: there were workrooms for woolwashing dyeing carding and spinning

column5: the looms were constantly busy tailors were always at work and every article of clothing and bedding was made up within the walls

column4: THE MORAL WELFARE OF THE INMATES WAS AS CLOSELY LOOKED AFTER AS THE PHYSICAL
column5: the moral welfare of the inmates was as closely looked after as the physical

column5: there was an attentive chaplain a schoolmaster and regular religious and other instruction

column5: compared with those highly meritorious institutions newgate still showed but badly

column4: ITS EVILS WERE INHERENT AND IRREMEDIABLE BUT SOME AMELIORATING MEASURES HAD BEEN INTRODUCED
column5: its evils were inherent and irremediable but some ameliorating measures had been introduced

column4: MAINLY THROUGH THE EXERTIONS OF A NEW GOVERNOR MR BROWN WHO SUCCEEDED MR NEWMAN AT NEWGATE IN EIGHTEEN SEVENTEEN
column5: mainly through the exertions of a new governor mr brown who succeeded mr newman at newgate in eighteen seventeen

column5: the most noticeable of the improvements introduced was a better regulation of dietaries within the prison

column4: THE OLD HAPHAZARD SYSTEM BY WHICH MEAT WAS ISSUED IN BULK
column5: the old haphazard system by which meat was issued in bulk

column4: A WEEK'S ALLOWANCE AT A TIME WAS ABOLISHED AND THERE WAS A REGULAR SCALE OF DAILY RATIONS ADOPTED
column5: a week's allowance at a time was abolished and there was a regular scale of daily rations adopted

column4: THE DIET WAS NOW AMPLE IT CONSISTED OF A POUND AND A HALF OF BREAD PER DIEM
column5: the diet was now ample it consisted of a pound and a half of bread per diem

column4: FOR BREAKFAST A PINT OF GRUEL FOR DINNER HALF A POUND OF BOILED MEAT OR A QUART OF SOUP WITH VEGETABLES ON ALTERNATE DAYS
column5: for breakfast a pint of gruel for dinner half a pound of boiled meat or a quart of soup with vegetables on alternate days

column4: THE FOOD WAS PROPERLY PREPARED IN THE PRISON KITCHEN
column5: the food was properly prepared in the prison kitchen

column4: MEAT WAS NO LONGER ISSUED RAW TO BE IMPERFECTLY COOKED BEFORE A WARD FIRE AND BOLTED GLUTTONOUSLY THE WHOLE TWO POUNDS AT ONE SITTING
column5: meat was no longer issued raw to be imperfectly cooked before a ward fire and bolted gluttonously the whole two pounds at one sitting

column4: MR BROWN CONFIDENTLY ASSERTED THAT NO JAIL IN ENGLAND NOW FED ITS INMATES SO WELL AS DID NEWGATE
column5: mr brown confidently asserted that no jail in england now fed its inmates so well as did newgate

column4: SO PLENTIFUL WAS THIS DIETARY THAT ALTHOUGH THE OLD PERMISSION REMAINED IN FORCE OF ALLOWING THE FRIENDS OF PRISONERS TO BRING THEM SUPPLIES FROM OUTSIDE
column5: so plentiful was this dietary that although the old permission remained in force of allowing the friends of prisoners to bring them supplies from outside

column4: THE PRACTICE WAS FALLING INTO ABEYANCE AND THE PRISONERS SELDOM REQUIRED PRIVATE ASSISTANCE TO EKE OUT THEIR MEALS
column5: the practice was falling into abeyance and the prisoners seldom required private assistance to eke out their meals

column4: IT WAS ALSO CLAIMED FOR THE MORE AMPLE AND MORE ORDERLY DISTRIBUTION OF VICTUALS THAT THE GENERAL HEALTH OF THE PRISONERS HAD GREATLY IMPROVED
column5: it was also claimed for the more ample and more orderly distribution of victuals that the general health of the prisoners had greatly improved

column4: MR BROWN ALSO MUCH TO HIS OWN CREDIT BROUGHT ABOUT THE ABANDONMENT OF THE PRACTICE OF IRONING ALL PRISONERS AS A MATTER OF COURSE
column5: mr brown also much to his own credit brought about the abandonment of the practice of ironing all prisoners as a matter of course

column4: IN EIGHTEEN EIGHTEEN PRISONERS AWAITING TRIAL IN NEWGATE WERE AT LENGTH RELIEVED FROM THIS ILLEGAL INFLICTION
column5: in eighteen eighteen prisoners awaiting trial in newgate were at length relieved from this illegal infliction

column4: CONVICTS WERE NOT EVEN COMPELLED TO WEAR IRONS PROVIDING THEY BEHAVED WELL
column5: convicts were not even compelled to wear irons providing they behaved well

column4: IT WAS FOUND THAT SHACKLES MIGHT BE SAFELY DISPENSED WITH EVEN IN THE CASE OF THE MOST DESPERATE CHARACTERS

column4: THIS WAS EFFECTED BY STOPPING THE NEARLY INDISCRIMINATE ADMISSION OF VISITORS WHICH HAD HITHERTO PREVAILED ALL OVER THE JAIL
column5: this was effected by stopping the nearly indiscriminate admission of visitors which had hitherto prevailed all over the jail

column4: IRONING IT WILL BE REMEMBERED WAS A DISTINGUISHING BADGE SO THAT WHEN THE JAIL WAS CLEARED THE FREE MIGHT BE READILY KNOWN FROM THE CAPTIVE AND ESCAPES PREVENTED
column5: ironing it will be remembered was a distinguishing badge so that when the jail was cleared the free might be readily known from the captive and escapes prevented

column5: under the new rule visitors were not allowed to pass into the interior of the prison but were detained between the grating

column4: THIS CHANGE LED TO SOME DISCONTENT UNTIL IT WAS FOUND THAT THE MUCH GREATER BOON OF RELIEF FROM IRONS ACCOMPANIED IT AND THE REFORM WAS QUIETLY ACCEPTED
column5: this change led to some discontent until it was found that the much greater boon of relief from irons accompanied it and the reform was quietly accepted

column4: INDEED THE BEST CONSEQUENCES FOLLOWED FROM THE REMOVAL OF IRONS THE PRISONERS WERE MUCH BETTER DISPOSED THERE WERE NO RIOTS AND FEWER DISTURBANCES
column5: indeed the best consequences followed from the removal of irons the prisoners were much better disposed there were no riots and fewer disturbances

column5: the first still produced deplorable results  results to be observable for many years to come

column5: other cases of moral deterioration have already been recorded

column4: IN THAT PRISON WITH ITS CELLS AND YARDS ARRANGED WITHIN THE SHELL OF AN ANCIENT ABBEY CHAPEL
column5: in that prison with its cells and yards arranged within the shell of an ancient abbey chapel

column4: THE PRISONERS WITHOUT FIRING BEDDING OR SUFFICIENT FOOD SPENT THEIR DAYS IN SURVEYING THEIR GROTESQUE PRISON
column5: the prisoners without firing bedding or sufficient food spent their days in surveying their grotesque prison

column4: OR CONTRIVING SOME MEANS OF ESCAPE BY CLIMBING THE FLUTED COLUMNS WHICH SUPPORTED THE GOTHIC ARCHES OF THE AISLES
column5: or contriving some means of escape by climbing the fluted columns which supported the gothic arches of the aisles

column4: AND SO PASSING BY THE ROOF DOWN INTO THE GARDEN AND ON TO FREEDOM
column5: and so passing by the roof down into the garden and on to freedom

column4: IN A COUNTY PRISON ADJOINING THE METROPOLIS THE SEPARATION BETWEEN THE MALE AND FEMALE QUARTERS WAS SUPPOSED TO BE ACCOMPLISHED BY THE ERECTION OF AN IRON RAILING
column5: in a county prison adjoining the metropolis the separation between the male and female quarters was supposed to be accomplished by the erection of an iron railing

column4: IN THIS SAME PRISON CAPITAL CONVICTS WERE CHAINED TO THE FLOOR UNTIL EXECUTION
column5: in this same prison capital convicts were chained to the floor until execution

column4: IN ANOTHER JAIL NOT FAR OFF MALE AND FEMALE FELONS STILL OCCUPIED THE SAME ROOM  UNDERGROUND AND REACHED BY A LADDER OF TEN STEPS
column5: in another jail not far off male and female felons still occupied the same room  underground and reached by a ladder of ten steps

column4: IN OTHERS THE SEPARATION BETWEEN THE SEXES CONSISTED IN A HANGING CURTAIN
column5: in others the separation between the sexes consisted in a hanging curtain

column4: OR AN IMAGINARY BOUNDARY LINE AND NOTHING PREVENTED PARTIES FROM PASSING TO EITHER SIDE
column5: or an imaginary boundary line and nothing prevented parties from passing to either side

column4: BUT AN EMPTY REGULATION WHICH ALL SO DISPOSED COULD DEFY
column5: but an empty regulation which all so disposed could defy

column4: NUMBERS OF THE JAILS WERE STILL UNPROVIDED WITH CHAPLAINS AND THE PRISONERS NEVER HEARD DIVINE SERVICE
column5: numbers of the jails were still unprovided with chaplains and the prisoners never heard divine service

column4: IN MANY OTHERS THERE WERE NO INFIRMARIES NO PLACES SET APART FOR THE CONFINEMENT OF PRISONERS AFFLICTED WITH DANGEROUS AND INFECTIOUS DISORDERS
column5: in many others there were no infirmaries no places set apart for the confinement of prisoners afflicted with dangerous and infectious disorders

column4: NO ATTEMPT WAS MADE TO MAINTAIN DISCIPLINE
column5: no attempt was made to maintain discipline

column4: HALF THE JAILS HAD NO CODE OF RULES PROPERLY PREPARED AND SANCTIONED BY THE JUDGES ACCORDING TO LAW
column5: half the jails had no code of rules properly prepared and sanctioned by the judges according to law

column4: BY DEGREES HOWEVER
column5: by degrees however

column4: THE CHANGES NECESSARY TO BRING THE PRISONS INTO CONFORMITY WITH THE RECENT ACTS WERE ATTEMPTED IF NOT ACTUALLY INTRODUCED INTO THE COUNTY PRISONS TO WHICH
column5: the changes necessary to bring the prisons into conformity with the recent acts were attempted if not actually introduced into the county prisons to which

column4: WITH A FEW OF THE MORE IMPORTANT CITY OR BOROUGH PRISONS THESE ACTS MORE ESPECIALLY APPLIED
column5: with a few of the more important city or borough prisons these acts more especially applied

column4: MOST OF THE LOCAL AUTHORITIES EMBARKED INTO CONSIDERABLE EXPENDITURE DETERMINED TO REBUILD THEIR JAILS DE NOVO ON THE MOST APPROVED PATTERN
column5: most of the local authorities embarked into considerable expenditure determined to rebuild their jails de novo on the most approved pattern

column4: OR TO REAPPROPRIATE RECONSTRUCT AND PATCH UP THE EXISTING PRISONS TILL THEY WERE MORE IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GROWING REQUIREMENTS OF THE TIMES
column5: or to reappropriate reconstruct and patch up the existing prisons till they were more in accordance with the growing requirements of the times

column4: RELIGIOUS WORSHIP BECAME MORE GENERALLY THE RULE CHAPLAINS WERE APPOINTED AND CHAPELS PROVIDED FOR THEM SURGEONS AND HOSPITALS ALSO
column5: religious worship became more generally the rule chaplains were appointed and chapels provided for them surgeons and hospitals also

column4: WORKSHOPS WERE BUILT AT MANY PRISONS VARIOUS KINDS OF MANUFACTURES AND TRADES WERE SET ON FOOT INCLUDING WEAVING MATTING SHOEMAKING AND TAILORING
column5: workshops were built at many prisons various kinds of manufactures and trades were set on foot including weaving matting shoemaking and tailoring

column4: THE INTERIOR OF ONE PRISON WAS ILLUMINATED THROUGHOUT WITH GAS  STILL A NOVELTY WHICH HAD BEEN GENERALLY ADOPTED IN LONDON ONLY FOUR YEARS PREVIOUSLY
column5: the interior of one prison was illuminated throughout with gas  still a novelty which had been generally adopted in london only four years previously

column4: A MEASURE WHICH MUST GREATLY TEND TO DISCOURAGE ATTEMPTS TO ESCAPE
column5: a measure which must greatly tend to discourage attempts to escape

column4: THERE WERE TREADWHEELS AT MOST OF THE PRISONS AND REGULAR EMPLOYMENT THEREON OR AT SOME OTHER KIND OF HARD LABOR
column5: there were treadwheels at most of the prisons and regular employment thereon or at some other kind of hard labor

column4: IN MANY PLACES TOO WHERE THE PRISONERS EARNED MONEY BY THEIR WORK THEY WERE GRANTED A PORTION OF IT FOR THEIR OWN USE AFTER PROPER DEDUCTION FOR MAINTENANCE
column5: in many places too where the prisoners earned money by their work they were granted a portion of it for their own use after proper deduction for maintenance

column4: ONLY A FEW GLARING EVILS STILL DEMANDED A REMEDY
column5: only a few glaring evils still demanded a remedy

column4: THE PROVISION OF SEPARATE SLEEPING CELLS WAS STILL QUITE INADEQUATE FOR INSTANCE
column5: the provision of separate sleeping cells was still quite inadequate for instance

column4: IN TWENTYTWO COUNTY JAILS THERE WERE ONE THOUSAND SIXTYTHREE SLEEPING CELLS IN ALL IN EIGHTEEN TWENTYTHREE
column5: in twentytwo county jails there were one thousand sixtythree sleeping cells in all in eighteen twentythree

column4: AND THE AVERAGE DAILY NUMBER COMMITTED THAT YEAR AMOUNTED TO THREE THOUSAND NINE HUNDRED EIGHTYFIVE
column5: and the average daily number committed that year amounted to three thousand nine hundred eightyfive

column4: THE WANT OF SLEEPING CELLS LONG CONTINUED A CRYING NEED
column5: the want of sleeping cells long continued a crying need

column4: FOUR YEARS LATER THE PRISON SOCIETY REPORTED
column5: four years later the prison society reported

column4: THAT IN FOUR PRISONS WHICH AT ONE TIME OF THE YEAR CONTAINED ONE THOUSAND THREE HUNDRED EIGHT PRISONERS THERE WERE ONLY SIXTYEIGHT SLEEPING ROOMS OR CELLS
column5: that in four prisons which at one time of the year contained one thousand three hundred eight prisoners there were only sixtyeight sleeping rooms or cells

column4: MAKING AN AVERAGE OF NINETEEN PERSONS OCCUPYING EACH ROOM
column5: making an average of nineteen persons occupying each room

column4: AT THE NEW PRISON CLERKENWELL WHICH HAD BECOME THE PRINCIPAL RECEPTION JAIL OF MIDDLESEX AND SO TOOK ALL THE UNTRIED
column5: at the new prison clerkenwell which had become the principal reception jail of middlesex and so took all the untried

column4: THE SLEEPING SPACE PER HEAD WAS ONLY SIXTEEN INCHES AND OFTEN AS MANY AS TWO HUNDRED NINETYTHREE MEN HAD TO BE ACCOMMODATED ON BARRACK BEDS
column5: the sleeping space per head was only sixteen inches and often as many as two hundred ninetythree men had to be accommodated on barrack beds

column4: OCCUPYING BARELY THREE HUNDRED NINETY FEET LINEAL
column5: occupying barely three hundred ninety feet lineal

column4: THE SCENES OF TUMULT AND OBSCENITY IN THESE NIGHT ROOMS ARE SAID TO HAVE BEEN BEYOND DESCRIPTION A PRISONER IN ONE NOCTURNAL RIOT LOST AN EYE
column5: the scenes of tumult and obscenity in these night rooms are said to have been beyond description a prisoner in one nocturnal riot lost an eye

column4: YET TO CLERKENWELL WERE NOW COMMITTED THE JUVENILES AND ALL WHO WERE INEXPERIENCED IN CRIME
column5: yet to clerkenwell were now committed the juveniles and all who were inexperienced in crime

column4: GREAT WANT OF UNIFORMITY IN TREATMENT IN THE VARIOUS PRISONS WAS STILL NOTICEABLE
column5: great want of uniformity in treatment in the various prisons was still noticeable

column4: AND WAS INDEED DESTINED TO CONTINUE FOR ANOTHER HALF CENTURY IN OTHER WORDS UNTIL THE INTRODUCTION OF THE PRISON ACT OF EIGHTEEN SEVENTYSEVEN
column5: and was indeed destined to continue for another half century in other words until the introduction of the prison act of eighteen seventyseven

column4: AT THE TIME OF WHICH I AM WRITING THERE WAS GREAT DIVERSITY OF PRACTICE AS REGARDS THE HOURS OF LABOR
column5: at the time of which i am writing there was great diversity of practice as regards the hours of labor

column4: IN SOME PRISONS THE PRISONERS WORKED SEVEN HOURS A DAY IN OTHERS TEN AND TEN AND A HALF
column5: in some prisons the prisoners worked seven hours a day in others ten and ten and a half

column4: THE NATURE OF THE EMPLOYMENT VARIED GREATLY IN SEVERITY ESPECIALLY THE TREADWHEEL LABOR
column5: the nature of the employment varied greatly in severity especially the treadwheel labor

column4: IN SOME COUNTY JAILS AS I HAVE ALREADY SAID FEMALE PRISONERS WERE PLACED UPON THE TREADWHEEL
column5: in some county jails as i have already said female prisoners were placed upon the treadwheel

column4: IN OTHERS WOMEN WERE VERY PROPERLY EXEMPTED FROM IT AND ALSO FROM ALL SEVERE LABOR
column5: in others women were very properly exempted from it and also from all severe labor

column4: EARNINGS WERE VERY DIFFERENTLY APPROPRIATED HERE THE PRISONERS WERE GIVEN THE WHOLE AMOUNT THERE A HALF OR A THIRD
column5: earnings were very differently appropriated here the prisoners were given the whole amount there a half or a third

column4: SOMETIMES THIS MONEY MIGHT BE EXPENDED IN THE PURCHASE OF EXTRA ARTICLES OF FOOD
column5: sometimes this money might be expended in the purchase of extra articles of food

column4: THE RATIONS VARIED CONSIDERABLY EVERYWHERE
column5: the rations varied considerably everywhere

column4: IT WAS STILL LIMITED TO BREAD IN SOME PLACES THE ALLOWANCE OF WHICH VARIED FROM ONE TO THREE POUNDS
column5: it was still limited to bread in some places the allowance of which varied from one to three pounds

column4: IN OTHERS MEAT SOUP GRUEL BEER WERE GIVEN
column5: in others meat soup gruel beer were given

column4: HERE AND THERE FOOD WAS NOT ISSUED IN KIND BUT A MONEY ALLOWANCE WHICH THE PRISONER MIGHT EXPEND HIMSELF
column5: here and there food was not issued in kind but a money allowance which the prisoner might expend himself

column4: BEDDING AND CLOTHING WAS STILL DENIED BUT ONLY IN A FEW JAILS
column5: bedding and clothing was still denied but only in a few jails

column4: IN OTHERS BOTH WERE SUPPLIED IN AMPLE QUANTITIES THE COST VARYING PER PRISONER FROM TWENTY SHILLINGS TO FIVE POUNDS
column5: in others both were supplied in ample quantities the cost varying per prisoner from twenty shillings to five pounds

column4: IT WAS PLAIN THAT ALTHOUGH THE LAW HAD DEFINED GENERAL PRINCIPLES OF PRISON GOVERNMENT
column5: it was plain that although the law had defined general principles of prison government

column4: TOO MUCH DISCRETION WAS STILL LEFT TO THE MAGISTRACY TO FILL IN THE DETAILS THE LEGISLATURE ONLY RECOMMENDED
column5: too much discretion was still left to the magistracy to fill in the details the legislature only recommended

column4: IT DID NOT PEREMPTORILY INSIST TOO OFTEN THE LETTER OF THE LAW WAS OBSERVED BUT NOT ITS SPIRIT
column5: it did not peremptorily insist too often the letter of the law was observed but not its spirit

column4: ONE GREAT IMPEDIMENT TO WIDE AMELIORATION WAS THAT A VAST NUMBER OF SMALL JAILS LAY OUT OF REACH OF THE LAW
column5: one great impediment to wide amelioration was that a vast number of small jails lay out of reach of the law

column4: WHEN THE NEW ACTS WERE INTRODUCED NUMEROUS PRISONS UNDER LOCAL JURISDICTION WERE EXEMPTED FROM THE OPERATION OF THE LAW
column5: when the new acts were introduced numerous prisons under local jurisdiction were exempted from the operation of the law

column4: THEY WERE SO RADICALLY BAD THAT REFORM SEEMED HOPELESS AND IT WAS THOUGHT WISER NOT TO BRING THEM UNDER PROVISIONS WHICH CLEARLY COULD NOT BE ENFORCED
column5: they were so radically bad that reform seemed hopeless and it was thought wiser not to bring them under provisions which clearly could not be enforced

column4: MR PEEL WHO AS HOME SECRETARY HAD CHARGE OF THE BILL
column5: mr peel who as home secretary had charge of the bill

column4: WHICH BECAME THE FOUR GEORGE THE FOURTH CAP SIXTYFOUR SAID THAT HE HAD ABSTAINED FROM LEGISLATING FOR THESE SMALL JURISDICTIONS ON MATURE DELIBERATION
column5: which became the four george the fourth cap sixtyfour said that he had abstained from legislating for these small jurisdictions on mature deliberation

column4: IT IS NOT HE SAID THAT I AM INSENSIBLE OF THE LAMENTABLE AND DISGRACEFUL SITUATION IN WHICH MANY OF THEM ARE
column5: it is not he said that i am insensible of the lamentable and disgraceful situation in which many of them are

column4: BUT I INDULGE A HOPE THAT MANY OF THEM WILL CONTRACT WITH THE COUNTIES
column5: but i indulge a hope that many of them will contract with the counties

column4: THAT MANY OF THEM WILL BUILD NEW JAILS AND THAT WHEN IN A YEAR OR TWO WE COME TO EXAMINE THEIR SITUATION
column5: that many of them will build new jails and that when in a year or two we come to examine their situation

column4: WE SHALL FIND BUT FEW WHICH HAVE NOT IN ONE OR OTHER OF THESE WAYS REMOVED THE GRIEVANCE OF WHICH SUCH JUST COMPLAINT IS MADE
column5: we shall find but few which have not in one or other of these ways removed the grievance of which such just complaint is made

column4: WHEN THAT TIME ARRIVES
column5: when that time arrives

column4: I SHALL NOT HESITATE TO ASK PARLIAMENT FOR POWERS TO COMPEL THEM TO MAKE THE NECESSARY ALTERATIONS FOR IT IS NOT TO BE ENDURED THAT THESE LOCAL JURISDICTIONS SHOULD REMAIN
column5: i shall not hesitate to ask parliament for powers to compel them to make the necessary alterations for it is not to be endured that these local jurisdictions should remain

column4: IN THE DEPLORABLE SITUATION IN WHICH MANY OF THEM NOW ARE
column5: in the deplorable situation in which many of them now are

column4: AT THIS TIME THERE WERE IN ENGLAND ONE HUNDRED AND SEVENTY BOROUGHS CITIES TOWNS AND LIBERTIES
column5: at this time there were in england one hundred and seventy boroughs cities towns and liberties

column4: WHICH POSSESSED THE RIGHT OF TRYING CRIMINALS FOR VARIOUS OFFENSES
column5: which possessed the right of trying criminals for various offenses

column4: NEARLY EVERY ONE OF THESE JURISDICTIONS HAD ITS OWN PRISON AND THERE WERE ONE HUNDRED AND SIXTY SUCH JAILS IN ALL
column5: nearly every one of these jurisdictions had its own prison and there were one hundred and sixty such jails in all

column4: MANY OF THEM CONSISTED OF ONE OR TWO ROOMS AT MOST
column5: many of them consisted of one or two rooms at most

column4: HE TOTAL NUMBER OF PRISONERS THEY RECEIVED DURING THE YEAR VARIED FROM TWO PERSONS TO MANY HUNDREDS
column5: he total number of prisoners they received during the year varied from two persons to many hundreds

column4: IT WAS IN THESE JAILS WITHDRAWN FROM THE PRESSURE OF AUTHORITY THAT THE NEW RULES WERE INVARIABLY IGNORED
column5: it was in these jails withdrawn from the pressure of authority that the new rules were invariably ignored

column4: THE RIGHT AND PRIVILEGE OF THE BOROUGH TO MAINTAIN ITS OWN PLACE OF CONFINEMENT WAS SO ANCIENT AND INDISPUTABLE
column5: the right and privilege of the borough to maintain its own place of confinement was so ancient and indisputable

column4: THAT FOR LONG NO IDEA OF INTERFERING WITH THEM WAS ENTERTAINED
column5: that for long no idea of interfering with them was entertained

column4: ALL THAT WAS URGED WAS THAT THE BOROUGH MAGISTRACY HAD NO RIGHT TO GOVERN THEIR JAILS
column5: all that was urged was that the borough magistracy had no right to govern their jails

column4: SO AS TO CORRUPT THOSE COMMITTED TO THE INJURY OF THE PEACE AND MORALS OF THE PUBLIC
column5: so as to corrupt those committed to the injury of the peace and morals of the public

column4: AS TIME PASSED HOWEVER THESE MAGISTRATES MADE NO EFFORT AT REFORM
column5: as time passed however these magistrates made no effort at reform

column4: THEY NEITHER BUILT NEW JAILS NOR CONTRACTED WITH THE COUNTIES AS HAD BEEN EXPECTED FOR THE TRANSFER OF THEIR PRISONERS
column5: they neither built new jails nor contracted with the counties as had been expected for the transfer of their prisoners

column4: AS THE SOCIETY PUT IT IN EIGHTEEN TWENTYSEVEN THE FRIENDS TO THE IMPROVEMENT OF PRISON DISCIPLINE WILL REGRET TO LEARN
column5: as the society put it in eighteen twentyseven the friends to the improvement of prison discipline will regret to learn

column4: THAT THE JAILS ATTACHED TO CORPORATE JURISDICTIONS CONTINUE TO BE THE FRUITFUL SOURCES
column5: that the jails attached to corporate jurisdictions continue to be the fruitful sources

column4: OF VICE AND MISERY DEBASING ALL WHO ARE CONFINED WITHIN THEIR WALLS AND DISSEMINATING THROUGH THEIR RESPECTIVE COMMUNITIES
column5: of vice and misery debasing all who are confined within their walls and disseminating through their respective communities

column4: THE KNOWLEDGE AND PRACTICE OF EVERY SPECIES OF CRIMINALITY
column5: the knowledge and practice of every species of criminality

column4: THE SOCIETY PROCEEDED TO SUPPORT THIS INDICTMENT BY FACTS IT IS MUCH THE OLD STORY
column5: the society proceeded to support this indictment by facts it is much the old story

column4: THE PRISONERS WERE LODGED IN ROOMS WHENCE THEY COULD CONVERSE WITH PASSENGERS IN THE STREETS AND FREELY OBTAIN SPIRITS AND OTHER PROHIBITED ARTICLES
column5: the prisoners were lodged in rooms whence they could converse with passengers in the streets and freely obtain spirits and other prohibited articles

column4: ALL DESCRIPTIONS OF OFFENDERS CONGREGATED TOGETHER IN THE FELONS' WARDS
column5: all descriptions of offenders congregated together in the felons' wards

column4: THE KEEPER AND HIS OFFICERS RESIDED AT A DISTANCE FROM THE JAIL AND LEFT ITS INMATES TO THEIR OWN DEVICES
column5: the keeper and his officers resided at a distance from the jail and left its inmates to their own devices

column4: THERE WAS NO DECENCY WHATEVER IN THE INTERNAL ARRANGEMENTS
column5: there was no decency whatever in the internal arrangements

column4: STILL NO SEPARATION OF THE SEXES NO MEANS OF ABLUTION OR OTHER NECESSARY SERVICES
column5: still no separation of the sexes no means of ablution or other necessary services

column4: ONE BOROUGH PRISON CONSISTED OF NOTHING MORE THAN A COUPLE OF CELLS ABOUT TEN YARDS SQUARE AND ABSOLUTELY NOTHING MORE
column5: one borough prison consisted of nothing more than a couple of cells about ten yards square and absolutely nothing more

column4: IN ANOTHER BOROUGH WITH A POPULATION OF TEN THOUSAND THE PRISON WAS OF THE SAME DIMENSIONS
column5: in another borough with a population of ten thousand the prison was of the same dimensions

column4: ONE CELL WAS A DUNGEON AND THE OTHER AN IMPROPER AND UNHEALTHY ABODE FOR ANY HUMAN BEING WITH A WATERCOURSE RUNNING THROUGH IT
column5: one cell was a dungeon and the other an improper and unhealthy abode for any human being with a watercourse running through it

column4: MOST OF THESE SMALL JAILS WERE STILL IN EXISTENCE AND IN MUCH THE SAME STATE EIGHT YEARS LATER
column5: most of these small jails were still in existence and in much the same state eight years later

column4: AS IS SHOWN BY THE REPORT OF THE COMMISSIONERS TO INQUIRE INTO THE STATE OF THE MUNICIPAL CORPORATIONS IN EIGHTEEN THIRTYFIVE
column5: as is shown by the report of the commissioners to inquire into the state of the municipal corporations in eighteen thirtyfive

column4: AN EXAMINATION OF THIS REPORT SHOWS HOW EVEN THE MOST INSIGNIFICANT TOWNSHIP HAD ITS JAIL
column5: an examination of this report shows how even the most insignificant township had its jail

column4: THUS DINAS MWDDY IN MERIONETHSHIRE HAD BESIDES THE PINFOLD AND THE STOCKS OR CRIB A LITTLE PRISON
column5: thus dinas mwddy in merionethshire had besides the pinfold and the stocks or crib a little prison

column4: CLUN IN SHROPSHIRE HAD A LOCKUP UNDER THE TOWN HALL
column5: clun in shropshire had a lockup under the town hall

column4: AT EYE IN SUFFOLK THE JAIL WAS PART OF THE POORHOUSE SO IT WAS AT RICHMOND IN YORKSHIRE WHERE THE MASTER OF THE WORKHOUSE WAS ALSO KEEPER OF THE JAIL
column5: at eye in suffolk the jail was part of the poorhouse so it was at richmond in yorkshire where the master of the workhouse was also keeper of the jail

column4: AT GODMANCHESTER THERE WAS NO JAIL BUT A CAGE TO SECURE PRISONERS TILL THEY COULD BE TAKEN BEFORE A MAGISTRATE
column5: at godmanchester there was no jail but a cage to secure prisoners till they could be taken before a magistrate

column4: KIDDERMINSTER HAD A PRISON ONE DAMP CHILL ROOM
column5: kidderminster had a prison one damp chill room

column4: THE ONLY APERTURE THROUGH WHICH AIR COULD BE ADMITTED BEING AN IRON GRATING LEVEL WITH THE STREET
column5: the only aperture through which air could be admitted being an iron grating level with the street

column4: THROUGH THE BARS OF WHICH QUILLS OR REEDS WERE INSERTED AND DRINK CONVEYED TO THE PRISONERS
column5: through the bars of which quills or reeds were inserted and drink conveyed to the prisoners

column4: AT WALSALL IN STAFFORDSHIRE
column5: at walsall in staffordshire

column4: THE JAIL CONSISTED OF SIX CELLS FREQUENTLY SO DAMP THAT THE MOISTURE TRICKLED DOWN THE WALLS THERE WAS NOT SPACE FOR AIR OR EXERCISE
column5: the jail consisted of six cells frequently so damp that the moisture trickled down the walls there was not space for air or exercise

column4: AND THE PRISON ALLOWANCE WAS STILL LIMITED TO BREAD AND WATER
column5: and the prison allowance was still limited to bread and water

column4: NEWGATE THROUGH ALL THESE YEARS CONTINUED A BYEWORD WITH THE SOCIETY
column5: newgate through all these years continued a byeword with the society

column4: SOME REFORMS HAD CERTAINLY BEEN INTRODUCED SUCH AS THE ABOLITION OF IRONS ALREADY REFERRED TO AND THE ESTABLISHMENT OF MALE AND FEMALE INFIRMARIES
column5: some reforms had certainly been introduced such as the abolition of irons already referred to and the establishment of male and female infirmaries

column4: THE REGULAR DAILY VISITATION OF THE CHAPLAIN WAS ALSO INSISTED UPON
column5: the regular daily visitation of the chaplain was also insisted upon

column4: BUT IT WAS POINTED OUT IN EIGHTEEN TWENTYTHREE THAT DEFECTIVE CONSTRUCTION MUST ALWAYS BAR THE WAY TO ANY RADICAL IMPROVEMENT IN NEWGATE
column5: but it was pointed out in eighteen twentythree that defective construction must always bar the way to any radical improvement in newgate

column4: WITHOUT ENLARGEMENT NO MATERIAL CHANGE IN DISCIPLINE OR INTERIOR ECONOMY COULD POSSIBLY BE INTRODUCED
column5: without enlargement no material change in discipline or interior economy could possibly be introduced

column4: THE CHAPEL STILL CONTINUED INCOMMODIOUS AND INSUFFICIENT
column5: the chapel still continued incommodious and insufficient

column4: FEMALE PRISONERS WERE STILL EXPOSED TO THE FULL VIEW OF THE MALES THE NETTING IN FRONT OF THE GALLERY BEING PERFECTLY USELESS AS A SCREEN
column5: female prisoners were still exposed to the full view of the males the netting in front of the gallery being perfectly useless as a screen

column4: IN EIGHTEEN TWENTYFOUR NEWGATE HAD NO GLASS IN ITS WINDOWS EXCEPT IN THE INFIRMARY AND ONE WARD OF THE CHAPEL YARD
column5: in eighteen twentyfour newgate had no glass in its windows except in the infirmary and one ward of the chapel yard

column4: AND THE PANES WERE FILLED IN WITH OILED PAPER AN INSUFFICIENT PROTECTION AGAINST THE WEATHER
column5: and the panes were filled in with oiled paper an insufficient protection against the weather

column4: AND AS THE WINDOWFRAMES WOULD NOT SHUT TIGHT THE PRISONERS COMPLAINED MUCH OF THE COLD ESPECIALLY AT NIGHT
column5: and as the windowframes would not shut tight the prisoners complained much of the cold especially at night

column4: THERE WAS A DIMINUTION IN THE NUMBERS IN CUSTODY DUE TO THE ADOPTION OF THE PRACTICE OF NOT COMMITTING AT ONCE TO NEWGATE EVERY OFFENDER FOR TRIAL AT THE OLD BAILEY
column5: there was a diminution in the numbers in custody due to the adoption of the practice of not committing at once to newgate every offender for trial at the old bailey

column4: BUT NOTHING HAD BEEN DONE TO IMPROVE THE PRISON BUILDINGS
column5: but nothing had been done to improve the prison buildings

column4: IN EIGHTEEN TWENTYSEVEN THE SOCIETY WAS COMPELLED TO REPORT THAT NO MATERIAL CHANGE HAD TAKEN PLACE IN NEWGATE SINCE THE PASSING OF THE PRISON LAWS
column5: in eighteen twentyseven the society was compelled to report that no material change had taken place in newgate since the passing of the prison laws

column4: AND THAT CONSEQUENTLY THE OBSERVANCE OF THEIR MOST IMPORTANT PROVISIONS WAS HABITUALLY NEGLECTED
column5: and that consequently the observance of their most important provisions was habitually neglected

column4: IT WAS ENACTED THAT THE COURT OF ALDERMEN SHOULD MAKE RULES FOR THE GOVERNMENT OF THE PRISON AND THAT THESE SHOULD BE POSTED PUBLICLY WITHIN THE WALLS
column5: it was enacted that the court of aldermen should make rules for the government of the prison and that these should be posted publicly within the walls

column4: AS YET NO RULES OR REGULATIONS HAD BEEN PRINTED OR PREPARED
column5: as yet no rules or regulations had been printed or prepared

column4: BY ANOTHER CLAUSE OF THE JAIL ACT TWO JUSTICES WERE TO BE APPOINTED TO VISIT THE PRISON AT LEAST THRICE IN EVERY QUARTER AND OFTENER IF OCCASION REQUIRED
column5: by another clause of the jail act two justices were to be appointed to visit the prison at least thrice in every quarter and oftener if occasion required

column4: THESE JUSTICES WERE TO INSPECT EVERY PART OF THE PRISON AND EXAMINE INTO THE STATE AND CONDITION OF PRISONERS
column5: these justices were to inspect every part of the prison and examine into the state and condition of prisoners

column4: THE CITY JUSTICES HAD NOT FULFILLED THIS OBLIGATION
column5: the city justices had not fulfilled this obligation

column4: IDLENESS WAS STILL THE GENERAL RULE FOR ALL PRISONERS IN NEWGATE IN DEFIANCE OF THE LAW
column5: idleness was still the general rule for all prisoners in newgate in defiance of the law

column4: THERE WAS NO INSTRUCTION OF ADULT PRISONERS IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE LAW THE SLEEPING ACCOMMODATION WAS STILL ALTOGETHER CONTRARY TO THE LATEST IDEAS
column5: there was no instruction of adult prisoners in accordance with the law the sleeping accommodation was still altogether contrary to the latest ideas

column4: THE VISITS OF FRIENDS WAS ONCE MORE UNRESERVEDLY ALLOWED AND THESE INCOMERS FREELY BROUGHT IN EXTRA PROVISIONS AND BEER
column5: the visits of friends was once more unreservedly allowed and these incomers freely brought in extra provisions and beer

column4: LAST AND WORST OF ALL THE ARRANGEMENTS FOR KEEPING THE CONDEMNED PRISONERS BETWEEN SENTENCE AND EXECUTION WERE MORE THAN UNSATISFACTORY
column5: last and worst of all the arrangements for keeping the condemned prisoners between sentence and execution were more than unsatisfactory

column4: THEY WERE NOT CONFINED APART FROM EACH OTHER BUT WERE CROWDED THIRTY OR FORTY TOGETHER IN THE PRESS YARD
column5: they were not confined apart from each other but were crowded thirty or forty together in the press yard

column4: SO THAT CORRUPT CONVERSATION OBLITERATED FROM THE MIND OF HIM WHO IS DOOMED TO SUFFER EVERY SERIOUS FEELING AND VALUABLE IMPRESSION
column5: so that corrupt conversation obliterated from the mind of him who is doomed to suffer every serious feeling and valuable impression

column4: I SHALL HAVE MORE TO SAY ON THIS SUBJECT AND UPON THE STATE OF NEWGATE GENERALLY IN THE FOLLOWING CHAPTER

column5: no doubt the governor for the time being mr cope was in a great measure to blame for all this and for the want of proper classification

column4: I SHALL HAVE OCCASION TO SPEAK AGAIN AND MORE AT LENGTH OF MR COPE'S CARELESS AND PERFUNCTORY DISCHARGE
column5: i shall have occasion to speak again and more at length of mr cope's careless and perfunctory discharge

column4: OF HIS MANY MANIFEST DUTIES BUT I SHALL HERE CONFINE MYSELF TO ANIMADVERTING ON HIS NEGLECT AS REGARDS THE APPROPRIATION OF HIS PRISON
column5: of his many manifest duties but i shall here confine myself to animadverting on his neglect as regards the appropriation of his prison

column4: HE WAS UNABLE TO GIVE ANY REASON WHATEVER FOR NOT UTILIZING THE WHOLE OF THE WARDS
column5: he was unable to give any reason whatever for not utilizing the whole of the wards

column4: HE SAW CERTAIN ROOMS FILL UP AND YET TOOK NO STEPS TO OPEN OTHERS THAT WERE LOCKED UP AND EMPTY
column5: he saw certain rooms fill up and yet took no steps to open others that were locked up and empty

column4: HE BLAMED THE CONSTRUCTION OF NEWGATE FOR THE NEGLECT OF CLASSIFICATION AND WAS YET COMPELLED TO CONFESS THAT HE HAD MADE NO ATTEMPT WHATEVER TO CARRY IT OUT
column5: he blamed the construction of newgate for the neglect of classification and was yet compelled to confess that he had made no attempt whatever to carry it out

column4: THE FACT WAS HE DID NOT KEEP THE CLASSIFICATION OF PRISONERS ON FIRST ARRIVAL IN HIS OWN HANDS NOR EVEN IN THAT OF HIS OFFICERS
column5: the fact was he did not keep the classification of prisoners on first arrival in his own hands nor even in that of his officers

column4: A NEW PRISONER'S FATE AS TO LOCATION RESTED REALLY WITH A POWERFUL FELLOWPRISONER
column5: a new prisoner's fate as to location rested really with a powerful fellowprisoner

column4: THE INSPECTORS FOUND THAT PRISONERS HAD THEIR PLACES ASSIGNED TO THEM
column5: the inspectors found that prisoners had their places assigned to them

column4: BY THE INNER GATESMAN HIMSELF A CONVICTED PRISONER AND A WARDSMAN OR RESPONSIBLE HEAD OF A ROOM
column5: by the inner gatesman himself a convicted prisoner and a wardsman or responsible head of a room

column4: THE WARDSMAN STILL EXACTED DUES OF WHICH MORE DIRECTLY
column5: the wardsman still exacted dues of which more directly

column4: AND THIS PARTICULAR OFFICIAL TOOK EXCELLENT CARE TO SELECT AS RESIDENTS FOR HIS OWN WARD THOSE MOST SUITABLE FROM HIS OWN POINT OF VIEW
column5: and this particular official took excellent care to select as residents for his own ward those most suitable from his own point of view

column4: THESE WARDSMEN BESIDES THUS RULING THE ROAST HAD NUMEROUS SPECIAL PRIVILEGES IF SUCH THEY CAN BE CALLED
column5: these wardsmen besides thus ruling the roast had numerous special privileges if such they can be called

column4: THEY WERE NOT OBLIGED TO ATTEND CHAPEL AND SELDOM IF EVER WENT PRISONERS SAID ONE OF THEM UNDER EXAMINATION DID NOT LIKE THE TROUBLE OF GOING TO CHAPEL
column5: they were not obliged to attend chapel and seldom if ever went prisoners said one of them under examination did not like the trouble of going to chapel

column4: THEY HAD A STANDING BEDSTEAD TO SLEEP ON AND A GOOD FLOCK MATTRESS DOUBLE ALLOWANCE OF PROVISIONS FILCHED FROM THE COMMON STOCK
column5: they had a standing bedstead to sleep on and a good flock mattress double allowance of provisions filched from the common stock

column4: NOBODY INTERFERED WITH THEM OR REGULATED THEIR CONDUCT THEY MIGHT GET DRUNK WHEN SO DISPOSED AND DID SO FREQUENTLY ALONE OR IN COMPANY
column5: nobody interfered with them or regulated their conduct they might get drunk when so disposed and did so frequently alone or in company

column4: EVIDENCE WAS GIVEN BEFORE THE INSPECTORS OF EIGHT OR TEN PRISONERS SEEN GIDDY DRUNK NOT ABLE TO SIT UPON FORMS
column5: evidence was given before the inspectors of eight or ten prisoners seen giddy drunk not able to sit upon forms

column4: THE FEMALE WARDSWOMEN WERE ALSO GIVEN TO INTEMPERANCE
column5: the female wardswomen were also given to intemperance

column4: THE MATRON DEPOSED TO HAVING SEEN THE GATESWOMAN EXCEEDINGLY DRUNK AND HAVING BEEN INSULTED BY HER
column5: the matron deposed to having seen the gateswoman exceedingly drunk and having been insulted by her

column4: THERE WAS NO PENALTY ATTACHED TO DRUNKENNESS
column5: there was no penalty attached to drunkenness

column4: A WARDSMAN DID NOT NECESSARILY LOSE HIS SITUATION FOR IT NOR WAS DRINK THE ONLY CREATURE COMFORT HE MIGHT ENJOY
column5: a wardsman did not necessarily lose his situation for it nor was drink the only creature comfort he might enjoy

column4: HE COULD INDULGE IN SNUFF IF A SNUFFTAKER
column5: he could indulge in snuff if a snufftaker

column4: AND MIGHT ALWAYS SMOKE HIS PIPE UNDISTURBED FOR ALTHOUGH THE USE OF TOBACCO HAD BEEN PROHIBITED SINCE THE REPORT OF THE LORDS COMMITTEE
column5: and might always smoke his pipe undisturbed for although the use of tobacco had been prohibited since the report of the lords committee

column4: IT WAS STILL FREELY INTRODUCED INTO THE PRISON
column5: it was still freely introduced into the prison

column4: PROBABLY AUTHORITY WOULD NOT HAVE BEEN SO RECKLESSLY USURPED BY THE WARDSMEN HAD NOT THE PROPER OFFICIALS TOO READILY SURRENDERED IT
column5: probably authority would not have been so recklessly usurped by the wardsmen had not the proper officials too readily surrendered it

column4: THE TURNKEYS LEFT THE PRISONERS VERY MUCH TO THEMSELVES NEVER ENTERING THE WARDS AFTER LOCKINGUP TIME AT DUSK TILL UNLOCKING NEXT MORNING
column5: the turnkeys left the prisoners very much to themselves never entering the wards after lockingup time at dusk till unlocking next morning

column4: AND THEN ONLY WENT ROUND TO COUNT THE NUMBER
column5: and then only went round to count the number

column4: MANY OF THEM WERE OTHERWISE AND IMPROPERLY OCCUPIED FOR HOURS EVERY DAY IN MENIAL SERVICES FOR THE GOVERNOR CLEANING HIS WINDOWS OR GROOMING HIS HORSE
column5: many of them were otherwise and improperly occupied for hours every day in menial services for the governor cleaning his windows or grooming his horse

column4: ONE TURNKEY HAD BEEN SO EMPLOYED SEVERAL HOURS DAILY FOR NEARLY ELEVEN YEARS
column5: one turnkey had been so employed several hours daily for nearly eleven years

column4: IT WAS NOT STRANGE THAT SUBORDINATES SHOULD NEGLECT THEIR DUTY WHEN SUPERIORS SET THE EXAMPLE
column5: it was not strange that subordinates should neglect their duty when superiors set the example

column4: NOTHING WAS MORE PROMINENTLY BROUGHT OUT BY THE INSPECTORS THAN THE INEFFICIENCY OF THE GOVERNOR AT THAT TIME MR COPE
column5: nothing was more prominently brought out by the inspectors than the inefficiency of the governor at that time mr cope

column4: HE MAY HAVE ERRED IN SOME POINTS THROUGH IGNORANCE BUT IN OTHERS HE WAS CLEARLY GUILTY OF CULPABLE NEGLECT
column5: he may have erred in some points through ignorance but in others he was clearly guilty of culpable neglect

column4: WE HAVE SEEN THAT HE TOOK NO PAINS TO CLASSIFY AND SEPARATE PRISONERS ON RECEPTION
column5: we have seen that he took no pains to classify and separate prisoners on reception

column4: THIS WAS ONLY ONE OF MANY GRAVE OMISSIONS ON HIS PART HE DID NOT FEEL IT INCUMBENT ON HIMSELF TO VISIT HIS PRISON OFTEN OR SEE HIS PRISONERS
column5: this was only one of many grave omissions on his part he did not feel it incumbent on himself to visit his prison often or see his prisoners

column4: THE ACT PRESCRIBED THAT HE SHOULD DO BOTH EVERY TWENTYFOUR HOURS BUT DAYS PASSED WITHOUT HIS ENTERING THE WARDS
column5: the act prescribed that he should do both every twentyfour hours but days passed without his entering the wards

column4: THE PRISONERS DECLARED THAT THEY DID NOT SEE HIM OFTENER THAN TWICE A WEEK
column5: the prisoners declared that they did not see him oftener than twice a week

column4: ONE MAN WHO HAD BEEN IN THE CONDEMNED WARD FOR TWO MONTHS SAID THE GOVERNOR ONLY CAME THERE FOUR TIMES
column5: one man who had been in the condemned ward for two months said the governor only came there four times

column4: AGAIN A TURNKEY DEPOSED THAT HIS CHIEF DID NOT ENTER THE WARDS MORE THAN ONCE A FORTNIGHT
column5: again a turnkey deposed that his chief did not enter the wards more than once a fortnight

column4: BUT IT IS ONLY FAIR TO MR COPE TO STATE THAT HE HIMSELF SAID HE WENT WHENEVER HE COULD FIND TIME
column5: but it is only fair to mr cope to state that he himself said he went whenever he could find time

column4: AND THAT HE WAS CONSTANTLY ENGAGED ATTENDING SESSIONS AND GOING WITH DRAFTS TO THE HULKS
column5: and that he was constantly engaged attending sessions and going with drafts to the hulks

column4: BUT WHEN HE DID VISIT HIS INSPECTIONS WERE OF THE MOST SUPERFICIAL CHARACTER
column5: but when he did visit his inspections were of the most superficial character

column4: SOMETIMES HE LOOKED AT HIS BOLTS AND BARS BUT HE NEVER EXAMINED THE CUPBOARDS COALBOXES OR OTHER POSSIBLE HIDINGPLACES FOR CARDS
column5: sometimes he looked at his bolts and bars but he never examined the cupboards coalboxes or other possible hidingplaces for cards

column4: DICE DANGEROUS IMPLEMENTS OR OTHER PROHIBITED ARTICLES
column5: dice dangerous implements or other prohibited articles

column4: HE ONLY ATTENDED CHAPEL ONCE ON SUNDAY NEVER ON THE WEEKDAY AND GENERALLY DEVOTED THE TIME SERVICE WAS IN PROGRESS
column5: he only attended chapel once on sunday never on the weekday and generally devoted the time service was in progress

column4: TO TAKING THE DESCRIPTIONS OF NEWLYARRIVED PRISONERS
column5: to taking the descriptions of newlyarrived prisoners

column4: HE REALLY DID NOT KNOW WHAT PASSED IN HIS JAIL
column5: he really did not know what passed in his jail

column4: AND WAS SURPRISED WHEN THE INSPECTORS PROVED TO HIM THAT PRACTICES OF WHICH HE WAS IGNORANT AND WHICH HE ADMITTED THAT HE REPREHENDED WENT ON WITHOUT HINDRANCE
column5: and was surprised when the inspectors proved to him that practices of which he was ignorant and which he admitted that he reprehended went on without hindrance

column4: HE WAS SATISFIED TO LET MATTERS RUN ON AS IN THE OLD TIMES HE SAID IN HIS OWN JUSTIFICATION WITH HIM WHAT WAS WAS RIGHT
column5: he was satisfied to let matters run on as in the old times he said in his own justification with him what was was right

column4: AND EVILS THAT SHOULD HAVE BEEN SPEEDILY ROOTED OUT REMAINED BECAUSE THEY HAD THE PRESCRIPTION OF LONG USAGE
column5: and evils that should have been speedily rooted out remained because they had the prescription of long usage

column4: HE KEPT NO DAILY JOURNAL OF OCCURRENCES AND NOTHING HOWEVER IMPORTANT WAS RECORDED AT THE TIME
column5: he kept no daily journal of occurrences and nothing however important was recorded at the time

column4: THE ALDERMEN NEVER CALLED UPON HIM TO REPORT AND LEFT HIM NEARLY UNSUPERVISED AND UNCONTROLLED
column5: the aldermen never called upon him to report and left him nearly unsupervised and uncontrolled

column4: IN HIS ADMINISTRATION OF DISCIPLINE HE WAS QUITE UNCERTAIN
column5: in his administration of discipline he was quite uncertain

column4: THE PUNISHMENTS HE INFLICTED WERE UNEQUAL
column5: the punishments he inflicted were unequal

column4: AND IT WAS NOT THE LEAST PART OF THE BLAME IMPUTED TO HIM THAT HE MADE SPECIAL FAVORITES OF PARTICULAR PRISONERS RETAINING OF HIS OWN ACCORD IN NEWGATE
column5: and it was not the least part of the blame imputed to him that he made special favorites of particular prisoners retaining of his own accord in newgate

column4: AND FOR YEARS FELONS WHO SHOULD HAVE BEEN SENT BEYOND THE SEAS
column5: and for years felons who should have been sent beyond the seas

column4: BUT INDEED HIS WHOLE RULE WAS FAR TOO MILD AND UNDER THIS MISTAKEN LENIENCY
column5: but indeed his whole rule was far too mild and under this mistaken leniency

column4: THE INTERIOR OF THE JAIL WAS MORE LIKE A BEARGARDEN OR THE NOISY PURLIEUS OF A PUBLICHOUSE THAN A PRISON
column5: the interior of the jail was more like a beargarden or the noisy purlieus of a publichouse than a prison

column4: IT WAS THE SAME OLD STORY  EVIL CONSTANTLY IN THE ASCENDANT THE LEAST CRIMINAL AT THE MERCY OF THE MOST DEPRAVED
column5: it was the same old story  evil constantly in the ascendant the least criminal at the mercy of the most depraved

column4: UNDER THE RECKLESS CONTEMPT FOR REGULATIONS
column5: under the reckless contempt for regulations

column4: THE APATHY OF THE AUTHORITIES AND THE UNDUE ASCENDANCY OF THOSE WHO AS CONVICTED FELONS SHOULD HAVE BEEN MOST STERNLY REPRESSED
column5: the apathy of the authorities and the undue ascendancy of those who as convicted felons should have been most sternly repressed

column4: THE MOST HARDENED AND THE OLDEST IN VICE HAD THE BEST OF IT WHILE THE INEXPERIENCED BEGINNER WENT TO THE WALL
column5: the most hardened and the oldest in vice had the best of it while the inexperienced beginner went to the wall

column4: EDWARD GIBBON WAKEFIELD WHO SPENT THREE YEARS IN NEWGATE A LITTLE BEFORE THE TIME OF THE INSPECTORS' FIRST REPORT
column5: edward gibbon wakefield who spent three years in newgate a little before the time of the inspectors' first report

column4: SAID WITH JUSTICE THAT INCREDIBLE SCENES OF HORROR OCCUR IN NEWGATE
column5: said with justice that incredible scenes of horror occur in newgate

column4: IT WAS MOREOVER IN HIS OPINION UNDOUBTEDLY THE GREATEST NURSERY OF CRIME IN LONDON
column5: it was moreover in his opinion undoubtedly the greatest nursery of crime in london

column4: THE DAYS WERE PASSED IN IDLENESS DEBAUCHERY RIOTOUS QUARRELING IMMORAL CONVERSATION
column5: the days were passed in idleness debauchery riotous quarreling immoral conversation

column4: GAMBLING INDIRECT CONTRAVENTION OF PARLIAMENTARY RULES INSTRUCTION IN ALL NEFARIOUS PROCESSES
column5: gambling indirect contravention of parliamentary rules instruction in all nefarious processes

column4: LIVELY DISCOURSE UPON PAST CRIMINAL EXPLOITS ELABORATE DISCUSSION OF OTHERS TO BE PERPETRATED AFTER RELEASE
column5: lively discourse upon past criminal exploits elaborate discussion of others to be perpetrated after release

column4: NO PROVISION WHATEVER WAS MADE FOR THE EMPLOYMENT OF PRISONERS NO MATERIALS WERE PURCHASED NO TRADE INSTRUCTORS APPOINTED
column5: no provision whatever was made for the employment of prisoners no materials were purchased no trade instructors appointed

column4: THERE WAS NO SCHOOL FOR ADULTS ONLY THE BOYS WERE TAUGHT ANYTHING AND THEIR INSTRUCTOR WITH HIS ASSISTANT WERE CONVICTED PRISONERS
column5: there was no school for adults only the boys were taught anything and their instructor with his assistant were convicted prisoners

column5: idle hands and unoccupied brains found in mischief the only means of whiling away the long hours of incarceration

column5: gaming of all kinds although forbidden by the jail acts was habitually practiced

column5: this was admitted in evidence by the turnkeys and was proved by the appearance of the prison tables which bore the marks of gamingboards deeply cut into them

column5: prisoners confessed that it was a favorite occupation the chief games being shoving halfpence on the table

column5: pitch in the hole cribbage dominoes and common tossing at which as much as four or five shillings would change hands in an hour

column5: but this was not the only amusement most of the wards took in the daily papers

column4: THE MOST POPULAR BEING THE TIMES MORNING HERALD AND MORNING CHRONICLE ON SUNDAY THE WEEKLY DISPATCH BELL'S LIFE AND THE WEEKLY MESSENGER
column5: the most popular being the times morning herald and morning chronicle on sunday the weekly dispatch bell's life and the weekly messenger

column5: the newsman had free access to the prison he passed in unsearched and unexamined and unaccompanied by an officer

column5: went at once to his customers who bought their paper and paid for it themselves

column5: the newsvendor was also a tobacconist

column5: and he had thus ample means of introducing to the prisoners the prohibited but always muchcoveted and generally procurable weed

column5: there was also a good supply of bibles and prayers

column5: the donation of a philanthropic gentleman captain brown but these particularly the bibles bore little appearance of having been used

column4: DRINK IN MORE OR LESS UNLIMITED QUANTITIES WAS STILL TO BE HAD
column5: drink in more or less unlimited quantities was still to be had

column5: spirits certainly were now excluded but a potman with full permission of the sheriffs

column5: brought in beer for sale from a neighboring publichouse and visited all the wards with no other escort than the prisoner gatesman

column5: but no steps were taken to prevent any prisoner from obtaining more if he could pay for it

column5: there were more varied and at times especially when beer had circulated freely more uproarious diversions

column5: wrestling in which legs were occasionally broken was freely indulged in also such low games as cobham

column5: leapfrog puss in the corner and fly the garter for which purpose the rugs were spread out to prevent feet slipping on the floor

column4: FEASTING ALTERNATED WITH FIGHTING
column5: feasting alternated with fighting

column5: the weekly introduction of food to which i shall presently refer formed the basis of luxurious banquets washed down by liquor

column5: and enlivened by flash songs and thrilling longwinded descriptions of robberies and other plants

column5: new arrivals especially the innocent and still guileless debutant were tormented with rude horseplay and assailed by the most insulting chaff

column5: if any man presumed to turn in too early

column5: he was toed that is to say a string was fastened to his big toe while he was asleep and he was dragged from off his mat

column5: or his bedclothes were drawn away across the room

column5: the ragged part of the prisoners were very anxious to destroy the clothes of the better dressed and often lighted small pieces of cloth

column5: which they dropped smoldering into their fellowprisoners' pockets
