column4: WE HAVE SEEN THAT MALE PRISONERS VISITED THEIR FEMALE RELATIONS AND FRIENDS ON THE FEMALE SIDE BESIDES THIS
column5: we have seen that male prisoners visited their female relations and friends on the female side besides this

column4: THE GATESMAN WHO PREPARED THE BRIEFS HAD INTERVIEWS WITH FEMALE PRISONERS ALONE WHILE TAKING THEIR INSTRUCTIONS A FEMALE CAME ALONE AND UNACCOMPANIED BY A MATRON
column5: the gatesman who prepared the briefs had interviews with female prisoners alone while taking their instructions a female came alone and unaccompanied by a matron

column4: TO CLEAN THE GOVERNOR'S OFFICE IN THE MALE PRISON
column5: to clean the governor's office in the male prison

column4: MALE PRISONERS CARRIED COAL INTO THE FEMALE PRISON WHEN THEY SAW AND COULD SPEAK OR PASS LETTERS TO THE FEMALE PRISONERS
column5: male prisoners carried coal into the female prison when they saw and could speak or pass letters to the female prisoners

column4: AND THE MEN COULD ALSO AT ANY TIME GO FOR TEA COFFEE AND SUGAR TO MRS BROWN'S SHOP WHICH WAS INSIDE THE FEMALE GATE
column5: and the men could also at any time go for tea coffee and sugar to mrs brown's shop which was inside the female gate

column4: IN THE BAILDOCK WHERE MOST IMPROPER GENERAL ASSOCIATION WAS PERMITTED THE FEMALE PRISONERS WERE OFTEN ALTOGETHER IN THE CHARGE OF MALE TURNKEYS
column5: in the baildock where most improper general association was permitted the female prisoners were often altogether in the charge of male turnkeys

column4: THE GOVERNOR WAS ALSO PERSONALLY RESPONSIBLE FOR GROSS CONTRAVENTION OF THIS RULE OF SEPARATION
column5: the governor was also personally responsible for gross contravention of this rule of separation

column4: AND WAS IN THE HABIT OF DRAWING FREQUENTLY UPON THE FEMALE PRISON FOR PRISONERS TO ACT AS DOMESTIC SERVANTS IN HIS OWN PRIVATE DWELLING
column5: and was in the habit of drawing frequently upon the female prison for prisoners to act as domestic servants in his own private dwelling

column4: SOME MEMBER OF THE LADIES' ASSOCIATION OBSERVED AND COMMENTED UPON THE FACT THAT A YOUNG ROSYCHEEKED GIRL HAD BEEN KEPT BY THE GOVERNOR FROM TRANSPORTATION
column5: some member of the ladies' association observed and commented upon the fact that a young rosycheeked girl had been kept by the governor from transportation

column4: WHILE OLDER WOMEN IN INFIRM HEALTH WERE SENT ACROSS THE SEAS
column5: while older women in infirm health were sent across the seas

column4: HIS EXCUSE WAS THAT HE HAD GIVEN THE GIRL HIS PROMISE THAT SHE SHOULD NOT GO AN ASSUMPTION OF PREROGATIVE WHICH BY NO MEANS RESTED WITH HIM
column5: his excuse was that he had given the girl his promise that she should not go an assumption of prerogative which by no means rested with him

column4: BUT HE AFTERWARDS ADMITTED THAT THE GIRL HAD BEEN RECOMMENDED TO HIM BY THE PRINCIPAL TURNKEY WHO KNEW SOMETHING OF HER FRIENDS
column5: but he afterwards admitted that the girl had been recommended to him by the principal turnkey who knew something of her friends

column4: THIS WOMAN WAS REALLY HIS SERVANT EMPLOYED TO HELP IN CLEANING AND TAKEN ON WHENEVER THERE WAS EXTRA WORK TO BE DONE
column5: this woman was really his servant employed to help in cleaning and taken on whenever there was extra work to be done

column4: THE GOVERNOR HAD A GREAT DISLIKE HE SAID TO SEEING STRANGERS IN HIS HOUSE
column5: the governor had a great dislike he said to seeing strangers in his house

column4: THIS GIRL HAD BEEN FIRST ENGAGED ON ACCOUNT OF THE EXTRA WORK ENTAILED BY CERTAIN PRISONERS
column5: this girl had been first engaged on account of the extra work entailed by certain prisoners

column4: COMMITTED BY THE HOUSE OF COMMONS WHO HAD BEEN LODGED IN THE GOVERNOR'S OWN HOUSE
column5: committed by the house of commons who had been lodged in the governor's own house

column4: THE HOUSE AT THIS TIME WAS FULL OF MEN AND VISITORS WAITERS CAME IN FROM THE TAVERNS WITH MEALS
column5: the house at this time was full of men and visitors waiters came in from the taverns with meals

column4: SOME OF THE PRISONERS HAD THEIR VALETS AND ALL THESE WERE CONSTANTLY IN AND OUT OF THE KITCHEN WHERE THIS FEMALE PRISONER WAS EMPLOYED
column5: some of the prisoners had their valets and all these were constantly in and out of the kitchen where this female prisoner was employed

column4: THERE WAS REVELING AND ROISTERING AS USUAL WITH HIGH LIFE BELOWSTAIRS
column5: there was reveling and roistering as usual with high life belowstairs

column4: THE GOVERNOR SENT DOWN WINE ON FESTIVE OCCASIONS OF WHICH NO DOUBT THE PRISONER HOUSEMAID HAD HER SHARE
column5: the governor sent down wine on festive occasions of which no doubt the prisoner housemaid had her share

column4: THE CHRONICLES OF NEWGATE VOLUME TWO BY ARTHUR GRIFFITHS SECTION TEN THE FIRST REPORT OF THE INSPECTOR OF PRISONS
column5: the chronicles of newgate volume two by arthur griffiths section ten the first report of the inspector of prisons

column4: EIGHTEEN YEARS HAD ELAPSED SINCE THE FORMATION OF THE LADIES' ASSOCIATION
column5: eighteen years had elapsed since the formation of the ladies' association

column4: AND MRS FRY WITH HER COLLEAGUES STILL LABORED ASSIDUOUSLY IN NEWGATE DEVOTING THEMSELVES MAINLY TO THE FEMALE PRISON
column5: and mrs fry with her colleagues still labored assiduously in newgate devoting themselves mainly to the female prison

column4: ALTHOUGH THEIR MINISTRATIONS WERE OCCASIONALLY EXTENDED TO THE MALE SIDE
column5: although their ministrations were occasionally extended to the male side

column4: THE INSPECTORS PAID TRIBUTE TO THE EXCELLENCE OF THE MOTIVES OF THESE PHILANTHROPIC LADIES AND RECOGNIZED THE GOOD THEY DID
column5: the inspectors paid tribute to the excellence of the motives of these philanthropic ladies and recognized the good they did

column4: THEY HAD INTRODUCED MUCH ORDER AND CLEANLINESS
column5: they had introduced much order and cleanliness

column4: HAD PROVIDED WORK FOR THOSE WHO HAD HITHERTO PASSED THEIR TIME IN TOTAL IDLENESS AND HAD MADE THE TREATMENT OF FEMALE TRANSPORTS ON THE WAY TO NEW SOUTH WALES
column5: had provided work for those who had hitherto passed their time in total idleness and had made the treatment of female transports on the way to new south wales

column4: THEIR ESPECIAL CARE
column5: their especial care

column4: THEY HAD TRIED MOREOVER
column5: they had tried moreover

column4: BY THEIR PRESENCE AND THEIR PIOUS DISINTERESTED EFFORTS TO RESTRAIN THE DISSOLUTE MANNERS AND VICIOUS LANGUAGE OF THE UNHAPPY AND DEPRAVED INMATES
column5: by their presence and their pious disinterested efforts to restrain the dissolute manners and vicious language of the unhappy and depraved inmates

column4: BUT IT WAS ALREADY PLAIN THAT THEY CONSTITUTED AN INDEPENDENT AUTHORITY WITHIN THE JAILS THEY WERE FREQUENTLY IN CONFLICT WITH THE CHAPLAIN
column5: but it was already plain that they constituted an independent authority within the jails they were frequently in conflict with the chaplain

column4: WHO NOT STRANGELY RESENTED THE ORDERS ISSUED BY THE ALDERMEN
column5: who not strangely resented the orders issued by the aldermen

column4: THAT WOMEN SHOULD BE FREQUENTLY KEPT FROM CHAPEL IN ORDER THAT THEY MIGHT ATTEND THE LADIES' LECTURES AND EXHORTATIONS
column5: that women should be frequently kept from chapel in order that they might attend the ladies' lectures and exhortations

column4: THE ADMISSION OF A CROWD OF VISITORS TO ASSIST IN THESE LAY SERVICES HAS ALREADY BEEN REMARKED UPON AS THE INSPECTORS POINTED OUT
column5: the admission of a crowd of visitors to assist in these lay services has already been remarked upon as the inspectors pointed out

column4: IT HAD THE BAD EFFECT OF DISTRACTING ATTENTION
column5: it had the bad effect of distracting attention

column4: IT TENDED TO DISSIPATE REFLECTION DIMINISH THE GLOOM OF THE PRISON AND MITIGATE THE PUNISHMENT WHICH THE LAW HAS SENTENCED THE PRISONER TO UNDERGO
column5: it tended to dissipate reflection diminish the gloom of the prison and mitigate the punishment which the law has sentenced the prisoner to undergo

column4: IT IS TO BE FEARED TOO THAT ALTHOUGH THE SURFACE WAS THUS WHITEWASHED AND DECOROUS MUCH THAT WAS VICIOUS STILL FESTERED AND RANKLED BENEATH
column5: it is to be feared too that although the surface was thus whitewashed and decorous much that was vicious still festered and rankled beneath

column4: AND THAT WHEN THE RESTRAINING INFLUENCES OF THE LADIES WERE ABSENT THE FEMALE PRISONERS RELAPSED INTO IMMORAL AND UNCLEANLY DISCOURSE
column5: and that when the restraining influences of the ladies were absent the female prisoners relapsed into immoral and uncleanly discourse

column4: EVEN IN THE DAYTIME WHEN SUPERVISION WAS WITHDRAWN THE LANGUAGE USED TO BE DREADFUL SAYS ONE OF THE WOMEN WHEN UNDER EXAMINATION
column5: even in the daytime when supervision was withdrawn the language used to be dreadful says one of the women when under examination

column4: SWEARING AND TALKING OF WHAT CRIMES THEY HAD COMMITTED AND HOW THEY HAD DONE IT ANOTHER WITNESS DECLARED SHE HAD HEARD THE MOST SHOCKING LANGUAGE IN THE YARD SHE SAID
column5: swearing and talking of what crimes they had committed and how they had done it another witness declared she had heard the most shocking language in the yard she said

column4: SHE HAD NEVER WITNESSED SUCH SCENES BEFORE AND HOPES SHE NEVER SHALL AGAIN  IT WAS DREADFUL
column5: she had never witnessed such scenes before and hopes she never shall again  it was dreadful

column4: AFTER LOCKINGUP TIME WHICH VARIED AS ON THE MALE SIDE ACCORDING TO THE DAYLIGHT THE SCENES WERE OFTEN RIOTOUS AND DISGRACEFUL
column5: after lockingup time which varied as on the male side according to the daylight the scenes were often riotous and disgraceful

column4: THE POOR WHO COULD AFFORD NO LUXURIES WENT TO BED EARLY BUT WERE KEPT AWAKE BY THE REVELRIES OF THE RICH
column5: the poor who could afford no luxuries went to bed early but were kept awake by the revelries of the rich

column4: WHO SUPPED ROYALLY ON THE SUPPLIES PROVIDED FROM OUTSIDE AND KEPT IT UP TILL TEN OR ELEVEN O'CLOCK
column5: who supped royally on the supplies provided from outside and kept it up till ten or eleven o'clock

column4: THERE WERE FREQUENT QUARRELS AND FIGHTS SHOES AND OTHER MISSILES WERE FREELY BANDIED ABOUT
column5: there were frequent quarrels and fights shoes and other missiles were freely bandied about

column4: AND WITH ALL THIS THE MOST DREADFUL OATHS THE WORST LANGUAGE TOO BAD TO BE REPEATED WERE MADE USE OF EVERY NIGHT
column5: and with all this the most dreadful oaths the worst language too bad to be repeated were made use of every night

column4: BAD AS WERE THE VARIOUS PARTS OF THE JAIL ALREADY DEALT WITH
column5: bad as were the various parts of the jail already dealt with

column4: THERE STILL REMAINED ONE WHERE THE GENERAL CALLOUS INDIFFERENCE AND MISMANAGEMENT CULMINATED IN CRUEL CULPABLE NEGLECT
column5: there still remained one where the general callous indifference and mismanagement culminated in cruel culpable neglect

column4: THE CONDITION OF THE CAPITALLYCONVICTED PRISONERS AFTER SENTENCE WAS STILL VERY DISGRACEFUL THE SIDE THEY OCCUPIED STILL KNOWN AS THE PRESSYARD
column5: the condition of the capitallyconvicted prisoners after sentence was still very disgraceful the side they occupied still known as the pressyard

column4: CONSISTED OF TWO DOZEN ROOMS AND FIFTEEN CELLS IN THESE VARIOUS CHAMBERS UNTIL JUST BEFORE THE INSPECTORS MADE THEIR REPORT
column5: consisted of two dozen rooms and fifteen cells in these various chambers until just before the inspectors made their report

column4: ALL CLASSES OF THE CONDEMNED THOSE CERTAIN TO SUFFER AND THE LARGER NUMBER WHO WERE NEARLY CERTAIN OF A REPRIEVE
column5: all classes of the condemned those certain to suffer and the larger number who were nearly certain of a reprieve

column4: WERE JUMBLED UP TOGETHER HIGGLEDYPIGGLEDY THE OLD AND THE YOUNG THE MURDERER AND THE CHILD WHO HAD BROKEN INTO A DWELLING
column5: were jumbled up together higgledypiggledy the old and the young the murderer and the child who had broken into a dwelling

column4: ALL PRIVACY WAS IMPOSSIBLE UNDER THE CIRCUMSTANCES
column5: all privacy was impossible under the circumstances

column4: AT TIMES THE NUMBERS CONGREGATED TOGETHER WERE VERY GREAT AS MANY AS FIFTY AND SIXTY EVEN MORE WERE CROWDED INDISCRIMINATELY INTO THE PRESSYARD
column5: at times the numbers congregated together were very great as many as fifty and sixty even more were crowded indiscriminately into the pressyard

column4: THE BETTERDISPOSED COMPLAINED BITTERLY OF WHAT THEY HAD TO ENDURE
column5: the betterdisposed complained bitterly of what they had to endure

column4: ONE MAN DECLARED THAT THE LANGUAGE OF THE CONDEMNED ROOMS WAS DISGUSTING THAT HE WAS DYING A DEATH EVERY DAY IN BEING COMPELLED TO ASSOCIATE WITH SUCH CHARACTERS
column5: one man declared that the language of the condemned rooms was disgusting that he was dying a death every day in being compelled to associate with such characters

column4: IN THE MIDST OF THE NOISY AND BLASPHEMOUS TALK NO ONE COULD PURSUE HIS MEDITATIONS ANY WHO TRIED TO PRAY BECAME THE SPORT AND RIDICULE OF HIS BRUTAL FELLOWS
column5: in the midst of the noisy and blasphemous talk no one could pursue his meditations any who tried to pray became the sport and ridicule of his brutal fellows

column4: OWING TO THE REPEATED ENTREATIES OF THE CRIMINALS WHO COULD HARDLY HOPE TO ESCAPE THE GALLOWS SOME SHOW OF CLASSIFICATION WAS CARRIED OUT
column5: owing to the repeated entreaties of the criminals who could hardly hope to escape the gallows some show of classification was carried out

column4: AND WHEN THE INSPECTORS VISITED NEWGATE THEY FOUND THE THREE CERTAIN TO DIE IN A DAYROOM BY THEMSELVES
column5: and when the inspectors visited newgate they found the three certain to die in a dayroom by themselves

column4: IN A SECOND ROOM WERE FOURTEEN MORE WHO HAD EVERY HOPE OF A REPRIEVE
column5: in a second room were fourteen more who had every hope of a reprieve

column4: THE WHOLE OF THESE SEVENTEEN HAD HOWEVER A COMMON AIRINGYARD AND TOOK THEIR EXERCISE THERE AT THE SAME TIME
column5: the whole of these seventeen had however a common airingyard and took their exercise there at the same time

column4: SO THAT MEN IN THE MOST AWFUL SITUATION DAILY EXPECTING TO BE HANGED
column5: so that men in the most awful situation daily expecting to be hanged

column4: WERE ASSOCIATED CONTINUALLY WITH A NUMBER OF THOSE WHO COULD LOOK WITH CERTAINTY ON A MITIGATION OF PUNISHMENT
column5: were associated continually with a number of those who could look with certainty on a mitigation of punishment

column4: THE LATTER LIGHTHEARTED AND RECKLESS CONDUCTED THEMSELVES IN THE MOST UNSEEMLY FASHION AND WITH AS MUCH INDIFFERENCE AS THE INMATES OF THE OTHER PARTS OF THE PRISON
column5: the latter lighthearted and reckless conducted themselves in the most unseemly fashion and with as much indifference as the inmates of the other parts of the prison

column4: THEY AMUSED THEMSELVES AFTER THEIR OWN FASHION PLAYED ALL DAY LONG AT BLINDMAN'SBUFF AND LEAPFROG OR BEAT EACH OTHER WITH A KNOTTED HANDKERCHIEF
column5: they amused themselves after their own fashion played all day long at blindman'sbuff and leapfrog or beat each other with a knotted handkerchief

column4: LAUGHING AND UPROARIOUS UTTERLY UNMINDFUL OF THE COMPANIONSHIP OF MEN UPON WHOM LAY THE SHADOW OF AN IMPENDING SHAMEFUL DEATH
column5: laughing and uproarious utterly unmindful of the companionship of men upon whom lay the shadow of an impending shameful death

column4: MEN WHOSE CASES WERE DANGEROUS AND THOSE MOST SERIOUSLY INCLINED COMPLAINED OF THESE ANNOYANCES
column5: men whose cases were dangerous and those most seriously inclined complained of these annoyances

column4: SO SUBVERSIVE OF MEDITATION SO DISTURBING TO THE THOUGHTS
column5: so subversive of meditation so disturbing to the thoughts

column4: THEY SUFFERED SICKENING ANXIETY AND WISHED TO BE LOCKED UP ALONE THIS INDISCRIMINATE ASSOCIATION LASTED FOR MONTHS
column5: they suffered sickening anxiety and wished to be locked up alone this indiscriminate association lasted for months

column4: DURING THE WHOLE OF WHICH TIME THE UNHAPPY CONVICTS WHO HAD BUT LITTLE HOPE OF COMMUTATION WERE EXPOSED TO THE MOCKERY OF THEIR RECKLESS ASSOCIATES
column5: during the whole of which time the unhappy convicts who had but little hope of commutation were exposed to the mockery of their reckless associates

column4: THE BRUTAL CALLOUSNESS OF THE BULK OF THE INMATES OF THE PRESSYARD MAY BE GATHERED FROM THE PRISON PUNISHMENTBOOK WHICH FREQUENTLY RECORDED SUCH ENTRIES AS THE FOLLOWING
column5: the brutal callousness of the bulk of the inmates of the pressyard may be gathered from the prison punishmentbook which frequently recorded such entries as the following

column4: BENJAMIN VINES AND DANIEL WARD PUT IN IRONS FOR TWO DAYS FOR BREAKING THE WINDOWS OF THE DAY ROOM IN THE CONDEMNED CELLS
column5: benjamin vines and daniel ward put in irons for two days for breaking the windows of the day room in the condemned cells

column4: JOSEPH COLEMAN PUT IN IRONS FOR THREE DAYS FOR STRIKING ONE OF THE PRISONERS IN THE SAME PLACE
column5: joseph coleman put in irons for three days for striking one of the prisoners in the same place

column4: THERE WERE DISPUTES AND QUARRELS CONSTANTLY AMONG THESE DOOMED MEN IT WAS A WORD AND BLOW AN ARGUMENT CLENCHED ALWAYS WITH A FIGHT
column5: there were disputes and quarrels constantly among these doomed men it was a word and blow an argument clenched always with a fight

column4: THE MORE PEACEABLY DISPOSED FOUND SOME OCCUPATION IN MAKING NEWGATE TOKENS
column5: the more peaceably disposed found some occupation in making newgate tokens

column4: LEADEN HEARTS AND GRINDING THE IMPRESSIONS OFF PENNYPIECES THEN PRICKING FIGURES OR WORDS ON THEM TO GIVE TO THEIR FRIENDS AS MEMORIALS
column5: leaden hearts and grinding the impressions off pennypieces then pricking figures or words on them to give to their friends as memorials

column4: TURNKEYS OCCASIONALLY VISITED THE PRESSYARD BUT ITS OCCUPANTS WERE UNDER LITTLE OR NO CONTROL
column5: turnkeys occasionally visited the pressyard but its occupants were under little or no control

column4: THE CHAPLAIN WHO MIGHT HAVE BEEN EXPECTED TO MAKE THESE MEN HIS PECULIAR CARE AND WHO AT ONE TIME HAD VISITED THEM FREQUENTLY OFTEN SEVERAL TIMES A WEEK
column5: the chaplain who might have been expected to make these men his peculiar care and who at one time had visited them frequently often several times a week

column4: HAD RELAXED HIS EFFORTS BECAUSE ACCORDING TO HIS OWN ACCOUNT HE WAS SO FREQUENTLY STOPPED IN THE PERFORMANCE OF HIS DUTIES
column5: had relaxed his efforts because according to his own account he was so frequently stopped in the performance of his duties

column4: IN HIS EVIDENCE BEFORE THE INSPECTORS HE DECLARED THAT FOR YEARS HE GAVE HIS WHOLE TIME TO HIS DUTIES FROM AN EARLY HOUR IN THE MORNING TILL LATE IN THE AFTERNOON
column5: in his evidence before the inspectors he declared that for years he gave his whole time to his duties from an early hour in the morning till late in the afternoon

column4: HE LEFT OFF BECAUSE HE WAS SO MUCH INTERFERED WITH AND LAUGHED AT AND FROM SEEING THAT NO SUCCESS ATTENDED HIS EFFORTS OWING TO THE EVILS ARISING FROM ASSOCIATION
column5: he left off because he was so much interfered with and laughed at and from seeing that no success attended his efforts owing to the evils arising from association

column4: LATTERLY HIS MINISTRATIONS TO THE CONDEMNED HAD BEEN RESTRICTED TO A VISIT ON SUNDAY AFTERNOONS AND OCCASIONALLY ABOUT ONCE A FORTNIGHT ON A WEEKDAY
column5: latterly his ministrations to the condemned had been restricted to a visit on sunday afternoons and occasionally about once a fortnight on a weekday

column4: IT IS ONLY FAIR TO MR COTTON TO ADD THAT ACCORDING TO HIS OWN JOURNAL HE WAS UNREMITTING IN HIS ATTENTIONS TO CONVICTS WHO WERE ACTUALLY CAST FOR DEATH
column5: it is only fair to mr cotton to add that according to his own journal he was unremitting in his attentions to convicts who were actually cast for death

column4: AND THE DAY OF WHOSE EXECUTION WAS FIXED HE HAD NO DOUBT A DIFFICULT MISSION TO DISCHARGE
column5: and the day of whose execution was fixed he had no doubt a difficult mission to discharge

column4: ON THE ONE HAND THE LADIES' ASSOCIATION SUPPORTED AND ENCOURAGED BY PUBLIC APPROVAL TRENCHED UPON HIS PECULIAR PROVINCE
column5: on the one hand the ladies' association supported and encouraged by public approval trenched upon his peculiar province

column4: ON THE OTHER THE GOVERNOR OF THE JAIL SNEERED AT HIS ZEAL
column5: on the other the governor of the jail sneered at his zeal

column4: STIGMATIZED HIS OFTEN MOST JUST STRICTURES ON ABUSES AS A BUNDLE OF NONSENSE AND THE ALDERMEN WHEN HE APPEALED TO THEM FOR PROTECTION AND COUNTENANCE
column5: stigmatized his often most just strictures on abuses as a bundle of nonsense and the aldermen when he appealed to them for protection and countenance

column4: GENERALLY SIDED WITH HIS OPPONENTS NEVERTHELESS THE INSPECTORS SUMMED UP AGAINST HIM
column5: generally sided with his opponents nevertheless the inspectors summed up against him

column4: WHILE ADMITTING THAT HE HAD HAD MANY DIFFICULTIES TO CONTEND WITH
column5: while admitting that he had had many difficulties to contend with

column4: AND THAT HE HAD AGAIN AND AGAIN PROTESTED AGAINST THE OBSTACLES THROWN IN HIS WAY THE INSPECTORS CANNOT FORBEAR EXPRESSING THEIR OPINION THAT HE MIGHT HAVE SHOWN GREATER PERSEVERANCE
column5: and that he had again and again protested against the obstacles thrown in his way the inspectors cannot forbear expressing their opinion that he might have shown greater perseverance

column4: IN THE FACE OF IMPEDIMENTS CONFESSEDLY DISCOURAGING
column5: in the face of impediments confessedly discouraging

column4: AS REGARDS THE PRIVATE TEACHING OF PRISONERS AND THEY WENT ON TO SAY THAT A RESOLVED ADHERENCE IN SPITE OF DISCOURAGEMENTS THE MOST DISHEARTENING
column5: as regards the private teaching of prisoners and they went on to say that a resolved adherence in spite of discouragements the most disheartening

column4: TO THAT LINE OF CONDUCT WHICH HIS DUTY IMPOSED ON HIM
column5: to that line of conduct which his duty imposed on him

column4: WOULD IT IS PROBABLE HAVE EVENTUALLY OVERCOME THE RELUCTANCE OF SOME OF THE PRISONERS AT LEAST AND WOULD HAVE POSSESSED SO MUCH MORAL DIGNITY
column5: would it is probable have eventually overcome the reluctance of some of the prisoners at least and would have possessed so much moral dignity

column4: AS EFFECTUALLY TO REBUKE AND ABASH THE PROFANE SPIRIT OF THE MORE INSOLENT AND DARING OF THE CRIMINALS
column5: as effectually to rebuke and abash the profane spirit of the more insolent and daring of the criminals

column4: THE LAX DISCIPLINE MAINTAINED IN NEWGATE WAS STILL FURTHER DETERIORATED BY THE PRESENCE OF TWO OTHER CLASSES OF PRISONERS WHO OUGHT NEVER TO HAVE BEEN INMATES OF SUCH A JAIL
column5: the lax discipline maintained in newgate was still further deteriorated by the presence of two other classes of prisoners who ought never to have been inmates of such a jail

column4: ONE OF THESE WERE THE CRIMINAL LUNATICS WHO WERE AT THIS TIME AND FOR LONG PREVIOUS CONTINUOUSLY IMPRISONED THERE
column5: one of these were the criminal lunatics who were at this time and for long previous continuously imprisoned there

column4: AS THE LAW STOOD SINCE THE PASSING OF THE NINTH GEORGE THE FOURTH C FORTY ANY TWO JUSTICES MIGHT REMOVE A PRISONER FOUND TO BE INSANE EITHER ON COMMITMENT
column5: as the law stood since the passing of the ninth george the fourth c forty any two justices might remove a prisoner found to be insane either on commitment

column4: OR ARRAIGNMENT TO AN ASYLUM AND THE SECRETARY OF STATE HAD THE SAME POWER AS REGARDS ANY WHO BECAME INSANE WHILE UNDERGOING SENTENCE
column5: or arraignment to an asylum and the secretary of state had the same power as regards any who became insane while undergoing sentence

column4: THESE POWERS WERE NOT INVARIABLY PUT IN FORCE AND THERE WERE IN CONSEQUENCE MANY UNHAPPY LUNATICS IN NEWGATE AND OTHER JAILS
column5: these powers were not invariably put in force and there were in consequence many unhappy lunatics in newgate and other jails

column4: WHOSE PROPER PLACE WAS THE ASYLUM
column5: whose proper place was the asylum

column4: AT THE TIME THE LORDS' COMMITTEE SAT THERE WERE EIGHT THUS RETAINED IN NEWGATE AND A RETURN IN THE APPENDIX OF THE LORDS' REPORT
column5: at the time the lords' committee sat there were eight thus retained in newgate and a return in the appendix of the lords' report

column4: GIVES A TOTAL OF THIRTYNINE LUNATICS CONFINED IN VARIOUS JAILS MANY OF THEM GUILTY OF MURDER AND OTHER SERIOUS CRIMES
column5: gives a total of thirtynine lunatics confined in various jails many of them guilty of murder and other serious crimes

column4: THE INSPECTORS IN THE FOLLOWING YEAR ON EXAMINING THE FACTS FOUND THAT SOME OF THESE POOR CREATURES HAD BEEN IN CONFINEMENT FOR LONG PERIODS
column5: the inspectors in the following year on examining the facts found that some of these poor creatures had been in confinement for long periods

column4: AT NEWGATE AND YORK CASTLE AS LONG AS FIVE YEARS AT ILCHESTER AND MORPETH FOR SEVEN YEARS AT WARWICK FOR EIGHT YEARS
column5: at newgate and york castle as long as five years at ilchester and morpeth for seven years at warwick for eight years

column4: AT BUCKINGHAM AND HEREFORD FOR ELEVEN YEARS
column5: at buckingham and hereford for eleven years

column4: AT APPLEBY FOR THIRTEEN YEARS AT ANGLESEA FOR FIFTEEN YEARS AT EXETER FOR SIXTEEN YEARS AND AT PEMBROKE
column5: at appleby for thirteen years at anglesea for fifteen years at exeter for sixteen years and at pembroke

column4: FOR NOT LESS A PERIOD THAN TWENTYFOUR YEARS
column5: for not less a period than twentyfour years

column4: IT WAS MANIFESTLY WRONG THAT SUCH PERSONS VISITED BY THE MOST AWFUL OF CALAMITIES SHOULD BE DETAINED IN A COMMON PRISON
column5: it was manifestly wrong that such persons visited by the most awful of calamities should be detained in a common prison

column4: NOT ONLY DID THEIR PRESENCE TEND GREATLY TO INTERFERE WITH THE DISCIPLINE OF THE PRISON BUT THEIR CONDITION WAS DEPLORABLE IN THE EXTREME
column5: not only did their presence tend greatly to interfere with the discipline of the prison but their condition was deplorable in the extreme

column4: THE LUNATIC BECAME THE SPORT OF THE IDLE AND THE DEPRAVED HIS CURE WAS OUT OF THE QUESTION
column5: the lunatic became the sport of the idle and the depraved his cure was out of the question

column4: HE WAS PLACED IN A SITUATION BEYOND ALL OTHERS CALCULATED TO CONFIRM HIS MALADY AND PROLONG HIS SUFFERINGS
column5: he was placed in a situation beyond all others calculated to confirm his malady and prolong his sufferings

column4: THE MATTER WAS STILL FURTHER COMPLICATED AT NEWGATE BY THE PRESENCE WITHIN THE WALLS OF SHAM LUNATICS SOME OF THOSE INCLUDED IN THE CATEGORY
column5: the matter was still further complicated at newgate by the presence within the walls of sham lunatics some of those included in the category

column4: HAD ACTUALLY BEEN RETURNED AS SANE FROM THE ASYLUM TO WHICH THEY HAD BEEN SENT AND THERE WAS ALWAYS SOME UNCERTAINTY AS TO WHO WAS MAD AND WHO NOT
column5: had actually been returned as sane from the asylum to which they had been sent and there was always some uncertainty as to who was mad and who not

column4: PRISONERS INDEED WERE KNOWN TO BOAST THAT THEY HAD SAVED THEIR NECKS BY FEIGNING INSANITY
column5: prisoners indeed were known to boast that they had saved their necks by feigning insanity

column4: IT WAS HIGH TIME THAT THE UNSATISFACTORY STATE OF THE LAW AS REGARDS THE TREATMENT OF CRIMINAL LUNATICS SHOULD BE REMEDIED
column5: it was high time that the unsatisfactory state of the law as regards the treatment of criminal lunatics should be remedied

column4: AND NOT THE LEAST OF THE GOOD SERVICES RENDERED BY THE NEW INSPECTORS WAS THEIR INQUIRY INTO THE STATUS OF THESE UNFORTUNATE PEOPLE AND THEIR RECOMMENDATION TO IMPROVE IT
column5: and not the least of the good services rendered by the new inspectors was their inquiry into the status of these unfortunate people and their recommendation to improve it

column5: the other inmates of the prison of an exceptional character and exempted from the regular discipline such as it was

column4: WERE THE TEN PERSONS COMMITTED TO NEWGATE BY THE HOUSE OF COMMONS IN EIGHTEEN THIRTYFIVE
column5: were the ten persons committed to newgate by the house of commons in eighteen thirtyfive

column5: these were the gentlemen concerned in the bribery case at ipswich in eighteen thirtyfive

column4: WHEN A PETITION WAS PRESENTED AGAINST THE RETURN OF MESSRS ADAM DUNDAS AND FITZROY KELLY VARIOUS WITNESSES INCLUDING MESSRS J B DASENT
column5: when a petition was presented against the return of messrs adam dundas and fitzroy kelly various witnesses including messrs j b dasent

column4: PILGRIM BOND AND CLAMP HAD REFUSED TO GIVE EVIDENCE BEFORE THE HOUSE OF COMMONS' COMMITTEE A SPEAKER'S WARRANT WAS ISSUED FOR THEIR ARREST WHEN THEY ABSCONDED
column5: pilgrim bond and clamp had refused to give evidence before the house of commons' committee a speaker's warrant was issued for their arrest when they absconded

column4: MR J E SPARROW AND MR CLIPPERTON
column5: mr j e sparrow and mr clipperton

column4: THE PARLIAMENTARY AGENTS OF THE MEMBERS WHOSE ELECTION WAS IMPUGNED WERE IMPLICATED IN AIDING AND ABETTING THE OTHERS TO ABSCOND AND A MR O'MALLY
column5: the parliamentary agents of the members whose election was impugned were implicated in aiding and abetting the others to abscond and a mr o'mally

column4: COUNSEL FOR THE TWO MP'S WAS ALSO CONCERNED
column5: counsel for the two mp's was also concerned

column4: PILGRIM AND DASENT WERE CAUGHT AND GIVEN INTO THE CUSTODY OF THE SERGEANTATARMS AND THE REST WERE EITHER ARRESTED OR THEY SURRENDERED
column5: pilgrim and dasent were caught and given into the custody of the sergeantatarms and the rest were either arrested or they surrendered

column4: A RESOLUTION AT ONCE PASSED THE HOUSE WITHOUT DIVISION TO COMMIT THE WHOLE TO NEWGATE WHERE THEY REMAINED FOR VARIOUS TERMS
column5: a resolution at once passed the house without division to commit the whole to newgate where they remained for various terms

column4: DASENT AND PILGRIM WERE RELEASED IN TEN DAYS ON MAKING DUE SUBMISSION
column5: dasent and pilgrim were released in ten days on making due submission

column4: O'MALLY SENT IN A MEDICAL CERTIFICATE DECLARING THAT THE IMPRISONMENT WAS ENDANGERING HIS LIFE AND AFTER SOME QUESTION HE WAS ALSO RELEASED
column5: o'mally sent in a medical certificate declaring that the imprisonment was endangering his life and after some question he was also released

column4: THE REST WERE DETAINED FOR MORE THAN A MONTH IT BEING CONSIDERED THAT THEY WERE THE MOST GUILTY AS BEING EITHER PROFESSIONAL AGENTS WHO ADVISED THE OTHERS TO ABSCOND
column5: the rest were detained for more than a month it being considered that they were the most guilty as being either professional agents who advised the others to abscond

column4: OR WITNESSES WHO DID NOT VOLUNTARILY COME FORWARD WHEN THE CHANCE WAS GIVEN THEM
column5: or witnesses who did not voluntarily come forward when the chance was given them

column4: MANY OF THE OLD CUSTOMS ONCE PREVALENT IN THE STATE SIDE SO PROPERLY CONDEMNED AND ABOLISHED
column5: many of the old customs once prevalent in the state side so properly condemned and abolished

column4: WERE REVIVED FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THESE GENTLEMEN WHOSE INCARCERATION WAS THUS RENDERED AS LITTLE LIKE IMPRISONMENT AS POSSIBLE
column5: were revived for the convenience of these gentlemen whose incarceration was thus rendered as little like imprisonment as possible

column4: A CERTAIN NUMBER WHO COULD AFFORD THE HIGH RATE OF A GUINEA PER DIEM FIXED BY THE UNDER SHERIFF WERE LODGED IN THE GOVERNOR'S HOUSE
column5: a certain number who could afford the high rate of a guinea per diem fixed by the under sheriff were lodged in the governor's house

column4: SLEPT THERE AND HAD THEIR MEALS PROVIDED FOR THEM FROM THE SESSIONS HOUSE OR LONDON COFFEEHOUSE
column5: slept there and had their meals provided for them from the sessions house or london coffeehouse

column4: A FEW OTHERS WHO COULD NOT AFFORD A PAYMENT OF MORE THAN HALF A GUINEA WERE PERMITTED TO MONOPOLIZE A PART OF THE PRISON INFIRMARY
column5: a few others who could not afford a payment of more than half a guinea were permitted to monopolize a part of the prison infirmary

column4: WHERE THE UPPER WARD WAS EXCLUSIVELY APPROPRIATED TO THEIR USE THEY ALSO HAD THEIR MEALS SENT IN AND WITH THE FOOD WINE ALMOST AD LIBITUM
column5: where the upper ward was exclusively appropriated to their use they also had their meals sent in and with the food wine almost ad libitum

column4: A PRISONER ONE OF THE WARDSMEN WAITED ON THOSE IN THE INFIRMARY THE OCCUPANTS OF THE GOVERNOR'S HOUSE HAD THEIR OWN SERVANTS OR THE GOVERNOR'S
column5: a prisoner one of the wardsmen waited on those in the infirmary the occupants of the governor's house had their own servants or the governor's

column4: AS A RULE VISITORS MANY OF THEM PERSONS OF GOOD POSITION CAME AND WENT ALL DAY LONG AND AS LATE AS NINE AT NIGHT
column5: as a rule visitors many of them persons of good position came and went all day long and as late as nine at night

column4: SOME TO THE INFIRMARY MANY MORE TO THE GOVERNOR'S HOUSE
column5: some to the infirmary many more to the governor's house

column4: THERE WERE NO RESTRAINTS CARDS AND BACKGAMMON WERE PLAYED AND THE TIME PASSED IN FEASTING AND REVELRY
column5: there were no restraints cards and backgammon were played and the time passed in feasting and revelry

column4: EVEN MR COPE ADMITTED THAT THE COMMITTAL OF THIS CLASS OF PRISONERS TO NEWGATE WAS MOST INCONVENIENT
column5: even mr cope admitted that the committal of this class of prisoners to newgate was most inconvenient

column4: AND THE INSPECTORS EXPRESSED THEMSELVES STILL MORE STRONGLY IN REPREHENSION OF THE PRACTICE
column5: and the inspectors expressed themselves still more strongly in reprehension of the practice

column4: THE INFIRMARY AT THIS PARTICULAR PERIOD EPITOMIZED THE CONDITION OF THE JAIL AT LARGE
column5: the infirmary at this particular period epitomized the condition of the jail at large

column4: IT WAS DIVERTED FROM ITS PROPER USES AND AS THE PLACE OF THE GREATEST COMFORT WAS ALLOTTED TO PERSONS WHO SHOULD NOT HAVE BEEN SENT TO NEWGATE AT ALL
column5: it was diverted from its proper uses and as the place of the greatest comfort was allotted to persons who should not have been sent to newgate at all

column4: ALL THE EVILS OF INDISCRIMINATE ASSOCIATION WERE STRONGLY ACCENTUATED BY THE CROWD COLLECTED WITHIN ITS NARROW LIMITS
column5: all the evils of indiscriminate association were strongly accentuated by the crowd collected within its narrow limits

column4: IT MAY EASILY BE IMAGINED SAY THE INSPECTORS IN SPEAKING OF THE PRISON GENERALLY
column5: it may easily be imagined say the inspectors in speaking of the prison generally

column4: ENOUGH HAS PROBABLY BEEN EXTRACTED FROM THIS MOST DAMNATORY REPORT TO GIVE A COMPLETE PICTURE OF THE DISGRACEFUL STATE IN WHICH NEWGATE STILL REMAINED IN EIGHTEEN THIRTYFIVE
column5: enough has probably been extracted from this most damnatory report to give a complete picture of the disgraceful state in which newgate still remained in eighteen thirtyfive

column4: THE INSPECTORS HOWEVER HONESTLY ADMITTED THAT ALTHOUGH THE SITE OF THE PRISON WAS CONVENIENT ITS CONSTRUCTION WAS AS BAD AS BAD COULD BE
column5: the inspectors however honestly admitted that although the site of the prison was convenient its construction was as bad as bad could be

column4: VALUABLE SPACE WAS CUMBERED WITH MANY LONG AND WINDING PASSAGES NUMEROUS STAIRCASES AND UNNECESSARILY THICK AND CUMBROUS INNER WALLS
column5: valuable space was cumbered with many long and winding passages numerous staircases and unnecessarily thick and cumbrous inner walls

column4: THE WARDS WERE IN SOME CASES SPACIOUS BUT THEY WERE ENTIRELY UNSUITED FOR SEPARATION OR THE INSPECTION OF PRISONERS
column5: the wards were in some cases spacious but they were entirely unsuited for separation or the inspection of prisoners

column4: THE YARDS WERE NARROW AND CONFINED MAINLY BECAUSE THE GROUND PLAN WAS RADICALLY VICIOUS THESE WERE EVILS INSEPARABLE FROM THE PLACE
column5: the yards were narrow and confined mainly because the ground plan was radically vicious these were evils inseparable from the place

column4: BUT THERE WERE OTHERS REMEDIABLE UNDER A BETTER SYSTEM OF MANAGEMENT
column5: but there were others remediable under a better system of management

column4: MORE ATTENTION TO VENTILATION WHICH WAS ALTOGETHER NEGLECTED AND INADEQUATE WOULD HAVE SECURED A BETTER ATMOSPHERE FOR THE UNHAPPY INMATES
column5: more attention to ventilation which was altogether neglected and inadequate would have secured a better atmosphere for the unhappy inmates

column4: WHO CONSTANTLY BREATHED AN AIR HEAVY AND WHEN THE WARDS WERE FIRST OPENED IN THE MORNING PARTICULARLY OFFENSIVE
column5: who constantly breathed an air heavy and when the wards were first opened in the morning particularly offensive

column4: AGAIN THE DISCIPLINE COMMONLY DEEMED INSEPARABLE FROM EVERY PLACE OF DURANCE WAS ENTIRELY WANTING
column5: again the discipline commonly deemed inseparable from every place of durance was entirely wanting

column4: THE PRIMARY OBJECT OF COMMITTING A PRISONER TO JAIL AS THE INSPECTORS POINTED OUT WAS TO DETER NOT ONLY THE CRIMINAL HIMSELF BUT OTHERS FROM CRIME
column5: the primary object of committing a prisoner to jail as the inspectors pointed out was to deter not only the criminal himself but others from crime

column4: AND TO DISPOSE HIM BY MEDITATION AND SECLUSION TO RETURN TO AN HONEST LIFE
column5: and to dispose him by meditation and seclusion to return to an honest life

column4: BUT AT NEWGATE THE CONVICTED PRISONER INSTEAD OF PRIVATION AND HARD FARE
column5: but at newgate the convicted prisoner instead of privation and hard fare

column4: THESE PUNGENT AND WELLGROUNDED STRICTURES APPLIED WITH STILL GREATER FORCE TO THE UNCONVICTED PRISONER THE MAN WHO CAME TO THE PRISON INNOCENT AND STILL UNCONTAMINATED
column5: these pungent and wellgrounded strictures applied with still greater force to the unconvicted prisoner the man who came to the prison innocent and still uncontaminated

column4: TO BE SUBJECTED TO THE SAME BANEFUL INFLUENCES AND TO SUFFER THE SAME MORAL DETERIORATION WHETHER ULTIMATELY CONVICTED OR SET FREE
column5: to be subjected to the same baneful influences and to suffer the same moral deterioration whether ultimately convicted or set free

column4: THE WHOLE SYSTEM OR MORE CORRECTLY THE WANT OF SYSTEM WAS BANEFUL AND PERNICIOUS TO THE LAST DEGREE
column5: the whole system or more correctly the want of system was baneful and pernicious to the last degree

column4: THE EVILS OF SUCH ASSOCIATION WERE AGGRAVATED BY THE UNBROKEN IDLENESS ONE EVIL INFLAMED THE OTHER REFORMATION
column5: the evils of such association were aggravated by the unbroken idleness one evil inflamed the other reformation

column4: OR ANY KIND OF MORAL IMPROVEMENT WAS IMPOSSIBLE THE PRISONER'S CAREER WAS INEVITABLY DOWNWARD TILL HE STRUCK THE LOWEST DEPTHS
column5: or any kind of moral improvement was impossible the prisoner's career was inevitably downward till he struck the lowest depths

column4: FORCED AND CONSTANT INTERCOURSE WITH THE MOST DEPRAVED INDIVIDUALS OF HIS OWN CLASS
column5: forced and constant intercourse with the most depraved individuals of his own class

column4: THE EMPLOYMENT OF THOSE MEANS AND AGENTS BY WHICH THE LOWEST PASSIONS AND THE MOST VULGAR PROPENSITIES OF MAN ARE PERPETUALLY KEPT IN THE HIGHEST STATE OF EXCITEMENT
column5: the employment of those means and agents by which the lowest passions and the most vulgar propensities of man are perpetually kept in the highest state of excitement

column4: DRINK GAMING OBSCENE AND BLASPHEMOUS LANGUAGE UTTER IDLENESS THE ALMOST UNRESTRICTED ADMISSION OF MONEY AND LUXURIES
column5: drink gaming obscene and blasphemous language utter idleness the almost unrestricted admission of money and luxuries

column4: UNCONTROLLED CONVERSATION WITH VISITORS OF THE VERY WORST DESCRIPTION  PROSTITUTES THIEVES RECEIVERS OF STOLEN GOODS
column5: uncontrolled conversation with visitors of the very worst description  prostitutes thieves receivers of stolen goods

column4: ALL THE TUMULTUOUS AND DIVERSIFIED PASSIONS AND EMOTIONS WHICH CIRCUMSTANCES LIKE THESE MUST NECESSARILY GENERATE
column5: all the tumultuous and diversified passions and emotions which circumstances like these must necessarily generate

column4: FORBID THE FAINTEST SHADOW OF A HOPE THAT IN A SOIL SO UNFAVORABLE FOR MORAL CULTURE
column5: forbid the faintest shadow of a hope that in a soil so unfavorable for moral culture

column4: ANY AWAKENING TRUTH SALUTARY EXHORTATION OR IMPERFECT RESOLUTIONS OF AMENDMENT CAN TAKE ROOT OR GROW
column5: any awakening truth salutary exhortation or imperfect resolutions of amendment can take root or grow

column4: STRONG AS WERE THE FOREGOING REMARKS THE INSPECTORS WOUND UP THEIR REPORT IN STILL MORE TRENCHANT LANGUAGE
column5: strong as were the foregoing remarks the inspectors wound up their report in still more trenchant language

column5: framing a terrible indictment against those responsible for the condition of newgate their words deserve to be quoted in full

column4: WE CANNOT CLOSE THESE REMARKS SAY THE INSPECTORS WITHOUT AN EXPRESSION OF THE PAINFUL FEELINGS WITH WHICH WE SUBMIT TO YOUR LORDSHIP
column5: we cannot close these remarks say the inspectors without an expression of the painful feelings with which we submit to your lordship

column4: THIS PICTURE OF THE EXISTING STATE OF NEWGATE
column5: this picture of the existing state of newgate

column4: THAT IN THIS VAST METROPOLIS THE CENTER OF WEALTH CIVILIZATION AND INFORMATION
column5: that in this vast metropolis the center of wealth civilization and information

column4: DISTINGUISHED AS THE SEAT OF RELIGION WORTH AND PHILANTHROPY
column5: distinguished as the seat of religion worth and philanthropy

column4: WHERE IS TO BE FOUND IN OPERATION EVERY EXPEDIENT BY WHICH IGNORANCE MAY BE SUPERSEDED BY KNOWLEDGE IDLENESS BY INDUSTRY AND SUFFERING BY BENEVOLENCE
column5: where is to be found in operation every expedient by which ignorance may be superseded by knowledge idleness by industry and suffering by benevolence

column4: THAT IN THE METROPOLIS OF THIS HIGHLYFAVORED COUNTRY TO WHICH THE EYES OF OTHER LANDS TURN FOR EXAMPLE A SYSTEM OF PRISON DISCIPLINE SUCH AS THAT ENFORCED IN NEWGATE
column5: that in the metropolis of this highlyfavored country to which the eyes of other lands turn for example a system of prison discipline such as that enforced in newgate

column4: SHOULD BE FOR A NUMBER OF YEARS IN UNDISTURBED OPERATION NOT ONLY IN CONTEMPT OF RELIGION AND HUMANITY
column5: should be for a number of years in undisturbed operation not only in contempt of religion and humanity

column4: BUT IN OPPOSITION TO THE RECORDED DENUNCIATIONS OF AUTHORITY AND IN DEFIANCE OF THE EXPRESS ENACTMENTS OF THE LAW
column5: but in opposition to the recorded denunciations of authority and in defiance of the express enactments of the law

column4: IS INDEED A SUBJECT WHICH CANNOT BUT IMPRESS EVERY CONSIDERATE MIND WITH HUMILIATION AND SORROW
column5: is indeed a subject which cannot but impress every considerate mind with humiliation and sorrow

column4: WE TRUST HOWEVER THAT THE DAY IS AT HAND WHEN THIS STAIN WILL BE REMOVED FROM THE CHARACTER OF THE CITY OF LONDON
column5: we trust however that the day is at hand when this stain will be removed from the character of the city of london

column4: AND WHEN THE FIRST MUNICIPAL AUTHORITY OF OUR LAND WILL BE NO LONGER SUBJECTED TO THE REPROACH OF FOSTERING AN INSTITUTION WHICH OUTRAGES THE RIGHTS AND FEELINGS OF HUMANITY
column5: and when the first municipal authority of our land will be no longer subjected to the reproach of fostering an institution which outrages the rights and feelings of humanity

column4: DEFEATS THE ENDS OF JUSTICE AND DISGRACES THE PROFESSION OF A CHRISTIAN COUNTRY
column5: defeats the ends of justice and disgraces the profession of a christian country

column4: THE PUBLICATION OF THIS REPORT RAISED A STORM IN THE CITY AND THE CORPORATION WAS ROUSED TO MAKE AN IMMEDIATE PROTEST
column5: the publication of this report raised a storm in the city and the corporation was roused to make an immediate protest

column5: a committee of aldermen was forthwith appointed to report upon the inspectors' report

column4: AND THE RESULT WAS ANOTHER LENGTHY BLUE BOOK PRINTED IN THE PARLIAMENTARY PAPERS EIGHTEEN THIRTYSIX
column5: and the result was another lengthy blue book printed in the parliamentary papers eighteen thirtysix

column4: TRAVERSING WHERE IT WAS POSSIBLE THE STATEMENTS OF THE INSPECTORS AND OFFERING EXPLANATION AND PALLIATION OF SUCH EVILS AS COULD NOT BE DENIED
column5: traversing where it was possible the statements of the inspectors and offering explanation and palliation of such evils as could not be denied

column4: THE INSPECTORS RETORTED WITHOUT LOSS OF TIME REITERATING THEIR CHARGES AND POINTING OUT THAT THE COMMITTEE OF ALDERMEN BY ITS OWN ADMISSION
column5: the inspectors retorted without loss of time reiterating their charges and pointing out that the committee of aldermen by its own admission

column4: JUSTIFIED THE ORIGINAL ALLEGATIONS IT WAS IMPOSSIBLE TO DENY THE INDISCRIMINATE ASSOCIATION THE GAMBLING DRINKING SMOKING QUARRELING IN THE JAIL
column5: justified the original allegations it was impossible to deny the indiscriminate association the gambling drinking smoking quarreling in the jail

column4: THE UNDUE AUTHORITY GIVEN TO PRISONERS THE LEVYING OF GARNISH UNDER ANOTHER NAME
column5: the undue authority given to prisoners the levying of garnish under another name

column4: THE NEGLECT OF THE CONDEMNED CONVICTS THE FILTHY CONDITION OF THE WARDS THE INSUFFICIENCY OF BEDDING AND CLOTHING
column5: the neglect of the condemned convicts the filthy condition of the wards the insufficiency of bedding and clothing

column4: THE MISEMPLOYMENT OF OFFICERS AND PRISONERS BY THE GOVERNOR
column5: the misemployment of officers and prisoners by the governor

column4: THE CORPORATION EVIDENTLY HAD THE WORST OF IT AND BEGAN TO FEEL THE NECESSITY FOR UNDERTAKING THE GREAT WORK OF REFORM
column5: the corporation evidently had the worst of it and began to feel the necessity for undertaking the great work of reform

column4: NEXT YEAR WE FIND THE INSPECTORS EXPRESSING THEIR SATISFACTION THAT THE FULL AND FAITHFUL EXPOSURE WHICH WE FELT IT OUR DUTY TO MAKE OF NEWGATE
column5: next year we find the inspectors expressing their satisfaction that the full and faithful exposure which we felt it our duty to make of newgate

column4: HAS BEEN PRODUCTIVE OF AT LEAST SOME ADVANTAGE
column5: has been productive of at least some advantage

column4: INASMUCH AS IT HAS AROUSED THE ATTENTION OF THOSE UPON WHOM PARLIAMENTARY REPORTS AND GRAND JURY PRESENTMENTS HAD HITHERTO FAILED TO MAKE THE SLIGHTEST IMPRESSION
column5: inasmuch as it has aroused the attention of those upon whom parliamentary reports and grand jury presentments had hitherto failed to make the slightest impression

column4: THE MEASURES OF IMPROVEMENT INTRODUCED WERE MAINLY AS FOLLOWS
column5: the measures of improvement introduced were mainly as follows

column4: THE FIXING OF INSPECTION HOLES IN THE DOORS AND WALLS SO AS TO INSURE MORE SUPERVISION OF WINDOWS OPENING INTO THE WELLHOLES
column5: the fixing of inspection holes in the doors and walls so as to insure more supervision of windows opening into the wellholes

column4: TO GIVE BETTER LIGHT AND VENTILATION THE CONSTRUCTION OF BEDPLACES THREE TIERS HIGH ALONGSIDE THE WALLS FOR MALES TWO TIERS FOR FEMALES
column5: to give better light and ventilation the construction of bedplaces three tiers high alongside the walls for males two tiers for females

column4: THE PROVISION OF DININGROOMS AND DININGTABLES
column5: the provision of diningrooms and diningtables

column4: THE INFIRMARY WAS ENLARGED THE ADMISSION OF VISITORS LIMITED AND THE PASSING OF ARTICLES PREVENTED BY A WIRE SCREEN
column5: the infirmary was enlarged the admission of visitors limited and the passing of articles prevented by a wire screen

column4: THE WINDOWS WERE TO BE GLAZED AND PAINTED TO PREVENT PRISONERS FROM LOOKING OUT
column5: the windows were to be glazed and painted to prevent prisoners from looking out

column4: BATHS FUMIGATING PLACES FOR CLOTHING WASHHOUSE AND THE REMOVAL OF DUSTBINS COMPLETED THE NEW ARRANGEMENTS IN THE MAIN PRISON
column5: baths fumigating places for clothing washhouse and the removal of dustbins completed the new arrangements in the main prison

column4: IN THE PRESSYARD THE PRESSROOM AND WARD ABOVE IT WERE PARCELED OUT INTO NINE SEPARATE SLEEPING CELLS
column5: in the pressyard the pressroom and ward above it were parceled out into nine separate sleeping cells

column4: EACH WAS PROVIDED WITH AN IRON BEDSTEAD AND A SMALL DESK AT WHICH THE CONDEMNED MAN MIGHT READ OR WRITE
column5: each was provided with an iron bedstead and a small desk at which the condemned man might read or write

column4: BUT THE ONE GREAT AND MOST CRYING EVIL REMAINED UNREMEDIED
column5: but the one great and most crying evil remained unremedied

column4: THE MISCHIEF OF JAIL ASSOCIATIONS SAY THE INSPECTORS
column5: the mischief of jail associations say the inspectors

column4: AND A TENDENCY TO RETURN TO MUCH OF THAT LAXITY AND REMISSNESS WHICH FORMERLY MARKED THE MANAGEMENT OF THIS PRISON
column5: and a tendency to return to much of that laxity and remissness which formerly marked the management of this prison

column4: AGAIN THE FOLLOWING YEAR THE INSPECTORS REPEAT THEIR CHARGE
column5: again the following year the inspectors repeat their charge

column4: OR THE INSPECTORS OF PRISONS AND THAT HE BE REQUIRED WHOLLY TO CONFINE HIMSELF TO THE PERFORMANCE OF HIS DUTY AS PRESCRIBED BY ACT OF PARLIAMENT
column5: or the inspectors of prisons and that he be required wholly to confine himself to the performance of his duty as prescribed by act of parliament

column4: THE INSPECTORS WERE NOT TO BE DETERRED HOWEVER BY ANY OPPOSITION FROM THE EARNEST DISCHARGE OF THEIR FUNCTIONS AND CONTINUED TO REPORT AGAINST NEWGATE
column5: the inspectors were not to be deterred however by any opposition from the earnest discharge of their functions and continued to report against newgate

column4: IN THEIR TENTH REPORT
column5: in their tenth report

column4: THEY STATE THAT THEY ARE COMPELLED BY AN IMPERATIVE SENSE OF DUTY TO ADVERT IN TERMS OF DECIDED CONDEMNATION TO THE LAMENTABLE CONDITION OF THE PRISONS OF THE CITY OF LONDON
column5: they state that they are compelled by an imperative sense of duty to advert in terms of decided condemnation to the lamentable condition of the prisons of the city of london

column4: NEWGATE GILTSPUR ST COMPTER AND THE CITY BRIDEWELL
column5: newgate giltspur st compter and the city bridewell

column4: IN WHICH THE MASTER EVIL OF JAIL ASSOCIATION AND CONSEQUENT CONTAMINATION STILL CONTINUES TO OPERATE DIRECTLY TO THE ENCOURAGEMENT OF CRIME
column5: in which the master evil of jail association and consequent contamination still continues to operate directly to the encouragement of crime

column5: the plan adopted for ventilating the diningroom on the 'master's side' and that of the middle yard is very inefficient

column4: IT CONSISTS OF SEVERAL CIRCULAR PERFORATIONS ABOUT TWO INCHES IN DIAMETER
column5: it consists of several circular perforations about two inches in diameter

column5: slanting downwards from the top of the walls to the outside adjoining the slaughterhouses of newgate market and occasionally in hot weather

column4: INSTEAD OF VENTILATING THE APARTMENTS THEY ONLY SERVE TO CONVEY THE OFFENSIVE EFFLUVIA ARISING FROM THE DECAYING ANIMAL MATTER INTO THE DININGROOMS
column5: instead of ventilating the apartments they only serve to convey the offensive effluvia arising from the decaying animal matter into the diningrooms

column4: SOMETIMES THE STENCH IN HOT WEATHER IS SAID TO BE VERY BAD
column5: sometimes the stench in hot weather is said to be very bad

column5: many rats also come through these socalled ventilators as they open close to the ground at the back of the prison

column4: AT THE SAME TIME THE INSPECTORS ANIMADVERT STRONGLY UPON THE MISCONDUCT OF PRISONERS AND THE FREQUENCY OF PRISON PUNISHMENTS
column5: at the same time the inspectors animadvert strongly upon the misconduct of prisoners and the frequency of prison punishments

column4: BOTH OFFENSES AND PUNISHMENTS AFFORDING A SUFFICIENT INDEX TO THE PRACTICES GOING FORWARD AND THEY WIND UP BY DECLARING
column5: both offenses and punishments affording a sufficient index to the practices going forward and they wind up by declaring

column4: THAT A STRICT COMPLIANCE WITH THEIR DUTIES GAVE THEM NO CHOICE BUT TO REPORT MATTERS AS WE FOUND THEM
column5: that a strict compliance with their duties gave them no choice but to report matters as we found them

column4: AND AGAIN AND AGAIN TO PROTEST AGAINST NEWGATE AS IT AT PRESENT EXISTS
column5: and again and again to protest against newgate as it at present exists

column5: no complete and permanent improvement was indeed possible while newgate remained unchanged

column5: i propose to return now to the subject of newgate executions

column5: the reasons for this change were fully set forth in a previous chapter

column5: already the severity of our criminal code and the number of capital felonies upon the statute book had brought a reaction

column4: AND WHILE THE COURTS ADHERED TO THE LETTER OF THE LAW APPEALS WERE CONSTANTLY MADE TO THE ROYAL PREROGATIVE OF MERCY
column5: and while the courts adhered to the letter of the law appeals were constantly made to the royal prerogative of mercy

column4: THIS WAS MORE PARTICULARLY THE PRACTICE IN LONDON
column5: this was more particularly the practice in london

column4: JUDGES ON ASSIZE WERE SATISFIED WITH SIMPLY RECORDING A SENTENCE OF DEATH AGAINST OFFENDERS WHOM THEY DID NOT THINK DESERVED THE EXTREME PENALTY
column5: judges on assize were satisfied with simply recording a sentence of death against offenders whom they did not think deserved the extreme penalty

column4: AT THE OLD BAILEY ALMOST EVERY ONE CAPITALLY CONVICTED BY A JURY WAS SENTENCED TO BE HANGED
column5: at the old bailey almost every one capitally convicted by a jury was sentenced to be hanged

column4: THE RESULT IN THE LATTER CASE WAS LEFT IN THE FIRST PLACE TO THE KING IN COUNCIL
column5: the result in the latter case was left in the first place to the king in council

column4: BUT THERE WAS A FURTHER APPEAL THEN AS NOW TO THE KING HIMSELF OR PRACTICALLY TO THE HOME SECRETARY
column5: but there was a further appeal then as now to the king himself or practically to the home secretary

column4: NEITHER IN TOWN OR COUNTRY WERE CASES ENTIRELY TAKEN ON THEIR OWN MERITS
column5: neither in town or country were cases entirely taken on their own merits

column4: CONVICTED OFFENDERS MIGHT HAVE GOOD OR BAD LUCK THEY MIGHT BE ARRAIGNED WHEN THEIR PARTICULAR CRIME WAS UNCOMMON AND WERE THEN NEARLY CERTAIN TO ESCAPE
column5: convicted offenders might have good or bad luck they might be arraigned when their particular crime was uncommon and were then nearly certain to escape

column4: OR THEIRS MIGHT BE ONE OF MANY AND IT MIGHT BE CONSIDERED NECESSARY TO MAKE AN EXAMPLE
column5: or theirs might be one of many and it might be considered necessary to make an example

column4: IN THIS LATTER IT MIGHT FAIRLY BE SAID THAT A MAN WAS PUT TO DEATH LESS FOR HIS OWN SINS THAN FOR THE CRIMES OF OTHERS
column5: in this latter it might fairly be said that a man was put to death less for his own sins than for the crimes of others

column4: THE ABSURDITY OF THE SYSTEM ITS IRREGULARITY AND CRUELTY WERE FULLY TOUCHED UPON BY THE INSPECTORS OF PRISONS IN THEIR FIRST REPORT
column5: the absurdity of the system its irregularity and cruelty were fully touched upon by the inspectors of prisons in their first report

column4: THEY FOUND AT NEWGATE UNDER DISGRACEFUL CONDITIONS AS ALREADY DESCRIBED
column5: they found at newgate under disgraceful conditions as already described

column4: SEVENTEEN CAPITAL CONVICTS UPON ALL OF WHOM THE SENTENCE OF DEATH HAD BEEN PASSED EVENTUALLY TWO ONLY OF THE WHOLE NUMBER SUFFERED
column5: seventeen capital convicts upon all of whom the sentence of death had been passed eventually two only of the whole number suffered

column4: TWO OTHERS WERE SENTENCED TO THREE MONTHS' IMPRISONMENT AND THE BALANCE TO VARYING TERMS
column5: two others were sentenced to three months' imprisonment and the balance to varying terms

column4: NOTHING COULD BE MORE STRONGLY MARKED THAN THE CONTRAST BETWEEN THE ULTIMATE DESTINY OF DIFFERENT INDIVIDUALS ALL ABIDING THE SAME AWFUL DOOM
column5: nothing could be more strongly marked than the contrast between the ultimate destiny of different individuals all abiding the same awful doom

column4: ON THE ONE HAND THE GALLOWS ON THE OTHER A SHORT IMPRISONMENT
column5: on the one hand the gallows on the other a short imprisonment

column4: THE INSPECTORS VERY PROPERLY DESIRED TO CALL ATTENTION TO THE INEVITABLE TENDENCY IN THIS MODE OF DEALING WITH THE MOST AWFUL SANCTIONS OF THE LAW
column5: the inspectors very properly desired to call attention to the inevitable tendency in this mode of dealing with the most awful sanctions of the law

column4: TO MAKE THOSE SANCTIONS AN OBJECT OF CONTEMPTUOUS MOCKERY
column5: to make those sanctions an object of contemptuous mockery

column4: THE CONSEQUENCES WERE PLAINLY PROVED TO THE INSPECTORS
column5: the consequences were plainly proved to the inspectors

column4: CAPITALLY CONVICTED PRISONERS DID AS A MATTER OF FACT TREAT WITH HABITUAL AND INEXPRESSIBLE LEVITY THE SENTENCE OF DEATH
column5: capitally convicted prisoners did as a matter of fact treat with habitual and inexpressible levity the sentence of death

column4: OF THIS I HAVE TREATED AT LENGTH IN THE LAST CHAPTER
column5: of this i have treated at length in the last chapter

column4: THE TIME THUS SPENT VARIED CONSIDERABLY
column5: the time thus spent varied considerably

column4: BUT IT WAS SELDOM LESS THAN SIX WEEKS IT ALL DEPENDED UPON THE SOVEREIGN'S DISPOSITION TO DO BUSINESS
column5: but it was seldom less than six weeks it all depended upon the sovereign's disposition to do business

column4: SOMETIMES THE PRIVY COUNCIL DID NOT MEET FOR MONTHS AND DURING ALL THAT TIME THE CONVICTS LANGUISHED WITH HOPE
column5: sometimes the privy council did not meet for months and during all that time the convicts languished with hope

column4: NEARLY INDEFINITELY DEFERRED
column5: nearly indefinitely deferred

column4: WHEN THE COUNCIL HAD DECIDED THE NEWS WAS CONVEYED TO NEWGATE BY THE RECORDER WHO MADE HIS REPORT AS IT WAS CALLED
column5: when the council had decided the news was conveyed to newgate by the recorder who made his report as it was called

column4: THE TIME OF THE ARRIVAL OF THIS REPORT WAS GENERALLY KNOWN AT NEWGATE
column5: the time of the arrival of this report was generally known at newgate

column4: AND ITS CONTENTS WERE ANXIOUSLY AWAITED BY BOTH CONVICTS IN THE PRESSYARD AND THEIR FRIENDS COLLECTED IN A CROWD OUTSIDE THE GATES
column5: and its contents were anxiously awaited by both convicts in the pressyard and their friends collected in a crowd outside the gates

column4: SOMETIMES THE REPORT WAS DELAYED
column5: sometimes the report was delayed

column4: ON ONE OCCASION MR WAKEFIELD TELLS US THE RECORDER WHO HAD ATTENDED THE COUNCIL AT WINDSOR DID NOT DELIVER THE REPORT TILL THE FOLLOWING DAY
column5: on one occasion mr wakefield tells us the recorder who had attended the council at windsor did not deliver the report till the following day

column4: THE PRISONERS AND THEIR FRIENDS THEREFORE WERE KEPT IN A STATE OF THE MOST VIOLENT SUSPENSE FOR MANY HOURS
column5: the prisoners and their friends therefore were kept in a state of the most violent suspense for many hours

column4: DURING WHICH THEY COUNTED THE MOMENTS  THE PRISONERS IN THEIR CELLS AS USUAL AND THEIR FRIENDS IN THE STREET IN FRONT OF NEWGATE WHERE THEY PASSED THE NIGHT
column5: during which they counted the moments  the prisoners in their cells as usual and their friends in the street in front of newgate where they passed the night

column4: I HAVE HEARD THE PROTRACTED AGONY OF BOTH CLASSES DESCRIBED BY THOSE WHO WITNESSED IT IN TERMS SO STRONG THAT I AM UNWILLING TO REPEAT THEM
column5: i have heard the protracted agony of both classes described by those who witnessed it in terms so strong that i am unwilling to repeat them

column4: THE CROWD OF MEN AND WOMEN WHO PASSED THE NIGHT IN FRONT OF NEWGATE BEGAN AS SOON AS THE HOUR WAS PASSED WHEN THEY HAD EXPECTED THE REPORT
column5: the crowd of men and women who passed the night in front of newgate began as soon as the hour was passed when they had expected the report

column4: TO UTTER IMPRECATIONS AGAINST THE RECORDER THE SECRETARY OF STATE THE COUNCIL AND THE KING
column5: to utter imprecations against the recorder the secretary of state the council and the king

column4: THEY NEVER CEASED CURSING UNTIL THE PASSION OF ANGER SO EXCITED WAS EXCHANGED FOR JOY IN SOME AND GRIEF IN OTHERS
column5: they never ceased cursing until the passion of anger so excited was exchanged for joy in some and grief in others

column4: I MYSELF HEARD MORE THAN ONE OF THOSE WHOSE LIVES WERE SPARED BY THAT DECISION OF THE COUNCIL
column5: i myself heard more than one of those whose lives were spared by that decision of the council

column4: AFTERWARDS EXPRESS A WISH TO MURDER THE RECORDER FOR HAVING KEPT THEM SO LONG IN SUSPENSE
column5: afterwards express a wish to murder the recorder for having kept them so long in suspense

column4: THE RECORDER'S REPORT GENERALLY REACHED NEWGATE LATE AT NIGHT
column5: the recorder's report generally reached newgate late at night

column4: ITS RECEIPT WAS IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWED BY THE PROMULGATION OF ITS CONTENTS TO THE PERSONS MOST CLOSELY CONCERNED
column5: its receipt was immediately followed by the promulgation of its contents to the persons most closely concerned

column4: WHICH WAS DONE WITH A SORT OF CEREMONY INTENDED TO BE IMPRESSIVE
column5: which was done with a sort of ceremony intended to be impressive

column4: THE WHOLE OF THE CONVICTS WERE ASSEMBLED TOGETHER IN ONE WARD AND MADE TO KNEEL DOWN
column5: the whole of the convicts were assembled together in one ward and made to kneel down

column4: TO THEM ENTERED THE CHAPLAIN OR ORDINARY OF NEWGATE IN FULL CANONICALS
column5: to them entered the chaplain or ordinary of newgate in full canonicals

column4: WHO IN SOLEMN TONES COMMUNICATED TO EACH IN TURN THE FATE IN STORE FOR HIM
column5: who in solemn tones communicated to each in turn the fate in store for him

column4: THE FORM OF IMPARTING THE INTELLIGENCE WAS GENERALLY THE SAME
column5: the form of imparting the intelligence was generally the same

column4: SOANDSO I AM SORRY TO TELL YOU THAT IT IS ALL AGAINST YOU OR
column5: soandso i am sorry to tell you that it is all against you or

column4: A B YOUR CASE HAS BEEN TAKEN INTO CONSIDERATION BY THE KING IN COUNCIL AND HIS MAJESTY HAS BEEN MERCIFULLY PLEASED TO SPARE YOUR LIFE
column5: a b your case has been taken into consideration by the king in council and his majesty has been mercifully pleased to spare your life

column4: THE FATAL NEWS WAS NOT ALWAYS RECEIVED IN THE SAME WAY
column5: the fatal news was not always received in the same way

column4: THE MEN WHO WERE DOOMED OFTEN FELL DOWN IN CONVULSIONS UPON THE FLOOR
column5: the men who were doomed often fell down in convulsions upon the floor

column4: SOMETIMES ANY WHO HAD HAD A NARROW ESCAPE FAINTED BUT THE BULK OF THOSE RESPITED LOOKED ON WITH UNFEELING INDIFFERENCE
column5: sometimes any who had had a narrow escape fainted but the bulk of those respited looked on with unfeeling indifference

column4: THE CHRONICLES OF NEWGATE VOLUME TWO BY ARTHUR GRIFFITHS SECTION TWELVE EXECUTIONS PART TWO
column5: the chronicles of newgate volume two by arthur griffiths section twelve executions part two

column4: IT IS SATISFACTORY TO BE ABLE TO RECORD THAT SOME CONSIDERATION WAS SHOWN THE CAPITAL CONVICT ACTUALLY AWAITING EXECUTION
column5: it is satisfactory to be able to record that some consideration was shown the capital convict actually awaiting execution

column4: EVEN SO SEVERE A CRITIC AS MR WAKEFIELD STATES THAT A STRANGER TO THE SCENE
column5: even so severe a critic as mr wakefield states that a stranger to the scene

column4: WOULD BE ASTONISHED TO OBSERVE THE PECULIAR TENDERNESS I WAS GOING TO ADD RESPECT
column5: would be astonished to observe the peculiar tenderness i was going to add respect

column4: WHICH PERSONS UNDER SENTENCE OF DEATH OBTAIN FROM ALL THE OFFICERS OF THE PRISON
column5: which persons under sentence of death obtain from all the officers of the prison

column4: BEFORE SENTENCE A PRISONER HAS ONLY TO OBSERVE THE REGULATIONS OF THE JAIL IN ORDER TO REMAIN NEGLECTED AND UNNOTICED
column5: before sentence a prisoner has only to observe the regulations of the jail in order to remain neglected and unnoticed

column4: ONCE ORDERED TO THE CELLS FRIENDS OF ALL CLASSES SUDDENLY RISE UP HIS FELLOWPRISONERS THE TURNKEYS THE CHAPLAIN
column5: once ordered to the cells friends of all classes suddenly rise up his fellowprisoners the turnkeys the chaplain

column4: THE KEEPERS AND THE SHERIFFS ALL SEEM INTERESTED IN HIS FATE AND HE CAN MAKE NO REASONABLE REQUEST THAT IS NOT AT ONCE GRANTED BY WHOMSOEVER HE MAY ADDRESS
column5: the keepers and the sheriffs all seem interested in his fate and he can make no reasonable request that is not at once granted by whomsoever he may address

column4: THIS RULE HAS SOME BUT VERY FEW EXCEPTIONS SUCH AS WHERE A HARDENED OFFENDER BEHAVES WITH GREAT LEVITY AND BRUTALITY AS IF HE CARED NOUGHT FOR HIS LIFE
column5: this rule has some but very few exceptions such as where a hardened offender behaves with great levity and brutality as if he cared nought for his life

column4: AND THOUGHT EVERY ONE ANXIOUS TO PROMOTE HIS DEATH
column5: and thought every one anxious to promote his death

column4: MR WAKEFIELD GOES ON TO REMARK THAT PERSONS CONVICTED OF FORGERY EXCITED AN EXTRAORDINARY DEGREE OF INTEREST IN ALL WHO APPROACHED THEM
column5: mr wakefield goes on to remark that persons convicted of forgery excited an extraordinary degree of interest in all who approached them

column4: THIS WAS NOTICEABLE WITH FAUNTLEROY WHO ON ACCOUNT OF HIS BIRTH AND ANTECEDENTS WAS ALLOWED TO OCCUPY A TURNKEY'S ROOM
column5: this was noticeable with fauntleroy who on account of his birth and antecedents was allowed to occupy a turnkey's room

column4: AND KEPT ALTOGETHER SEPARATE FROM THE OTHER PRISONERS UNTIL THE DAY OF HIS DEATH
column5: and kept altogether separate from the other prisoners until the day of his death

column4: IT CANNOT BE DENIED HOWEVER THAT THE ORDINARY'S TREATMENT WAS SOMEWHAT UNFEELING AND IN PROOF THEREOF
column5: it cannot be denied however that the ordinary's treatment was somewhat unfeeling and in proof thereof

column4: I WILL QUOTE AN EXTRACT FROM THE REVEREND GENTLEMAN'S OWN JOURNAL
column5: i will quote an extract from the reverend gentleman's own journal

column4: HE SEEMS TO HAVE IMPROVED THE OCCASION WHEN PREACHING THE CONDEMNED SERMON BEFORE FAUNTLEROY BY POINTING A MORAL FROM THAT UNHAPPY MAN'S OWN CASE
column5: he seems to have improved the occasion when preaching the condemned sermon before fauntleroy by pointing a moral from that unhappy man's own case

column4: FOR THIS THE CHAPLAIN WAS A FEW DAYS LATER SUMMONED BEFORE THE JAIL COMMITTEE OF ALDERMEN
column5: for this the chaplain was a few days later summoned before the jail committee of aldermen

column4: AND INFORMED THAT THE PUBLIC WOULD NOT IN FUTURE BE ADMITTED TO HEAR THE CONDEMNED SERMON I WAS ALSO INFORMED WRITES MR COTTON
column5: and informed that the public would not in future be admitted to hear the condemned sermon i was also informed writes mr cotton

column4: THAT THIS RESOLUTION WAS IN CONSEQUENCE OF THEIR THE ALDERMEN'S DISAPPROVING OF THE LAST DISCOURSE DELIVERED BY ME
column5: that this resolution was in consequence of their the aldermen's disapproving of the last discourse delivered by me

column4: PREVIOUS TO THE EXECUTION OF HENRY FAUNTLEROY FOR UTTERING A FORGED SECURITY
column5: previous to the execution of henry fauntleroy for uttering a forged security

column4: IN WHICH IT WAS SAID I HAD ENLARGED UPON THE HEINOUS NATURE OF HIS CRIME AND WARNED THE PUBLIC TO AVOID SUCH CONDUCT
column5: in which it was said i had enlarged upon the heinous nature of his crime and warned the public to avoid such conduct

column4: I WAS INFORMED THAT THIS UNNECESSARILY HARASSED HIS FEELINGS AND THAT THE OBJECT OF SUCH SERMONS WAS SOLELY TO CONSOLE THE PRISONER
column5: i was informed that this unnecessarily harassed his feelings and that the object of such sermons was solely to console the prisoner

column4: AND THAT FROM THE TIME OF HIS CONVICTION NOTHING BUT WHAT IS CONSOLATORY SHOULD BE ADDRESSED TO A CRIMINAL
column5: and that from the time of his conviction nothing but what is consolatory should be addressed to a criminal

column4: ONE OF THE ALDERMEN MOREOVER INFORMED ME THAT THE WHOLE COURT OF ALDERMEN WERE UNANIMOUS IN THEIR OPINION ON THIS SUBJECT
column5: one of the aldermen moreover informed me that the whole court of aldermen were unanimous in their opinion on this subject

column4: AS TO THE EXCLUSION OF STRANGERS ON THESE OCCASIONS
column5: as to the exclusion of strangers on these occasions

column4: THE EXPERIENCE I HAVE HAD CONVINCES ME THAT ONE AND PERHAPS THE ONLY GOOD OF AN EXECUTION I E THE SOLEMN ADMONITION TO THE PUBLIC
column5: the experience i have had convinces me that one and perhaps the only good of an execution i e the solemn admonition to the public

column4: WILL THEREBY BE LOST
column5: will thereby be lost

column4: PROBABLY THE READER WILL SIDE WITH THE ALDERMEN AGAINST THE ORDINARY
column5: probably the reader will side with the aldermen against the ordinary

column4: THIS EPISODE THROWS SOME DOUBT UPON THE TENDERNESS AND PROPER FEELING EXHIBITED BY THE CHAPLAIN TOWARDS THE MOST DESERVING MEMBERS OF HIS CRIMINAL FLOCK
column5: this episode throws some doubt upon the tenderness and proper feeling exhibited by the chaplain towards the most deserving members of his criminal flock

column4: AND THE IDEA WILL BE STRENGTHENED BY THE FOLLOWING ACCOUNT OF THE SUNDAY SERVICE IN THE PRISON CHAPEL ON THE OCCASION WHEN THE CONDEMNED SERMON WAS PREACHED
column5: and the idea will be strengthened by the following account of the sunday service in the prison chapel on the occasion when the condemned sermon was preached

column4: THE EXTRACT IS FROM MR E GIBBON WAKEFIELD'S BROCHURE THE DATE EIGHTEEN TWENTYEIGHT JUST THREE YEARS AFTER FAUNTLEROY'S DEATH
column5: the extract is from mr e gibbon wakefield's brochure the date eighteen twentyeight just three years after fauntleroy's death

column4: STRANGERS WERE NOW EXCLUDED BUT THE SHERIFFS ATTENDED IN STATE WEARING THEIR GOLD CHAINS
column5: strangers were now excluded but the sheriffs attended in state wearing their gold chains

column4: WHILE BEHIND THEIR PEW STOOD A COUPLE OF TALL FOOTMEN IN STATE LIVERIES
column5: while behind their pew stood a couple of tall footmen in state liveries

column4: THE SHERIFFS WERE IN ONE GALLERY
column5: the sheriffs were in one gallery

column4: IN THE OTHER OPPOSITE WERE THE CONVICTS CAPITALLY CONVICTED WHO HAD BEEN RESPITED
column5: in the other opposite were the convicts capitally convicted who had been respited

column4: DOWN BELOW BETWEEN THE GALLERIES WAS THE MASS OF THE PRISON POPULATION
column5: down below between the galleries was the mass of the prison population

column4: THE SCHOOLMASTER AND THE JUVENILE PRISONERS BEING SEATED ROUND THE COMMUNIONTABLE OPPOSITE THE PULPIT
column5: the schoolmaster and the juvenile prisoners being seated round the communiontable opposite the pulpit

column4: IN THE CENTER OF THE CHAPEL WAS THE CONDEMNED PEW A LARGE DOCKLIKE ERECTION PAINTED BLACK
column5: in the center of the chapel was the condemned pew a large docklike erection painted black

column4: THOSE WHO SAT IN IT WERE VISIBLE TO THE WHOLE CONGREGATION AND STILL MORE TO THE ORDINARY
column5: those who sat in it were visible to the whole congregation and still more to the ordinary

column4: WHOSE DESK AND PULPIT WERE JUST IN FRONT OF THE CONDEMNED PEW AND WITHIN A COUPLE OF YARDS OF IT
column5: whose desk and pulpit were just in front of the condemned pew and within a couple of yards of it

column4: THE OCCUPANTS OF THIS TERRIBLE BLACK PEW WERE THE LAST ALWAYS TO ENTER THE CHAPEL
column5: the occupants of this terrible black pew were the last always to enter the chapel

column4: UPON THE OCCASION WHICH I AM DESCRIBING THEY WERE FOUR IN NUMBER AND HERE I WILL CONTINUE THE NARRATIVE IN MR WAKEFIELD'S OWN WORDS
column5: upon the occasion which i am describing they were four in number and here i will continue the narrative in mr wakefield's own words

column4: FIRST IS A YOUTH OF EIGHTEEN CONDEMNED FOR STEALING IN A DWELLINGHOUSE GOODS VALUED ABOVE FIVE POUNDS
column5: first is a youth of eighteen condemned for stealing in a dwellinghouse goods valued above five pounds

column4: HIS FEATURES HAVE NO FELONIOUS CAST
column5: his features have no felonious cast

column4: HE STEPS BOLDLY WITH HEAD UPRIGHT LOOKS TO THE WOMEN'S GALLERY AND SMILES HIS INTENTION IS TO PASS FOR A BRAVE FELLOW
column5: he steps boldly with head upright looks to the women's gallery and smiles his intention is to pass for a brave fellow

column4: BUT THE ATTEMPT FAILS HE TREMBLES HIS KNEES KNOCK TOGETHER AND HIS HEAD DROOPS AS HE ENTERS THE CONDEMNED PEW
column5: but the attempt fails he trembles his knees knock together and his head droops as he enters the condemned pew

column4: THE NEXT CONVICT IS CLEARLY AND UNMISTAKABLY A VILLAIN
column5: the next convict is clearly and unmistakably a villain

column4: HE IS A HARDENED OFFENDER PREVIOUSLY CAST FOR LIFE REPRIEVED TRANSPORTED TO AUSTRALIA AND SINCE RETURNED WITHOUT PARDON
column5: he is a hardened offender previously cast for life reprieved transported to australia and since returned without pardon

column4: FOR THIS OFFENSE THE PUNISHMENT IS DEATH
column5: for this offense the punishment is death

column4: HE HAS HOWEVER DOUBLY EARNED HIS SENTENCE AND IS ACTUALLY CONDEMNED FOR BURGLARY COMMITTED SINCE HIS ARRIVAL IN ENGLAND
column5: he has however doubly earned his sentence and is actually condemned for burglary committed since his arrival in england

column4: HIS LOOK AT THE SHERIFFS AND THE ORDINARY IS FULL OF SCORN AND DEFIANCE
column5: his look at the sheriffs and the ordinary is full of scorn and defiance

column4: THE THIRD CONVICT IS A SHEEPSTEALER A POOR IGNORANT FELLOW IN WHOSE CRIME ARE MITIGATING CIRCUMSTANCES
column5: the third convict is a sheepstealer a poor ignorant fellow in whose crime are mitigating circumstances

column4: BUT WHO IS LEFT TO DIE ON THE SUPPOSITION THAT THIS IS NOT HIS FIRST CONVICTION AND STILL MORE BECAUSE A GOOD MANY SHEEP HAVE OF LATE BEEN STOLEN BY OTHER PEOPLE
column5: but who is left to die on the supposition that this is not his first conviction and still more because a good many sheep have of late been stolen by other people

column4: HE IS QUITE CONTENT TO DIE
column5: he is quite content to die

column4: INDEED THE CHAPLAIN AND OTHERS HAVE BROUGHT HIM FIRMLY TO BELIEVE THAT HIS SITUATION IS ENVIABLE AND THAT THE GATES OF HEAVEN ARE OPEN TO RECEIVE HIM
column5: indeed the chaplain and others have brought him firmly to believe that his situation is enviable and that the gates of heaven are open to receive him

column4: THE LAST OF THE FOUR IS SAID TO HAVE BEEN A CLERGYMAN OF THE CHURCH OF ENGLAND CONDEMNED FOR FORGERY A MISERABLE OLD MAN IN A TATTERED SUIT OF BLACK
column5: the last of the four is said to have been a clergyman of the church of england condemned for forgery a miserable old man in a tattered suit of black

column4: ALREADY HE IS HALF DEAD
column5: already he is half dead

column4: GREAT EFFORTS HAVE BEEN MADE TO SAVE HIS LIFE
column5: great efforts have been made to save his life

column4: FRIENDS EVEN UTTER STRANGERS HAVE INTERCEDED FOR HIM AND TO THE LAST HE HAS BUOYED HIMSELF UP BY HOPE OF REPRIEVE
column5: friends even utter strangers have interceded for him and to the last he has buoyed himself up by hope of reprieve

column4: NOW HIS DOOM IS SEALED IRREVOCABLY AND HE HAS GIVEN HIMSELF UP TO DESPAIR
column5: now his doom is sealed irrevocably and he has given himself up to despair

column5: buries his head under his body

column5: the sheriffs shudder their inquisitive friends crane forward the keeper frowns on the excited congregation

column5: the lately smirking footmen close their eyes and forget their liveries the ordinary clasps his hands the turnkeys cry 'hush'

column5: the forger has never moved

column5: all have sung 'the lamentation of a sinner' and have seemed to pray 'especially for those now awaiting the awful execution of the law'

column5: the ordinary of newgate is an orthodox unaffected church of england divine

column4: WHO PREACHES PLAIN HOMELY DISCOURSES AS FIT AS ANY RELIGIOUS DISCOURSE CAN BE FIT FOR THE IRRITATED AUDIENCE
column5: who preaches plain homely discourses as fit as any religious discourse can be fit for the irritated audience

column5: the sermon of this day whether eloquent or plain useful or useless must produce a striking effect at the moment of its delivery

column5: the text without another word is enough to raise the wildest passions of the audience

column5: for a while the preacher addresses himself to the congregation at large who listen attentively

column5: while the eyes of the latter are wandering round the chapel and one of them is occasionally winked impudently at some acquaintance amongst the prisoners for trial

column4: A NOT ALTOGETHER NEW CRIME HOWEVER AKIN TO MURDER
