column4: ALTHOUGH HAPPILY NEVER PASSING BEYOND DASTARDLY ATTEMPTS CROPPED UP IN THESE TIMES AND WAS OFTEN FREQUENTLY REPEATED WITHIN A SHORT INTERVAL
column5: although happily never passing beyond dastardly attempts cropped up in these times and was often frequently repeated within a short interval

column4: THE PRESENT QUEEN VERY SOON AFTER HER ACCESSION
column5: the present queen very soon after her accession

column4: BECAME THE VICTIM OF THE MOST COWARDLY AND UNMANLY OUTRAGES AND THE ATTEMPTED MURDER OF THE SOVEREIGN BY OXFORD IN EIGHTEEN FORTY
column5: became the victim of the most cowardly and unmanly outrages and the attempted murder of the sovereign by oxford in eighteen forty

column4: WAS FOLLOWED IN THE VERY NEXT YEAR BY THOSE OF FRANCIS AND OF BEAN IN TWO CONSECUTIVE MONTHS
column5: was followed in the very next year by those of francis and of bean in two consecutive months

column4: WHILE IN EIGHTEEN FIFTY HER MAJESTY WAS THE VICTIM OF ANOTHER OUTRAGE AT THE HANDS OF ONE PATE
column5: while in eighteen fifty her majesty was the victim of another outrage at the hands of one pate

column4: THESE CRIMES HAD THEIR ORIGIN TOO OFTEN IN THE DISORDERED BRAINS OF LUNATICS AT LARGE LIKE CAPTAIN GOODE
column5: these crimes had their origin too often in the disordered brains of lunatics at large like captain goode

column4: THEIR PERPETRATORS WERE CHARGED WITH HIGH TREASON BUT MET WITH MERCIFUL CLEMENCY AS IRRESPONSIBLE BEINGS
column5: their perpetrators were charged with high treason but met with merciful clemency as irresponsible beings

column4: BUT AT VARIOUS DATES TREASON MORE DISTINCT AND TANGIBLE CAME TO THE FRONT ATTEMPTS TO LEVY WAR AGAINST THE STATE
column5: but at various dates treason more distinct and tangible came to the front attempts to levy war against the state

column4: THE WELLKNOWN CATO STREET CONSPIRACY
column5: the wellknown cato street conspiracy

column4: WHICH GREW OUT OF DISTURBED SOCIAL CONDITIONS AFTER THE LAST FRENCH WAR AMIDST GENERAL DISTRESS
column5: which grew out of disturbed social conditions after the last french war amidst general distress

column4: AND WHEN THE PEOPLE WERE BEGINNING TO AGITATE FOR A LARGER SHARE OF POLITICAL POWER WAS AMONG THE EARLIEST AND TO SOME EXTENT THE MOST DESPERATE OF THESE
column5: and when the people were beginning to agitate for a larger share of political power was among the earliest and to some extent the most desperate of these

column4: ITS RINGLEADERS THISTLEWOOD AND THE REST WERE AFTER CAPTURE HONORED BY COMMITTAL AS STATE PRISONERS TO THE TOWER
column5: its ringleaders thistlewood and the rest were after capture honored by committal as state prisoners to the tower

column4: BUT THEY CAME ONE AND ALL TO NEWGATE FOR TRIAL AT THE OLD BAILEY AND REMAINED THERE AFTER CONVICTION TILL THEY WERE HANGED
column5: but they came one and all to newgate for trial at the old bailey and remained there after conviction till they were hanged

column4: LATER ON THE CHARTISTS AGITATED PERSISTENTLY FOR THE CONCESSION EMBRACED IN THE SOCALLED PEOPLE'S CHARTER MANY OF WHICH
column5: later on the chartists agitated persistently for the concession embraced in the socalled people's charter many of which

column4: ARE BY THIS TIME ACTUALLY AND BY MORE LEGITIMATE EFFORTS ENGRAFTED UPON OUR CONSTITUTION
column5: are by this time actually and by more legitimate efforts engrafted upon our constitution

column4: BUT THE CHARTISTS SOUGHT THEIR ENDS BY RIOT AND REBELLION AND GAINED ONLY IMPRISONMENT FOR THEIR PAINS
column5: but the chartists sought their ends by riot and rebellion and gained only imprisonment for their pains

column4: SOME FIVE HUNDRED IN ALL WERE ARRESTED BUT AS ONLY THREE OF THESE WERE LODGED IN NEWGATE I SHALL NOT RECUR TO THEM IN MY NARRATIVE
column5: some five hundred in all were arrested but as only three of these were lodged in newgate i shall not recur to them in my narrative

column4: THE CATO STREET CONSPIRACY WOULD HAVE BEEN SIMPLY RIDICULOUS BUT FOR THE RECKLESSNESS OF THE DESPERADOES WHO PLANNED IT
column5: the cato street conspiracy would have been simply ridiculous but for the recklessness of the desperadoes who planned it

column4: THAT SOME THIRTY OR MORE NEEDY MEN SHOULD HOPE TO REVOLUTIONIZE ENGLAND IS A SUFFICIENT PROOF OF THE ABSURDITY OF THEIR ATTEMPT
column5: that some thirty or more needy men should hope to revolutionize england is a sufficient proof of the absurdity of their attempt

column4: BUT THEY PROCEEDED IN ALL SERIOUSNESS AND WOULD HAVE SHRUNK FROM NO OUTRAGE OR ATROCITY IN FURTHERANCE OF THEIR FOOLHARDY ENTERPRISE
column5: but they proceeded in all seriousness and would have shrunk from no outrage or atrocity in furtherance of their foolhardy enterprise

column4: THE MASSACRE OF THE WHOLE OF THE CABINET MINISTERS AT ONE STROKE WAS TO BE FOLLOWED BY AN ATTACK
column5: the massacre of the whole of the cabinet ministers at one stroke was to be followed by an attack

column4: UPON THE OLD MAN AND THE OLD WOMAN AS THEY STYLED THE MANSION HOUSE AND THE BANK OF ENGLAND
column5: upon the old man and the old woman as they styled the mansion house and the bank of england

column4: AT THE FORMER THE PROVISIONAL GOVERNMENT WAS TO BE ESTABLISHED
column5: at the former the provisional government was to be established

column4: WHICH UNDER THISTLEWOOD AS DICTATOR WAS TO RULE THE NATION BY FIRST HANDING OVER ITS CAPITAL TO FIRE AND PILLAGE
column5: which under thistlewood as dictator was to rule the nation by first handing over its capital to fire and pillage

column4: THIS THISTLEWOOD HAD SEEN MANY VICISSITUDES THROUGHOUT HIS STRANGE ADVENTUROUS CAREER THE SON OF A RESPECTABLE LINCOLNSHIRE FARMER
column5: this thistlewood had seen many vicissitudes throughout his strange adventurous career the son of a respectable lincolnshire farmer

column4: HE BECAME A MILITIA OFFICER AND MARRIED A WOMAN WITH TEN THOUSAND POUNDS IN WHICH HOWEVER SHE HAD ONLY A LIFE INTEREST
column5: he became a militia officer and married a woman with ten thousand pounds in which however she had only a life interest

column4: SHE DIED EARLY AND THISTLEWOOD LEFT TO HIS OWN RESOURCES
column5: she died early and thistlewood left to his own resources

column4: FOLLOWED THE PROFESSION OF ARMS FIRST IN THE BRITISH SERVICE AND THEN IN THAT OF THE FRENCH REVOLUTIONARY GOVERNMENT
column5: followed the profession of arms first in the british service and then in that of the french revolutionary government

column4: IT WAS DURING THIS PERIOD THAT HE WAS SAID TO HAVE IMBIBED HIS REVOLUTIONARY IDEAS
column5: it was during this period that he was said to have imbibed his revolutionary ideas

column4: RETURNING TO ENGLAND
column5: returning to england

column4: HE FOUND HIMSELF RICH IN A SMALL LANDED PROPERTY WHICH HE PRESENTLY SOLD TO A MAN WHO BECAME BANKRUPT BEFORE HE HAD PAID OVER THE PURCHASE MONEY
column5: he found himself rich in a small landed property which he presently sold to a man who became bankrupt before he had paid over the purchase money

column4: AFTER THIS HE TRIED FARMING BUT FAILED
column5: after this he tried farming but failed

column4: HE MARRIED AGAIN AND CAME TO LONDON WHERE HE SOON BECAME NOTORIOUS AS A RECKLESS GAMBLER AND A POLITICIAN HOLDING THE MOST EXTREME VIEWS
column5: he married again and came to london where he soon became notorious as a reckless gambler and a politician holding the most extreme views

column4: IN THIS WAY HE FORMED THE ACQUAINTANCE OF WATSON AND OTHERS WITH WHOM HE WAS ARRAIGNED FOR TREASONABLE PRACTICES AND IMPRISONED
column5: in this way he formed the acquaintance of watson and others with whom he was arraigned for treasonable practices and imprisoned

column4: ON HIS RELEASE HE SENT A CHALLENGE TO LORD SIDMOUTH THE HOME SECRETARY AND WAS AGAIN ARRESTED AND IMPRISONED
column5: on his release he sent a challenge to lord sidmouth the home secretary and was again arrested and imprisoned

column4: ON HIS SECOND RELEASE GOADED BY HIS FANCIED WRONGS HE BEGAN TO PLOT A DARK AND DREADFUL REVENGE
column5: on his second release goaded by his fancied wrongs he began to plot a dark and dreadful revenge

column4: AND THUS THE CONSPIRACY IN WHICH HE WAS THE PRIME MOVER TOOK SHAPE AND CAME TO A HEAD
column5: and thus the conspiracy in which he was the prime mover took shape and came to a head

column4: THE GOVERNMENT OBTAINED EARLY AND FULL INFORMATION OF THE NEFARIOUS SCHEME
column5: the government obtained early and full information of the nefarious scheme

column4: ONE OF THE CONSPIRATORS BY NAME EDWARDS
column5: one of the conspirators by name edwards

column4: MADE A VOLUNTARY CONFESSION TO SIR HERBERT TAYLOR ONE MORNING AT WINDSOR AFTER WHICH THISTLEWOOD AND HIS ACCOMPLICES WERE CLOSELY WATCHED
column5: made a voluntary confession to sir herbert taylor one morning at windsor after which thistlewood and his accomplices were closely watched

column4: AND MEASURES TAKEN TO ARREST THEM WHEN THEIR PLANS WERE SO FAR DEVELOPED THAT NO DOUBT COULD REMAIN AS TO THEIR GUILT
column5: and measures taken to arrest them when their plans were so far developed that no doubt could remain as to their guilt

column4: THE DAY APPOINTED FOR THE MURDER AND RISING ACTUALLY ARRIVED BEFORE THE AUTHORITIES INTERFERED
column5: the day appointed for the murder and rising actually arrived before the authorities interfered

column4: IT WAS THE DAY ON WHICH LORD HARROWBY WAS TO ENTERTAIN HIS COLLEAGUES AT DINNER IN GROSVENOR SQUARE
column5: it was the day on which lord harrowby was to entertain his colleagues at dinner in grosvenor square

column4: THE OCCASION WAS CONSIDERED EXCELLENT BY THE CONSPIRATORS FOR DISPOSAL OF THE WHOLE CABINET AT ONE BLOW
column5: the occasion was considered excellent by the conspirators for disposal of the whole cabinet at one blow

column4: AND IT WAS ARRANGED THAT ONE OF THEIR NUMBER SHOULD KNOCK AT LORD HARROWBY'S DOOR ON THE PRETENSE OF LEAVING A PARCEL
column5: and it was arranged that one of their number should knock at lord harrowby's door on the pretense of leaving a parcel

column4: AND THAT WHEN IT WAS OPENED THE WHOLE BAND SHOULD RUSH IN
column5: and that when it was opened the whole band should rush in

column4: WHILE A FEW SECURED THE SERVANTS THE REST WERE TO FALL UPON LORD HARROWBY AND HIS GUESTS
column5: while a few secured the servants the rest were to fall upon lord harrowby and his guests

column4: HANDGRENADES WERE TO BE THROWN INTO THE DININGROOM AND DURING THE NOISE AND CONFUSION THE ASSASSINATION OF THE MINISTERS WAS TO BE COMPLETED
column5: handgrenades were to be thrown into the diningroom and during the noise and confusion the assassination of the ministers was to be completed

column4: THE HEADS OF LORD CASTLEREAGH AND LORD SIDMOUTH BEING CARRIED AWAY IN A BAG
column5: the heads of lord castlereagh and lord sidmouth being carried away in a bag

column4: LORD HARROWBY'S DINNERPARTY WAS POSTPONED BUT THE CONSPIRATORS KNEW NOTHING OF IT
column5: lord harrowby's dinnerparty was postponed but the conspirators knew nothing of it

column4: AND THOSE WHO WATCHED HIS HOUSE WERE FURTHER ENCOURAGED IN THEIR MISTAKE BY THE ARRIVAL OF MANY CARRIAGES
column5: and those who watched his house were further encouraged in their mistake by the arrival of many carriages

column4: BOUND AS IT HAPPENED TO THE ARCHBISHOP OF YORK'S
column5: bound as it happened to the archbishop of york's

column4: MEANWHILE THE MAIN BODY REMAINED AT THEIR HEADQUARTERS A RUINED STABLE IN CATO STREET
column5: meanwhile the main body remained at their headquarters a ruined stable in cato street

column4: EDGEWARE ROAD COMPLETING THEIR DISPOSITIONS FOR ASSUMING SUPREME POWER AFTER THE BLOW HAD BEEN STRUCK
column5: edgeware road completing their dispositions for assuming supreme power after the blow had been struck

column4: HERE THEY WERE SURPRISED BY THE POLICE HEADED BY A MAGISTRATE AND SUPPORTED BY A STRONG DETACHMENT OF HER MAJESTY'S GUARDS
column5: here they were surprised by the police headed by a magistrate and supported by a strong detachment of her majesty's guards

column4: THE POLICE WERE THE FIRST TO ARRIVE ON THE SPOT THE GUARDS HAVING ENTERED THE STREET AT THE WRONG END
column5: the police were the first to arrive on the spot the guards having entered the street at the wrong end

column4: THE CONSPIRATORS WERE IN A LOFT APPROACHED BY A LADDER AND A TRAPDOOR ACCESS THROUGH WHICH COULD ONLY BE OBTAINED ONE BY ONE
column5: the conspirators were in a loft approached by a ladder and a trapdoor access through which could only be obtained one by one

column4: THE FIRST CONSTABLE WHO ENTERED THISTLEWOOD RAN THROUGH THE BODY WITH A SWORD BUT OTHERS QUICKLY FOLLOWED
column5: the first constable who entered thistlewood ran through the body with a sword but others quickly followed

column4: THE LIGHTS WERE EXTINGUISHED AND A DESPERATE CONFLICT ENSUED
column5: the lights were extinguished and a desperate conflict ensued

column4: THE GUARDS HEADED BY LORD ADOLPHUS FITZ CLARENCE NOW REINFORCED THE POLICE AND THE CONSPIRATORS GAVE WAY
column5: the guards headed by lord adolphus fitz clarence now reinforced the police and the conspirators gave way

column4: NINE OF THE LATTER WERE CAPTURED WITH ALL THE WAR MATERIAL CUTLASSES PISTOLS HANDGRENADES AND AMMUNITION
column5: nine of the latter were captured with all the war material cutlasses pistols handgrenades and ammunition

column4: THISTLEWOOD AND FOURTEEN MORE SUCCEEDED FOR THE MOMENT IN MAKING THEIR ESCAPE BUT MOST OF THEM WERE SUBSEQUENTLY TAKEN
column5: thistlewood and fourteen more succeeded for the moment in making their escape but most of them were subsequently taken

column4: THISTLEWOOD WAS DISCOVERED NEXT MORNING IN A MEAN HOUSE IN WHITE STREET MOORFIELDS
column5: thistlewood was discovered next morning in a mean house in white street moorfields

column4: HE WAS IN BED WITH HIS BREECHES ON IN THE POCKETS OF WHICH WERE FOUND A NUMBER OF CARTRIDGES THE BLACK BELT HE HAD WORN AT CATO STREET
column5: he was in bed with his breeches on in the pockets of which were found a number of cartridges the black belt he had worn at cato street

column4: AND A MILITARY SASH
column5: and a military sash

column4: THE TRIAL OF THE CONSPIRATORS CAME ON SOME SIX WEEKS LATER AT THE OLD BAILEY
column5: the trial of the conspirators came on some six weeks later at the old bailey

column4: THISTLEWOOD MADE A LONG AND RAMBLING DEFENSE THE CHIEF FEATURES OF WHICH WERE ABUSE OF LORD SIDMOUTH AND THE VILIFICATION OF THE INFORMER EDWARDS
column5: thistlewood made a long and rambling defense the chief features of which were abuse of lord sidmouth and the vilification of the informer edwards

column4: SEVERAL OF THE OTHER PRISONERS TOOK THE SAME LINE AS REGARDS EDWARDS
column5: several of the other prisoners took the same line as regards edwards

column4: AND THERE SEEMS TO HAVE BEEN GOOD REASON FOR SUPPOSING THAT HE WAS A GREATER VILLAIN THAN ANY OF THOSE ARRAIGNED
column5: and there seems to have been good reason for supposing that he was a greater villain than any of those arraigned

column4: HE HAD BEEN IN A STATE OF ABJECT MISERY AND WHEN HE FIRST JOINED THE REFORMERS AS THE CATO STREET CONSPIRATORS CALLED THEMSELVES
column5: he had been in a state of abject misery and when he first joined the reformers as the cato street conspirators called themselves

column4: HE HAD NEITHER A BED TO LIE UPON NOR A COAT TO HIS BACK
column5: he had neither a bed to lie upon nor a coat to his back

column4: HIS SUDDEN ACCESS TO MEANS UNLIMITED WAS NO DOUBT DUE TO THE PROFITABLE ROLE HE SOON ADOPTED OF GOVERNMENT INFORMER AND SPY
column5: his sudden access to means unlimited was no doubt due to the profitable role he soon adopted of government informer and spy

column4: AND IT IS PRETTY CERTAIN THAT FOR SOME TIME HE SERVED BOTH SIDES
column5: and it is pretty certain that for some time he served both sides

column4: ON THE ONE INVEIGLING SILLY ENTHUSIASTS TO JOIN IN THE PLOT AND DENOUNCING THEM ON THE OTHER
column5: on the one inveigling silly enthusiasts to join in the plot and denouncing them on the other

column4: THE EMPLOYMENT OF EDWARDS AND THE MANNER IN WHICH THE CONSPIRATORS WERE ALLOWED TO COMMIT THEMSELVES FURTHER AND FURTHER BEFORE THE LAW WAS SET IN MOTION AGAINST THEM
column5: the employment of edwards and the manner in which the conspirators were allowed to commit themselves further and further before the law was set in motion against them

column4: WERE NOT ALTOGETHER CREDITABLE TO THE GOVERNMENT
column5: were not altogether creditable to the government

column4: IT WAS ASSERTED NOT WITHOUT FOUNDATION AT THESE TRIALS THAT EDWARDS REPEATEDLY INCITED THE ASSOCIATES HE WAS BETRAYING
column5: it was asserted not without foundation at these trials that edwards repeatedly incited the associates he was betraying

column4: TO COMMIT OUTRAGE TO SET FIRE TO HOUSES THROW HANDGRENADES INTO THE CARRIAGES OF MINISTERS
column5: to commit outrage to set fire to houses throw handgrenades into the carriages of ministers

column4: THAT HE WAS TO USE THISTLEWOOD'S WORDS A CONTRIVER INSTIGATOR AND ENTRAPPER
column5: that he was to use thistlewood's words a contriver instigator and entrapper

column4: THE GOVERNMENT WERE PROBABLY NOT PROUD OF THEIR AGENT FOR EDWARDS AFTER THE CONVICTION HAD BEEN ASSURED WENT ABROAD TO ENJOY IT WAS SAID
column5: the government were probably not proud of their agent for edwards after the conviction had been assured went abroad to enjoy it was said

column4: AN AMPLE PENSION SO LONG AS HE DID NOT RETURN TO ENGLAND
column5: an ample pension so long as he did not return to england

column4: FIVE OF THE CONSPIRATORS THISTLEWOOD INGS BRUNT DAVIDSON AND TIDD WERE SENTENCED TO DEATH
column5: five of the conspirators thistlewood ings brunt davidson and tidd were sentenced to death

column4: AND SUFFERED IN THE USUAL WAY IN FRONT OF NEWGATE WITH THE ADDITIONAL PENALTY OF DECAPITATION AS TRAITORS AFTER THEY HAD BEEN HANGED
column5: and suffered in the usual way in front of newgate with the additional penalty of decapitation as traitors after they had been hanged

column4: A CROWD AS GREAT AS ANY KNOWN COLLECTED IN THE OLD BAILEY TO SEE THE CEREMONY ABOUT WHICH THERE WERE SOME PECULIAR FEATURES WORTH RECORDING
column5: a crowd as great as any known collected in the old bailey to see the ceremony about which there were some peculiar features worth recording

column4: THE RECKLESS DEMEANOR OF ALL THE CONVICTS EXCEPT DAVIDSON WAS MOST MARKED THISTLEWOOD AND INGS SUCKED ORANGES ON THE SCAFFOLD
column5: the reckless demeanor of all the convicts except davidson was most marked thistlewood and ings sucked oranges on the scaffold

column4: THEY WITH BRUNT AND TIDD SCORNED THE ORDINARY'S MINISTRATIONS
column5: they with brunt and tidd scorned the ordinary's ministrations

column4: BUT INGS SAID HE HOPED GOD WOULD BE MORE MERCIFUL TO HIM THAN MEN HAD BEEN
column5: but ings said he hoped god would be more merciful to him than men had been

column4: INGS WAS ESPECIALLY DEFIANT HE SOUGHT TO CHEER DAVIDSON WHO SEEMED AFFECTED CRYING OUT
column5: ings was especially defiant he sought to cheer davidson who seemed affected crying out

column4: COME OLD COCKOFWAX IT WILL SOON BE OVER
column5: come old cockofwax it will soon be over

column4: AS THE EXECUTIONER FASTENED THE NOOSE HE NODDED TO A FRIEND HE SAW IN THE CROWD
column5: as the executioner fastened the noose he nodded to a friend he saw in the crowd

column4: AND CATCHING SIGHT OF THE COFFINS RANGED AROUND THE GALLOWS HE SMILED AT THE SHOW WITH CONTEMPTUOUS INDIFFERENCE
column5: and catching sight of the coffins ranged around the gallows he smiled at the show with contemptuous indifference

column4: HE ROARED OUT SNATCHES OF A SONG ABOUT DEATH OR LIBERTY AND JUST BEFORE HE WAS TURNED OFF
column5: he roared out snatches of a song about death or liberty and just before he was turned off

column4: YELLED OUT THREE CHEERS TO THE POPULACE WHOM HE FACED
column5: yelled out three cheers to the populace whom he faced

column4: HE TOLD THE EXECUTIONER TO DO IT TIDY TO PULL IT TIGHT AND WAS IN A STATE OF HYSTERICAL EXALTATION UP TO THE VERY LAST
column5: he told the executioner to do it tidy to pull it tight and was in a state of hysterical exaltation up to the very last

column4: DAVIDSON WHO WAS THE ONLY ONE WHO SEEMED TO REALIZE HIS AWFUL SITUATION LISTENED PATIENTLY AND WITH THANKFULNESS TO THE CHAPLAIN
column5: davidson who was the only one who seemed to realize his awful situation listened patiently and with thankfulness to the chaplain

column4: AND DIED IN A MANNER STRONGLY CONTRASTING WITH THAT OF HIS FELLOWS
column5: and died in a manner strongly contrasting with that of his fellows

column4: AFTER THE FIVE BODIES HAD HUNG FOR HALFANHOUR A MAN IN A MASK CAME FORWARD TO COMPLETE THE SENTENCE
column5: after the five bodies had hung for halfanhour a man in a mask came forward to complete the sentence

column4: CONTEMPORARY REPORTS STATE THAT FROM THE SKILLFUL MANNER IN WHICH HE PERFORMED THE DECAPITATION
column5: contemporary reports state that from the skillful manner in which he performed the decapitation

column4: HE WAS GENERALLY SUPPOSED TO BE A SURGEON
column5: he was generally supposed to be a surgeon

column4: BE THIS AS IT MAY THE WEAPON USED WAS ONLY AN ORDINARY AXE WHICH RATHER INDICATES THAT FORCE NOT SKILL WAS EMPLOYED
column5: be this as it may the weapon used was only an ordinary axe which rather indicates that force not skill was employed

column4: THIS AXE IS STILL IN EXISTENCE AND IS PRESERVED AT NEWGATE WITH VARIOUS OTHER UNPLEASANT CURIOSITIES
column5: this axe is still in existence and is preserved at newgate with various other unpleasant curiosities

column4: BUT IS ONLY AN ORDINARY COMMONPLACE TOOL
column5: but is only an ordinary commonplace tool

column4: THESE WERE THE LAST EXECUTIONS FOR HIGH TREASON BUT NOT THE LAST PRISONERS BY MANY WHO PASSED THROUGH NEWGATE CHARGED WITH SEDITION
column5: these were the last executions for high treason but not the last prisoners by many who passed through newgate charged with sedition

column4: ATTACKS UPON THE SOVEREIGN AS I HAVE SAID BECAME MORE COMMON AFTER THE ACCESSION OF THE YOUNG QUEEN VICTORIA IN EIGHTEEN THIRTYEIGHT
column5: attacks upon the sovereign as i have said became more common after the accession of the young queen victoria in eighteen thirtyeight

column4: IT WAS A FORM OF HIGH TREASON NOT UNKNOWN IN EARLIER REIGNS IN SEVENTEEN EIGHTYSIX A MAD WOMAN MARGARET NICHOLSON
column5: it was a form of high treason not unknown in earlier reigns in seventeen eightysix a mad woman margaret nicholson

column4: TRIED TO STAB GEORGE THE THIRD AS HE WAS ALIGHTING FROM HIS CARRIAGE AT THE GATE OF ST JAMES'S PALACE
column5: tried to stab george the third as he was alighting from his carriage at the gate of st james's palace

column4: SHE WAS SEIZED BEFORE SHE COULD DO ANY MISCHIEF
column5: she was seized before she could do any mischief

column4: AND EVENTUALLY LODGED IN BETHLEHEM HOSPITAL WHERE SHE DIED AFTER FORTY YEARS' DETENTION AT THE ADVANCED AGE OF ONE HUNDRED
column5: and eventually lodged in bethlehem hospital where she died after forty years' detention at the advanced age of one hundred

column4: AGAIN A SOLDIER BY NAME HATFIELD WHO HAD BEEN WOUNDED IN THE HEAD AND DISCHARGED FROM THE ARMY FOR UNSOUNDNESS OF MIND
column5: again a soldier by name hatfield who had been wounded in the head and discharged from the army for unsoundness of mind

column4: FIRED A PISTOL AT GEORGE THE THIRD FROM THE PIT OF DRURY LANE THEATRE IN EIGHTEEN HUNDRED
column5: fired a pistol at george the third from the pit of drury lane theatre in eighteen hundred

column4: WILLIAM THE FOURTH WAS ALSO THE VICTIM OF A MURDEROUS OUTRAGE ON ASCOT RACECOURSE IN EIGHTEEN THIRTYTWO
column5: william the fourth was also the victim of a murderous outrage on ascot racecourse in eighteen thirtytwo

column4: WHEN JOHN COLLINS A PERSON IN THE GARB OF A SAILOR OF WRETCHED APPEARANCE AND HAVING A WOODEN LEG
column5: when john collins a person in the garb of a sailor of wretched appearance and having a wooden leg

column4: THREW A STONE AT THE KING WHICH HIT HIM ON THE FOREHEAD BUT DID NO SERIOUS INJURY
column5: threw a stone at the king which hit him on the forehead but did no serious injury

column4: COLLINS WHEN CHARGED PLEADED THAT HE HAD LOST HIS LEG IN ACTION THAT HE HAD PETITIONED WITHOUT SUCCESS FOR A PENSION
column5: collins when charged pleaded that he had lost his leg in action that he had petitioned without success for a pension

column4: AND THAT AS HE WAS STARVING HE HAD RESOLVED ON THIS DESPERATE DEED
column5: and that as he was starving he had resolved on this desperate deed

column4: FEELING AS HE SAID THAT HE MIGHT AS WELL BE SHOT OR HANGED AS REMAIN IN SUCH A STATE
column5: feeling as he said that he might as well be shot or hanged as remain in such a state

column4: HE WAS EVENTUALLY SENTENCED TO DEATH BUT THE PLEA OF LUNACY WAS ALLOWED AND HE WAS CONFINED FOR LIFE
column5: he was eventually sentenced to death but the plea of lunacy was allowed and he was confined for life

column5: none of the foregoing attempts were however so dastardly or determined as that made by oxford upon our present gracious queen

column4: TWO YEARS AFTER SHE ASCENDED THE THRONE
column5: two years after she ascended the throne

column4: THE COWARDLY CRIME WAS PROBABLY ENCOURAGED BY THE FEARLESS AND CONFIDING MANNER IN WHICH THE QUEEN
column5: the cowardly crime was probably encouraged by the fearless and confiding manner in which the queen

column4: SECURE AS IT SEEMED IN THE AFFECTIONS OF HER LOYAL PEOPLE FREELY APPEARED IN PUBLIC
column5: secure as it seemed in the affections of her loyal people freely appeared in public

column5: oxford who was only nineteen at the time his offense was committed had been born at birmingham

column5: but he came as a lad to london and took service as a potboy to a publican

column5: from this he was promoted to barman and as such had charge of the business in various publichouses

column5: he left his last situation in april eighteen forty and established himself in lodgings in lambeth

column4: AFTER WHICH HE DEVOTED HIMSELF TO PISTOL PRACTICE IN SHOOTINGGALLERIES SOMETIMES IN LEICESTER SQUARE
column5: after which he devoted himself to pistol practice in shootinggalleries sometimes in leicester square

column4: SOMETIMES IN THE STRAND OR THE WEST END
column5: sometimes in the strand or the west end

column4: HIS ACQUAINTANCES OFTEN ASKED HIS OBJECT IN THIS BUT HE KEPT HIS OWN COUNSEL TILL THE TENTH JUNE
column5: his acquaintances often asked his object in this but he kept his own counsel till the tenth june

column4: ON THAT DAY OXFORD WAS ON THE WATCH AT BUCKINGHAM PALACE
column5: on that day oxford was on the watch at buckingham palace

column4: HE SAW PRINCE ALBERT RETURN THERE FROM A VISIT TO WOOLWICH AND THEN PASSED ON TO CONSTITUTION HILL
column5: he saw prince albert return there from a visit to woolwich and then passed on to constitution hill

column5: in order to keep up the credit of our house i have forged powers of attorney for the above sums and parties

column5: he went to the bank and found that no stocks stood in her name he called at once upon fauntleroy his client's bankers for an explanation

column5: declared that they had hitherto formed a high opinion of his honor integrity and goodness of disposition

column5: visited mr fauntleroy my application for books for him not having been attended i had no prayerbook to give him

column5: one was that of captain montgomery who assumed the aliases of colonel wallace and colonel morgan

column5: he thereupon conceived an idea of carrying her off and marrying her willy nilly at gretna green

column4: NO MORE CURIOUS INSTANCE OF THIS EVER OCCURRED THAN THE ASSAULT MADE BY ONE HOWARD UPON A MR MULLAY WITH INTENT TO ROB HIM
column5: no more curious instance of this ever occurred than the assault made by one howard upon a mr mullay with intent to rob him

column4: THE LATTER HAD ADVERTISED OFFERING A SUM OF ONE THOUSAND POUNDS TO ANYONE WHO WOULD INTRODUCE HIM TO SOME MERCANTILE EQUIPMENT
column5: the latter had advertised offering a sum of one thousand pounds to anyone who would introduce him to some mercantile equipment

column4: HOWARD REPLIED DESIRING MR MULLAY TO CALL UPON HIM IN A HOUSE IN RED LION SQUARE
column5: howard replied desiring mr mullay to call upon him in a house in red lion square

column4: MR MULLAY WENT AND A SECOND INTERVIEW WAS AGREED UPON WHEN A THIRD PERSON MR OWEN
column5: mr mullay went and a second interview was agreed upon when a third person mr owen

column4: THROUGH WHOSE INTEREST AN APPOINTMENT UNDER GOVERNMENT WAS TO BE OBTAINED FOR MULLAY WOULD BE PRESENT
column5: through whose interest an appointment under government was to be obtained for mullay would be present

column4: MR MULLAY CALLED AGAIN TAKING WITH HIM FIVE HUNDRED POUNDS IN CASH HOWARD DISCOVERED THIS AND HIS MANNER WAS VERY SUSPICIOUS
column5: mr mullay called again taking with him five hundred pounds in cash howard discovered this and his manner was very suspicious

column4: THERE WERE WEAPONS IN THE ROOM  A LONG KNIFE A HEAVY TRAPBALL BAT AND A POKER
column5: there were weapons in the room  a long knife a heavy trapball bat and a poker

column4: MR MULLAY BECAME ALARMED AND AS MR OWEN DID NOT APPEAR WITHDREW
column5: mr mullay became alarmed and as mr owen did not appear withdrew

column4: HOWARD STRANGE TO SAY MAKING NO ATTEMPT TO DETAIN HIM PROBABLY BECAUSE MULLAY PROMISED TO RETURN A FEW DAYS LATER AND TO BRING MORE MONEY
column5: howard strange to say making no attempt to detain him probably because mullay promised to return a few days later and to bring more money

column4: ON THIS RENEWED VISIT MR OWEN WAS STILL ABSENT AND MR MULLAY AGREED TO WRITE HIM A NOTE FROM A COPY HOWARD GAVE HIM
column5: on this renewed visit mr owen was still absent and mr mullay agreed to write him a note from a copy howard gave him

column4: WHILE THUS ENGAGED HOWARD THRUST THE POKER INTO THE FIRE
column5: while thus engaged howard thrust the poker into the fire

column4: MULLAY PROTESTED AND THEN HOWARD UNDER THE INFLUENCE OF UNGOVERNABLE RAGE AS IT SEEMED JUMPED UP
column5: mullay protested and then howard under the influence of ungovernable rage as it seemed jumped up

column4: LOCKED THE DOOR AND ATTACKED MULLAY VIOLENTLY WITH THE TRAPBALL BAT AND KNIFE
column5: locked the door and attacked mullay violently with the trapball bat and knife

column4: MULLAY DEFENDED HIMSELF AND MANAGED TO BREAK THE KNIFE BUT NOT BEFORE HE HAD CUT HIMSELF SEVERELY
column5: mullay defended himself and managed to break the knife but not before he had cut himself severely

column4: A LIFE AND DEATH STRUGGLE ENSUED MULLAY CRIED MURDER
column5: a life and death struggle ensued mullay cried murder

column4: HOWARD SWORE HE WOULD FINISH HIM BUT PROVED THE WEAKER OF THE TWO AND MULLAY GOT HIM DOWN ON THE FLOOR
column5: howard swore he would finish him but proved the weaker of the two and mullay got him down on the floor

column4: BY THIS TIME THE NEIGHBORS WERE AROUSED AND SEVERAL PEOPLE CAME TO THE SCENE OF THE AFFRAY
column5: by this time the neighbors were aroused and several people came to the scene of the affray

column4: HOWARD WAS SECURED GIVEN INTO CUSTODY AND COMMITTED TO NEWGATE
column5: howard was secured given into custody and committed to newgate

column4: THE DEFENSE HE SET UP WAS THAT MULLAY HAD USED EPITHETS TOWARDS HIM WHILE THEY WERE NEGOTIATING A BUSINESS MATTER
column5: the defense he set up was that mullay had used epithets towards him while they were negotiating a business matter

column4: AND THAT BEING AN IRRITABLE TEMPER HE HAD STRUCK MULLAY AFTER WHICH A VIOLENT SCUFFLE TOOK PLACE
column5: and that being an irritable temper he had struck mullay after which a violent scuffle took place

column4: IT WAS HOWEVER PROVED THAT HOWARD WAS IN NEEDY CIRCUMSTANCES AND THAT HIS PROPOSALS TO MR MULLAY COULD ONLY HAVE ORIGINATED IN A DESIRE TO ROB HIM
column5: it was however proved that howard was in needy circumstances and that his proposals to mr mullay could only have originated in a desire to rob him

column4: HE WAS FOUND GUILTY OF AN ASSAULT WITH INTENT AND SENTENCED TO TRANSPORTATION FOR FOURTEEN YEARS
column5: he was found guilty of an assault with intent and sentenced to transportation for fourteen years

column4: A MORE COMPLICATED AND ALTOGETHER MOST EXTRAORDINARY CASE OF ASSAULT WITH INTENT TO EXTORT MONEY OCCURRED A FEW YEARS LATER
column5: a more complicated and altogether most extraordinary case of assault with intent to extort money occurred a few years later

column4: IT WAS PERPETRATED UPON A RESPECTABLE COUNTRY SOLICITOR
column5: it was perpetrated upon a respectable country solicitor

column4: MR GEE OF BISHOP STORTFORD WHO ADMINISTERED THE ESTATE OF A CERTAIN MR CANNING DECEASED
column5: mr gee of bishop stortford who administered the estate of a certain mr canning deceased

column4: THIS MR CANNING HAD LEFT HIS WIDOW A LIFE INTEREST IN TWO THOUSAND POUNDS SO LONG AS SHE REMAINED UNMARRIED
column5: this mr canning had left his widow a life interest in two thousand pounds so long as she remained unmarried

column4: THE MONEY WENT AFTER HER TO HER CHILDREN
column5: the money went after her to her children

column4: MR GEE HAD INVESTED ONE THOUSAND TWO HUNDRED POUNDS OF THIS AND WAS SEEKING HOW BEST TO PLACE THE REMAINING EIGHT HUNDRED POUNDS
column5: mr gee had invested one thousand two hundred pounds of this and was seeking how best to place the remaining eight hundred pounds

column4: WHEN HE WAS ASKED TO MEET A MR HEATH IN LONDON WITH REGARD TO THE SALE OF CERTAIN LANDS AT BISHOP STORTFORD
column5: when he was asked to meet a mr heath in london with regard to the sale of certain lands at bishop stortford

column4: AN APPOINTMENT WAS MADE AND KEPT BY MR GEE
column5: an appointment was made and kept by mr gee

column4: BUT ON ARRIVAL HE WAS MET BY A YOUNG SAILOR WITH A LETTER WHICH BEGGED MR GEE TO GO TO HEATH'S HOUSE AS THE LATTER WAS NOT WELL
column5: but on arrival he was met by a young sailor with a letter which begged mr gee to go to heath's house as the latter was not well

column4: MR GEE WENT IN THE COACH SENT FOR HIM AND ALIGHTED AT TWENTYSEVEN YORK STREET WEST COMMERCIAL ROAD
column5: mr gee went in the coach sent for him and alighted at twentyseven york street west commercial road

column4: THE COACH IMMEDIATELY DROVE OFF MR GEE ENTERED THE HOUSE ASKED FOR MR HEATH WAS TOLD HE WOULD FIND HIM IN THE BACK KITCHEN AT BREAKFAST
column5: the coach immediately drove off mr gee entered the house asked for mr heath was told he would find him in the back kitchen at breakfast

column4: HE WAS ABOUT TO DESCEND THE STAIRS WHEN THREE PERSONS ONE OF THEM THE YOUNG SAILOR
column5: he was about to descend the stairs when three persons one of them the young sailor

column4: FELL UPON HIM AND IN SPITE OF HIS RESISTANCE CARRIED HIM INTO A SORT OF DEN PARTITIONED OFF AT THE END OF THE BACK KITCHEN
column5: fell upon him and in spite of his resistance carried him into a sort of den partitioned off at the end of the back kitchen

column4: THERE HE WAS SEATED ON SOME SORT OF WOODEN BENCH AND SECURELY FASTENED
column5: there he was seated on some sort of wooden bench and securely fastened

column4: A CHAIN FIXED TO STAPLES AT HIS BACK PASSED ROUND HIS CHEST UNDER HIS ARMS AND WAS PADLOCKED ON THE LEFT SIDE
column5: a chain fixed to staples at his back passed round his chest under his arms and was padlocked on the left side

column4: HIS FEET WERE BOUND WITH CORDS AND MADE FAST TO RINGS IN THE FLOOR THUS MANACLED ONE OF THE PARTY WHO PRETENDED TO BE MRS CANNING'S BROTHER
column5: his feet were bound with cords and made fast to rings in the floor thus manacled one of the party who pretended to be mrs canning's brother

column4: ADDRESSED HIM INSISTING THAT HE SHOULD FORTHWITH SIGN A CHEQUE FOR THE EIGHT HUNDRED POUNDS OF THE CANNING INHERITANCE STILL UNINVESTED
column5: addressed him insisting that he should forthwith sign a cheque for the eight hundred pounds of the canning inheritance still uninvested

column4: AND WRITE AN ORDER SUFFICIENT TO SECURE THE SURRENDER OF THE OTHER ONE THOUSAND TWO HUNDRED POUNDS
column5: and write an order sufficient to secure the surrender of the other one thousand two hundred pounds

column4: MR GEE AT FIRST STOUTLY REFUSED
column5: mr gee at first stoutly refused

column4: THEN AS THEY WARNED HIM THAT HE WOULD BE KEPT A PRISONER IN TOTAL DARKNESS IN THIS HORRIBLE DEN UNTIL HE AGREED TO THEIR DEMANDS
column5: then as they warned him that he would be kept a prisoner in total darkness in this horrible den until he agreed to their demands

column4: HE GAVE IN AND SIGNED THE DOCUMENTS THUS ILLEGALLY EXTORTED
column5: he gave in and signed the documents thus illegally extorted

column4: ONE WAS A CHEQUE FOR EIGHT HUNDRED POUNDS ON HIS BANKERS THE OTHER AN ORDER TO MR BELL OF NEWPORT ESSEX REQUESTING THE SURRENDER OF A DEED
column5: one was a cheque for eight hundred pounds on his bankers the other an order to mr bell of newport essex requesting the surrender of a deed

column4: HIS CAPTORS HAVING THUS SUCCEEDED IN THEIR DESIGNS LEFT HIM NO DOUBT TO REALIZE THE MONEY
column5: his captors having thus succeeded in their designs left him no doubt to realize the money

column4: THE DOOR OF HIS PLACE OF DURANCE STOOD OPEN AND MR GEE BEGAN TO CONSIDER WHETHER HE MIGHT NOT ESCAPE
column5: the door of his place of durance stood open and mr gee began to consider whether he might not escape

column4: FOR THREE HOURS HE STRUGGLED WITHOUT SUCCESS WITH HIS BONDS
column5: for three hours he struggled without success with his bonds

column4: BUT AT LENGTH MANAGED TO WRIGGLE OUT OF THE CHAIN WHICH CONFINED HIS BODY AND SOON LOOSENED THE ROPES ROUND HIS FEET
column5: but at length managed to wriggle out of the chain which confined his body and soon loosened the ropes round his feet

column4: THUS FREE HE ELUDED THE VIGILANCE OF TWO OF THE PARTY WHO WERE AT DINNER IN THE FRONT KITCHEN
column5: thus free he eluded the vigilance of two of the party who were at dinner in the front kitchen

column4: AND CREEPING OUT INTO THE GARDEN AT THE BACK CLIMBED THE WALL AND GOT INTO THE STREET
column5: and creeping out into the garden at the back climbed the wall and got into the street

column4: HIS FIRST ACT WAS TO SEND A MESSENGER TO STOP THE CHEQUE AND THE ORDER TO MR BELL HIS NEXT TO SEEK THE HELP OF THE POLICE
column5: his first act was to send a messenger to stop the cheque and the order to mr bell his next to seek the help of the police

column4: TWO BOW STREET RUNNERS WERE DISPATCHED TO THE HOUSE IN YORK STREET WHICH HAD EVIDENTLY BEEN TAKEN ON PURPOSE FOR THE OUTRAGE
column5: two bow street runners were dispatched to the house in york street which had evidently been taken on purpose for the outrage

column4: THERE WAS NO FURNITURE IN THE PLACE AND THE DEN IN THE KITCHEN HAD BEEN RECENTLY AND SPECIALLY CONSTRUCTED OF BOARDS OF IMMENSE STRENGTH AND THICKNESS
column5: there was no furniture in the place and the den in the kitchen had been recently and specially constructed of boards of immense strength and thickness

column4: IT WAS A CELL FIVE FEET BY THREE WITHIN ANOTHER THE INTERVENING BEING FILLED WITH RAMMED EARTH TO DEADEN THE SOUND
column5: it was a cell five feet by three within another the intervening being filled with rammed earth to deaden the sound

column4: THE CHRONICLES OF NEWGATE VOLUME TWO BY ARTHUR GRIFFITHS SECTION FIFTEEN NEWGATE NOTORIETIES PART THREE
column5: the chronicles of newgate volume two by arthur griffiths section fifteen newgate notorieties part three

column4: ON THE ARRIVAL OF THE POLICE THE HOUSE WAS EMPTY
column5: on the arrival of the police the house was empty

column4: THE TWO MEN ON GUARD HAD GONE OFF IMMEDIATELY AFTER MR GEE HAD ESCAPED BUT THEY RETURNED LATER IN THE DAY AND WERE APPREHENDED
column5: the two men on guard had gone off immediately after mr gee had escaped but they returned later in the day and were apprehended

column4: INQUIRIES SET ON FOOT ALSO ELICITED THE SUSPICION THAT THE PERSON WHO HAD REPRESENTED MRS CANNING'S BROTHER
column5: inquiries set on foot also elicited the suspicion that the person who had represented mrs canning's brother

column4: WAS A BLIND MAN NAMED EDWARDS WHO HAD TAKEN THIS HOUSE IN YORK STREET AND WHO WAS KNOWN TO BE A FREQUENT VISITOR AT MRS CANNING'S
column5: was a blind man named edwards who had taken this house in york street and who was known to be a frequent visitor at mrs canning's

column4: A WATCH WAS SET ON HIM AT HER HOUSE WHERE HE WAS SOON AFTERWARDS ARRESTED
column5: a watch was set on him at her house where he was soon afterwards arrested

column4: EDWARDS WHOM MR GEE EASILY IDENTIFIED WITH THE OTHERS AT ONCE ADMITTED THAT HE WAS THE PRIME MOVER OF THE CONSPIRACY
column5: edwards whom mr gee easily identified with the others at once admitted that he was the prime mover of the conspiracy

column4: HE HAD SOUGHT BY ALL LEGAL MEANS TO OBTAIN POSSESSION OF THE TWO THOUSAND POUNDS BUT HAD FAILED AND HAD HAD RECOURSE TO MORE VIOLENT MEANS
column5: he had sought by all legal means to obtain possession of the two thousand pounds but had failed and had had recourse to more violent means

column4: IT TURNED OUT THAT HE WAS REALLY MARRIED TO MRS CANNING
column5: it turned out that he was really married to mrs canning

column4: BOTH HAVING BEEN RECOGNIZED BY THE CLERGYMAN WHO HAD PERFORMED THE CEREMONY AND THE ASSAULT HAD BEEN COMMITTED TO SECURE THE MONEY
column5: both having been recognized by the clergyman who had performed the ceremony and the assault had been committed to secure the money

column4: WHICH MRS CANNING HAD LOST BY REMARRIAGE
column5: which mrs canning had lost by remarriage

column4: ALL THREE MEN WERE COMMITTED FOR TRIAL ALTHOUGH EDWARDS WISHED TO EXCULPATE THE OTHERS AS HAVING ONLY ACTED UNDER HIS ORDER
column5: all three men were committed for trial although edwards wished to exculpate the others as having only acted under his order

column4: AT THE TRIAL THE INDICTMENT CHARGING THEM WITH FELONY COULD NOT BE SUSTAINED BUT THEY WERE FOUND GUILTY OF CONSPIRACY AND ASSAULT
column5: at the trial the indictment charging them with felony could not be sustained but they were found guilty of conspiracy and assault

column4: EDWARDS WAS SENTENCED TO TWO YEARS' IMPRISONMENT IN NEWGATE
column5: edwards was sentenced to two years' imprisonment in newgate

column4: WEEDON AND LECASSER TO TWELVE AND SIX MONTHS RESPECTIVELY IN COLDBATH FIELDS
column5: weedon and lecasser to twelve and six months respectively in coldbath fields

column4: AT NO PERIOD COULD THIEVES IN LONDON OR ELSEWHERE HAVE PROSPERED HAD THEY BEEN UNABLE TO DISPOSE OF THEIR ILLGOTTEN GOODS
column5: at no period could thieves in london or elsewhere have prospered had they been unable to dispose of their illgotten goods

column4: THE TRADE OF FENCE OR RECEIVER THEREFORE IS VERY NEARLY AS OLD AS THE CRIMES WHICH IT SO OBVIOUSLY FOSTERED
column5: the trade of fence or receiver therefore is very nearly as old as the crimes which it so obviously fostered

column4: ONE OF THE MOST NOTORIOUS AND FOR A TIME MOST SUCCESSFUL PRACTITIONERS IN THIS ILLICIT TRADE PASSED THROUGH NEWGATE IN EIGHTEEN THIRTYONE
column5: one of the most notorious and for a time most successful practitioners in this illicit trade passed through newgate in eighteen thirtyone

column4: THE NAME OF IKEY SOLOMONS WAS LONG REMEMBERED BY THIEF AND THIEFTAKER
column5: the name of ikey solomons was long remembered by thief and thieftaker

column4: HE BEGAN AS AN ITINERANT STREET VENDOR AT EIGHT AT TEN HE PASSED BAD MONEY
column5: he began as an itinerant street vendor at eight at ten he passed bad money

column4: AT FOURTEEN HE WAS A PICKPOCKET AND A DUFFER OR A SELLER OF SHAM GOODS
column5: at fourteen he was a pickpocket and a duffer or a seller of sham goods

column4: HE EARLY SAW THE PROFITS TO BE MADE OUT OF PURCHASING STOLEN GOODS BUT COULD NOT EMBARK IN IT AT FIRST FOR WANT OF CAPITAL
column5: he early saw the profits to be made out of purchasing stolen goods but could not embark in it at first for want of capital

column4: HE WAS TAKEN UP WHEN STILL IN HIS TEENS FOR STEALING A POCKETBOOK AND WAS SENTENCED TO TRANSPORTATION BUT DID NOT GET BEYOND THE HULKS AT CHATHAM
column5: he was taken up when still in his teens for stealing a pocketbook and was sentenced to transportation but did not get beyond the hulks at chatham

column4: ON HIS RELEASE AN UNCLE A SLOPSELLER IN CHATHAM GAVE HIM A SITUATION AS BARKER OR SALESMAN
column5: on his release an uncle a slopseller in chatham gave him a situation as barker or salesman

column4: AT WHICH HE REALIZED ONE HUNDRED FIFTY POUNDS WITHIN A COUPLE OF YEARS
column5: at which he realized one hundred fifty pounds within a couple of years

column4: WITH THIS CAPITAL HE RETURNED TO LONDON AND SET UP AS A FENCE
column5: with this capital he returned to london and set up as a fence

column4: HE HAD SUCH GREAT APTITUDE FOR BUSINESS AND SUCH A THOROUGH KNOWLEDGE OF THE REAL VALUE OF GOODS
column5: he had such great aptitude for business and such a thorough knowledge of the real value of goods

column4: THAT HE WAS SOON ADMITTED TO BE ONE OF THE BEST JUDGES KNOWN OF ALL KINDS OF PROPERTY FROM A GLASS BOTTLE TO A FIVE HUNDRED GUINEA CHRONOMETER
column5: that he was soon admitted to be one of the best judges known of all kinds of property from a glass bottle to a five hundred guinea chronometer

column4: BUT HE NEVER PAID MORE THAN A FIXED PRICE FOR ALL ARTICLES OF THE SAME CLASS WHATEVER THEIR INTRINSIC VALUE
column5: but he never paid more than a fixed price for all articles of the same class whatever their intrinsic value

column4: THUS A WATCH WAS PAID FOR AS A WATCH WHETHER IT WAS OF GOLD OR SILVER A PIECE OF LINEN AS SUCH WHETHER THE STUFF WAS COARSE OR FINE
column5: thus a watch was paid for as a watch whether it was of gold or silver a piece of linen as such whether the stuff was coarse or fine

column4: THIS RULE IN DEALING WITH STOLEN GOODS CONTINUES TO THIS DAY AND HAS MADE THE FORTUNE OF MANY SINCE IKEY
column5: this rule in dealing with stolen goods continues to this day and has made the fortune of many since ikey

column4: SOLOMONS ALSO ESTABLISHED A SYSTEM OF PROVINCIAL AGENCY BY WHICH STOLEN GOODS WERE PASSED ON FROM LONDON TO THE SEAPORTS AND SO ABROAD
column5: solomons also established a system of provincial agency by which stolen goods were passed on from london to the seaports and so abroad

column4: JEWELS WERE RESET
column5: jewels were reset

column4: DIAMONDS REFACED ALL MARKS BY WHICH OTHER ARTICLES MIGHT BE IDENTIFIED THE SELVAGES OF LINEN THE STAMPS ON SHOES
column5: diamonds refaced all marks by which other articles might be identified the selvages of linen the stamps on shoes

column4: THE NUMBER AND NAMES ON WATCHES WERE CAREFULLY REMOVED OR OBLITERATED AFTER THE GOODS PASSED OUT OF HIS HANDS
column5: the number and names on watches were carefully removed or obliterated after the goods passed out of his hands

column4: ON ONE OCCASION THE WHOLE OF THE PROCEEDS OF A ROBBERY FROM A BOOT SHOP WAS TRACED TO SOLOMONS'
column5: on one occasion the whole of the proceeds of a robbery from a boot shop was traced to solomons'

column4: THE OWNER CAME WITH THE POLICE AND WAS MORALLY CONVINCED THAT IT WAS HIS PROPERTY
column5: the owner came with the police and was morally convinced that it was his property

column4: BUT COULD NOT POSITIVELY IDENTIFY IT AND IKEY DEFIED THEM TO REMOVE A SINGLE SHOE
column5: but could not positively identify it and ikey defied them to remove a single shoe

column4: IN THE END THE INJURED BOOTMAKER AGREED TO BUY BACK HIS STOLEN STOCK
column5: in the end the injured bootmaker agreed to buy back his stolen stock

column4: AT THE PRICE SOLOMONS HAD PAID FOR IT AND IT COST HIM ABOUT A HUNDRED POUNDS TO RESTOCK HIS SHOP WITH HIS OWN GOODS
column5: at the price solomons had paid for it and it cost him about a hundred pounds to restock his shop with his own goods

column4: AS A GENERAL RULE IKEY SOLOMONS CONFINED HIS PURCHASES TO SMALL ARTICLES MOSTLY OF JEWELERY AND PLATE
column5: as a general rule ikey solomons confined his purchases to small articles mostly of jewelery and plate

column4: WHICH HE KEPT CONCEALED IN A HIDINGPLACE WITH A TRAPDOOR JUST UNDER HIS BED
column5: which he kept concealed in a hidingplace with a trapdoor just under his bed

column4: HE LIVED IN ROSEMARY LANE AND SOMETIMES HE HAD AS MUCH AS TWENTY THOUSAND POUNDS WORTH OF GOODS SECRETED ON THE PREMISES
column5: he lived in rosemary lane and sometimes he had as much as twenty thousand pounds worth of goods secreted on the premises

column4: WHEN HIS TRADE WAS BUSIEST HE SET UP A SECOND ESTABLISHMENT AT THE HEAD OF WHICH ALTHOUGH HE WAS MARRIED
column5: when his trade was busiest he set up a second establishment at the head of which although he was married

column4: HE PUT ANOTHER LADY WITH WHOM HE WAS ON INTIMATE TERMS
column5: he put another lady with whom he was on intimate terms

column4: THE SECOND HOUSE WAS IN LOWER QUEEN STREET ISLINGTON AND HE USED IT FOR SOME TIME AS A DEPOT FOR VALUABLES
column5: the second house was in lower queen street islington and he used it for some time as a depot for valuables

column4: BUT IT WAS EVENTUALLY DISCOVERED BY MRS SOLOMONS A VERY JEALOUS WIFE
column5: but it was eventually discovered by mrs solomons a very jealous wife

column4: AND THIS WITH THE DANGER ARISING FROM AN EXTENSIVE ROBBERY OF WATCHES IN CHEAPSIDE IN WHICH IKEY WAS IMPLICATED AS A RECEIVER
column5: and this with the danger arising from an extensive robbery of watches in cheapside in which ikey was implicated as a receiver

column4: LED HIM TO THINK SERIOUSLY OF TRYING HIS FORTUNES IN ANOTHER LAND
column5: led him to think seriously of trying his fortunes in another land

column4: HE WAS ABOUT TO EMIGRATE TO NEW SOUTH WALES WHEN HE WAS ARRESTED AT ISLINGTON AND COMMITTED TO NEWGATE ON A CHARGE OF RECEIVING STOLEN GOODS
column5: he was about to emigrate to new south wales when he was arrested at islington and committed to newgate on a charge of receiving stolen goods

column4: WHILE THUS INCARCERATED HE MANAGED TO ESCAPE FROM CUSTODY BUT NOT ACTUALLY FROM JAIL BY AN INGENIOUS CONTRIVANCE WHICH IS WORTH MENTIONING
column5: while thus incarcerated he managed to escape from custody but not actually from jail by an ingenious contrivance which is worth mentioning

column4: HE CLAIMED TO BE ADMITTED TO BAIL AND WAS TAKEN FROM NEWGATE ON A WRIT OF HABEAS BEFORE ONE OF THE JUDGES SITTING AT WESTMINSTER
column5: he claimed to be admitted to bail and was taken from newgate on a writ of habeas before one of the judges sitting at westminster

column4: HE WAS CONVEYED IN A COACH DRIVEN BY A CONFEDERATE AND UNDER THE ESCORT OF A COUPLE OF TURNKEYS
column5: he was conveyed in a coach driven by a confederate and under the escort of a couple of turnkeys

column4: SOLOMONS WHILE WAITING TO APPEAR IN COURT PERSUADED THE TURNKEYS TO TAKE HIM TO A PUBLICHOUSE WHERE ALL MIGHT REFRESH
column5: solomons while waiting to appear in court persuaded the turnkeys to take him to a publichouse where all might refresh

column4: WHILE THERE HE WAS JOINED BY HIS WIFE AND OTHER FRIENDS
column5: while there he was joined by his wife and other friends

column4: AFTER A SHORT CAROUSE THE PRISONER WENT INTO WESTMINSTER HIS CASE WAS HEARD BAIL REFUSED AND HE WAS ORDERED BACK TO NEWGATE
column5: after a short carouse the prisoner went into westminster his case was heard bail refused and he was ordered back to newgate

column4: BUT HE ONCE MORE PERSUADED THE TURNKEYS TO PAUSE AT THE PUBLIC WHERE MORE LIQUOR WAS CONSUMED
column5: but he once more persuaded the turnkeys to pause at the public where more liquor was consumed

column4: WHEN THE JOURNEY WAS RESUMED MRS SOLOMONS ACCOMPANIED HER HUSBAND IN THE COACH HALFWAY TO NEWGATE SHE WAS TAKEN WITH A FIT
column5: when the journey was resumed mrs solomons accompanied her husband in the coach halfway to newgate she was taken with a fit

column4: ONE TURNKEY WAS STUPIDLY DRUNK AND IKEY PERSUADED THE OTHER WHO WAS NOT MUCH BETTER
column5: one turnkey was stupidly drunk and ikey persuaded the other who was not much better

column4: TO LET THE COACH CHANGE AND PASS PETTICOAT LANE EN ROUTE TO THE JAIL WHERE THE SUFFERING WOMAN MIGHT BE HANDED OVER TO HER FRIENDS
column5: to let the coach change and pass petticoat lane en route to the jail where the suffering woman might be handed over to her friends

column4: ON STOPPING AT A DOOR IN THIS LOW STREET IKEY JUMPED OUT RAN INTO THE HOUSE SLAMMING THE DOOR BEHIND HIM
column5: on stopping at a door in this low street ikey jumped out ran into the house slamming the door behind him

column4: HE PASSED THROUGH AND OUT AT THE BACK AND WAS SOON BEYOND PURSUIT
column5: he passed through and out at the back and was soon beyond pursuit

column4: BYANDBY THE TURNKEYS SOBERED BY THEIR LOSS RETURNED TO NEWGATE ALONE AND PLEADED IN EXCUSE THAT THEY HAD BEEN DRUGGED
column5: byandby the turnkeys sobered by their loss returned to newgate alone and pleaded in excuse that they had been drugged

column4: IKEY LEFT NO TRACES AND THE POLICE COULD HEAR NOTHING OF HIM HE HAD IN FACT GONE OUT OF THE COUNTRY TO COPENHAGEN WHENCE HE PASSED ON TO NEW YORK
column5: ikey left no traces and the police could hear nothing of him he had in fact gone out of the country to copenhagen whence he passed on to new york

column4: THERE HE DEVOTED HIMSELF TO THE CIRCULATION OF FORGED NOTES HE WAS ALSO ANXIOUS TO DO BUSINESS IN WATCHES
column5: there he devoted himself to the circulation of forged notes he was also anxious to do business in watches

column4: AND BEGGED HIS WIFE TO SEND HIM OVER A CONSIGNMENT OF CHEAP RIGHTEOUS WATCHES OR SUCH AS HAD BEEN HONESTLY OBTAINED AND NOT ON THE CROSS
column5: and begged his wife to send him over a consignment of cheap righteous watches or such as had been honestly obtained and not on the cross

column4: BUT MRS SOLOMONS COULD NOT RESIST THE TEMPTATION TO DABBLE IN STOLEN GOODS AND SHE WAS FOUND SHIPPING WATCHES OF THE WRONG CATEGORY TO NEW YORK
column5: but mrs solomons could not resist the temptation to dabble in stolen goods and she was found shipping watches of the wrong category to new york

column4: FOR THIS SHE RECEIVED A SENTENCE OF FOURTEEN YEARS' TRANSPORTATION AND WAS SENT TO VAN DIEMEN'S LAND
column5: for this she received a sentence of fourteen years' transportation and was sent to van diemen's land

column4: IKEY JOINED HER AT HOBART TOWN WHERE THEY SET UP A GENERAL SHOP AND SOON BEGAN TO PROSPER
column5: ikey joined her at hobart town where they set up a general shop and soon began to prosper

column4: HE WAS HOWEVER RECOGNIZED AND ERE LONG AN ORDER CAME OUT FROM HOME FOR HIS ARREST AND TRANSFER TO ENGLAND
column5: he was however recognized and ere long an order came out from home for his arrest and transfer to england

column4: WHICH PRESENTLY FOLLOWED AND AGAIN FOUND HIMSELF AN INMATE OF NEWGATE WAITING TRIAL AS A RECEIVER AND A PRISONBREAKER
column5: which presently followed and again found himself an inmate of newgate waiting trial as a receiver and a prisonbreaker

column5: the first of whom has added to the british language a synonym for illegal suppression

column5: and of these bishop and williams who were guilty of many peculiar atrocities ended their murderous careers in front of the debtors' door at newgate

column5: bishop whose real name was head married a halfsister of williams' williams was a professional resurrectionist or bodysnatcher

column5: a trade almost openly countenanced when subjects for the anatomy schools were only to be got by rifling graves or worse

column5: bishop was a carpenter but having been suddenly thrown out of work he joined his brotherinlaw in his line of business

column4: AFTER A LITTLE
column5: after a little

column5: bishop got weary of the dangers and fatigues of exhumation and proposed to williams that instead of disinterring they should murder their subjects

column5: bishop confessed that he was moved to this by the example of burke and hare

column5: they pursued their terrible trade for five years without scruple and without detection

column5: eventually the law overtook them but almost by accident

column5: they presented themselves about noon one day at the dissecting room of king's college hospital accompanied by a third man

column5: an avowed snatcher and habitu of the fortune of war a publichouse in smithfield frequented openly by men of this awful profession

column4: THIS MAN MAY ASKED THE PORTER AT KING'S COLLEGE IF HE WANTED ANYTHING THE EUPHEMISM FOR OFFERING A BODY
column5: this man may asked the porter at king's college if he wanted anything the euphemism for offering a body

column4: THE PORTER ASKED WHAT HE HAD GOT AND THE ANSWER WAS A MALE SUBJECT
column5: the porter asked what he had got and the answer was a male subject

column5: reference was made to mr partridge the demonstrator in anatomy

column5: and after some haggling they agreed on a price and in the afternoon the snatchers brought a hamper which contained a body in a sack

column5: the porter received it but from its freshness became suspicious of foul play

column5: mr partridge was sent for and he with some of the students soon decided that the corpse had not died a natural death

column5: the snatchers were detained the police sent for and arrest followed as a matter of course

column5: an inquest was held on the body which was identified as that of an italian boy

column5: carlo ferrari who made a living by exhibiting white mice about the streets

column5: and the jury returned a verdict of willful murder against persons unknown expressing a strong opinion that bishop

column5: williams and may had been concerned in the transaction

column5: meanwhile a search had been made at nova scotia gardens bethnal green where bishop and williams lived

column5: at first nothing peculiar was found but at a second search the backgarden ground was dug up

column5: and in one corner at some depth a bundle of clothes were unearthed which with a hairy cap

column4: WERE KNOWN TO BE WHAT FERRARI HAD WORN WHEN LAST SEEN
column5: were known to be what ferrari had worn when last seen

column5: in another portion of the garden more clothing partly male and partly female was discovered

column5: plainly pointing to the perpetration of other crimes

column5: these facts were represented before the police magistrate

column5: who examined bishop and his fellows and further incriminating evidence adduced to the effect that the prisoners had bartered for a coach to carry a stiff 'un

column5: they had also been seen to leave their cottage carrying out a sack with something heavy inside on this they were fully committed to newgate for trial

column5: this trial came off in due course at the central criminal court where the prisoners were charged on two counts

column5: one that of the murder of the italian boy the other that of a boy unknown

column5: the evidence from first to last was circumstantial

column5: but the jury after a short deliberation did not hesitate to bring in a verdict of guilty and all three were condemned to death

column5: shortly before the day fixed for execution bishop made a full confession the bulk of which bore the impress of truth

column5: although it included statements that were improbable and unsubstantiated

column5: he asserted that the victim was a lincolnshire lad and not an italian boy although the latter was fully proved

column5: according to the confession death had been inflicted by drowning in a well whereas the medical evidence all pointed to violence

column4: IT WAS HOWEVER PRETTY CLEAR THAT THIS VICTIM LIKE PRECEDING ONES HAD BEEN LURED TO NOVA SCOTIA GARDENS AND THERE DRUGGED WITH A LARGE DOSE OF LAUDANUM
column5: it was however pretty clear that this victim like preceding ones had been lured to nova scotia gardens and there drugged with a large dose of laudanum

column4: WHILE THEY WERE IN A STATE OF INSENSIBILITY THE MURDER WAS COMMITTED
column5: while they were in a state of insensibility the murder was committed

column5: bishop's confession was endorsed by williams and the immediate result was the respite of may

column5: a very painful scene occurred in newgate when the news of his escape from death was imparted to may

column5: he fainted and the warrant of mercy nearly proved his deathblow the other two looked on at his agitation with an indifference amounting to apathy

column5: the execution took place a week or two later in the presence of such a crowd as had not been seen near newgate for years

column4: I WILL CLOSE THIS CHAPTER WITH A BRIEF ACCOUNT OF ANOTHER MURDER
column5: i will close this chapter with a brief account of another murder

column5: the memory of which is still fresh in the minds of londoners although half a century has passed since it was committed

column5: the horror with which greenacre's crime struck the town was unparalleled since the time when catherine hayes slew her husband

column5: there were many features of resemblance in these crimes

column5: the decapitation and dismemberment the bestowal of the remains in various parts of the town the preservation of the head in spirits of wine

column5: in the hope that the features might some day be recognized were alike in both

column5: the murder in both cases was long a profound mystery in this which i am now describing

column5: a bricklayer found a human trunk near some new buildings in the edgeware road one morning in the last week of eighteen thirtysix

column5: the inquest on these remains which medical examination showed to be those of a female

column5: returned a verdict of willful murder against some person unknown

column5: where a workman found a bundle containing two human legs in a drain

column5: and there was now evidence sufficient to establish conclusively that the woman thus collected piecemeal had been barbarously done to death

column5: this brought suspicion on to a certain james greenacre

column5: whom she was to have married and in whose company she had left her own lodgings to visit his in camberwell

column5: greenacre a stout middleaged man wrapped in a brown greatcoat assumed an air of insolent bravado

column5: suspicion grew almost to certainty as the evidence was unfolded

column5: mrs brown was a washerwoman supposed to be worth some money hence greenacre's offer of marriage

column5: they were apparently good friends when last seen together at a neighbor's where they seemed perfectly happy and sociable and eager for the wedding day

column5: but greenacre in his confession pretended that he and his intended had quarreled over her property or the want of it

column5: this wrapped up in a silk handkerchief

column5: while conversing with mrs brown he declared the unfortunate woman was rocking herself to and fro in a chair

column5: but the medical evidence was clear that the decapitation had been effected during life and the jury after a short deliberation

column5: the most extensive and systematic robberies were planned and carried out so as long to escape detection

column5: came to light in this same year eighteen fortyone

column5: but it was long before the public realized that the fraudulent clerk and the great theatrical manager were one and the same person
