column5: watts's crime was discovered by the secretary of the globe company who came suddenly upon the extensive falsification of the passbook

column4: AN INQUIRY WAS AT ONCE SET ON FOOT AND THE FRAUDS WERE TRACED TO WATTS
column5: an inquiry was at once set on foot and the frauds were traced to watts

column4: THE LATTER WHEN FIRST TAXED WITH HIS OFFENSE PROTESTED HIS INNOCENCE BOLDLY AND POSITIVELY DENIED ALL KNOWLEDGE OF THE AFFAIR
column5: the latter when first taxed with his offense protested his innocence boldly and positively denied all knowledge of the affair

column4: AND HE HAD SO CLEVERLY DESTROYED ALL TRACES THAT IT WAS NOT EASY TO BRING HOME THE CHARGE
column5: and he had so cleverly destroyed all traces that it was not easy to bring home the charge

column4: BUT IT WAS PROVED THAT WATTS HAD APPROPRIATED ONE CHEQUE FOR FOURTEEN HUNDRED POUNDS
column5: but it was proved that watts had appropriated one cheque for fourteen hundred pounds

column4: WHICH HE HAD PAID INTO HIS OWN BANKERS AND ON THIS HE WAS COMMITTED TO NEWGATE FOR TRIAL
column5: which he had paid into his own bankers and on this he was committed to newgate for trial

column4: THERE WERE TWO COUNTS IN THE INDICTMENT ONE FOR STEALING A CHEQUE VALUE FOURTEEN HUNDRED POUNDS THE SECOND FOR STEALING A BIT OF PAPER VALUE ONE PENNY
column5: there were two counts in the indictment one for stealing a cheque value fourteen hundred pounds the second for stealing a bit of paper value one penny

column4: THE JURY FOUND HIM GUILTY OF THE LATTER ONLY WITH A POINT OF LAW RESERVED THIS WAS FULLY ARGUED BEFORE THREE JUDGES
column5: the jury found him guilty of the latter only with a point of law reserved this was fully argued before three judges

column4: AND NOT FOR THE SLIGHT OFFENSE AS IT APPEARED ON THE RECORD
column5: and not for the slight offense as it appeared on the record

column4: THE SENTENCE OF THE COURT ONE OF TEN YEARS' TRANSPORTATION STRUCK THE PRISONER WITH DISMAY
column5: the sentence of the court one of ten years' transportation struck the prisoner with dismay

column4: HE HAD BEEN LED TO SUPPOSE THAT TWELVE MONTHS' IMPRISONMENT WAS THE UTMOST THE LAW COULD INFLICT AND HE BROKE DOWN UTTERLY UNDER THE UNEXPECTED BLOW
column5: he had been led to suppose that twelve months' imprisonment was the utmost the law could inflict and he broke down utterly under the unexpected blow

column4: THAT SAME EVENING HE COMMITTED SUICIDE IN NEWGATE
column5: that same evening he committed suicide in newgate

column4: THE DETAILS OF THE SUICIDE WERE GIVEN AT THE INQUEST WATTS HAD BEEN IN ILLHEALTH FROM THE TIME OF HIS FIRST ARREST
column5: the details of the suicide were given at the inquest watts had been in illhealth from the time of his first arrest

column4: IN GILTSPUR STREET COMPTER WHERE HE WAS FIRST LODGED
column5: in giltspur street compter where he was first lodged

column4: HE SHOWED SYMPTOMS OF DELIRIUM TREMENS AND ADMITTED THAT HE HAD BEEN ADDICTED TO THE EXCESSIVE USE OF STIMULANTS
column5: he showed symptoms of delirium tremens and admitted that he had been addicted to the excessive use of stimulants

column4: HIS HEALTH IMPROVED BUT WAS STILL INDIFFERENT WHEN HE WAS BROUGHT UP FOR SENTENCE AND HE WAS AN OCCUPANT OF THE NEWGATE INFIRMARY
column5: his health improved but was still indifferent when he was brought up for sentence and he was an occupant of the newgate infirmary

column4: HE RETURNED FROM COURT IN A STATE OF GLOOMY DEJECTION
column5: he returned from court in a state of gloomy dejection

column4: AND IN THE MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT ONE OF THE FELLOWPRISONERS WHO SLEPT IN THE SAME WARD NOTICED THAT HE WAS NOT IN HIS BED
column5: and in the middle of the night one of the fellowprisoners who slept in the same ward noticed that he was not in his bed

column4: THIS MAN GOT UP TO LOOK FOR HIM AND FOUND HIM HANGING FROM THE BARS OF A NEIGHBORING ROOM
column5: this man got up to look for him and found him hanging from the bars of a neighboring room

column4: HE HAD MADE USE OF A PIECE OF ROPE CUT OUT FROM THE SACKING OF HIS BEDSTEAD AND HAD TIED HIS FEET TOGETHER WITH A SILK POCKETHANDKERCHIEF
column5: he had made use of a piece of rope cut out from the sacking of his bedstead and had tied his feet together with a silk pockethandkerchief

column4: THE PRISON OFFICERS WERE CALLED BUT WATTS WAS QUITE COLD AND STIFF WHEN HE WAS CUT DOWN
column5: the prison officers were called but watts was quite cold and stiff when he was cut down

column4: STRANGE TO SAY A SECOND SUICIDE OCCURRED IN NEWGATE THE SAME NIGHT
column5: strange to say a second suicide occurred in newgate the same night

column4: THAT OF A PRIZEFIGHTER NAMED DONOVAN TRIED THE SAME DAY AND CONVICTED OF MANSLAUGHTER
column5: that of a prizefighter named donovan tried the same day and convicted of manslaughter

column4: SENTENCE OF DEATH HAD BEEN RECORDED AGAINST DONOVAN WHO LIKE WATTS HAD SEEMINGLY BEEN OVERCOME WITH SUDDEN DESPAIR
column5: sentence of death had been recorded against donovan who like watts had seemingly been overcome with sudden despair

column4: IN EIGHTEEN FIFTYTHREE A SECOND CASE OF GIGANTIC FRAUD ALARMED AND SCANDALIZED THE FINANCIAL WORLD
column5: in eighteen fiftythree a second case of gigantic fraud alarmed and scandalized the financial world

column4: IT OUTSHONE THE DEFALCATIONS OF WATTS
column5: it outshone the defalcations of watts

column4: NOTHING TO EQUAL THE EXCITEMENT CAUSED BY THE FORGERIES OF ROBERT FERDINAND PRIES HAD BEEN KNOWN BEFORE IN THE CITY OF LONDON
column5: nothing to equal the excitement caused by the forgeries of robert ferdinand pries had been known before in the city of london

column4: HE WAS A CORN MERCHANT WHO OPERATED LARGELY IN GRAIN
column5: he was a corn merchant who operated largely in grain

column4: SO ENORMOUS WERE HIS TRANSACTIONS THAT THEY OFTEN AFFECTED THE MARKETS AND CAUSED GREAT FLUCTUATIONS IN PRICES
column5: so enormous were his transactions that they often affected the markets and caused great fluctuations in prices

column4: THESE HAD BEEN ATTRIBUTED TO POLITICAL ACTION SOME THOUGHT THAT THE LARGE PURCHASES IN FOREIGN GRAINS EFFECTED AT LOSING PRICES
column5: these had been attributed to political action some thought that the large purchases in foreign grains effected at losing prices

column4: WERE INTENDED BY THE PROTECTIONISTS TO DEPRESS THE WHEAT MARKET AND SECURE THE SUPPORT OF THE FARMERS AT THE FORTHCOMING ELECTION
column5: were intended by the protectionists to depress the wheat market and secure the support of the farmers at the forthcoming election

column4: OTHERS THAT NAPOLEON THE THIRD BUT RECENTLY PROCLAIMED EMPEROR OF THE FRENCH WISHED TO GAIN THE POPULARITY NECESSARY TO SECURE THE PEOPLE
column5: others that napoleon the third but recently proclaimed emperor of the french wished to gain the popularity necessary to secure the people

column4: FEW REALIZED THAT THESE MYSTERIOUS OPERATIONS WERE THE CONVULSIVE ATTEMPT OF A RUINED AND DISHONEST SPECULATOR TO SUSTAIN HIS CREDIT
column5: few realized that these mysterious operations were the convulsive attempt of a ruined and dishonest speculator to sustain his credit

column4: PRIES ALTHOUGH ENJOYING A HIGH REPUTATION IN THE CITY HAD LONG BEEN IN A BAD WAY
column5: pries although enjoying a high reputation in the city had long been in a bad way

column4: HIS EXTENSIVE BUSINESS HAD BEEN CARRIED ON BY FRAUD
column5: his extensive business had been carried on by fraud

column4: HIS METHOD WAS TO OBTAIN ADVANCES TWICE OVER ON THE SAME BILLS OF LADING OR CORN WARRANTS THE DUPLICATES WERE FORGED
column5: his method was to obtain advances twice over on the same bills of lading or corn warrants the duplicates were forged

column4: IN THIS WAY HE OBTAINED VAST SUMS FROM SEVERAL FIRMS AND ONE TO WHICH HE WAS INDEBTED UPWARDS OF FIFTY THOUSAND POUNDS SUBSEQUENTLY STOPPED PAYMENT
column5: in this way he obtained vast sums from several firms and one to which he was indebted upwards of fifty thousand pounds subsequently stopped payment

column4: PRIES AT LENGTH WAS DISCOVERED
column5: pries at length was discovered

column4: THROUGH A DISHONORED CHEQUE FOR THREE THOUSAND POUNDS PAID OVER AS AN INSTALLMENT OF EIGHTEEN THOUSAND POUNDS OWING FOR AN ADVANCE ON WARRANTS
column5: through a dishonored cheque for three thousand pounds paid over as an installment of eighteen thousand pounds owing for an advance on warrants

column4: INQUIRIES WERE INSTITUTED WHEN THE CHEQUE WAS PROTESTED WHICH LED TO THE DISCOVERY OF THE FORGERIES
column5: inquiries were instituted when the cheque was protested which led to the discovery of the forgeries

column4: PRIES WAS LODGED IN NEWGATE TRIED AT THE OLD BAILEY AND TRANSPORTED FOR LIFE
column5: pries was lodged in newgate tried at the old bailey and transported for life

column4: ANOTHER SET OF FRAUDS WHICH RESEMBLED THOSE OF PRIES IN PRINCIPLE ALTHOUGH NOT IN PRACTICE WERE SOON AFTERWARDS DISCOVERED
column5: another set of frauds which resembled those of pries in principle although not in practice were soon afterwards discovered

column4: PROPOSED TO GAIN THE CAPITAL HE NEEDED FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES BY RAISING MONEY ON DOCK WARRANTS FOR IMPORTED GOODS WHICH HAD NO REAL EXISTENCE
column5: proposed to gain the capital he needed for business purposes by raising money on dock warrants for imported goods which had no real existence

column4: WHEN SUCH GOODS ARRIVED THEY WERE FREQUENTLY LEFT AT A WHARF PAYING RENT UNTIL IT SUITED THE IMPORTER TO REMOVE THEM
column5: when such goods arrived they were frequently left at a wharf paying rent until it suited the importer to remove them

column4: THE DOCK WARRANT WAS ISSUED BY THE WHARFINGER AS CERTIFICATE THAT HE HELD THE GOODS
column5: the dock warrant was issued by the wharfinger as certificate that he held the goods

column4: THE WARRANT THUS REPRESENTED MONEY AND WAS OFTEN USED AS SUCH BEING ENDORSED AND PASSED FROM HAND TO HAND AS OTHER NEGOTIABLE BILLS
column5: the warrant thus represented money and was often used as such being endorsed and passed from hand to hand as other negotiable bills

column4: COLE'S PLAN WAS TO HAVE A WHARF OF HIS OWN NOMINALLY OCCUPIED BY A CREATURE TRADING AS MALTBY AND CO
column5: cole's plan was to have a wharf of his own nominally occupied by a creature trading as maltby and co

column4: GOODS WOULD BE LANDED AT THIS WHARF
column5: goods would be landed at this wharf

column4: MALTBY AND CO WOULD ISSUE WARRANTS ON THEM DELIVERABLE TO THE IMPORTER AND THE GOODS WERE THEN PASSED TO BE STORED IN NEIGHBORING WAREHOUSES
column5: maltby and co would issue warrants on them deliverable to the importer and the goods were then passed to be stored in neighboring warehouses

column4: THE OWNERS OF THE LATTER WOULD THEN ISSUE A SECOND SET OF WARRANTS ON THESE GOODS IN TOTAL IGNORANCE OF THE FACT THAT THEY WERE ALREADY PLEDGED
column5: the owners of the latter would then issue a second set of warrants on these goods in total ignorance of the fact that they were already pledged

column4: COLE QUICKLY RAISED MONEY ON BOTH SETS OF WARRANTS HE CARRIED ON THIS GAME FOR SOME TIME WITH GREAT SUCCESS
column5: cole quickly raised money on both sets of warrants he carried on this game for some time with great success

column4: AND SO DEVELOPED HIS BUSINESS THAT IN ONE YEAR HIS TRANSACTIONS AMOUNTED TO A COUPLE OF MILLIONS OF POUNDS
column5: and so developed his business that in one year his transactions amounted to a couple of millions of pounds

column4: HE HAD SEVERAL NARROW ESCAPES
column5: he had several narrow escapes

column4: ONCE A WARRANTHOLDER SENT DOWN A CLERK TO VIEW CERTAIN GOODS AND THE CLERK FOUND THAT THESE GOODS HAD ALREADY A STOP UPON THEM OR WERE PLEDGED
column5: once a warrantholder sent down a clerk to view certain goods and the clerk found that these goods had already a stop upon them or were pledged

column4: COLE ESCAPED BY THROWING THE BLAME ON A CARELESS PARTNER AND AT ONCE REMOVED THE STOP
column5: cole escaped by throwing the blame on a careless partner and at once removed the stop

column4: AGAIN SOME OF THE DUPLICATE AND FICTITIOUS WARRANTS WERE HELD BY A FIRM WHICH SUSPENDED PAYMENT AND THERE WAS NO KNOWING INTO WHOSE HANDS THEY MIGHT FALL
column5: again some of the duplicate and fictitious warrants were held by a firm which suspended payment and there was no knowing into whose hands they might fall

column4: COLE FOUND OUT WHERE THEY WERE AND REDEEMED THEM AT A HEAVY OUTLAY THUS OBTAINING BUSINESS RELATIONS WITH THE FIRM THAT HELD THEM
column5: cole found out where they were and redeemed them at a heavy outlay thus obtaining business relations with the firm that held them

column4: WHICH WERE SOON DEVELOPED MUCH TO THAT FIRM'S SUBSEQUENT ANGER AND REGRET
column5: which were soon developed much to that firm's subsequent anger and regret

column4: LAST OF ALL THE WELLKNOWN BANKERS OVEREND AND GURNEY WHOSE OWN AFFAIRS CREATED MUCH EXCITEMENT SOME YEARS LATER
column5: last of all the wellknown bankers overend and gurney whose own affairs created much excitement some years later

column4: WISHING TO VERIFY THE VALUE OF WARRANTS THEY HELD AND SENDING TO MALTBY AND CO'S WHARF FOUND OUT HALF THE TRUTH
column5: wishing to verify the value of warrants they held and sending to maltby and co's wharf found out half the truth

column4: THESE BANKERS WISHING FOR MORE SPECIFIC INFORMATION
column5: these bankers wishing for more specific information

column4: ASKED DAVIDSON AND GORDON A FIRM WITH WHICH COLE WAS CLOSELY ALLIED WHETHER THE WARRANTS MEANT GOODS OR NOTHING
column5: asked davidson and gordon a firm with which cole was closely allied whether the warrants meant goods or nothing

column4: THEY COULD NOT DENY THAT THE LATTER WAS THE TRUTH AND WERE FORTHWITH STIGMATIZED BY MR CHAPMAN OVEREND AND GURNEY'S REPRESENTATIVE AS ROGUES
column5: they could not deny that the latter was the truth and were forthwith stigmatized by mr chapman overend and gurney's representative as rogues

column4: CHRONICLES OF NEWGATE VOLUME TWO BY ARTHUR GRIFFITHS SECTION EIGHTEEN NEWGATE NOTORIETIES CONTINUED PART THREE
column5: chronicles of newgate volume two by arthur griffiths section eighteen newgate notorieties continued part three

column4: THE COURSE OF THE SWINDLERS WAS BY NO MEANS SMOOTH BUT IT WAS NOT TILL EIGHTEEN FIFTYFOUR THAT SUSPICION AROSE THAT ANYTHING WAS WRONG
column5: the course of the swindlers was by no means smooth but it was not till eighteen fiftyfour that suspicion arose that anything was wrong

column4: A FIRM WHICH HELD A LOT OF WARRANTS SUDDENLY DEMANDED THE DELIVERY OF THE GOODS THEY COVERED
column5: a firm which held a lot of warrants suddenly demanded the delivery of the goods they covered

column4: THE GOODS HAVING NO EXISTENCE COLE OF COURSE COULD NOT DELIVER THEM
column5: the goods having no existence cole of course could not deliver them

column4: ABOUT THIS TIME DAVIDSON AND GORDON THE PEOPLE ABOVEMENTIONED
column5: about this time davidson and gordon the people abovementioned

column4: WHO HAD FRAUDULENT WARRANTS OUT OF THEIR OWN TO THE EXTENT OF ONE HUNDRED FIFTY THOUSAND POUNDS SUSPENDED PAYMENT AND ABSCONDED
column5: who had fraudulent warrants out of their own to the extent of one hundred fifty thousand pounds suspended payment and absconded

column4: THIS AFFECTED COLE'S CREDIT AND UGLY REPORTS WERE IN CIRCULATION CHARGING HIM WITH THE ISSUE OF SIMULATED WARRANTS
column5: this affected cole's credit and ugly reports were in circulation charging him with the issue of simulated warrants

column4: THESE INDEED WERE OUT TO THE VALUE OF THREE HUNDRED SIXTYSEVEN THOUSAND EIGHT HUNDRED POUNDS
column5: these indeed were out to the value of three hundred sixtyseven thousand eight hundred pounds

column4: COLE'S DIFFICULTIES INCREASED MORE AND MORE WARRANTHOLDERS CAME DOWN UPON HIM DEMANDING TO REALIZE THEIR GOODS
column5: cole's difficulties increased more and more warrantholders came down upon him demanding to realize their goods

column4: COLE NOW SUSPENDED PAYMENT
column5: cole now suspended payment

column4: MALTBY WHO HAD BOLTED WAS PURSUED AND ARRESTED TO END HIS LIFE MISERABLY BY COMMITTING SUICIDE IN A NEWGATE CELL
column5: maltby who had bolted was pursued and arrested to end his life miserably by committing suicide in a newgate cell

column4: COLE TOO WAS APPREHENDED AND IN DUE COURSE TRIED AT THE CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT
column5: cole too was apprehended and in due course tried at the central criminal court

column4: HE WAS FOUND GUILTY AND SENTENCED TO THE SEEMINGLY INADEQUATE PUNISHMENT OF FOUR YEARS' TRANSPORTATION
column5: he was found guilty and sentenced to the seemingly inadequate punishment of four years' transportation

column4: DAVIDSON AND GORDON WERE ALSO SENTENCED TO IMPRISONMENT
column5: davidson and gordon were also sentenced to imprisonment

column5: a more distressing case stands next on the criminal records

column5: the failure and subsequent sentence of the bankers messrs strahan paul and bates

column4: FOR THE FRAUDULENT DISPOSAL OF SECURITIES LODGED IN THEIR HANDS THIS FIRM WAS ONE OF THE OLDEST BANKING ESTABLISHMENTS IN THE KINGDOM
column5: for the fraudulent disposal of securities lodged in their hands this firm was one of the oldest banking establishments in the kingdom

column4: AND DATED BACK TO THE COMMONWEALTH WHEN UNDER THE TITLE OF SNOW AND WALTON IT CARRIED ON BUSINESS AS PAWNBROKERS
column5: and dated back to the commonwealth when under the title of snow and walton it carried on business as pawnbrokers

column5: the strahan of the firm which came to grief was a snow who changed his name for a fortune of two hundred thousand pounds

column4: HE WAS A MAN ESTEEMED AND RESPECTED IN SOCIETY AND THE WORLD OF FINANCE INCAPABLE AS IT WAS THOUGHT OF A DISHONEST DEED
column5: he was a man esteemed and respected in society and the world of finance incapable as it was thought of a dishonest deed

column4: SIR JOHN DEAN PAUL HAD INHERITED A BARONETCY FROM HIS FATHER TOGETHER WITH AN HONORED NAME
column5: sir john dean paul had inherited a baronetcy from his father together with an honored name

column4: HE WAS HIMSELF A PROMINENT MEMBER OF THE LOW CHURCH OF AUSTERE PIETY ACTIVE IN ALL GOOD WORKS
column5: he was himself a prominent member of the low church of austere piety active in all good works

column4: MR BATES HAD BEEN CONFIDENTIAL MANAGING CLERK AND WAS TAKEN INTO THE FIRM NOT ALONE AS A REWARD FOR LONG AND FAITHFUL SERVICE
column5: mr bates had been confidential managing clerk and was taken into the firm not alone as a reward for long and faithful service

column4: BUT THAT HE MIGHT STRENGTHEN IT BY HIS LONG EXPERIENCE AND KNOWN BUSINESS CAPACITY
column5: but that he might strengthen it by his long experience and known business capacity

column4: THE BANK ENJOYED AN EXCELLENT REPUTATION IT HAD A GOOD CONNECTION AND WAS SUPPOSED TO BE PERFECTLY SOUND
column5: the bank enjoyed an excellent reputation it had a good connection and was supposed to be perfectly sound

column4: MOREOVER THE PARTNERS WERE SOBER STEADY MEN WHO PAID UNREMITTING ATTENTION TO BUSINESS
column5: moreover the partners were sober steady men who paid unremitting attention to business

column4: YET EVEN SO EARLY AS THE DEATH OF THE FIRST SIR JOHN PAUL
column5: yet even so early as the death of the first sir john paul

column4: THE BANK WAS INSOLVENT AND INSTEAD OF STARTING ON A FRESH LIFE WITH A NEW NAME IT SHOULD THEN AND THERE HAVE CLOSED ITS DOORS
column5: the bank was insolvent and instead of starting on a fresh life with a new name it should then and there have closed its doors

column5: in december eighteen fiftyone the balance sheet showed a deficiency of upwards of seventy thousand pounds

column4: THE BANK HAD BEEN CONDUCTED ON FALSE PRINCIPLES
column5: the bank had been conducted on false principles

column4: IT HAD ASSUMED ENORMOUS RESPONSIBILITIES  ON ONE SIDE BY THE OWNERSHIP OF THE MOSTYN COLLIERIES A VALUELESS PROPERTY
column5: it had assumed enormous responsibilities  on one side by the ownership of the mostyn collieries a valueless property

column4: AND ON THE OTHER BY BACKING UP
column5: and on the other by backing up

column5: an impecunious and rotten firm of contractors with vast liabilities and pledged to impossible works abroad

column4: THE ENGAGEMENTS OF THE BANK ON THESE TWO HEADS AMOUNTING TO NEARLY HALF A MILLION OF MONEY
column5: the engagements of the bank on these two heads amounting to nearly half a million of money

column4: PRODUCED IMMEDIATE EMBARRASSMENT AND FINANCIAL DISTRESS
column5: produced immediate embarrassment and financial distress

column4: THE BANK WAS ALREADY INSOLVENT
column5: the bank was already insolvent

column4: AND THE PARTNERS HAD TO DECIDE BETWEEN SUSPENDING PAYMENT OR CONTINUING TO HOLD ITS HEAD ABOVE WATER BY FLAGITIOUS PROCESSES
column5: and the partners had to decide between suspending payment or continuing to hold its head above water by flagitious processes

column4: THEY CHOSE UNHAPPILY FOR THEMSELVES THE LATTER ALTERNATIVE
column5: they chose unhappily for themselves the latter alternative

column4: MONEY THEY MUST HAVE AND MONEY THEY RAISED TO MEET THEIR URGENT NECESSITIES UPON THE BALANCES AND SECURITIES DEPOSITED WITH THEM BY THEIR CUSTOMERS
column5: money they must have and money they raised to meet their urgent necessities upon the balances and securities deposited with them by their customers

column4: THIS BORROWING CONTINUED AND ON SUCH A SCALE THAT THEIR PAPER WAS SOON AT A DISCOUNT
column5: this borrowing continued and on such a scale that their paper was soon at a discount

column4: AND THE VARIOUS DISCOUNT HOUSES WOULD NOT ADVANCE SUFFICIENT SUMS TO RELIEVE THE NECESSITIES OF THE BANK
column5: and the various discount houses would not advance sufficient sums to relieve the necessities of the bank

column5: then it was that instead of merely pledging securities the bank sold them outright and thus passed the rubicon of fraud

column4: THIS WENT ON FOR SOME TIME AND MIGHT NEVER HAVE BEEN DISCOVERED HAD SOME GOOD STROKE OF LUCK PROVIDED ANY OF THE PARTNERS
column5: this went on for some time and might never have been discovered had some good stroke of luck provided any of the partners

column4: WITH MONEY ENOUGH TO RETRIEVE THE POSITION OF THE BANK BUT THAT PASSED FROM BAD TO WORSE
column5: with money enough to retrieve the position of the bank but that passed from bad to worse

column5: the firm's paper went down further and further in value an application to the committee of bankers for assistance was peremptorily refused

column4: THEN CAME A RUN ON THE BANK AND IT WAS COMPELLED TO STOP PAYMENT
column5: then came a run on the bank and it was compelled to stop payment

column4: ITS DEBTS AMOUNTED TO THREEQUARTERS OF A MILLION AND THE DIVIDEND IT EVENTUALLY PAID WAS THREE AND TWOPENCE IN THE POUND
column5: its debts amounted to threequarters of a million and the dividend it eventually paid was three and twopence in the pound

column5: but worse than the bankruptcy was the confession made by the partners in the court

column5: they admitted that they had made away with many of the securities entrusted to their keeping

column5: following this warrants were issued for their arrest

column5: the specific charge being the unlawful negotiation of danish bonds and other shares belonging to the rev dr griffiths of rochester

column4: TO THE VALUE OF TWENTY THOUSAND POUNDS
column5: to the value of twenty thousand pounds

column5: bates was at once captured in norfolk street strand

column5: police officers went down at night to nutfield near reigate and arrested sir john paul but allowed the prisoner to sleep there

column5: next morning they only just saved the train to town and left sir john behind on the platform but he subsequently surrendered himself

column5: mr strahan was arrested at a friend's house in bryanston square

column5: all three were tried at the central criminal court and sentenced to fourteen years' transportation passing some time in newgate en route

column5: bates the least guilty was pardoned in eighteen fiftyeight

column5: two cases of extensive embezzlement which were discovered almost simultaneously those of robson and redpath

column4: WILL LONG BE REMEMBERED BOTH WITHIN AND WITHOUT THE COMMERCIAL WORLD
column5: will long be remembered both within and without the commercial world

column5: robson was of humble origin but he was well educated and he had some literary abilities

column5: one at least of which 'love and loyalty' with wallack in a leading part achieved a certain success

column5: he began life as a lawwriter earning thereby some fifteen or eighteen shillings a week

column5: but the firm he served got him a situation as clerk in the office of the great northern railway

column5: he now married although his salary was only a pound a week but he soon got on

column5: within a year he was advanced to the post of chief clerk in the transfer department at a salary of one hundred fifty pounds a year

column5: his immediate chief was a mr fasson upon whose confidence he gained so rapidly through his activity industry and engaging manners

column5: some time elapsed before robson succumbed to temptation

column5: he was not the first man of loose morality and expensive tastes

column5: he conceived the idea of transferring shares bogus shares from a person who held none to any one who would buy them in the open market

column4: TILL THE DEFALCATIONS FROM FRAUDULENT TRANSFERS AND FRAUDULENT ISSUES COMBINED AMOUNTED TO TWENTYSEVEN THOUSAND POUNDS

column5: whether representing real or fictitious shares does not appear but they were certificates connected in some way with robson's long practiced frauds

column5: robson said they were at kilburn priory

column5: let us go to kilburn for them together said mr fasson growing suspicious

column5: he came back to explain that he had mislaid them

column5: robson again left him but only to gather together hastily all the money and valuables on which he could lay his hands with which he left the house

column5: mr fasson waited and waited for his subordinate to reappear and at last discovered his flight

column5: newgate officers who remember robson still describe him as a fine young man who behaved well as a prisoner

column4: BUT WHO HAD ALL THE APPEARANCE OF A CARELESS THOUGHTLESS HAPPYGOLUCKY FELLOW
column5: but who had all the appearance of a careless thoughtless happygolucky fellow

column5: but it was based upon more extended and audacious forgeries

column5: redpath's crime arose from his peculiar and independent position as registrar of stock of the great northern railway company

column5: this offered him great facilities for the creation of artificial stock its sale from a fictitious holder and transfer to himself

column5: by inserting say one before five hundred and thus making it

column5: by these means redpath misappropriated vast sums during a period extending over ten years

column5: what do you know of our clerk asked mr denison of his lordship only that he is a capital fellow who gives the best dinners and balls in town

column4: THE WOUNDS BROKE OPEN AND BLED PROFUSELY WHILE THE LAST DREAD PENALTY WAS BEING PERFORMED TO THE MANIFEST EXCITEMENT AND INDIGNATION OF THE CROWD
column5: the wounds broke open and bled profusely while the last dread penalty was being performed to the manifest excitement and indignation of the crowd

column4: A MORE DARING AND SKILFUL ESCAPE WAS EFFECTED IN EIGHTEEN THIRTYSIX BY THE CHIMNEYSWEEP HENRY WILLIAMS
column5: a more daring and skilful escape was effected in eighteen thirtysix by the chimneysweep henry williams

column4: WHO WHILE DETAINED IN THE PRESSYARD AS A CAPITAL CONVICT UNDER SENTENCE OF DEATH FOR BURGLARY
column5: who while detained in the pressyard as a capital convict under sentence of death for burglary

column4: MANAGED TO GET AWAY IN THE VERY SAME SPOT WHERE HIS NAMESAKE HAD NINE YEARS BEFORE SO MISERABLY FAILED
column5: managed to get away in the very same spot where his namesake had nine years before so miserably failed

column4: ESCAPE SEEMED ABSOLUTELY HOPELESS
column5: escape seemed absolutely hopeless

column4: AND WOULD CERTAINLY HAVE BEEN IMPOSSIBLE TO ANY ONE LESS NIMBLE THAN A CHIMNEYSWEEP TRAINED UNDER THE OLD SYSTEM TO ASCEND THE MOST INTRICATE FLUES
column5: and would certainly have been impossible to any one less nimble than a chimneysweep trained under the old system to ascend the most intricate flues

column4: EVEN AFTER WILLIAMS HAD GOT OUT PERSONS WERE DISPOSED TO DISBELIEVE THAT THE ESCAPE HAD BEEN ACCOMPLISHED IN THE MANNER INDICATED
column5: even after williams had got out persons were disposed to disbelieve that the escape had been accomplished in the manner indicated

column4: THEY PREFERRED TO CREDIT IT TO CARELESSNESS OR COLLUSION FROM OFFICERS OF THE JAIL
column5: they preferred to credit it to carelessness or collusion from officers of the jail

column4: YET FROM THE CIRCUMSTANTIAL ACCOUNT GIVEN BY WILLIAMS AFTER RECAPTURE THERE CAN BE LITTLE DOUBT THAT HE GOT AWAY AS WILL BE DESCRIBED
column5: yet from the circumstantial account given by williams after recapture there can be little doubt that he got away as will be described

column4: WILLIAMS AS A CAPITAL CONVICT WAS LODGED IN THE PRESSYARD OR CONDEMNED WARD
column5: williams as a capital convict was lodged in the pressyard or condemned ward

column4: HE HAD ACCESS TO THE AIRING YARD AND THERE WAS FOR HOURS NO KIND OF SUPERVISION
column5: he had access to the airing yard and there was for hours no kind of supervision

column4: IN ONE CORNER OF THE AIRING YARD STOOD A CISTERN AT SOME HEIGHT FROM THE GROUND
column5: in one corner of the airing yard stood a cistern at some height from the ground

column4: THE WALL BENEATH AND ABOVE IT WAS RUSTICATED IN OTHER WORDS THE GRANITE SURFACE HAD BECOME ROUGHENED AND OFFERED A SORT OF FOOTHOLD
column5: the wall beneath and above it was rusticated in other words the granite surface had become roughened and offered a sort of foothold

column4: ABOUT FIFTY FEET FROM THE GROUND LEVEL AND ABOVE THE CISTERN A REVOLVING CHEVAUXDEFRISE OF IRON WAS FIXED
column5: about fifty feet from the ground level and above the cistern a revolving chevauxdefrise of iron was fixed

column4: WITH ONLY A SHORT INTERVAL BETWEEN IT AND THE WALL SUPPORTED BY A HORIZONTAL IRON RAILING WITH UPRIGHT POINTS
column5: with only a short interval between it and the wall supported by a horizontal iron railing with upright points

column4: IN THE WALL ABOVE THE CHEVAUXDEFRISE PROJECTED A SERIES OF IRON SPIKES SHARP ENOUGH TO FORBID FURTHER ASCENT
column5: in the wall above the chevauxdefrise projected a series of iron spikes sharp enough to forbid further ascent

column4: WILLIAMS SURVEYED THESE FORMIDABLE OBSTACLES TO EVASION AND CALMLY PROCEEDED TO SURMOUNT THEM
column5: williams surveyed these formidable obstacles to evasion and calmly proceeded to surmount them

column4: HIS FIRST TASK WAS TO GAIN THE TOP OF THE CISTERN THIS HE EFFECTED BY KEEPING HIS BACK TO ONE SIDE OF THE ANGLE
column5: his first task was to gain the top of the cistern this he effected by keeping his back to one side of the angle

column4: AND WORKING WITH HIS HANDS BEHIND HIM WHILE HE USED HIS BARE FEET LIKE CLAWS UPON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE WALL ANGLE
column5: and working with his hands behind him while he used his bare feet like claws upon the other side of the wall angle

column4: THE CONDITION OF THE STONE SURFACE JUST MENTIONED ASSISTED HIM IN THIS AND HE MANAGED TO GET BEYOND THE CISTERN TO THE RAILING BELOW THE CHEVAUXDEFRISE
column5: the condition of the stone surface just mentioned assisted him in this and he managed to get beyond the cistern to the railing below the chevauxdefrise

column4: THE LEAST SLIP NOW WOULD HAVE BEEN FATAL TO HIM BUT HE COULD NOT THRUST HIS BODY IN THROUGH THE NARROW SPACE LEFT BY THE CHEVAUXDEFRISE
column5: the least slip now would have been fatal to him but he could not thrust his body in through the narrow space left by the chevauxdefrise

column4: AND WAS COMPELLED TO WORK ALONG THE RAILING ROUND THREEQUARTERS OF THE SQUARE OF THE YARD
column5: and was compelled to work along the railing round threequarters of the square of the yard

column4: AND AT LENGTH REACHED A POINT OPPOSITE THE TOP OF THE BUILDING CONTAINING THE CONDEMNED WARDS THIS HAD BEEN A PERILOUS AND PAINFUL TASK
column5: and at length reached a point opposite the top of the building containing the condemned wards this had been a perilous and painful task

column4: THE SPIKES OF THE RAILING PENETRATED HIS FLESH AND MADE PROGRESSION SLOW AND DIFFICULT
column5: the spikes of the railing penetrated his flesh and made progression slow and difficult

column4: BUT THE WORST PART OF THE BUSINESS WAS TO JUMP FROM THIS IRKSOME FOOTHOLD OF THE IRON GRATING ON TO THE TOP OF THE BUILDING JUST MENTIONED
column5: but the worst part of the business was to jump from this irksome foothold of the iron grating on to the top of the building just mentioned

column4: A DISTANCE OF EIGHT OR NINE FEET
column5: a distance of eight or nine feet

column4: HE HAD HERE COMPLETED HIS ASCENT
column5: he had here completed his ascent

column4: HIS NEXT JOB WAS TO DESCEND OUTSIDE NEWGATE
column5: his next job was to descend outside newgate

column4: CLAMBERING ALONG THE ROOF
column5: clambering along the roof

column4: HE PASSED TO THE TOP OF THE ORDINARY'S RESIDENCE HOPING TO FIND AN OPEN SKYLIGHT BY WHICH HE MIGHT ENTER AND SO WORK DOWNSTAIRS
column5: he passed to the top of the ordinary's residence hoping to find an open skylight by which he might enter and so work downstairs

column4: IF THE WORST CAME TO THE WORST HE INTENDED TO HAVE GONE DOWN SOME CHIMNEY AS HE HAD OFTEN DONE BEFORE IN THE WAY OF BUSINESS
column5: if the worst came to the worst he intended to have gone down some chimney as he had often done before in the way of business

column4: BUT HE DID NOT LIKE THE RISK OF ENTERING A ROOM BY THE FIREPLACE AND THE CHANCES OF DETECTION IT OFFERED
column5: but he did not like the risk of entering a room by the fireplace and the chances of detection it offered

column4: HE TRAVERSED VAINLY ALL THE ROOFS IN NEWGATE STREET
column5: he traversed vainly all the roofs in newgate street

column4: RUNNING A GREAT RISK OF DISCOVERY AS HE PASSED BY A LOT OF WORKMEN AT TYLER'S MANUFACTORY IN WARWICK SQUARE WHICH HAD FORMERLY BEEN THE COLLEGE OF PHYSICIANS
column5: running a great risk of discovery as he passed by a lot of workmen at tyler's manufactory in warwick square which had formerly been the college of physicians

column4: AS HIS COAT WAS AN ENCUMBRANCE HE LEFT IT ON THE TOP OF THE THIRD HOUSE IN NEWGATE STREET AND THUS IN SHIRTSLEEVES BAREFOOT AND BAREHEADED
column5: as his coat was an encumbrance he left it on the top of the third house in newgate street and thus in shirtsleeves barefoot and bareheaded

column4: HE WORKED ALONG TO THE ROOFS IN WARWICK LANE
column5: he worked along to the roofs in warwick lane

column4: HERE HE CAME UPON A WOMAN ON THE LEADS HANGING OUT CLOTHES TO DRY
column5: here he came upon a woman on the leads hanging out clothes to dry

column4: WILLIAMS CONCEALED HIMSELF BEHIND A CHIMNEY TILL SHE HAD REENTERED HER GARRET
column5: williams concealed himself behind a chimney till she had reentered her garret

column4: AND THEN FOLLOWING HER DOWN A STEP LADDER INTO THE HOUSE TOLD HIS STORY APPEALED TO AND WON HER COMPASSION
column5: and then following her down a step ladder into the house told his story appealed to and won her compassion

column4: SHE SUFFERED HIM TO PASS DOWNSTAIRS
column5: she suffered him to pass downstairs

column4: BELOW HE MET ANOTHER WOMAN AND A GIRL BOTH OF WHOM WERE TERRIFIED AT HIS APPEARANCE BUT
column5: below he met another woman and a girl both of whom were terrified at his appearance but

column4: WHEN HE EXPLAINED THAT HE WAS RUNNING AWAY FROM THE GALLOWS THEY LEFT HIM THE ROAD CLEAR
column5: when he explained that he was running away from the gallows they left him the road clear

column4: TO WALK OUT INTO THE STREET WAS AN EASY AFFAIR AND HE WAS NOW FREE WITH ONE AND FOURPENCE IN HIS POCKET AND A SHIRT AND TROUSERS FOR ALL HIS CLOTHING
column5: to walk out into the street was an easy affair and he was now free with one and fourpence in his pocket and a shirt and trousers for all his clothing

column4: DENIED ADMISSION EVERYWHERE AS A RAGGED HALFNAKED BEGGAR
column5: denied admission everywhere as a ragged halfnaked beggar

column4: HE TRAMPED ACROSS LONDON BRIDGE TO WANDSWORTH WHERE HE REFRESHED HIMSELF WITH A PINT OF STRONG ALE THE FIRST SUSTENANCE HE HAD TAKEN SINCE HIS ESCAPE
column5: he tramped across london bridge to wandsworth where he refreshed himself with a pint of strong ale the first sustenance he had taken since his escape

column4: AND CONTINUED HIS MARCH TO KINGSTON WHERE HE SLEPT SOUNDLY UNDER A HEDGE TILL NEXT MORNING
column5: and continued his march to kingston where he slept soundly under a hedge till next morning

column4: ENTERING A TOWN HE OBTAINED EMPLOYMENT AT ONCE AS A CHIMNEYSWEEP
column5: entering a town he obtained employment at once as a chimneysweep

column4: FROM A WIDOW WOMAN WHO GAVE HIM BUB AND GRUB OR FOOD AND ONEANDSIXPENCE FOR EVERY NINE DAYS' WORK
column5: from a widow woman who gave him bub and grub or food and oneandsixpence for every nine days' work

column4: DISSATISFIED WITH THIS REMUNERATION HE AGAIN TOOK TO THE ROAD AND TRAMPED INTO HAMPSHIRE
column5: dissatisfied with this remuneration he again took to the road and tramped into hampshire

column4: WHERE HE PRESENTLY COMMITTED A BURGLARY AT LYMINGTON WAS CAUGHT AND LODGED IN WINCHESTER JAIL
column5: where he presently committed a burglary at lymington was caught and lodged in winchester jail

column4: MR COPE THE GOVERNOR OF NEWGATE HAVING BEEN COMMUNICATED WITH PROCEEDED TO WINCHESTER WHERE HE AT ONCE IDENTIFIED WILLIAMS
column5: mr cope the governor of newgate having been communicated with proceeded to winchester where he at once identified williams

column4: THE SUCCESS ALTHOUGH VERY SHORTLIVED WHICH ATTENDED HIM NO DOUBT INSPIRED OTHER INMATES OF NEWGATE TO FOLLOW HIS EXAMPLE
column5: the success although very shortlived which attended him no doubt inspired other inmates of newgate to follow his example

column4: IT WAS FOR SOME TIME AFTER THIS A CONSTANT PRACTICE TO GO UP THE CHIMNEYS IN THE HOPES OF ESCAPING BY THE FLUE
column5: it was for some time after this a constant practice to go up the chimneys in the hopes of escaping by the flue

column4: EVEN THEN HOWEVER IRONS ACROSS BARRED THE ASCENT AFTER A CERTAIN DISTANCE AND IN NO ONE CASE DID A FUGITIVE GET CLEAR AWAY
column5: even then however irons across barred the ascent after a certain distance and in no one case did a fugitive get clear away

column4: A MAN NAMED LEARS UNDER SENTENCE OF TRANSPORTATION FOR AN ATTEMPT AT MURDER ON BOARD SHIP GOT UP PART OF THE WAY
column5: a man named lears under sentence of transportation for an attempt at murder on board ship got up part of the way

column4: BUT HAD TO COME DOWN AGAIN COVERED WITH SOOT AND FILTH JUST AS THE OFFICERS ENTERED THE WARD
column5: but had to come down again covered with soot and filth just as the officers entered the ward

column4: LEARS WAS REWARDED BY BEING OBLIGED TO WEAR CROSS IRONS ON HIS LEGS A PUNISHMENT RARELY INFLICTED IN NEWGATE
column5: lears was rewarded by being obliged to wear cross irons on his legs a punishment rarely inflicted in newgate

column4: AND PROBABLY ONE OF THE FEW CASES OF A RECURRENCE BUT UNDER PROPER SAFEGUARDS AND LIMITATIONS TO THE OLD SYSTEM OF CHAINS
column5: and probably one of the few cases of a recurrence but under proper safeguards and limitations to the old system of chains

column4: ON ANOTHER OCCASION MR COPE THE GOVERNOR CAME IN AND MISSED A MAN
column5: on another occasion mr cope the governor came in and missed a man

column4: THE WARD WAS ONE SHORT OF ITS NUMBER WHAT HAD BECOME OF THE FELLOW
column5: the ward was one short of its number what had become of the fellow

column4: THE FUGITIVE UNCOMFORTABLY ENSCONCED IN THE FLUE CAME DOWN OF HIS OWN ACCORD LIKE COLONEL COLT'S RACCOON
column5: the fugitive uncomfortably ensconced in the flue came down of his own accord like colonel colt's raccoon

column4: AFTER THIS GREAT IRON GUARDS JUST AS ARE TO BE SEEN IN LUNATIC ASYLUMS
column5: after this great iron guards just as are to be seen in lunatic asylums

column4: WERE FIXED OVER THE FIREPLACES AND THE PRISONERS HAD NO LONGER ACCESS TO THE CHIMNEYS
column5: were fixed over the fireplaces and the prisoners had no longer access to the chimneys

column4: AMONG THE ESCAPES STILL REMEMBERED WAS ONE IN EIGHTEEN FORTYNINE ACCOMPLISHED BY A MAN WHO HAD BEEN EMPLOYED
column5: among the escapes still remembered was one in eighteen fortynine accomplished by a man who had been employed

column4: WORKING AT THE ROOF OF THE CHAPEL ON THE FEMALE SIDE
column5: working at the roof of the chapel on the female side

column4: HE WAS ENGAGED IN WHITEWASHING AND CLEANING THE OFFICER WHO HAD HIM IN CHARGE LEFT HIM ON THE STAIRS LEADING TO THE GALLERY
column5: he was engaged in whitewashing and cleaning the officer who had him in charge left him on the stairs leading to the gallery

column4: TAKING ADVANTAGE OF BEING UNOBSERVED HE GOT OUT THROUGH THE ROOF ON TO THE LEADS AND TRAVELED ALONG THEM TOWARDS NUMBER ONE NEWGATE STREET
column5: taking advantage of being unobserved he got out through the roof on to the leads and traveled along them towards number one newgate street

column4: THIS WAS A PUBLICHOUSE
column5: this was a publichouse

column4: HE STEPPED IN AT A GARRET WINDOW COOLLY WALKED DOWNSTAIRS AND ENTERED THE BAR
column5: he stepped in at a garret window coolly walked downstairs and entered the bar

column4: THEY ASKED HIM HOW HE HAD CUT HIS HAND WHICH WAS BLEEDING AND HE SAID HE HAD DONE IT WHILE WORKING UP ON THE ROOF
column5: they asked him how he had cut his hand which was bleeding and he said he had done it while working up on the roof

column4: NO FURTHER NOTICE WAS TAKEN OF HIM NO ONE SEEMINGLY SUSPECTED THAT HE WAS A PRISONER AND HE WAS SUFFERED TO WALK OFF WITHOUT LET OR HINDRANCE
column5: no further notice was taken of him no one seemingly suspected that he was a prisoner and he was suffered to walk off without let or hindrance

column4: IN EIGHTEEN FIFTYTHREE THREE MEN ESCAPED IN COMPANY FROM ONE OF THE WARDS IN THE MIDDLE YARD
column5: in eighteen fiftythree three men escaped in company from one of the wards in the middle yard

column4: THEY WERE PENAL SERVITUDE MEN THEIR NAMES BELL BROWN AND BARRY AND THEY WERE AWAITING TRANSFER TO LEICESTER
column5: they were penal servitude men their names bell brown and barry and they were awaiting transfer to leicester

column4: WHICH WITH WAKEFIELD WAS UTILIZED AS A RECEPTACLE FOR CONVICTS NOT GOING TO WESTERN AUSTRALIA
column5: which with wakefield was utilized as a receptacle for convicts not going to western australia

column4: OR ANY OF THE NEW ESTABLISHMENTS AT HOME AT PORTLAND DARTMOOR OR ELSEWHERE
column5: or any of the new establishments at home at portland dartmoor or elsewhere

column4: THESE MEN MANAGED TO CUT A HOLE IN THE CEILING OF THE WARD NEAR THE IRON CAGE ON THE LANDING AND SO GOT ACCESS TO THE ROOF
column5: these men managed to cut a hole in the ceiling of the ward near the iron cage on the landing and so got access to the roof

column4: AT THAT TIME ROPE MATS WERE STILL USED AS BEDS
column5: at that time rope mats were still used as beds

column4: ONE OF THE THREE SHAMMING ILL REMAINED ALL DAY IN HIS WARD WHERE HE EMPLOYED HIMSELF UNRAVELING THE ROPE FROM THE SLEEPINGMATS
column5: one of the three shamming ill remained all day in his ward where he employed himself unraveling the rope from the sleepingmats

column4: BY EVENING HE MANUFACTURED A GOOD LONG LENGTH
column5: by evening he manufactured a good long length

column4: AND AFTER ALL WAS QUIET THE THREE GOT ON TO THE ROOF THROUGH THE HOLE AND SO ON TO TYLER'S MANUFACTORY CLOSE BY
column5: and after all was quiet the three got on to the roof through the hole and so on to tyler's manufactory close by

column4: WHENCE THEY LET THEMSELVES DOWN INTO THE STREET BY THE ROPE
column5: whence they let themselves down into the street by the rope

column4: THESE MEN WERE ALL IN PRISON DRESS AT THE TIME OF THEIR ESCAPE BUT ONE OF THEIR NUMBER BELL SENT BACK HIS CLOTHES A FEW DAYS LATER BY PARCEL'S DELIVERY
column5: these men were all in prison dress at the time of their escape but one of their number bell sent back his clothes a few days later by parcel's delivery

column4: WITH A CIVIL NOTE TO THE GOVERNOR SAYING HE HAD NO FURTHER USE FOR THEM ALL THREE FUGITIVES WERE RECAPTURED
column5: with a civil note to the governor saying he had no further use for them all three fugitives were recaptured

column4: BROWN ALMOST AT ONCE THEN BARRY WHO WAS TAKEN AT THE EAST END IN A PUBLICHOUSE WHERE HE HAD ARRANGED TO MEET A PAL
column5: brown almost at once then barry who was taken at the east end in a publichouse where he had arranged to meet a pal

column4: THE NEWGATE OFFICERS OBTAINED INFORMATION OF THIS AND WENT TO THE SPOT WHERE THEY EFFECTED THE CAPTURE
column5: the newgate officers obtained information of this and went to the spot where they effected the capture

column4: BUT NOT TILL THEY HAD HAD AN EXCITING CHASE DOWN THE STREET
column5: but not till they had had an exciting chase down the street

column4: THE THIRD BELL REMAINED LONGEST AT LARGE HE TOO WAS RUN INTO AT A LODGING IN THE KINGSLAND ROAD
column5: the third bell remained longest at large he too was run into at a lodging in the kingsland road

column4: THE OFFICERS DROPPED ON TO HIM WHILE HE WAS STILL IN BED BUT AS THEY CAME UPSTAIRS HE JUMPED UP AND HID IN A CUPBOARD
column5: the officers dropped on to him while he was still in bed but as they came upstairs he jumped up and hid in a cupboard

column4: ALL THREE AFTER RECAPTURE PASSED ON AS ORIGINALLY INTENDED TO LEICESTER WHERE THEY DID THEIR BIT AND WERE RELEASED
column5: all three after recapture passed on as originally intended to leicester where they did their bit and were released

column4: BUT ONLY TO BE TAKEN SOON AFTERWARDS FOR A FRESH OFFENSE AND AGAIN PASS THROUGH NEWGATE WITH SENTENCES OF PENAL SERVITUDE
column5: but only to be taken soon afterwards for a fresh offense and again pass through newgate with sentences of penal servitude

column4: A LATER CASE WAS STILL MORE REMARKABLE AS IT WAS EFFECTED AFTER THE ALTERATION OF THE PRISON AND ITS RECONSTRUCTION ON THE NEWEST LINES
column5: a later case was still more remarkable as it was effected after the alteration of the prison and its reconstruction on the newest lines

column4: A SAILOR KRAPPS BY NAME OCCUPIED ONE OF THE UPPER CELLS IN THE NEW BLOCK
column5: a sailor krapps by name occupied one of the upper cells in the new block

column4: THE DOORS THROUGH INCOMPLETE KNOWLEDGE OF PRISON NEEDS WERE NOT AS NOW SHEETED WITH IRON
column5: the doors through incomplete knowledge of prison needs were not as now sheeted with iron

column4: THE PRISONER HAD NOTHING TO DEAL WITH BUT WOODEN PANELS AND BY DINT OF CUTTING AND CHOPPING HE GOT BOTH THE LOWER PANELS OUT
column5: the prisoner had nothing to deal with but wooden panels and by dint of cutting and chopping he got both the lower panels out

column4: THROUGH THE APERTURE HE CREPT OUT ON TO THE LANDING AT THE DEAD OF NIGHT AND SO DOWN INTO THE CENTRAL SPACE OF THE BUILDING
column5: through the aperture he crept out on to the landing at the dead of night and so down into the central space of the building

column4: UNDER SUPERIOR ORDERS ALL THE DOORS AND GATES OF THIS BLOCK WERE LEFT OPEN AT NIGHT TO ALLOW THE NIGHT WATCHMAN TO PASS FREELY TO ALL PARTS
column5: under superior orders all the doors and gates of this block were left open at night to allow the night watchman to pass freely to all parts

column4: THIS WAS CONSIDERED SAFER THAN INTRUSTING HIM WITH KEYS
column5: this was considered safer than intrusting him with keys

column4: KRAPPS WALKED AT ONCE INTO THE YARD AND ACROSS TO THE FEMALE SIDE WHERE HE FOUND SOME OF THE WASHING STILL HANGING OUT TO DRY
column5: krapps walked at once into the yard and across to the female side where he found some of the washing still hanging out to dry

column4: HE MADE A STRONG ROPE WITH SEVERAL OF THE SHEETS THEN RETURNING TO THE MALE YARD
column5: he made a strong rope with several of the sheets then returning to the male yard

column4: GOT HOLD OF THE STEP LADDER USED IN LIGHTING THE GAS AND WHICH UNDER OUR MORE CAREFUL SUPERVISION WOULD HAVE BEEN AS NOWADAYS CHAINED UP
column5: got hold of the step ladder used in lighting the gas and which under our more careful supervision would have been as nowadays chained up

column4: CUTTING THE CORD WHICH FASTENED THE TWO LEGS OF THE STEP LADDER HE OPENED THEM OUT AND MADE ONE LONG LENGTH
column5: cutting the cord which fastened the two legs of the step ladder he opened them out and made one long length

column4: WITH THIS PLACED AGAINST THE WALL NEAR THE CHEVAUXDEFRISE HE MADE AN ESCALADE
column5: with this placed against the wall near the chevauxdefrise he made an escalade

column4: THE TOP OF THE WALL WAS GAINED WITHOUT DIFFICULTY
column5: the top of the wall was gained without difficulty

column4: ALONG THIS KRAPPS CRAWLED AND THEN DROPPED DOWN ON TO THE COOKHOUSE
column5: along this krapps crawled and then dropped down on to the cookhouse

column4: HE NOW PUT IN REQUISITION THE ROPE MADE OF THE SHEETS AND WITH ITS HELP LOWERED HIMSELF INTO THE STREET
column5: he now put in requisition the rope made of the sheets and with its help lowered himself into the street

column4: DOWN BELOW WERE MARKETCARTS WAITING FOR DAYLIGHT AND AMONG THEM KRAPPS FOUND A REFUGE AND FRIENDS
column5: down below were marketcarts waiting for daylight and among them krapps found a refuge and friends

column4: THE FIRST INTIMATION OF HIS ESCAPE WAS AFFORDED BY THE POLICE WHO INFORMED THE PRISON AUTHORITIES NEXT DAY THAT A ROPE WAS HANGING DOWN FROM THE COOKHOUSE ROOF
column5: the first intimation of his escape was afforded by the police who informed the prison authorities next day that a rope was hanging down from the cookhouse roof

column4: NOTHING MORE WAS HEARD OF KRAPPS THE CURIOUS THING IN HIS CASE WAS THAT HIS OFFENSE WAS A TRIFLING ONE
column5: nothing more was heard of krapps the curious thing in his case was that his offense was a trifling one

column4: HE WAS STILL UNTRIED BUT WOULD ALMOST CERTAINLY HAVE ESCAPED WITH A MINOR PENALTY SAY OF THREE OR FOUR MONTHS' IMPRISONMENT
column5: he was still untried but would almost certainly have escaped with a minor penalty say of three or four months' imprisonment

column4: THERE IS HOWEVER NO EXPLANATION OF THE MOTIVES WHICH PROMPT PRISONERS TO ATTEMPT ESCAPES
column5: there is however no explanation of the motives which prompt prisoners to attempt escapes

column4: CASES WELL AUTHENTICATED HAVE BEEN KNOWN OF MEN WHO HAD ALL BUT COMPLETED THEIR SENTENCES AND FOR WHOM THE PRISON GATES WOULD OPEN WITHIN A FEW DAYS
column5: cases well authenticated have been known of men who had all but completed their sentences and for whom the prison gates would open within a few days

column4: WHO YET FACED EXTRAORDINARY RISKS TO ADVANCE THEIR ENLARGEMENT BY ONLY A FEW HOURS
column5: who yet faced extraordinary risks to advance their enlargement by only a few hours

column4: ON THE OTHER HAND AT THE GREAT CONVICT ESTABLISHMENTS SUCH IS THE MORAL RESTRAINT OF A SYSTEMATIC DISCIPLINE
column5: on the other hand at the great convict establishments such is the moral restraint of a systematic discipline

column4: THAT NUMBERS OF MEN LIFERS AND OTHERS WITH TEN FOURTEEN OR TWENTY YEARS TO DO CAN BE TRUSTED TO WORK OUT OF DOORS WITHOUT BOLTS AND BARS
column5: that numbers of men lifers and others with ten fourteen or twenty years to do can be trusted to work out of doors without bolts and bars

column4: AT A DISTANCE FROM THE PRISON
column5: at a distance from the prison

column4: THE LAST ESCAPE FROM NEWGATE WAS ONLY THREE YEARS AGO AND OCCURRED JUST BEFORE THE FINAL CLOSING OF THE PRISON
column5: the last escape from newgate was only three years ago and occurred just before the final closing of the prison

column4: NO REPORT OF IT WAS MADE PUBLIC AS THE MAN WAS ALMOST IMMEDIATELY RECAPTURED
column5: no report of it was made public as the man was almost immediately recaptured

column4: HE WAS AT WORK UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE ARTISAN WARDER OF THE PRISON
column5: he was at work under the supervision of the artisan warder of the prison

column4: WHO PERMITTED HIM TO GO UP ON TO THE ROOF OF THE OLD WARDS IN ORDER TO THROW WATER FOR FLUSHING PURPOSES DOWN A SHOOT
column5: who permitted him to go up on to the roof of the old wards in order to throw water for flushing purposes down a shoot

column5: he was out of sight while so employed and remained so long absent that the warder becoming uneasy went in search of him

column4: HE HAD DISAPPEARED
column5: he had disappeared

column4: ENCOURAGED BY THE SHOUTS AND SIGNALS OF SOME WORKMEN EMPLOYED ON A BUILDING OUTSIDE THE PRISONER MADE ONE OF THE MOST MARVELLOUS JUMPS ON RECORD
column5: encouraged by the shouts and signals of some workmen employed on a building outside the prisoner made one of the most marvellous jumps on record

column4: FROM THE BUILDING HE WAS ON TO A DISTANT WALL WITH A DROP OF SIXTY FEET BETWEEN
column5: from the building he was on to a distant wall with a drop of sixty feet between

column5: then he ran along the coping of the wall towards its angle with tyler's manufactory and dropped down on to the gridiron below

column4: THIS WAS NOT STRONG ENOUGH TO CARRY HIM AND HE FELL THROUGH
column5: this was not strong enough to carry him and he fell through

column5: suicides and executions were however always the most effectual methods of making exit from durance

column5: suicides at newgate were numerous enough but they seldom possessed any novel or unusual features

column5: prison suicides seldom do except as regards ingenuity and determination

column4: ONLY GREAT RESOLUTION INDEED PERSISTED IN TO THE BITTER END

column4: THAT DAY PALMER HAD BOUGHT MORE STRYCHNIA AND HAD CALLED IN A FRESH DOCTOR
column5: that day palmer had bought more strychnia and had called in a fresh doctor

column4: THE SECOND ATTACK WAS FATAL AND ENDED IN COOK'S DEATH FROM TETANUS
column5: the second attack was fatal and ended in cook's death from tetanus

column4: THIS TETANUS ACCORDING TO THE PROSECUTION WAS PRODUCED BY STRYCHNIA AND FOLLOWED THE ADMINISTRATION OF PILLS BY PALMER
column5: this tetanus according to the prosecution was produced by strychnia and followed the administration of pills by palmer

column4: PRESCRIBED NOMINALLY BY THE FRESH DOCTOR FOR WHICH PALMER HAD SUBSTITUTED HIS OWN
column5: prescribed nominally by the fresh doctor for which palmer had substituted his own

column4: COOK'S DEATH WAS HORRIBLE
column5: cook's death was horrible

column4: FEARFUL PAROXYSMS AND CRAMPS ENDING IN SUFFOCATION BY THE TETANIC RIGOR WHICH CAUGHT THE MUSCLES OF THE CHEST
column5: fearful paroxysms and cramps ending in suffocation by the tetanic rigor which caught the muscles of the chest

column4: AFTER COOK'S DEATH HIS STEPFATHER WHO WAS MUCH ATTACHED TO HIM CAME TO RUGELEY
column5: after cook's death his stepfather who was much attached to him came to rugeley

column4: HE WAS STRUCK WITH THE APPEARANCE OF THE CORPSE WHICH WAS NOT EMACIATED AS AFTER A LONG DISEASE ENDING IN DEATH
column5: he was struck with the appearance of the corpse which was not emaciated as after a long disease ending in death

column4: WHILE THE MUSCLES OF THE FINGERS WERE TIGHTLY CLENCHED NOT OPEN AS USUAL IN A CORPSE
column5: while the muscles of the fingers were tightly clenched not open as usual in a corpse

column5: he said nothing but began to feel uneasy when he found that cook's bettingbook was missing and that palmer put it forward

column4: THAT HIS FRIEND HAD DIED GREATLY EMBARRASSED WITH BILLS TO THE AMOUNT OF FOUR THOUSAND POUNDS OUT IN HIS NAME
column5: that his friend had died greatly embarrassed with bills to the amount of four thousand pounds out in his name

column4: PALMER TOO SHOWED AN INDECENT HASTE IN PREPARING THE BODY FOR INTERMENT AND IN OBTAINING THE USUAL CERTIFICATE
column5: palmer too showed an indecent haste in preparing the body for interment and in obtaining the usual certificate

column4: AFTER THIS THE STEPFATHER INSISTED UPON A POSTMORTEM WHICH WAS CONDUCTED SOMEWHAT CARELESSLY
column5: after this the stepfather insisted upon a postmortem which was conducted somewhat carelessly

column4: THE INTESTINES WERE HOWEVER PRESERVED AND SENT FOR ANALYSIS
column5: the intestines were however preserved and sent for analysis

column4: BUT IT WAS PROVED THAT PALMER TRIED HARD TO GET POSSESSION OF THE JAR CONTAINING THEM
column5: but it was proved that palmer tried hard to get possession of the jar containing them

column4: AND EVEN SOUGHT TO UPSET THE VEHICLE BY WHICH THEY WERE BEING CONVEYED A PART OF THE WAY TO LONDON
column5: and even sought to upset the vehicle by which they were being conveyed a part of the way to london

column4: THE EXAMINATION OF THE STOMACH BETRAYED THE PRESENCE OF ANTIMONY IN LARGE QUANTITIES BUT NO STRYCHNIA
column5: the examination of the stomach betrayed the presence of antimony in large quantities but no strychnia

column4: AND IT WAS ON THE ENTIRE ABSENCE OF THE LATTER THAT THE DEFENSE WAS PRINCIPALLY BASED WHEN PALMER WAS BROUGHT TO TRIAL
column5: and it was on the entire absence of the latter that the defense was principally based when palmer was brought to trial

column4: ALL THE CIRCUMSTANCES WERE SO SUSPICIOUS THAT HE COULD NOT ESCAPE THE CRIMINAL CHARGE
column5: all the circumstances were so suspicious that he could not escape the criminal charge

column4: HE HAD ALREADY BEEN ARRESTED ON A WRIT ISSUED AT THE INSTANCE OF THE MONEYLENDERS AND AN ACTION HAD BEEN COMMENCED AGAINST MRS PALMER ON HER ACCEPTANCES
column5: he had already been arrested on a writ issued at the instance of the moneylenders and an action had been commenced against mrs palmer on her acceptances

column4: IT CAME OUT AT ONCE THAT THESE HAD BEEN FORGED AND THE WHOLE AFFAIR AT ONCE TOOK THE UGLIEST COMPLEXION
column5: it came out at once that these had been forged and the whole affair at once took the ugliest complexion

column4: A GOVERNMENT PROSECUTION WAS INSTITUTED AND PALMER WAS BROUGHT TO NEWGATE FOR TRIAL AT THE CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT
column5: a government prosecution was instituted and palmer was brought to newgate for trial at the central criminal court

column4: THERE WAS NOT MUCH RESERVE ABOUT HIM WHEN THERE
column5: there was not much reserve about him when there

column4: HE FREQUENTLY DECLARED BEFORE AND DURING THE TRIAL THAT IT WOULD BE IMPOSSIBLE TO FIND HIM GUILTY
column5: he frequently declared before and during the trial that it would be impossible to find him guilty

column4: HE NEVER ACTUALLY SAID THAT HE WAS NOT GUILTY BUT HE WAS CONFIDENT HE WOULD NOT BE CONVICTED
column5: he never actually said that he was not guilty but he was confident he would not be convicted

column4: HE RELIED ON THE ABSENCE OF THE STRYCHNIA
column5: he relied on the absence of the strychnia

column4: BUT THE CHAIN OF CIRCUMSTANTIAL EVIDENCE WAS STRONG ENOUGH TO SATISFY THE JURY WHO AGREED TO THEIR VERDICT IN AN HOUR
column5: but the chain of circumstantial evidence was strong enough to satisfy the jury who agreed to their verdict in an hour

column4: AT THE LAST MOMENT PALMER TOSSED A BIT OF PAPER OVER TO HIS COUNSEL ON WHICH HE HAD WRITTEN QUOTE I THINK THERE WILL BE A VERDICT OF NOT GUILTY END QUOTE
column5: at the last moment palmer tossed a bit of paper over to his counsel on which he had written quote i think there will be a verdict of not guilty end quote

column4: EVEN AFTER THE DEATH SENTENCE HAD BEEN PASSED UPON HIM HE CLUNG TO THE HOPE THAT THE GOVERNMENT WOULD GRANT HIM A REPRIEVE
column5: even after the death sentence had been passed upon him he clung to the hope that the government would grant him a reprieve

column4: TO THE LAST THEREFORE HE PLAYED THE PART OF A MAN WRONGFULLY CONVICTED AND DID NOT ABANDON HOPE
column5: to the last therefore he played the part of a man wrongfully convicted and did not abandon hope

column4: EVEN WHEN THE HIGH SHERIFF HAD TOLD HIM THERE WAS NO POSSIBILITY OF A REPRIEVE AND WITHIN A FEW HOURS OF EXECUTION
column5: even when the high sheriff had told him there was no possibility of a reprieve and within a few hours of execution

column4: HE SUFFERED AT STAFFORD IN FRONT OF THE JAIL
column5: he suffered at stafford in front of the jail

column5: palmer speedily found imitators

column5: within a few weeks occurred the leeds poisoning case in which the murderer undoubtedly was inspired by the facts made public at palmer's trial

column4: DOVE A FIENDISH BRUTE FOUND FROM THE EVIDENCE IN THAT CASE THAT HE COULD KILL HIS WIFE WHOM HE HATED
column5: dove a fiendish brute found from the evidence in that case that he could kill his wife whom he hated

column4: WITH EXQUISITE TORTURE AND WITH A POISON THAT WOULD LEAVE AS HE THOUGHT NO TRACE
column5: with exquisite torture and with a poison that would leave as he thought no trace

column4: IN THE LATTER HOPE HE WAS HAPPILY DISAPPOINTED BUT AS THIS CASE IS BEYOND MY SUBJECT I MERELY MENTION IT AS ONE OF THE GROUP ALREADY REFERRED TO
column5: in the latter hope he was happily disappointed but as this case is beyond my subject i merely mention it as one of the group already referred to

column4: THREE YEARS LATER CAME THE CASE OF DR SMETHURST
column5: three years later came the case of dr smethurst

column4: PRESENTING STILL GREATER FEATURES OF RESEMBLANCE WITH PALMER'S FOR BOTH WERE MEDICAL MEN AND BOTH RAISED DIFFICULT QUESTIONS OF MEDICAL JURISPRUDENCE
column5: presenting still greater features of resemblance with palmer's for both were medical men and both raised difficult questions of medical jurisprudence

column5: in both the jury had no doubt as to the guilt of the accused only in smethurst's case the then home secretary sir george cornewall lewis

column4: COULD NOT DIVEST HIS MIND OF SERIOUS DOUBT AND OF WHICH THE MURDERER GOT THE BENEFIT
column5: could not divest his mind of serious doubt and of which the murderer got the benefit

column4: SMETHURST'S ESCAPE MAY HAVE INFLUENCED THE JURY IN THE POPLAR POISONING CASE
column5: smethurst's escape may have influenced the jury in the poplar poisoning case

column4: WHICH FOLLOWED CLOSE ON ITS HEELS ALTHOUGH IN THAT THE VERDICT OF NOT GUILTY WAS EXCUSABLE AS THE EVIDENCE WAS ENTIRELY CIRCUMSTANTIAL
column5: which followed close on its heels although in that the verdict of not guilty was excusable as the evidence was entirely circumstantial

column5: there was no convincing proof that the accused had administered the poison although beyond question that poison had occasioned the death

column4: DR SMETHURST WAS LONG AN INMATE OF NEWGATE AND WAS TRIED AT THE CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT
column5: dr smethurst was long an inmate of newgate and was tried at the central criminal court

column5: he had all the characteristics of the poisoner  the calm deliberation

column4: THE PROTRACTED DISSIMULATION AS WITH UNSHRINKING RELENTLESS WICKEDNESS THE DEADLY WORK IS CARRIED ON TO THE END
column5: the protracted dissimulation as with unshrinking relentless wickedness the deadly work is carried on to the end

column5: smethurst's victim was a miss bankes with whom he had contracted a bigamous marriage

column4: HE HAD MET HER AT A BOARDINGHOUSE WHERE HE LIVED WITH HIS OWN WIFE A PERSON OF SHADY ANTECEDENTS
column5: he had met her at a boardinghouse where he lived with his own wife a person of shady antecedents

column4: AND WHOM HE LEFT WITHOUT SCRUPLE TO JOIN MISS BANKES
column5: and whom he left without scruple to join miss bankes

column4: THE LATTER SEEMS TO HAVE SUCCUMBED ONLY TOO WILLINGLY TO HIS FASCINATIONS AND TO HAVE AS READILY AGREED TO MARRY HIM
column5: the latter seems to have succumbed only too willingly to his fascinations and to have as readily agreed to marry him

column4: IN SPITE OF THE EXISTENCE OF THE OTHER MRS SMETHURST
column5: in spite of the existence of the other mrs smethurst

column5: probably the doctor had told her the story he brought forward when tried for bigamy namely

column4: THAT MRS SMETHURST HAD NO RIGHT TO THE NAME BUT HAD A HUSBAND OF HER OWN ONE JOHNSON ALIVE  A STORY SUBSEQUENTLY DISPROVED
column5: that mrs smethurst had no right to the name but had a husband of her own one johnson alive  a story subsequently disproved

column5: miss bankes seems to have counted upon some species of whitewashing no less than the repudiation of the other marriage

column4: AND TOLD HER SISTER AS MUCH WHEN THEY LAST MET
column5: and told her sister as much when they last met

column5: for some months smethurst and miss bankes lived together as man and wife first in london and then at richmond

column5: she had a little fortune of her own some one thousand seven hundred pounds or one thousand eight hundred pounds

column4: AND A LIFEINTEREST IN FIVE THOUSAND POUNDS A FACT ON WHICH SMETHURST'S COUNSEL DWELT WITH MUCH WEIGHT
column5: and a lifeinterest in five thousand pounds a fact on which smethurst's counsel dwelt with much weight

column4: AS INDICATING A MOTIVE FOR KEEPING HER ALIVE RATHER THAN KILLING HER
column5: as indicating a motive for keeping her alive rather than killing her

column5: but probably the lump sum was the bait or perhaps smethurst wished to return to his temporarily deserted first wife

column5: whatever the exact cause which impelled him to crime it seems certain that he began to give her some poison

column5: either arsenic or antimony or both in small quantities

column5: with the idea of subjecting her to the irritant poison slowly but surely until the desired effect death was achieved

column5: as she became worse and worse smethurst called in the best medical advice in richmond

column5: but was careful to prime them with his facts and lead them if possible to accept his diagnosis of the case

column5: smethurst was found guilty by the jury and sentenced to death

column5: but a long public discussion followed and in consequence he was reprieved

column5: there is not absolute and complete evidence of his guilt end quote

column5: but he was subsequently again tried for bigamy and sentenced to twelve months' imprisonment

column5: catherine wilson was a female poisoner who did business wholesale

column5: she was tried in april eighteen sixtytwo on suspicion of having attempted to poison a neighbor with oil of vitriol

column5: the circumstances were strange mrs wilson had gone to the chemist's for medicine

column5: in all cases the symptoms were much the same

column5: vomiting violent retching purging such as are visible in cholera and all dated from the time when she knew a young man named dixon

column5: who had been in the habit of taking colchicum for rheumatism mrs wilson heard then casually from a medical man

column5: that it was a very dangerous medicine and she profited by what she had heard

column5: soon afterwards dixon died showing all the symptoms already described

column5: while with mrs wilson she became suddenly and alarmingly ill and died in great agony

column5: her husband who came up to town would not allow a postmortem and again mrs wilson escaped

column5: mrs atkinson's symptoms had been the same as dixon's then mrs wilson went to live with a man named taylor

column5: who was presently attacked in the same way as the others but but thanks to the prompt administration of remedies he recovered

column5: after this came the charge of administering oil of vitriol which failed as has been described

column5: that immediately afterwards mrs soames was taken ill with vomiting and purging

column5: and that mrs wilson administered the same medicine again and again

column5: the last time mrs soames showed great reluctance to take it but wilson said it would certainly do her good

column5: this mysterious medicine wilson kept carefully locked up and allowed no one to see it

column5: but its nature was betrayed when this last victim also died

column5: but a more careful investigation attributed it beyond doubt to overdoses of colchicum

column5: dr alfred taylor the great authority and writer on medical jurisprudence corroborated this and in his evidence on the trial

column5: this fact was referred to by the judge in his summing up

column5: wilson was duly sentenced to death and suffered impenitent hardened and without any confession of her guilt

column5: the first case was that of the 'flowery land'

column5: her captain was john smith

column5: most of them as was proved by their subsequent acts blackguards of the deepest dye

column5: six were spaniards or rather natives of manilla and men of color one was a greek another a turk

column5: the captain's brother a passenger on board the 'flowery land' was also stabbed to death and his body thrown overboard

column5: the old gentleman's signature to this deed of gift was a forgery

column4: BUT UPON THIS FORGED AND FALSE CONVEYANCE WILLIAM ROUPELL WHO HAD ALREADY EMBARKED UPON A CAREER OF WILD EXTRAVAGANCE
column5: but upon this forged and false conveyance william roupell who had already embarked upon a career of wild extravagance

column4: OBTAINED A MORTGAGE OF SEVEN THOUSAND POUNDS
column5: obtained a mortgage of seven thousand pounds

column4: IN EIGHTEEN FIFTYSIX THE FATHER DIED
column5: in eighteen fiftysix the father died

column4: IT HAD BEEN SUPPOSED UP TO THIS DATE THAT HE HAD WILLED HIS PROPERTY AMOUNTING IN ALL TO UPWARDS OF TWO HUNDRED THOUSAND POUNDS
column5: it had been supposed up to this date that he had willed his property amounting in all to upwards of two hundred thousand pounds

column5: but after the funeral william roupell produced another and a later will

column4: LEAVING EVERYTHING TO THE WIDOW AND CONSTITUTING WILLIAM SOLE EXECUTOR
column5: leaving everything to the widow and constituting william sole executor

column4: THIS WILL WAS A DELIBERATE FORGERY
column5: this will was a deliberate forgery

column5: five or six years later william roupell minutely described how he had effected the fraud

column5: the day his father died he got the keys of his private bureau opened it and took out the authentic will

column4: AFTER READING IT AND FINDING THIS UNFAVORABLE TO HIMSELF HE RESOLVED TO CARRY OUT HIS DELIBERATE PLAN
column5: after reading it and finding this unfavorable to himself he resolved to carry out his deliberate plan

column4: NAMELY TO SUPPRESS IT AND SUBSTITUTE ANOTHER
column5: namely to suppress it and substitute another

column4: HE HIMSELF PREPARED IT ON A BLANK FORM WHICH HE HAD BROUGHT WITH HIM ON PURPOSE
column5: he himself prepared it on a blank form which he had brought with him on purpose

column4: TO THIS FRAUDULENT INSTRUMENT HE APPENDED FORGED SIGNATURES AND IN DUE COURSE OBTAINED PROBATE
column5: to this fraudulent instrument he appended forged signatures and in due course obtained probate

column5: as he possessed nearly unbounded influence over his mother her accession to the property meant that william could dispose of it as he pleased

column5: he embarked forthwith in a career of the wildest extravagance and ere long he had parted in his mother's name with most of the landed estates

column5: his disappearance gave color and substance to evil reports already in circulation that the will and conveyance above referred to

column5: he confessed himself a perjurer in having sworn to the false will and a wholesale forger having manufactured no less than ten false signatures

column5: his uniform good conduct gained him release from portland on ticketofleave in eighteen eightytwo just twenty years after his conviction

column5: then he explained to the bank manager

column5: the site of which was to be sold to christ's hospital but the intention was of course to embody and absorb old newgate in the new construction

column5: the proposal made was to purchase some fifty thousand square feet between newgate warwick lane and the sessions house

column4: THE SITUATION HAVING BEEN PROVED BY LONG EXPERIENCE TO BE SALUBRIOUS
column5: the situation having been proved by long experience to be salubrious

column5: it was urged that the area selected for purchase must be excessively costly to acquire and still quite inadequate for the city needs

column5: the home secretary had laid it down that at least five acres would be indispensable and such an area it was impossible to obtain within the limits of the city

column5: why not move the city prison bodily into this more rural spot with its purer air and greater breathing space

column4: THE NECESSARY PRELIMINARIES TOOK SOME TIME BUT THE CONTRACTS FOR THE NEW BUILDING WERE COMPLETED IN EIGHTEEN FORTYNINE WHEN THE WORKS WERE COMMENCED

column4: IT WAS TO ACCOMMODATE ONLY THE CONVICTED PRISONERS SENTENCED TO TERMS SHORT OF PENAL SERVITUDE AND AFTER ITS COMPLETION
column5: it was to accommodate only the convicted prisoners sentenced to terms short of penal servitude and after its completion

column4: IT WAS INTENDED AS FAR AS POSSIBLE THAT EXCEPT AWAITING TRIAL NO PRISONER SHOULD FIND HIMSELF RELEGATED TO NEWGATE

column4: THIS PRINCIPLE BECAME MORE AND MORE GENERALLY THE RULE ALTHOUGH IT HAS NEVER BEEN PUNCTILIOUSLY OBSERVED NOW AND AGAIN

column5: misdemeanants have found their way into newgate and within the last few years one offender against the privileges of the house of commons

column5: with the reduction of numbers to be accommodated there was ample space in newgate for its reconstruction on the most approved modern lines

column5: this block contained one hundred and thirty cells embracing every modern improvement

column4: THIS BLOCK WAS COMPLETED IN EIGHTEEN FIFTYNINE AFTER WHICH THE HITHERTO UNAVOIDABLE AND LONGCONTINUED PROMISCUOUS ASSOCIATION OF PRISONERS
column5: this block was completed in eighteen fiftynine after which the hitherto unavoidable and longcontinued promiscuous association of prisoners

column5: in eighteen sixtyone a similar work was undertaken to provide separate cellular accommodation for the female inmates of newgate

column4: AND BY THE FOLLOWING YEAR FORTYSEVEN NEW CELLS HAD BEEN BUILT ON THE MOST APPROVED PLAN

column5: during this reconstruction the female prisoners were lodged in holloway

column5: the first glass house or room in which prisoners could talk in private with their attorneys but yet be seen by the warder on the watch had been constructed

column4: BUT NO STRUCTURAL ALTERATIONS WERE MADE FROM THE DATE FIRST QUOTED UNTIL THE TIME OF CLOSING THE PRISON IN EIGHTEEN EIGHTYONE

column4: BUT IN THE INTERVAL VERY COMPREHENSIVE AND I THINK IT MUST BE ADMITTED SALUTARY CHANGES WERE SUCCESSIVELY INTRODUCED INTO THE MANAGEMENT OF PRISONS
column5: but in the interval very comprehensive and i think it must be admitted salutary changes were successively introduced into the management of prisons

column4: NEWGATE NATURALLY SHARED IN ANY ADVANTAGES DUE TO THESE REFORMS I PROPOSE THEREFORE TO REFER TO THEM IN THE CONCLUDING PAGES OF THIS WORK
column5: newgate naturally shared in any advantages due to these reforms i propose therefore to refer to them in the concluding pages of this work

column4: AND THUS BRING THE HISTORY OF PRISON DISCIPLINE DOWN TO OUR OWN TIMES
column5: and thus bring the history of prison discipline down to our own times

column5: the last inquiry into the condition and management of our jails and houses of correction was that made by the lords' committee in eighteen sixtythree

column4: THE INQUIRY WAS MOST SEARCHING AND COMPLETE AND THE COMMITTEE SPOKE PLAINLY IN ITS REPORT
column5: the inquiry was most searching and complete and the committee spoke plainly in its report

column4: IT ANIMADVERTED STRONGLY ON THE MANY AND WIDE DIFFERENCES AS REGARDS CONSTRUCTION LABOR DIET AND GENERAL DISCIPLINE
column5: it animadverted strongly on the many and wide differences as regards construction labor diet and general discipline

column4: WHICH EXISTED IN THE VARIOUS PRISONS
column5: which existed in the various prisons

column4: LEADING TO AN INEQUALITY UNCERTAINTY AND INEFFICIENCY OF PUNISHMENT PRODUCTIVE OF THE MOST PREJUDICIAL RESULTS
column5: leading to an inequality uncertainty and inefficiency of punishment productive of the most prejudicial results

column4: THE VARIETIES IN CONSTRUCTION WERE STILL VERY MARKED
column5: the varieties in construction were still very marked

column5: in many prisons the prisoners were still associated and from the want of a sufficient number of cells the principle of separation was still greatly neglected

column4: YET THIS PRINCIPLE AS THE COMMITTEE POINTED OUT MUST NOW BE ACCEPTED AS THE FOUNDATION OF PRISON DISCIPLINE
column5: yet this principle as the committee pointed out must now be accepted as the foundation of prison discipline

column4: WHILE ITS RIGID MAINTENANCE WAS IN ITS OPINION VITAL TO THE EFFICIENCY OF THE JAILS
column5: while its rigid maintenance was in its opinion vital to the efficiency of the jails

column4: EVEN WHERE CELLS HAD BEEN BUILT
column5: even where cells had been built

column4: THEY WERE FREQUENTLY BELOW THE STANDARD SIZE AND WERE THEREFORE NOT CERTIFIED FOR OCCUPATION AS WAS REQUIRED BY LAW
column5: they were frequently below the standard size and were therefore not certified for occupation as was required by law

column5: great numbers were not lighted at night and were without means by which their inmates could communicate in case of urgent necessity with their keepers

column5: still greater were the differences with regard to employment the various authorities held widely different opinions as to what constituted hard labor

column5: here the treadwheel was in use there cellular cranks or hardlabor machines

column5: both however varied greatly in mechanism and in the amount of energy they called forth

column5: while the former was intended for the congregate labor of a number and the latter as its name implies imposed continuous solitary toil

column5: at other prisons shotdrill the lifting and carrying of heavy round shot was the favorite method of inflicting penal labor

column5: and it was decidedly of opinion that in all short sentences the hard labor of the treadwheel crank and so forth should be the invariable rule

column5: in dietaries again the same wide diversity of practice obtained

column5: the efforts made by sir james graham years before to introduce uniformity in this particular had failed of effect

column5: in a word the value of diet as a part of penal discipline was still insufficiently recognized

column5: the prisons were still far from inflicting the three punishments hard labor hard fare and a hard bed

column5: there was unrestrained association of untried and convicted juvenile with adult prisoners vagrants misdemeanants felons

column5: which warders dreading assault were afraid to enter after dark even to check rioting and disturbance
