column4: BUT DISCIPLINE WAS TO BE MAINTAINED IF NECESSARY BY PUNISHMENT
column5: but discipline was to be maintained if necessary by punishment

column4: WHILE DECENCY AND GOOD ORDER WERE TO BE INSURED BY THE STRICT PROHIBITION OF GAMBLING AND DRUNKENNESS
column5: while decency and good order were to be insured by the strict prohibition of gambling and drunkenness

column4: THE LATTER WAS RENDERED NEARLY IMPOSSIBLE BY THE PENALTIES IMPOSED ON PERSONS BRINGING SPIRITUOUS LIQUORS INTO THE JAIL
column5: the latter was rendered nearly impossible by the penalties imposed on persons bringing spirituous liquors into the jail

column4: THE OLD CUSTOM SO FRUITFUL OF THE WORST EVILS OF KEEPING A TAP INSIDE THE PRISON WAS MADE ILLEGAL
column5: the old custom so fruitful of the worst evils of keeping a tap inside the prison was made illegal

column4: SO WAS THE EMPLOYMENT OF PRISONERS IN ANY POSITION OF TRUST OR AUTHORITY
column5: so was the employment of prisoners in any position of trust or authority

column4: THEY WERE NOT TO BE TURNKEYS OR ASSISTANT TURNKEYS NEITHER WARDSMAN NOR YARDSMAN OVERSEER
column5: they were not to be turnkeys or assistant turnkeys neither wardsman nor yardsman overseer

column4: MONITOR OR SCHOOLMASTER NOR TO BE ENGAGED IN THE SERVICE OF ANY OFFICER OF THE PRISON
column5: monitor or schoolmaster nor to be engaged in the service of any officer of the prison

column4: THE ACT OF EIGHTEEN SIXTYFIVE ALSO ENCOURAGED AND EMPOWERED THE LOCAL AUTHORITIES TO ALTER ENLARGE OR REBUILD THEIR PRISONS
column5: the act of eighteen sixtyfive also encouraged and empowered the local authorities to alter enlarge or rebuild their prisons

column4: THEY MIGHT RAISE FUNDS FOR THIS PURPOSE PROVIDED A CERTIFICATE FOR THE NECESSITY FOR THE NEW WORKS WAS GIVEN EITHER BY THE RECORDER
column5: they might raise funds for this purpose provided a certificate for the necessity for the new works was given either by the recorder

column4: CHAIRMAN OF QUARTER SESSIONS OR EVEN BY A COUPLE OF JUSTICES
column5: chairman of quarter sessions or even by a couple of justices

column4: EVERY FACILITY WAS PROMISED THE SANCTION OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE WOULD NOT BE WITHHELD IF PLANS AND ESTIMATES WERE DULY SUBMITTED
column5: every facility was promised the sanction of the secretary of state would not be withheld if plans and estimates were duly submitted

column4: AND THEY MET WITH THE APPROVAL OF HIS PROFESSIONAL ADVISER THE SURVEYORGENERAL OF PRISONS
column5: and they met with the approval of his professional adviser the surveyorgeneral of prisons

column4: THE FUNDS NECESSARY WOULD BE ADVANCED BY THE PUBLIC WORKS LOAN COMMISSIONERS AND THE INTEREST MIGHT BE CHARGED AGAINST THE COUNTY OR BOROUGH RATES
column5: the funds necessary would be advanced by the public works loan commissioners and the interest might be charged against the county or borough rates

column4: NOR WERE THESE THE ONLY INDUCEMENTS OFFERED WHERE LOCAL AUTHORITIES WERE INDISPOSED TO SET THEIR PRISONS IN ORDER
column5: nor were these the only inducements offered where local authorities were indisposed to set their prisons in order

column4: OR HESITATED TO EMBARK UPON ANY CONSIDERABLE EXPENDITURE TO ALTER OR REBUILD
column5: or hesitated to embark upon any considerable expenditure to alter or rebuild

column4: THEY WERE AT LIBERTY TO HIRE SUITABLE CELL ACCOMMODATION FROM ANY NEIGHBORS WHO MIGHT HAVE IT TO SPARE THE ONLY PROVISO
column5: they were at liberty to hire suitable cell accommodation from any neighbors who might have it to spare the only proviso

column4: THAT NO SUCH CONTRACT WAS VALID BETWEEN ONE JURISDICTION AND ANOTHER UNLESS THE SECRETARY OF STATE WAS SATISFIED THAT THE PRISON IT WAS INTENDED TO USE
column5: that no such contract was valid between one jurisdiction and another unless the secretary of state was satisfied that the prison it was intended to use

column4: CAME UP IN ALL RESPECTS TO MODERN REQUIREMENTS
column5: came up in all respects to modern requirements

column4: BUT THE ACT WAS NOT LIMITED TO PERMISSIVE LEGISLATION ITS PROVISIONS AND ENACTMENTS WERE BACKED UP BY CERTAIN PENALTIES
column5: but the act was not limited to permissive legislation its provisions and enactments were backed up by certain penalties

column4: THE SECRETARY OF STATE WAS EMPOWERED TO DEAL RATHER SUMMARILY WITH INADEQUATE PRISONS IN OTHER WORDS
column5: the secretary of state was empowered to deal rather summarily with inadequate prisons in other words

column4: WITH THOSE IN WHICH THERE WAS NO SEPARATION NO PROPER ENFORCEMENT OF HARD LABOR NO CHAPEL INFIRMARY AND SO FORTH
column5: with those in which there was no separation no proper enforcement of hard labor no chapel infirmary and so forth

column4: HE COULD IN THE FIRST PLACE WITHHOLD THE GOVERNMENT GRANT IN AID OF PRISON FUNDS BY REFUSING THE CERTIFICATE TO THE TREASURY UPON WHICH THE ALLOWANCE WAS PAID
column5: he could in the first place withhold the government grant in aid of prison funds by refusing the certificate to the treasury upon which the allowance was paid

column4: THIS HE MIGHT DO ON THE REPRESENTATION OF THE INSPECTOR OF PRISONS
column5: this he might do on the representation of the inspector of prisons

column4: WHO WAS BOUND TO REPORT ANY DEFICIENCIES AND ABUSES HE MIGHT FIND AT HIS PERIODICAL VISITS THE SECRETARY OF STATE MIGHT GO FURTHER
column5: who was bound to report any deficiencies and abuses he might find at his periodical visits the secretary of state might go further

column4: WHERE THE LOCAL AUTHORITY HAD NEGLECTED TO COMPLY WITH THE PROVISIONS OF THE EIGHTEEN SIXTYFIVE ACT FOR FOUR CONSECUTIVE YEARS
column5: where the local authority had neglected to comply with the provisions of the eighteen sixtyfive act for four consecutive years

column4: HE COULD CLOSE THE INADEQUATE PRISON BY DECLARING IT UNFIT FOR THE RECEPTION OF PRISONERS
column5: he could close the inadequate prison by declaring it unfit for the reception of prisoners

column4: HIS ORDER WOULD AT THE SAME TIME SPECIFY SOME NEIGHBORING AND MORE SATISFACTORY PRISON WHICH THE LOCAL AUTHORITY WOULD BE COMPELLED TO UTILIZE INSTEAD
column5: his order would at the same time specify some neighboring and more satisfactory prison which the local authority would be compelled to utilize instead

column4: AND WITH THE CONCURRENCE OF THE OTHER AUTHORITY AND ON PAYMENT A FEW PROVISOS GOVERNED THESE RATHER EXTENSIVE POWERS
column5: and with the concurrence of the other authority and on payment a few provisos governed these rather extensive powers

column4: IT WAS NECESSARY FOR INSTANCE TO GIVE DUE NOTICE WHEN THE GOVERNMENT GRANT WAS TO BE WITHDRAWN
column5: it was necessary for instance to give due notice when the government grant was to be withdrawn

column4: AND WITH THE WARNING A COPY OF THE PARTICULAR DEFECTS AND ALLEGATIONS WAS TO BE SENT TO THE LOCAL AUTHORITY
column5: and with the warning a copy of the particular defects and allegations was to be sent to the local authority

column4: THE LATTER TOO WAS TO BE LAID BEFORE THE HOUSE OF COMMONS
column5: the latter too was to be laid before the house of commons

column4: IN THE SAME WAY SIX MONTHS' NOTICE WAS REQUIRED IN CASES WHERE THE CLOSING OF A PRISON WAS CONTEMPLATED
column5: in the same way six months' notice was required in cases where the closing of a prison was contemplated

column4: BUT IF THESE CONDITIONS WERE OBSERVED THE SECRETARY OF STATE COULD DEAL SHARPLY ENOUGH WITH THE DEFAULTING JURISDICTIONS
column5: but if these conditions were observed the secretary of state could deal sharply enough with the defaulting jurisdictions

column4: YET THE LAW WAS SELDOM IF EVER ENFORCED
column5: yet the law was seldom if ever enforced

column4: IT WAS PRACTICALLY INOPERATIVE AS REGARDS THE PENALTIES FOR NEGLECT IT WAS NO DOUBT AS IRKSOME AND INCONVENIENT TO THE SECRETARY OF STATE
column5: it was practically inoperative as regards the penalties for neglect it was no doubt as irksome and inconvenient to the secretary of state

column4: TO AVAIL HIMSELF OF HIS POWERS AS IT WAS DIFFICULT TO BRING HOME THE DERELICTIONS OF DUTIES AND EVASION OF THE ACTS TOO MUCH WAS LEFT TO THE INSPECTORS
column5: to avail himself of his powers as it was difficult to bring home the derelictions of duties and evasion of the acts too much was left to the inspectors

column4: IT WAS NEARLY IMPOSSIBLE FOR THEM TO EXERCISE A VERY CLOSE SUPERVISION OVER THE WHOLE OF THE PRISONS OF THE COUNTRY
column5: it was nearly impossible for them to exercise a very close supervision over the whole of the prisons of the country

column4: THERE WERE ONLY TWO OF THEM AND THEY COULD NOT VISIT EACH PRISON MORE THAN ONCE IN EACH YEAR SOMETIMES NOT OFTENER THAN ONCE IN EIGHTEEN MONTHS
column5: there were only two of them and they could not visit each prison more than once in each year sometimes not oftener than once in eighteen months

column4: THE TASK IMPOSED UPON THEM TENDING AS IT DID TO THE IMPOSITION OF A FINE UPON THE LOCAL AUTHORITIES WAS NOT A PLEASANT ONE
column5: the task imposed upon them tending as it did to the imposition of a fine upon the local authorities was not a pleasant one

column4: AND IT IS NOT STRANGE IF THEY DID NOT VERY FREQUENTLY HAND UP THE OFFENDERS TO THE REPROOF AND CORRECTION OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE
column5: and it is not strange if they did not very frequently hand up the offenders to the reproof and correction of the secretary of state

column4: AS THE ALMOST INEVITABLE CONSEQUENCE WHILE THE MORE GLARING DEFECTS IN PRISON MANAGEMENT DISAPPEARED
column5: as the almost inevitable consequence while the more glaring defects in prison management disappeared

column4: MATTERS WENT ON AFTER THE EIGHTEEN SIXTYFIVE ACT MUCH THE SAME AS THEY HAD DONE BEFORE DISTRICTS DIFFERED GREATLY IN THE ATTENTION THEY PAID TO PRISON AFFAIRS
column5: matters went on after the eighteen sixtyfive act much the same as they had done before districts differed greatly in the attention they paid to prison affairs

column4: IN ONE PART THE MOST PRAISEWORTHY ACTIVITY PREVAILED
column5: in one part the most praiseworthy activity prevailed

column4: IN ANOTHER THERE WAS HALFHEARTEDNESS EVEN APATHY AND AN ALMOST COMPLETE CONTEMPT FOR THE PROVISIONS OF THE ACT
column5: in another there was halfheartedness even apathy and an almost complete contempt for the provisions of the act

column4: AS THE YEARS PASSED GREAT WANT OF UNIFORMITY CONTINUED TO PREVAIL THROUGHOUT THE PRISONS OF THE UNITED KINGDOM
column5: as the years passed great want of uniformity continued to prevail throughout the prisons of the united kingdom

column4: THE WHOLE QUESTION ASSUMED SUFFICIENT IMPORTANCE TO BECOME A PART OF THE GOVERNMENT PROGRAM WHEN LORD BEACONSFIELD TOOK OFFICE IN EIGHTEEN SEVENTYFOUR
column5: the whole question assumed sufficient importance to become a part of the government program when lord beaconsfield took office in eighteen seventyfour

column4: THE HOME SECRETARY IN THAT ADMINISTRATION
column5: the home secretary in that administration

column4: MR NOW SIR RICHARD CROSS HAVING APPLIED HIMSELF VIGOROUSLY TO THE TASK OF REORGANIZING THE WHOLE SYSTEM BECAME CONVINCED
column5: mr now sir richard cross having applied himself vigorously to the task of reorganizing the whole system became convinced

column4: THAT NO COMPLETE REFORM COULD BE ACCOMPLISHED SO LONG AS THE PRISONS WERE LEFT UNDER THE JURISDICTION OF THE LOCAL AUTHORITIES
column5: that no complete reform could be accomplished so long as the prisons were left under the jurisdiction of the local authorities

column4: THE PRISONS BILL OF EIGHTEEN SEVENTYSIX CONTEMPLATED THE TRANSFER OF THE PRISONS TO GOVERNMENT
column5: the prisons bill of eighteen seventysix contemplated the transfer of the prisons to government

column4: THIS BILL REINTRODUCED IN EIGHTEEN SEVENTYSEVEN BECAME LAW THAT YEAR AFTER WHICH THE WHOLE OF THE PRISONS INCLUDING NEWGATE
column5: this bill reintroduced in eighteen seventyseven became law that year after which the whole of the prisons including newgate

column4: PASSED UNDER THE MORE DIRECT CONTROL OF THE STATE
column5: passed under the more direct control of the state

column4: SINCE THEN A STRONG CENTRAL AUTHORITY HAS LABORED STEADFASTLY TO COMPASS CONCENTRATION
column5: since then a strong central authority has labored steadfastly to compass concentration

column4: TO CLOSE USELESS PRISONS AND TO INSURE THAT UNIFORMITY OF SYSTEM WHICH ALL THOUGHTFUL PERSONS HAD LONG ADMITTED TO BE OF PARAMOUNT IMPORTANCE
column5: to close useless prisons and to insure that uniformity of system which all thoughtful persons had long admitted to be of paramount importance

column4: IN THE ADMINISTRATION OF PRISONS
column5: in the administration of prisons

column4: THREE YEARS AFTER THE ADVENT OF THE PRISON COMMISSIONERS IT WAS DECIDED THAT NEWGATE WAS AN EXCESSIVELY COSTLY AND REDUNDANT ESTABLISHMENT
column5: three years after the advent of the prison commissioners it was decided that newgate was an excessively costly and redundant establishment

column4: IT WAS ONLY FILLED AT THE PERIODS WHEN THE SESSIONS OF THE CENTRAL CRIMINAL COURT WERE IN PROGRESS
column5: it was only filled at the periods when the sessions of the central criminal court were in progress

column4: AT OTHERS AN EXPENSIVE STAFF WAS MAINTAINED WITH LITTLE OR NOTHING TO DO
column5: at others an expensive staff was maintained with little or nothing to do

column4: AT A SHORT DISTANCE STOOD ANOTHER PRISON OF DETENTION THAT OF CLERKENWELL
column5: at a short distance stood another prison of detention that of clerkenwell

column4: WITH SPARE ACCOMMODATION SUFFICIENT TO RECEIVE ALL PRISONERS WHO WERE THEN COMMITTED TO NEWGATE THESE ARGUMENTS WERE UNANSWERABLE
column5: with spare accommodation sufficient to receive all prisoners who were then committed to newgate these arguments were unanswerable

column4: ACCORDINGLY IT WAS ORDERED BY SIR WILLIAM HARCOURT THE PRESENT SECRETARY OF STATE THAT NEWGATE SHOULD CEASE TO BE USED AS A REGULAR PRISON
column5: accordingly it was ordered by sir william harcourt the present secretary of state that newgate should cease to be used as a regular prison

column4: AND IT IS NOW EXCEPT DURING SESSIONS OR WHEN THE GALLOWS IS IN REQUISITION PRACTICALLY AND FOR EVER CLOSED
column5: and it is now except during sessions or when the gallows is in requisition practically and for ever closed

column4: MARION HARLAND'S COOKERY FOR BEGINNERS BREAD SPONGE AND BREAKFAST BREADS
column5: marion harland's cookery for beginners bread sponge and breakfast breads

column4: BREAD RAISED WITH WHAT IS KNOWN TO BAKERS AS A SPONGE REQUIRES MORE TIME AND A TRIFLE MORE WORK THAN THE SIMPLER FORM FOR WHICH I HAVE JUST ALREADY GIVEN DIRECTIONS
column5: bread raised with what is known to bakers as a sponge requires more time and a trifle more work than the simpler form for which i have just already given directions

column4: BUT IT KEEPS FRESH LONGER IS SOFTER AND MORE NUTRITIOUS AND A SECONDRATE BRAND OF FLOUR THUS TREATED PRODUCES A BETTER LOAF
column5: but it keeps fresh longer is softer and more nutritious and a secondrate brand of flour thus treated produces a better loaf

column4: THAN WHEN MIXED UP WITH YEAST AND WATER ONLY
column5: than when mixed up with yeast and water only

column4: SPONGEMAKING IS THEREFORE AN IMPORTANT IF NOT AN ESSENTIAL ACCOMPLISHMENT IN A COOK BE SHE NOVICE OR VETERAN
column5: spongemaking is therefore an important if not an essential accomplishment in a cook be she novice or veteran

column4: THREE POTATOES OF FAIR SIZE PEELED AND BOILED MEALY
column5: three potatoes of fair size peeled and boiled mealy

column4: FIVE TABLESPOONFULS OF YEAST ONE TABLESPOONFUL OF WHITE SUGAR
column5: five tablespoonfuls of yeast one tablespoonful of white sugar

column4: ONE TABLESPOONFUL OF BUTTER
column5: one tablespoonful of butter

column4: THREE CUPS OF LUKEWARM WATER IN WHICH THE POTATOES WERE BOILED STRAINED THROUGH A COARSE CLOTH
column5: three cups of lukewarm water in which the potatoes were boiled strained through a coarse cloth

column4: ONE HEAPING CUP OF SIFTED FLOUR
column5: one heaping cup of sifted flour

column4: PUT THE POTATOES INTO A LARGE BOWL OR TRAY AND MASH THEM TO POWDER WITH A POTATO BEETLE OR A WOODEN SPOON
column5: put the potatoes into a large bowl or tray and mash them to powder with a potato beetle or a wooden spoon

column4: WHILE STILL HOT MIX IN THE SUGAR AND BUTTER BEATING ALL TO A LUMPLESS CREAM
column5: while still hot mix in the sugar and butter beating all to a lumpless cream

column4: ADD A FEW SPOONFULS AT A TIME THE POTATOWATER ALTERNATELY WITH THE FLOUR BY THE HANDFUL
column5: add a few spoonfuls at a time the potatowater alternately with the flour by the handful

column4: BEATING THE BATTER SMOOTH AS YOU GO ON UNTIL ALL OF THE LIQUID AND FLOUR HAS GONE IN
column5: beating the batter smooth as you go on until all of the liquid and flour has gone in

column4: BEAT HARD ONE MINUTE BEFORE POURING IN THE YEAST
column5: beat hard one minute before pouring in the yeast

column4: IT IS WELL TO STIR INTO THE YEAST A BIT OF SODA NO LARGER THAN A GRAIN OF CORN ALREADY WET UP IN A TEASPOONFUL OF BOILING WATER
column5: it is well to stir into the yeast a bit of soda no larger than a grain of corn already wet up in a teaspoonful of boiling water

column4: NOW WHIP UP THE BATTER WITH A WOODEN SPOON FOR ANOTHER MINUTE AND THE SPONGE IS MADE
column5: now whip up the batter with a wooden spoon for another minute and the sponge is made

column4: THROW A CLOTH OVER THE BOWL AND SET BY FOR FIVE OR SIX HOURS TO RISE
column5: throw a cloth over the bowl and set by for five or six hours to rise

column4: IF YOU INTEND TO BAKE IN THE FORENOON MAKE THE SPONGE AT BEDTIME IF IN THE AFTERNOON EARLY IN THE MORNING
column5: if you intend to bake in the forenoon make the sponge at bedtime if in the afternoon early in the morning

column4: WHEN THE SPONGE IS LIGHT SIFT A QUART AND A CUP OF FLOUR INTO A BOWL OR TRAY WITH TWO TEASPOONFULS OF SALT
column5: when the sponge is light sift a quart and a cup of flour into a bowl or tray with two teaspoonfuls of salt

column4: INTO A HOLLOW LIKE A CRATER IN THE MIDDLE OF THE FLOUR EMPTY YOUR SPONGEBOWL AND WORK THE FLOUR DOWN INTO IT
column5: into a hollow like a crater in the middle of the flour empty your spongebowl and work the flour down into it

column4: WASH OUT THE BOWL WITH A LITTLE LUKEWARM WATER AND ADD THIS TO THE DOUGH IF IT SHOULD PROVE TOO SOFT WORK IN CAUTIOUSLY A LITTLE MORE FLOUR
column5: wash out the bowl with a little lukewarm water and add this to the dough if it should prove too soft work in cautiously a little more flour

column4: IF TOO STIFF WARM WATER A SPOONFUL AT A TIME UNTIL YOU CAN HANDLE THE PASTE EASILY THE DANGER IS IN GETTING IT TOO STIFF NOW
column5: if too stiff warm water a spoonful at a time until you can handle the paste easily the danger is in getting it too stiff now

column4: KNEAD AND SET FOR RISINGS FIRST AND SECOND AS YOU HAVE ALREADY BEEN INSTRUCTED THIS SPONGE WILL BE FOUND ESPECIALLY USEFUL IN MAKING GRAHAM BREAD
column5: knead and set for risings first and second as you have already been instructed this sponge will be found especially useful in making graham bread

column4: ONE QUART OF GRAHAM FLOUR ONE CUP OF WHITE FLOUR
column5: one quart of graham flour one cup of white flour

column4: ONE HALF CUP OF INDIAN MEAL ONE HALF CUP OF MOLASSES TWO TEASPOONFULS OF SALT SODA THE SIZE OF A PEA
column5: one half cup of indian meal one half cup of molasses two teaspoonfuls of salt soda the size of a pea

column4: HALF THE QUANTITY OF SPONGE GIVEN IN PRECEDING RECEIPT
column5: half the quantity of sponge given in preceding receipt

column4: WARM WATER FOR RINSING BOWL  ABOUT HALF A CUP
column5: warm water for rinsing bowl  about half a cup

column4: PUT THE BROWN OR GRAHAM FLOUR UNSIFTED INTO THE BREADBOWL
column5: put the brown or graham flour unsifted into the breadbowl

column4: SIFT INTO IT WHITE FLOUR MEAL AND SALT AND STIR UP WELL WHILE DRY
column5: sift into it white flour meal and salt and stir up well while dry

column4: INTO THE CRATER DUG OUT IN THE MIDDLE POUR THE SPONGE WARM WATER THE MOLASSES AND SODA DISSOLVED IN HOT WATER
column5: into the crater dug out in the middle pour the sponge warm water the molasses and soda dissolved in hot water

column4: KNEAD AS YOU WOULD WHITE BREAD AND SET ASIDE FOR THE RISING
column5: knead as you would white bread and set aside for the rising

column4: IT WILL NOT SWELL SO FAST AS THE WHITE SO GIVE YOURSELF MORE TIME FOR MAKING IT
column5: it will not swell so fast as the white so give yourself more time for making it

column4: WHEN LIGHT KNEAD WELL AND LONG
column5: when light knead well and long

column4: MAKE INTO TWO LOAVES THEN PUT INTO WELLGREASED PANS AND LEAVE FOR AN HOUR OR UNTIL IT BECOMES MORE THAN TWICE THE ORIGINAL SIZE OF THE DOUGH
column5: make into two loaves then put into wellgreased pans and leave for an hour or until it becomes more than twice the original size of the dough

column4: TAKE CARE THAT IT DOES NOT BURN IN BAKING THE MOLASSES RENDERS IT LIABLE TO SCORCHING
column5: take care that it does not burn in baking the molasses renders it liable to scorching

column4: THE OVEN MUST BE STEADY BUT NOT SO HOT AS FOR WHITE BREAD NOR WILL THE GRAHAM BREAD BE DONE QUITE SO SOON AS THAT MADE OF BOLTED FLOUR
column5: the oven must be steady but not so hot as for white bread nor will the graham bread be done quite so soon as that made of bolted flour

column4: TURN THE PANS ONCE WHILE BAKING MOVING THEM AS GENTLY AS POSSIBLE
column5: turn the pans once while baking moving them as gently as possible

column4: IF RUDELY SHAKEN OR JARRED THERE WILL BE HEAVY STREAKS IN LOAVES
column5: if rudely shaken or jarred there will be heavy streaks in loaves

column4: GRAHAM BREAD IS WHOLESOME AND SWEET AND OUGHT TO BE EATEN FREQUENTLY IN EVERY FAMILY PARTICULARLY BY YOUNG PEOPLE WHOSE BONES AND TEETH ARE IN FORMING
column5: graham bread is wholesome and sweet and ought to be eaten frequently in every family particularly by young people whose bones and teeth are in forming

column4: THE PHOSPHATES WHICH THE PROCESS OF BOLTING REMOVES TO A LARGE EXTENT FROM WHITE FLOUR GO DIRECTLY TO THE MANUFACTURE OF BONE
column5: the phosphates which the process of bolting removes to a large extent from white flour go directly to the manufacture of bone

column4: AND THESE ALSO TEND TO NOURISH AND STRENGTHEN THE BRAIN
column5: and these also tend to nourish and strengthen the brain

column4: AFTER MIXING YOUR BREAD IN THE MORNING EITHER WITH SPONGE OR WITH YEAST DIVIDE THE KNEADED DOUGH INTO TWO PORTIONS
column5: after mixing your bread in the morning either with sponge or with yeast divide the kneaded dough into two portions

column4: MOULD ONE INTO A ROUND BALL AND SET ASIDE FOR A LOAF AS ALREADY DIRECTED
column5: mould one into a round ball and set aside for a loaf as already directed

column4: MAKE A HOLE IN THE MIDDLE OF THE OTHER BATCH AND POUR INTO IT A TABLESPOONFUL OF BUTTER JUST MELTED BUT NOT HOT
column5: make a hole in the middle of the other batch and pour into it a tablespoonful of butter just melted but not hot

column4: CLOSE THE DOUGH OVER IT DUST YOUR HANDS AND KNEADINGBOARD WITH FLOUR AND WORK IN THE SHORTENING UNTIL THE DOUGH IS ELASTIC AND CEASES TO BE STICKY
column5: close the dough over it dust your hands and kneadingboard with flour and work in the shortening until the dough is elastic and ceases to be sticky

column4: PUT IT INTO A FLOURED BOWL COVER WITH A CLOTH AND SET AWAY OUT OF DRAUGHT AND UNDUE HEAT FOR THREE HOURS
column5: put it into a floured bowl cover with a cloth and set away out of draught and undue heat for three hours

column4: KNEAD IT AGAIN THEN AND WAIT UPON ITS RISING FOR ANOTHER THREE HOURS THE DOUGH SHOULD BE AS SOFT AS CAN BE HANDLED
column5: knead it again then and wait upon its rising for another three hours the dough should be as soft as can be handled

column4: WHEN IT IS LIGHT FOR THE SECOND TIME FLOUR YOUR BOARD RUBBING IN THE FLOUR AND BLOWING LIGHTLY AWAY WHAT DOES NOT ADHERE TO THE SURFACE
column5: when it is light for the second time flour your board rubbing in the flour and blowing lightly away what does not adhere to the surface

column4: TOSS THE LUMP DOUGH UPON IT AND KNEAD THOROUGHLY FOR FIVE MINUTES
column5: toss the lump dough upon it and knead thoroughly for five minutes

column4: FLOUR A ROLLINGPIN AND ROLL THE DOUGH INTO A SHEET NOT MORE THAN HALF AN INCH THICK
column5: flour a rollingpin and roll the dough into a sheet not more than half an inch thick

column4: CUT THIS INTO ROUND CAKES WITH A BISCUITCUTTER OR A SHARPEDGED TUMBLER AND FOLD NOT QUITE IN THE MIDDLE
column5: cut this into round cakes with a biscuitcutter or a sharpedged tumbler and fold not quite in the middle

column4: IN THE FORM OF TURNOVERS PINCHING THE CORNERS OF THE FOLD PRETTY HARD TO HINDER THE FLAP OF DOUGH FROM FLYING UP AS THE RISING PROCEEDS
column5: in the form of turnovers pinching the corners of the fold pretty hard to hinder the flap of dough from flying up as the rising proceeds

column4: RUB THE BOTTOM AND SIDES OF A BAKINGPAN WITH SWEET LARD OR BUTTER DO THIS WITH A BIT OF CLEAN SOFT RAG OR TISSUEPAPER
column5: rub the bottom and sides of a bakingpan with sweet lard or butter do this with a bit of clean soft rag or tissuepaper

column4: VISITING EVERY CORNER OF THE PAN BUT NOT LEAVING THICK LAYERS AND STREAKS OF GREASE AFTER IT
column5: visiting every corner of the pan but not leaving thick layers and streaks of grease after it

column4: ARRANGE THE ROLLS IN REGULAR ROWS IN THE PAN ABOUT A QUARTER OF AN INCH APART
column5: arrange the rolls in regular rows in the pan about a quarter of an inch apart

column4: COVER WITH A CLOTH AND SET NEARER THE FIRE THAN YOU DARED TRUST THE DOUGH AND LET THEM RISE FOR AN HOUR
column5: cover with a cloth and set nearer the fire than you dared trust the dough and let them rise for an hour

column4: PEEP UNDER THE CLOTH TWO OR THREE TIMES TO SEE WHETHER THEY RISE EVENLY AND TURN THE PAN AROUND ONCE THAT ALL MAY BE EQUALLY EXPOSED TO THE HEAT
column5: peep under the cloth two or three times to see whether they rise evenly and turn the pan around once that all may be equally exposed to the heat

column4: WHEN THE TIME IS UP AND THE ROLLS ARE PUFFY AND PROMISING SET THEM IN A PRETTY QUICK OVEN AND BAKE HALF AN HOUR
column5: when the time is up and the rolls are puffy and promising set them in a pretty quick oven and bake half an hour

column4: TURNING THE PAN ONCE IN THIS TIME AND COVERING WITH CLEAN  NEVER PRINTED  PAPER SHOULD THEY BROWN TOO FAST
column5: turning the pan once in this time and covering with clean  never printed  paper should they brown too fast

column4: BREAK THE ROLLS APART FROM ONE ANOTHER AND EAT WARM THEY ARE ALSO GOOD COLD AND IF THE DIRECTIONS BE FOLLOWED IMPLICITLY VERY GOOD ALWAYS
column5: break the rolls apart from one another and eat warm they are also good cold and if the directions be followed implicitly very good always

column4: GRAHAM ROLLS ARE MADE BY TREATING THE DOUGH MIXED FOR GRAHAM BREAD AS ABOVE AND FOLLOWING THE FOREGOING RECEIPT IN EVERY SECTION BUT ALLOWING MORE TIME FOR RISING AND BAKING
column5: graham rolls are made by treating the dough mixed for graham bread as above and following the foregoing receipt in every section but allowing more time for rising and baking

column4: THEY ARE EVEN BETTER WHEN COLD THAN HOT
column5: they are even better when cold than hot

column5: breakfast biscuit

column5: two cups of fresh milk slightly warmed

column5: one quart and a cup of flour sifted

column4: FIVE TABLESPOONFULS OF YEAST
column5: five tablespoonfuls of yeast

column4: ONE EVEN TABLESPOONFUL OF WHITE SUGAR
column5: one even tablespoonful of white sugar

column4: ONE EVEN TEASPOONFUL OF SALT
column5: one even teaspoonful of salt

column5: bit of soda as large as a pea dissolved in hot water

column4: ONE TABLESPOONFUL OF BUTTER JUST MELTED NOT HOT
column5: one tablespoonful of butter just melted not hot

column4: YOLK OF ONE EGG BEATEN LIGHT
column5: yolk of one egg beaten light

column4: SIFT THE FLOUR SALT AND SUGAR INTO A BOWL
column5: sift the flour salt and sugar into a bowl

column4: HOLLOW THE HEAP IN THE CENTER AND POUR IN THE MILK WORKING DOWN THE FLOUR INTO THE LIQUID WITH A SPOON OR YOUR HANDS UNTIL IT IS THOROUGHLY MELTED
column5: hollow the heap in the center and pour in the milk working down the flour into the liquid with a spoon or your hands until it is thoroughly melted

column4: INTO A SECOND HOLLOW POUR THE YEAST AND KNEAD THOROUGHLY FOR FIFTEEN MINUTES
column5: into a second hollow pour the yeast and knead thoroughly for fifteen minutes

column4: WRAP BOWL AND BISCUIT IN A THICK CLOTH AND SET TO RISE WHERE IT WILL NEITHER BECOME CHILLED NOR SOUR OVER NIGHT
column5: wrap bowl and biscuit in a thick cloth and set to rise where it will neither become chilled nor sour over night

column4: STUDY THE TEMPERATURE IN DIFFERENT PARTS OF THE KITCHEN AND KITCHEN CLOSETS TO THE END OF FINDING THE BEST PLACES FOR RAISING DOUGH AND SPONGE
column5: study the temperature in different parts of the kitchen and kitchen closets to the end of finding the best places for raising dough and sponge

column4: DO ALL THIS AT BEDTIME EARLY IN THE MORNING TURN OUT THE DOUGH UPON A FLOURED BOARD WORK IT FOR A MINUTE INTO MANAGEABLE SHAPE
column5: do all this at bedtime early in the morning turn out the dough upon a floured board work it for a minute into manageable shape

column4: DRILL SEVERAL FINGERHOLES IN IT AND FILL THEM WITH THE MELTED BUTTER THE DISSOLVED SODA AND THE BEATEN YOLK OF EGG
column5: drill several fingerholes in it and fill them with the melted butter the dissolved soda and the beaten yolk of egg

column4: PINCH THE DOUGH HARD TO STOP THE MOUTHS OF THESE CAVITIES
column5: pinch the dough hard to stop the mouths of these cavities

column4: AND KNEAD FOR TEN MINUTES CAREFULLY AT FIRST LEST THE LIQUIDS SHOULD BE WASTED AND MORE BOLDLY WHEN THEY ARE ABSORBED BY THE PASTE
column5: and knead for ten minutes carefully at first lest the liquids should be wasted and more boldly when they are absorbed by the paste

column4: ROLL OUT INTO A SHEET HALF AN INCH THICK WITH A FLOURED ROLLINGPIN CUT INTO ROUND CAKES SET THESE CLOSELY TOGETHER IN A WELLGREASED PAN
column5: roll out into a sheet half an inch thick with a floured rollingpin cut into round cakes set these closely together in a wellgreased pan

column4: PRICK EACH WITH A FORK AND LET THEM RISE NEAR THE FIRE FOR HALF AN HOUR COVERED WITH A LIGHT CLOTH
column5: prick each with a fork and let them rise near the fire for half an hour covered with a light cloth

column4: BAKE FROM TWENTY TO TWENTYFIVE MINUTES IN A QUICK OVEN TURNING THE PAN AROUND ONCE QUICKLY AND LIGHTLY
column5: bake from twenty to twentyfive minutes in a quick oven turning the pan around once quickly and lightly

column4: BREAK APART FROM ONE ANOTHER AND PILE ON A PLATE THROWING A CLEAN DOILY OR A SMALL NAPKIN OVER THEM BREAK OPEN AT TABLE
column5: break apart from one another and pile on a plate throwing a clean doily or a small napkin over them break open at table

column4: HOT ROLLS AND MUFFINS SHOULD NEVER BE CUT
column5: hot rolls and muffins should never be cut

column4: ONE WORD WITH REGARD TO GETTING UP EARLY IN ORDER TO GIVE DOUGH A CHANCE FOR THE SECOND RISING
column5: one word with regard to getting up early in order to give dough a chance for the second rising

column4: IT IS NOT A WHOLESOME PRACTICE FOR ANY WOMAN  LEAST OF ALL A YOUNG GIRL TO BE OUT OF BED TWO HOURS BEFORE SHE EATS HER BREAKFAST
column5: it is not a wholesome practice for any woman  least of all a young girl to be out of bed two hours before she eats her breakfast

column4: STUDYING UPON AN EMPTY STOMACH PROVOKES DYSPEPSIA AND INJURES THE EYES
column5: studying upon an empty stomach provokes dyspepsia and injures the eyes

column4: ACTIVE EXERCISE IN LIKE CIRCUMSTANCES TEMPTS DEBILITY AND DISEASE
column5: active exercise in like circumstances tempts debility and disease

column4: YET OUR BREAD AND ROLLS MUST BE LOOKED AFTER AT THE PROPER TIME
column5: yet our bread and rolls must be looked after at the proper time

column4: HAVE YOURSELF CALLED ON BISCUIT MORNINGS AN HOUR EARLIER THAN USUAL
column5: have yourself called on biscuit mornings an hour earlier than usual

column4: RISE WASH FACE AND HANDS RINSE THE MOUTH OUT AND BRUSH BACK THE HAIR
column5: rise wash face and hands rinse the mouth out and brush back the hair

column4: PUT ON STOCKINGS AND SLIPPERS SUCH UNDERCLOTHING AS MAY BE NEEDED TO PREVENT COLD A WRAPPER AND THE KITCHEN APRON
column5: put on stockings and slippers such underclothing as may be needed to prevent cold a wrapper and the kitchen apron

column4: COVER YOUR HAIR ENTIRELY WITH A HANDKERCHIEF OR SWEEPING CAP
column5: cover your hair entirely with a handkerchief or sweeping cap

column4: BEFORE BEGINNING OPERATIONS DOWNSTAIRS EAT A HALFSLICE OF DRY BREAD OR A BISCUIT
column5: before beginning operations downstairs eat a halfslice of dry bread or a biscuit

column4: YOU WILL NOT RELISH IT BUT TAKE IT ALL THE SAME TO APPEASE THE EMPTY DISCONTENTED STOMACH
column5: you will not relish it but take it all the same to appease the empty discontented stomach

column4: HAVING MADE OUT YOUR ROLLS AND TUCKED THEM UP SNUGLY FOR THE FINAL RISE RETURN TO YOUR CHAMBER FOR A COMFORTABLE BATH AND TOILET
column5: having made out your rolls and tucked them up snugly for the final rise return to your chamber for a comfortable bath and toilet

column4: WHEN HABITED FOR THE DAY IN ALL EXCEPT THE OUTER GOWN COLLAR ETC SLIP ON THE WRAPPER AGAIN AND RUN DOWN TO PUT THE BISCUITS IN THE OVEN
column5: when habited for the day in all except the outer gown collar etc slip on the wrapper again and run down to put the biscuits in the oven

column4: UNLESS IT IS TOO HOT THEY WILL GET NO HARM WHILE YOU FINISH DRESSING IN TEN MINUTES JUST IN SEASON TO TURN THE PAN
column5: unless it is too hot they will get no harm while you finish dressing in ten minutes just in season to turn the pan

column4: FROM THE BEGINNING OF YOUR APPRENTICESHIP IN HOUSEWIFERY LEARN HOW TO DOVETAIL YOUR DUTIES NEATLY INTO ONE ANOTHER
column5: from the beginning of your apprenticeship in housewifery learn how to dovetail your duties neatly into one another

column4: A WISE ACCOMMODATION OF PARTS AND ANGLES AND COMPACTNESS IN THE ADJUSTMENT OF MUSTBEDONES
column5: a wise accommodation of parts and angles and compactness in the adjustment of mustbedones

column4: ARE BETTER THAN MERE PERSONAL STRENGTH IN THE ACCOMPLISHMENT OF SUCH TASKS AS FALL TO WOMEN TO PERFORM
column5: are better than mere personal strength in the accomplishment of such tasks as fall to women to perform

column4: MASTER THESE AND DO NOT LET THEM MASTER YOU
column5: master these and do not let them master you

column4: WEAVE THE LITTLE DUTIES IN AND UNDER AND AMONG WHAT SEEM TO BE THE GREATER
column5: weave the little duties in and under and among what seem to be the greater

column4: WHILE YOUR BREAD IS TAKING A THREE HOURS RISE YOU ARE FREE IN BODY AND MIND FOR OTHER THINGS
column5: while your bread is taking a three hours rise you are free in body and mind for other things

column4: THE GRAND SECRET OF KEEPING HOUSE WELL AND WITHOUT WORRY LIES IN THE ART OF PACKING AND FITTING DIFFERENT KINDS OF WORK AND IN PICKING UP THE MINUTES
column5: the grand secret of keeping house well and without worry lies in the art of packing and fitting different kinds of work and in picking up the minutes

column4: OTHER THINGS BESIDES RISING DOUGH GET ON QUITE AS WELL WITHOUT YOUR STANDING BY TO WATCH THEM
column5: other things besides rising dough get on quite as well without your standing by to watch them

column4: THE FIRESIDE CHATS OF FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT BY FRANKLIN D ROOSEVELT SECTION SIX
column5: the fireside chats of franklin delano roosevelt by franklin d roosevelt section six

column4: SEPTEMBER THIRTY NINETEEN THIRTYFOUR
column5: september thirty nineteen thirtyfour

column4: THREE MONTHS HAVE PASSED SINCE I TALKED WITH YOU SHORTLY AFTER THE ADJOURNMENT OF THE CONGRESS
column5: three months have passed since i talked with you shortly after the adjournment of the congress

column4: TONIGHT I CONTINUE THAT REPORT THOUGH BECAUSE OF THE SHORTNESS OF TIME I MUST DEFER A NUMBER OF SUBJECTS TO A LATER DATE
column5: tonight i continue that report though because of the shortness of time i must defer a number of subjects to a later date

column4: RECENTLY THE MOST NOTABLE PUBLIC QUESTIONS THAT HAVE CONCERNED US ALL
column5: recently the most notable public questions that have concerned us all

column4: HAVE HAD TO DO WITH INDUSTRY AND LABOR AND WITH RESPECT TO THESE CERTAIN DEVELOPMENTS HAVE TAKEN PLACE WHICH I CONSIDER OF IMPORTANCE
column5: have had to do with industry and labor and with respect to these certain developments have taken place which i consider of importance

column4: I AM HAPPY TO REPORT THAT AFTER YEARS OF UNCERTAINTY CULMINATING IN THE COLLAPSE OF THE SPRING OF NINETEEN THIRTYTHREE
column5: i am happy to report that after years of uncertainty culminating in the collapse of the spring of nineteen thirtythree

column4: WE ARE BRINGING ORDER OUT OF THE OLD CHAOS
column5: we are bringing order out of the old chaos

column4: WITH A GREATER CERTAINTY OF THE EMPLOYMENT OF LABOR AT A REASONABLE WAGE AND OF MORE BUSINESS AT A FAIR PROFIT
column5: with a greater certainty of the employment of labor at a reasonable wage and of more business at a fair profit

column4: THESE GOVERNMENTAL AND INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENTS HOLD PROMISE OF NEW ACHIEVEMENTS FOR THE NATION
column5: these governmental and industrial developments hold promise of new achievements for the nation

column4: MEN MAY DIFFER AS TO THE PARTICULAR FORM OF GOVERNMENTAL ACTIVITY
column5: men may differ as to the particular form of governmental activity

column4: WITH RESPECT TO INDUSTRY AND BUSINESS BUT NEARLY ALL ARE AGREED THAT PRIVATE ENTERPRISE IN TIMES SUCH AS THESE
column5: with respect to industry and business but nearly all are agreed that private enterprise in times such as these

column4: BUT ALSO OUR PROCESSES OF CIVILIZATION
column5: but also our processes of civilization

column4: THE UNDERLYING NECESSITY FOR SUCH ACTIVITY
column5: the underlying necessity for such activity

column4: IS INDEED AS STRONG NOW AS IT WAS YEARS AGO WHEN ELIHU ROOT SAID THE FOLLOWING VERY SIGNIFICANT WORDS
column5: is indeed as strong now as it was years ago when elihu root said the following very significant words

column4: INSTEAD OF THE GIVE AND TAKE OF FREE INDIVIDUAL CONTRACT
column5: instead of the give and take of free individual contract

column4: THE TREMENDOUS POWER OF ORGANIZATION HAS COMBINED GREAT AGGREGATIONS OF CAPITAL IN ENORMOUS INDUSTRIAL ESTABLISHMENTS
column5: the tremendous power of organization has combined great aggregations of capital in enormous industrial establishments

column4: WORKING THROUGH VAST AGENCIES OF COMMERCE AND EMPLOYING GREAT MASSES OF MEN IN MOVEMENTS OF PRODUCTION
column5: working through vast agencies of commerce and employing great masses of men in movements of production

column4: AND TRANSPORTATION AND TRADE SO GREAT IN THE MASS THAT EACH INDIVIDUAL CONCERNED IN THEM IS QUITE HELPLESS BY HIMSELF
column5: and transportation and trade so great in the mass that each individual concerned in them is quite helpless by himself

column4: THE RELATIONS BETWEEN THE EMPLOYER AND THE EMPLOYED BETWEEN THE OWNERS OF AGGREGATED CAPITAL AND THE UNITS OF ORGANIZED LABOR
column5: the relations between the employer and the employed between the owners of aggregated capital and the units of organized labor

column4: BETWEEN THE SMALL PRODUCER THE SMALL TRADER THE CONSUMER
column5: between the small producer the small trader the consumer

column4: AND THE GREAT TRANSPORTING AND MANUFACTURING AND DISTRIBUTING AGENCIES
column5: and the great transporting and manufacturing and distributing agencies

column4: ALL PRESENT NEW QUESTIONS FOR THE SOLUTION OF WHICH THE OLD RELIANCE UPON THE FREE ACTION OF INDIVIDUAL WILLS APPEARS QUITE INADEQUATE
column5: all present new questions for the solution of which the old reliance upon the free action of individual wills appears quite inadequate

column4: AND IN MANY DIRECTIONS THE INTERVENTION OF THAT ORGANIZED CONTROL WHICH WE CALL GOVERNMENT
column5: and in many directions the intervention of that organized control which we call government

column4: SEEMS NECESSARY TO PRODUCE THE SAME RESULT OF JUSTICE AND RIGHT CONDUCT
column5: seems necessary to produce the same result of justice and right conduct

column4: WHICH OBTAINED THROUGH THE ATTRITION OF INDIVIDUALS BEFORE THE NEW CONDITIONS AROSE
column5: which obtained through the attrition of individuals before the new conditions arose

column4: IT WAS IN THIS SPIRIT THUS DESCRIBED BY SECRETARY ROOT
column5: it was in this spirit thus described by secretary root

column4: THAT WE APPROACHED OUR TASK OF REVIVING PRIVATE ENTERPRISE IN MARCH NINETEEN THIRTYTHREE
column5: that we approached our task of reviving private enterprise in march nineteen thirtythree

column4: OUR FIRST PROBLEM WAS OF COURSE THE BANKING SITUATION BECAUSE AS YOU KNOW THE BANKS HAD COLLAPSED
column5: our first problem was of course the banking situation because as you know the banks had collapsed

column4: SOME BANKS COULD NOT BE SAVED BUT THE GREAT MAJORITY OF THEM EITHER THROUGH THEIR OWN RESOURCES OR WITH GOVERNMENT AID
column5: some banks could not be saved but the great majority of them either through their own resources or with government aid

column4: HAVE BEEN RESTORED TO COMPLETE PUBLIC CONFIDENCE
column5: have been restored to complete public confidence

column4: THIS HAS GIVEN SAFETY TO MILLIONS OF DEPOSITORS IN THESE BANKS
column5: this has given safety to millions of depositors in these banks

column4: CLOSELY FOLLOWING THIS GREAT CONSTRUCTIVE EFFORT WE HAVE THROUGH VARIOUS FEDERAL AGENCIES
column5: closely following this great constructive effort we have through various federal agencies

column4: SAVED DEBTORS AND CREDITORS ALIKE IN MANY OTHER FIELDS OF ENTERPRISE SUCH AS LOANS ON FARM MORTGAGES AND HOME MORTGAGES
column5: saved debtors and creditors alike in many other fields of enterprise such as loans on farm mortgages and home mortgages

column4: LOANS TO THE RAILROADS AND INSURANCE COMPANIES AND FINALLY HELP FOR HOME OWNERS AND INDUSTRY ITSELF
column5: loans to the railroads and insurance companies and finally help for home owners and industry itself

column4: IN ALL OF THESE EFFORTS THE GOVERNMENT HAS COME TO THE ASSISTANCE OF BUSINESS
column5: in all of these efforts the government has come to the assistance of business

column4: AND WITH THE FULL EXPECTATION THAT THE MONEY USED TO ASSIST THESE ENTERPRISES WILL EVENTUALLY BE REPAID
column5: and with the full expectation that the money used to assist these enterprises will eventually be repaid

column4: I BELIEVE IT WILL BE
column5: i believe it will be

column4: THE SECOND STEP WE HAVE TAKEN IN THE RESTORATION OF NORMAL BUSINESS ENTERPRISE
column5: the second step we have taken in the restoration of normal business enterprise

column4: HAS BEEN TO CLEAN UP THOROUGHLY UNWHOLESOME CONDITIONS IN THE FIELD OF INVESTMENT
column5: has been to clean up thoroughly unwholesome conditions in the field of investment

column4: IN THIS WE HAVE HAD ASSISTANCE FROM MANY BANKERS AND BUSINESSMEN
column5: in this we have had assistance from many bankers and businessmen

column4: MOST OF WHOM RECOGNIZE THE PAST EVILS IN THE BANKING SYSTEM IN THE SALE OF SECURITIES IN THE DELIBERATE ENCOURAGEMENT OF STOCK GAMBLING
column5: most of whom recognize the past evils in the banking system in the sale of securities in the deliberate encouragement of stock gambling

column4: IN THE SALE OF UNSOUND MORTGAGES AND IN MANY OTHER WAYS IN WHICH THE PUBLIC LOST BILLIONS OF DOLLARS
column5: in the sale of unsound mortgages and in many other ways in which the public lost billions of dollars

column4: THEY SAW THAT WITHOUT CHANGES IN THE POLICIES AND METHODS OF INVESTMENT
column5: they saw that without changes in the policies and methods of investment

column4: THERE COULD BE NO RECOVERY OF PUBLIC CONFIDENCE IN THE SECURITY OF SAVINGS
column5: there could be no recovery of public confidence in the security of savings

column4: THE COUNTRY NOW ENJOYS THE SAFETY OF BANK SAVINGS UNDER THE NEW BANKING LAWS
column5: the country now enjoys the safety of bank savings under the new banking laws

column4: THE CAREFUL CHECKING OF NEW SECURITIES UNDER THE SECURITIES ACT
column5: the careful checking of new securities under the securities act

column4: AND THE CURTAILMENT OF RANK STOCK SPECULATION THROUGH THE SECURITIES EXCHANGE ACT
column5: and the curtailment of rank stock speculation through the securities exchange act

column4: I SINCERELY HOPE THAT AS A RESULT
column5: i sincerely hope that as a result

column4: PEOPLE WILL BE DISCOURAGED IN UNHAPPY EFFORTS TO GET RICH QUICK BY SPECULATING IN SECURITIES
column5: people will be discouraged in unhappy efforts to get rich quick by speculating in securities

column4: THE AVERAGE PERSON ALMOST ALWAYS LOSES
column5: the average person almost always loses

column4: ONLY A VERY SMALL MINORITY OF THE PEOPLE OF THIS COUNTRY BELIEVE IN GAMBLING AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR THE OLD PHILOSOPHY OF BENJAMIN FRANKLIN
column5: only a very small minority of the people of this country believe in gambling as a substitute for the old philosophy of benjamin franklin

column4: THAT THE WAY TO WEALTH IS THROUGH WORK
column5: that the way to wealth is through work

column4: IN MEETING THE PROBLEMS OF INDUSTRIAL RECOVERY THE CHIEF AGENCY OF THE GOVERNMENT HAS BEEN THE NATIONAL RECOVERY ADMINISTRATION
column5: in meeting the problems of industrial recovery the chief agency of the government has been the national recovery administration

column4: UNDER ITS GUIDANCE TRADES AND INDUSTRIES COVERING OVER NINETY PERCENT OF ALL INDUSTRIAL EMPLOYEES
column5: under its guidance trades and industries covering over ninety percent of all industrial employees

column4: HAVE ADOPTED CODES OF FAIR COMPETITION WHICH HAVE BEEN APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT
column5: have adopted codes of fair competition which have been approved by the president

column4: UNDER THESE CODES IN THE INDUSTRIES COVERED CHILD LABOR HAS BEEN ELIMINATED
column5: under these codes in the industries covered child labor has been eliminated

column4: THE WORK DAY AND THE WORK WEEK HAVE BEEN SHORTENED
column5: the work day and the work week have been shortened

column4: MINIMUM WAGES HAVE BEEN ESTABLISHED AND OTHER WAGES ADJUSTED TOWARD A RISING STANDARD OF LIVING
column5: minimum wages have been established and other wages adjusted toward a rising standard of living

column4: THE EMERGENCY PURPOSE OF THE NRA WAS TO PUT MEN TO WORK AND SINCE ITS CREATION MORE THAN FOUR MILLION PERSONS HAVE BEEN REEMPLOYED
column5: the emergency purpose of the nra was to put men to work and since its creation more than four million persons have been reemployed

column4: IN GREAT PART THROUGH THE COOPERATION OF AMERICAN BUSINESS BROUGHT ABOUT UNDER THE CODES
column5: in great part through the cooperation of american business brought about under the codes

column4: BENEFITS OF THE INDUSTRIAL RECOVERY PROGRAM HAVE COME
column5: benefits of the industrial recovery program have come

column4: NOT ONLY TO LABOR IN THE FORM OF NEW JOBS IN RELIEF FROM OVERWORK AND IN RELIEF FROM UNDERPAY
column5: not only to labor in the form of new jobs in relief from overwork and in relief from underpay

column4: BUT ALSO TO THE OWNERS AND MANAGERS OF INDUSTRY BECAUSE
column5: but also to the owners and managers of industry because

column4: TOGETHER WITH A GREAT INCREASE IN THE PAYROLLS THERE HAS COME A SUBSTANTIAL RISE IN THE TOTAL OF INDUSTRIAL PROFITS
column5: together with a great increase in the payrolls there has come a substantial rise in the total of industrial profits

column4: A RISE FROM A DEFICIT FIGURE IN THE FIRST QUARTER OF NINETEEN THIRTYTHREE
column5: a rise from a deficit figure in the first quarter of nineteen thirtythree

column4: TO A LEVEL OF SUSTAINED PROFITS WITHIN ONE YEAR FROM THE INAUGURATION OF NRA
column5: to a level of sustained profits within one year from the inauguration of nra

column4: NOW IT SHOULD NOT BE EXPECTED THAT EVEN EMPLOYED LABOR AND CAPITAL WOULD BE COMPLETELY SATISFIED WITH PRESENT CONDITIONS
column5: now it should not be expected that even employed labor and capital would be completely satisfied with present conditions

column4: EMPLOYED WORKERS HAVE NOT BY ANY MEANS ALL ENJOYED A RETURN TO THE EARNINGS OF PROSPEROUS TIMES
column5: employed workers have not by any means all enjoyed a return to the earnings of prosperous times

column4: ALTHOUGH MILLIONS OF HITHERTO UNDERPRIVILEGED WORKERS ARE TODAY FAR BETTER PAID THAN EVER BEFORE
column5: although millions of hitherto underprivileged workers are today far better paid than ever before

column4: ALSO BILLIONS OF DOLLARS OF INVESTED CAPITAL HAVE TODAY A GREATER SECURITY OF PRESENT AND FUTURE EARNING POWER THAN BEFORE
column5: also billions of dollars of invested capital have today a greater security of present and future earning power than before

column4: THIS IS BECAUSE OF THE ESTABLISHMENT OF FAIR COMPETITIVE STANDARDS AND BECAUSE OF RELIEF FROM UNFAIR COMPETITION
column5: this is because of the establishment of fair competitive standards and because of relief from unfair competition

column4: IN WAGE CUTTING WHICH DEPRESSES MARKETS AND DESTROYS PURCHASING POWER
column5: in wage cutting which depresses markets and destroys purchasing power

column4: BUT IT IS AN UNDENIABLE FACT THAT THE RESTORATION OF OTHER BILLIONS OF SOUND INVESTMENTS TO A REASONABLE EARNING POWER
column5: but it is an undeniable fact that the restoration of other billions of sound investments to a reasonable earning power

column4: COULD NOT BE BROUGHT ABOUT IN ONE YEAR
column5: could not be brought about in one year

column4: THERE IS NO MAGIC FORMULA
column5: there is no magic formula

column4: NO ECONOMIC PANACEA WHICH COULD SIMPLY REVIVE OVERNIGHT THE HEAVY INDUSTRIES AND THE TRADES DEPENDENT UPON THEM
column5: no economic panacea which could simply revive overnight the heavy industries and the trades dependent upon them

column4: NEVERTHELESS THE GAINS OF TRADE AND INDUSTRY AS A WHOLE HAVE BEEN SUBSTANTIAL
column5: nevertheless the gains of trade and industry as a whole have been substantial

column4: IN THESE GAINS AND IN THE POLICIES OF THE ADMINISTRATION THERE ARE ASSURANCES THAT HEARTEN ALL FORWARD LOOKING MEN AND WOMEN
column5: in these gains and in the policies of the administration there are assurances that hearten all forward looking men and women

column4: WITH THE CONFIDENCE THAT WE ARE DEFINITELY REBUILDING OUR POLITICAL AND ECONOMIC SYSTEM ON THE LINES LAID DOWN BY THE NEW DEAL
column5: with the confidence that we are definitely rebuilding our political and economic system on the lines laid down by the new deal

column4: LINES WHICH AS I HAVE SO OFTEN MADE CLEAR ARE IN COMPLETE ACCORD WITH THE UNDERLYING PRINCIPLES OF ORDERLY POPULAR GOVERNMENT
column5: lines which as i have so often made clear are in complete accord with the underlying principles of orderly popular government

column4: WHICH AMERICANS HAVE DEMANDED SINCE THE WHITE MAN FIRST CAME TO THESE SHORES
column5: which americans have demanded since the white man first came to these shores

column4: WE COUNT IN THE FUTURE AS IN THE PAST ON THE DRIVING POWER OF INDIVIDUAL INITIATIVE
column5: we count in the future as in the past on the driving power of individual initiative

column4: AND THE INCENTIVE OF FAIR PRIVATE PROFIT
column5: and the incentive of fair private profit

column4: STRENGTHENED WITH THE ACCEPTANCE OF THOSE OBLIGATIONS TO THE PUBLIC INTEREST WHICH REST UPON US ALL
column5: strengthened with the acceptance of those obligations to the public interest which rest upon us all

column4: WE HAVE THE RIGHT TO EXPECT THAT THIS DRIVING POWER WILL BE GIVEN PATRIOTICALLY AND WHOLEHEARTEDLY TO OUR NATION
column5: we have the right to expect that this driving power will be given patriotically and wholeheartedly to our nation

column4: WE HAVE PASSED THROUGH THE FORMATIVE PERIOD OF CODE MAKING IN THE NATIONAL RECOVERY ADMINISTRATION
column5: we have passed through the formative period of code making in the national recovery administration

column4: AND HAVE EFFECTED A REORGANIZATION OF THE NRA
column5: and have effected a reorganization of the nra

column4: SUITED TO THE NEEDS OF THE NEXT PHASE WHICH IS IN TURN A PERIOD OF PREPARATION FOR LEGISLATION WHICH WILL DETERMINE ITS PERMANENT FORM
column5: suited to the needs of the next phase which is in turn a period of preparation for legislation which will determine its permanent form

column4: IN THIS RECENT REORGANIZATION WE HAVE RECOGNIZED THREE DISTINCT FUNCTIONS
column5: in this recent reorganization we have recognized three distinct functions

column4: FIRST THE LEGISLATIVE OR POLICY MAKING FUNCTION
column5: first the legislative or policy making function

column4: SECOND THE ADMINISTRATIVE FUNCTION OF CODE MAKING AND REVISION AND THIRD THE JUDICIAL FUNCTION WHICH INCLUDES ENFORCEMENT
column5: second the administrative function of code making and revision and third the judicial function which includes enforcement

column4: CONSUMER COMPLAINTS AND THE SETTLEMENT OF DISPUTES BETWEEN EMPLOYERS AND EMPLOYEES AND BETWEEN ONE EMPLOYER AND ANOTHER
column5: consumer complaints and the settlement of disputes between employers and employees and between one employer and another

column4: WE ARE NOW PREPARED TO MOVE INTO THIS SECOND PHASE ON THE BASIS OF OUR EXPERIENCE IN THE FIRST PHASE
column5: we are now prepared to move into this second phase on the basis of our experience in the first phase

column4: UNDER THE ABLE AND ENERGETIC LEADERSHIP OF GENERAL JOHNSON
column5: under the able and energetic leadership of general johnson

column4: WE SHALL WATCH CAREFULLY THE WORKING OF THIS NEW MACHINERY FOR THE SECOND PHASE OF NRA
column5: we shall watch carefully the working of this new machinery for the second phase of nra

column4: MODIFYING IT WHERE IT NEEDS MODIFICATION AND FINALLY MAKING RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE CONGRESS
column5: modifying it where it needs modification and finally making recommendations to the congress

column4: IN ORDER THAT THE FUNCTIONS OF NRA WHICH HAVE PROVED THEIR WORTH MAY BE MADE A PART OF THE PERMANENT MACHINERY OF GOVERNMENT
column5: in order that the functions of nra which have proved their worth may be made a part of the permanent machinery of government

column4: LET ME CALL YOUR ATTENTION TO THE FACT THAT THE NATIONAL INDUSTRIAL RECOVERY ACT
column5: let me call your attention to the fact that the national industrial recovery act

column4: GAVE BUSINESSMEN THE OPPORTUNITY THEY HAD SOUGHT FOR YEARS TO IMPROVE BUSINESS CONDITIONS THROUGH WHAT HAS BEEN CALLED SELFGOVERNMENT IN INDUSTRY
column5: gave businessmen the opportunity they had sought for years to improve business conditions through what has been called selfgovernment in industry

column4: IF THE CODES WHICH HAVE BEEN WRITTEN HAVE BEEN TOO COMPLICATED
column5: if the codes which have been written have been too complicated

column4: IF THEY HAVE GONE TOO FAR IN SUCH MATTERS AS PRICE FIXING AND LIMITATION OF PRODUCTION
column5: if they have gone too far in such matters as price fixing and limitation of production

column4: LET IT BE REMEMBERED THAT SO FAR AS POSSIBLE CONSISTENT WITH THE IMMEDIATE PUBLIC INTEREST OF THIS PAST YEAR
column5: let it be remembered that so far as possible consistent with the immediate public interest of this past year

column4: AND THE VITAL NECESSITY OF IMPROVING LABOR CONDITIONS
column5: and the vital necessity of improving labor conditions

column4: THE REPRESENTATIVES OF TRADE AND INDUSTRY WERE PERMITTED TO WRITE THEIR IDEAS INTO THE CODES
column5: the representatives of trade and industry were permitted to write their ideas into the codes

column4: IT IS NOW TIME TO REVIEW THESE ACTIONS AS A WHOLE TO DETERMINE THROUGH DELIBERATIVE MEANS IN THE LIGHT OF EXPERIENCE
column5: it is now time to review these actions as a whole to determine through deliberative means in the light of experience

column4: FROM THE STANDPOINT OF THE GOOD OF THE INDUSTRIES THEMSELVES AS WELL AS THE GENERAL PUBLIC INTEREST
column5: from the standpoint of the good of the industries themselves as well as the general public interest

column4: WHETHER THE METHODS AND POLICIES ADOPTED IN THE EMERGENCY
column5: whether the methods and policies adopted in the emergency

column4: HAVE BEEN BEST CALCULATED TO PROMOTE INDUSTRIAL RECOVERY AND A PERMANENT IMPROVEMENT OF BUSINESS AND LABOR CONDITIONS
column5: have been best calculated to promote industrial recovery and a permanent improvement of business and labor conditions

column4: THERE MAY BE A SERIOUS QUESTION AS TO THE WISDOM OF MANY OF THOSE DEVICES TO CONTROL PRODUCTION
column5: there may be a serious question as to the wisdom of many of those devices to control production

column5: or to prevent destructive price cutting which many business organizations have insisted were necessary

column5: or whether their effect may have been to prevent that volume of production which would make possible lower prices and increased employment

column5: another question arises as to whether in fixing minimum wages on the basis of an hourly or weekly wage

column5: we have reached into the heart of the problem which is to provide such annual earnings for the lowest paid worker as will meet his minimum needs

column5: we also question the wisdom of extending code requirements suited to the great industrial centers and to large employers

column4: TO THE GREAT NUMBER OF SMALL EMPLOYERS IN THE SMALLER COMMUNITIES
column5: to the great number of small employers in the smaller communities

column4: DURING THE LAST TWELVE MONTHS OUR INDUSTRIAL RECOVERY HAS BEEN TO SOME EXTENT RETARDED BY STRIKES
column5: during the last twelve months our industrial recovery has been to some extent retarded by strikes

column4: INCLUDING A FEW OF MAJOR IMPORTANCE
column5: including a few of major importance

column5: i would not minimize the inevitable losses to employers and employees and to the general public through such conflicts

column4: BUT I WOULD POINT OUT THAT THE EXTENT AND SEVERITY OF LABOR DISPUTES DURING THIS PERIOD
column5: but i would point out that the extent and severity of labor disputes during this period

column4: HAS BEEN FAR LESS THAN IN ANY PREVIOUS COMPARABLE PERIOD
column5: has been far less than in any previous comparable period

column4: WHEN THE BUSINESSMEN OF THE COUNTRY WERE DEMANDING THE RIGHT TO ORGANIZE THEMSELVES ADEQUATELY TO PROMOTE THEIR LEGITIMATE INTERESTS
column5: when the businessmen of the country were demanding the right to organize themselves adequately to promote their legitimate interests

column5: when the farmers were demanding legislation which would give them opportunities and incentives to organize themselves for a common advance

column5: it was natural that the workers should seek and obtain a statutory declaration of their constitutional right

column5: to organize themselves for collective bargaining as embodied in section seven a of the national industrial recovery act

column4: MACHINERY SET UP BY THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT HAS PROVIDED SOME NEW METHODS OF ADJUSTMENT
column5: machinery set up by the federal government has provided some new methods of adjustment

column4: BOTH EMPLOYERS AND EMPLOYEES MUST SHARE THE BLAME OF NOT USING THEM AS FULLY AS THEY SHOULD
column5: both employers and employees must share the blame of not using them as fully as they should

column5: the employer who turns away from impartial agencies of peace

column5: who denies freedom of organization to his employees or fails to make every reasonable effort at a peaceful solution of their differences

column4: IS NOT FULLY SUPPORTING THE RECOVERY EFFORT OF HIS GOVERNMENT
column5: is not fully supporting the recovery effort of his government

column5: the workers who turn away from these same impartial agencies and decline to use their good offices to gain their ends

column4: ARE LIKEWISE NOT FULLY COOPERATING WITH THEIR GOVERNMENT
column5: are likewise not fully cooperating with their government

column5: it is time that we made a cleancut effort to bring about that united action of management and labor

column4: WHICH IS ONE OF THE HIGH PURPOSES OF THE RECOVERY ACT
column5: which is one of the high purposes of the recovery act

column4: WE HAVE PASSED THROUGH MORE THAN A YEAR OF EDUCATION
column5: we have passed through more than a year of education

column4: STEP BY STEP WE HAVE CREATED ALL THE GOVERNMENT AGENCIES NECESSARY TO INSURE AS A GENERAL RULE INDUSTRIAL PEACE
column5: step by step we have created all the government agencies necessary to insure as a general rule industrial peace

column4: WITH JUSTICE FOR ALL THOSE WILLING TO USE THESE AGENCIES WHENEVER THEIR VOLUNTARY BARGAINING FAILS TO PRODUCE A NECESSARY AGREEMENT
column5: with justice for all those willing to use these agencies whenever their voluntary bargaining fails to produce a necessary agreement

column5: there should be at least a full and fair trial given to these means of ending industrial warfare

column5: and in such an effort we should be able to secure for employers and employees and consumers

column5: the benefits that all derive from the continuous peaceful operation of our essential enterprises

column5: accordingly i propose to confer within the coming month

column4: WITH SMALL GROUPS OF THOSE TRULY REPRESENTATIVE OF LARGE EMPLOYERS OF LABOR AND OF LARGE GROUPS OF ORGANIZED LABOR
column5: with small groups of those truly representative of large employers of labor and of large groups of organized labor

column5: in order to seek their cooperation in establishing what i may describe as a specific trial period of industrial peace

column4: FROM THOSE WILLING TO JOIN IN ESTABLISHING THIS HOPEDFOR PERIOD OF PEACE
column5: from those willing to join in establishing this hopedfor period of peace

column5: i shall seek assurances of the making and maintenance of agreements which can be mutually relied upon

column4: UNDER WHICH WAGES HOURS AND WORKING CONDITIONS
column5: under which wages hours and working conditions

column5: may be determined and any later adjustments shall be made either by agreement or in case of disagreement

column5: through the mediation or arbitration of state or federal agencies

column5: i shall not ask either employers or employees permanently to lay aside the weapons common to industrial war

column5: but i shall ask both groups to give a fair trial to peaceful methods of adjusting their conflicts of opinion and interest

column5: and to experiment for a reasonable time with measures suitable to civilize our industrial civilization

column5: closely allied to the nra

column5: both directly on the public works themselves and indirectly in the industries supplying the materials for these public works

column5: to those who say that our expenditures for public works and other means for recovery are a waste that we cannot afford

column5: what may be necessary for those countries is not my responsibility to determine

column5: a permanent army of unemployed

column5: we must make it a national principle that we will not tolerate a large army of unemployed and that we will arrange our national economy

column5: complain that all we have done is unnecessary and subject to great risks

column5: now that these people are coming out of their storm cellars they forget that there ever was a storm

column5: they point to england

column5: to issue new bonds therefore bearing only three and one half percent interest

column5: thereby saving the british treasury one hundred and fifty million dollars a year in interest alone

column5: nearly all americans are sensible and calm people

column5: we do not get greatly excited nor is our peace of mind disturbed whether we be businessmen or workers or farmers

column5: we are not frightened by reactionary lawyers or political editors

column5: all of these cries have been heard before
