column4: HOWEVER FOR THE FIRST TIME IN FIVE YEARS THE RELIEF ROLLS HAVE DECLINED INSTEAD OF INCREASED DURING THE WINTER MONTHS
column5: however for the first time in five years the relief rolls have declined instead of increased during the winter months

column4: THEY ARE STILL DECLINING
column5: they are still declining

column4: THE SIMPLE FACT IS THAT MANY MILLION MORE PEOPLE HAVE PRIVATE WORK TODAY THAN TWO YEARS AGO TODAY OR ONE YEAR AGO TODAY
column5: the simple fact is that many million more people have private work today than two years ago today or one year ago today

column4: AND EVERY DAY THAT PASSES OFFERS MORE CHANCES TO WORK FOR THOSE WHO WANT TO WORK
column5: and every day that passes offers more chances to work for those who want to work

column4: IN SPITE OF THE FACT THAT UNEMPLOYMENT REMAINS A SERIOUS PROBLEM
column5: in spite of the fact that unemployment remains a serious problem

column4: HERE AS IN EVERY OTHER NATION WE HAVE COME TO RECOGNIZE THE POSSIBILITY AND THE NECESSITY OF CERTAIN HELPFUL REMEDIAL MEASURES
column5: here as in every other nation we have come to recognize the possibility and the necessity of certain helpful remedial measures

column4: THESE MEASURES ARE OF TWO KINDS
column5: these measures are of two kinds

column4: THE FIRST IS TO MAKE PROVISIONS INTENDED TO RELIEVE TO MINIMIZE AND TO PREVENT FUTURE UNEMPLOYMENT
column5: the first is to make provisions intended to relieve to minimize and to prevent future unemployment

column4: THE SECOND IS TO ESTABLISH THE PRACTICAL MEANS TO HELP THOSE WHO ARE UNEMPLOYED IN THIS PRESENT EMERGENCY
column5: the second is to establish the practical means to help those who are unemployed in this present emergency

column4: OUR SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION IS AN ATTEMPT TO ANSWER THE FIRST OF THESE QUESTIONS OUR WORKS RELIEF PROGRAM THE SECOND
column5: our social security legislation is an attempt to answer the first of these questions our works relief program the second

column4: THE PROGRAM FOR SOCIAL SECURITY NOW PENDING BEFORE THE CONGRESS IS A NECESSARY PART OF THE FUTURE UNEMPLOYMENT POLICY OF THE GOVERNMENT
column5: the program for social security now pending before the congress is a necessary part of the future unemployment policy of the government

column4: WHILE OUR PRESENT AND PROJECTED EXPENDITURES FOR WORK RELIEF ARE WHOLLY WITHIN THE REASONABLE LIMITS OF OUR NATIONAL CREDIT RESOURCES
column5: while our present and projected expenditures for work relief are wholly within the reasonable limits of our national credit resources

column4: IT IS OBVIOUS THAT WE CANNOT CONTINUE TO CREATE GOVERNMENTAL DEFICITS FOR THAT PURPOSE YEAR AFTER YEAR
column5: it is obvious that we cannot continue to create governmental deficits for that purpose year after year

column4: WE MUST BEGIN NOW TO MAKE PROVISION FOR THE FUTURE
column5: we must begin now to make provision for the future

column4: THAT IS WHY OUR SOCIAL SECURITY PROGRAM IS AN IMPORTANT PART OF THE COMPLETE PICTURE
column5: that is why our social security program is an important part of the complete picture

column4: IT PROPOSES BY MEANS OF OLD AGE PENSIONS
column5: it proposes by means of old age pensions

column4: TO HELP THOSE WHO HAVE REACHED THE AGE OF RETIREMENT TO GIVE UP THEIR JOBS AND THUS GIVE TO THE YOUNGER GENERATION GREATER OPPORTUNITIES FOR WORK
column5: to help those who have reached the age of retirement to give up their jobs and thus give to the younger generation greater opportunities for work

column4: AND TO GIVE TO ALL A FEELING OF SECURITY AS THEY LOOK TOWARD OLD AGE
column5: and to give to all a feeling of security as they look toward old age

column4: THE UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE PART OF THE LEGISLATION
column5: the unemployment insurance part of the legislation

column4: WILL NOT ONLY HELP TO GUARD THE INDIVIDUAL IN FUTURE PERIODS OF LAYOFF AGAINST DEPENDENCE UPON RELIEF
column5: will not only help to guard the individual in future periods of layoff against dependence upon relief

column4: BUT IT WILL BY SUSTAINING PURCHASING POWER CUSHION THE SHOCK OF ECONOMIC DISTRESS
column5: but it will by sustaining purchasing power cushion the shock of economic distress

column4: ANOTHER HELPFUL FEATURE OF UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE IS THE INCENTIVE IT WILL GIVE TO EMPLOYERS TO PLAN MORE CAREFULLY
column5: another helpful feature of unemployment insurance is the incentive it will give to employers to plan more carefully

column4: IN ORDER THAT UNEMPLOYMENT MAY BE PREVENTED BY THE STABILIZING OF EMPLOYMENT ITSELF
column5: in order that unemployment may be prevented by the stabilizing of employment itself

column4: PROVISIONS FOR SOCIAL SECURITY HOWEVER ARE PROTECTIONS FOR THE FUTURE
column5: provisions for social security however are protections for the future

column4: OUR RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE IMMEDIATE NECESSITIES OF THE UNEMPLOYED HAS BEEN MET BY THE CONGRESS
column5: our responsibility for the immediate necessities of the unemployed has been met by the congress

column4: THROUGH THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE WORK PLAN IN THE HISTORY OF THE NATION
column5: through the most comprehensive work plan in the history of the nation

column4: OUR PROBLEM IS TO PUT TO WORK THREE AND ONEHALF MILLION EMPLOYABLE PERSONS NOW ON THE RELIEF ROLLS
column5: our problem is to put to work three and onehalf million employable persons now on the relief rolls

column4: IT IS A PROBLEM QUITE AS MUCH FOR PRIVATE INDUSTRY AS FOR THE GOVERNMENT
column5: it is a problem quite as much for private industry as for the government

column4: WE ARE LOSING NO TIME GETTING THE GOVERNMENT'S VAST WORK RELIEF PROGRAM UNDERWAY
column5: we are losing no time getting the government's vast work relief program underway

column4: AND WE HAVE EVERY REASON TO BELIEVE THAT IT SHOULD BE IN FULL SWING BY AUTUMN
column5: and we have every reason to believe that it should be in full swing by autumn

column4: IN DIRECTING IT I SHALL RECOGNIZE SIX FUNDAMENTAL PRINCIPLES
column5: in directing it i shall recognize six fundamental principles

column4: ONE THE PROJECTS SHOULD BE USEFUL
column5: one the projects should be useful

column4: PROJECTS SHALL BE OF A NATURE THAT A CONSIDERABLE PROPORTION OF THE MONEY SPENT WILL GO INTO WAGES FOR LABOR
column5: projects shall be of a nature that a considerable proportion of the money spent will go into wages for labor

column4: PROJECTS WILL BE SOUGHT WHICH PROMISE ULTIMATE RETURN TO THE FEDERAL TREASURY OF A CONSIDERABLE PROPORTION OF THE COSTS
column5: projects will be sought which promise ultimate return to the federal treasury of a considerable proportion of the costs

column4: FUNDS ALLOTTED FOR EACH PROJECT SHOULD BE ACTUALLY AND PROMPTLY SPENT AND NOT HELD OVER UNTIL LATER YEARS
column5: funds allotted for each project should be actually and promptly spent and not held over until later years

column4: IN ALL CASES PROJECTS MUST BE OF A CHARACTER TO GIVE EMPLOYMENT TO THOSE ON THE RELIEF ROLLS
column5: in all cases projects must be of a character to give employment to those on the relief rolls

column4: SIX PROJECTS WILL BE ALLOCATED TO LOCALITIES OR RELIEF AREAS IN RELATION TO THE NUMBER OF WORKERS ON RELIEF ROLLS IN THOSE AREAS
column5: six projects will be allocated to localities or relief areas in relation to the number of workers on relief rolls in those areas

column4: I NEXT WANT TO MAKE IT CLEAR EXACTLY HOW WE SHALL DIRECT THE WORK
column5: i next want to make it clear exactly how we shall direct the work

column4: I HAVE SET UP A DIVISION OF APPLICATIONS AND INFORMATION
column5: i have set up a division of applications and information

column4: TO WHICH ALL PROPOSALS FOR THE EXPENDITURE OF MONEY MUST GO FOR PRELIMINARY STUDY AND CONSIDERATION
column5: to which all proposals for the expenditure of money must go for preliminary study and consideration

column4: AFTER THE DIVISION OF APPLICATIONS AND INFORMATION HAS SIFTED THOSE PROJECTS
column5: after the division of applications and information has sifted those projects

column4: THEY WILL BE SENT TO AN ALLOTMENT DIVISION COMPOSED OF REPRESENTATIVES OF THE MORE IMPORTANT GOVERNMENTAL AGENCIES
column5: they will be sent to an allotment division composed of representatives of the more important governmental agencies

column4: CHARGED WITH CARRYING ON WORK RELIEF PROJECTS
column5: charged with carrying on work relief projects

column4: THE GROUP WILL ALSO INCLUDE REPRESENTATIVES OF CITIES AND OF LABOR FARMING BANKING AND INDUSTRY
column5: the group will also include representatives of cities and of labor farming banking and industry

column4: THIS ALLOTMENT DIVISION WILL CONSIDER ALL OF THE RECOMMENDATIONS SUBMITTED TO IT
column5: this allotment division will consider all of the recommendations submitted to it

column4: AND SUCH PROJECTS AS THEY APPROVE WILL BE NEXT SUBMITTED TO THE PRESIDENT WHO UNDER THE ACT IS REQUIRED TO MAKE FINAL ALLOCATIONS
column5: and such projects as they approve will be next submitted to the president who under the act is required to make final allocations

column4: THE NEXT STEP WILL BE TO NOTIFY THE PROPER GOVERNMENT AGENCY
column5: the next step will be to notify the proper government agency

column4: IN WHOSE FIELD THE PROJECT FALLS AND ALSO TO NOTIFY ANOTHER AGENCY WHICH I AM CREATING  A PROGRESS DIVISION
column5: in whose field the project falls and also to notify another agency which i am creating  a progress division

column4: THIS DIVISION WILL HAVE THE DUTY OF COORDINATING THE PURCHASES OF MATERIALS AND SUPPLIES
column5: this division will have the duty of coordinating the purchases of materials and supplies

column4: AND OF MAKING CERTAIN THAT PEOPLE WHO ARE EMPLOYED WILL BE TAKEN FROM THE RELIEF ROLLS
column5: and of making certain that people who are employed will be taken from the relief rolls

column4: IT WILL ALSO HAVE THE RESPONSIBILITY OF DETERMINING WORK PAYMENTS IN VARIOUS LOCALITIES
column5: it will also have the responsibility of determining work payments in various localities

column4: OF MAKING FULL USE OF EXISTING EMPLOYMENT SERVICES AND TO ASSIST PEOPLE ENGAGED IN RELIEF WORK
column5: of making full use of existing employment services and to assist people engaged in relief work

column4: TO MOVE AS RAPIDLY AS POSSIBLE BACK INTO PRIVATE EMPLOYMENT WHEN SUCH EMPLOYMENT IS AVAILABLE
column5: to move as rapidly as possible back into private employment when such employment is available

column4: MOREOVER THIS DIVISION WILL BE CHARGED WITH KEEPING PROJECTS MOVING ON SCHEDULE
column5: moreover this division will be charged with keeping projects moving on schedule

column4: I HAVE FELT IT TO BE ESSENTIALLY WISE AND PRUDENT TO AVOID SO FAR AS POSSIBLE
column5: i have felt it to be essentially wise and prudent to avoid so far as possible

column4: THE CREATION OF NEW GOVERNMENTAL MACHINERY FOR SUPERVISING THIS WORK
column5: the creation of new governmental machinery for supervising this work

column4: THE NATIONAL GOVERNMENT NOW HAS AT LEAST SIXTY DIFFERENT AGENCIES WITH THE STAFF
column5: the national government now has at least sixty different agencies with the staff

column4: AND THE EXPERIENCE AND THE COMPETENCE NECESSARY TO CARRY ON THE TWO HUNDRED AND FIFTY OR THREE HUNDRED KINDS OF WORK THAT WILL BE UNDERTAKEN
column5: and the experience and the competence necessary to carry on the two hundred and fifty or three hundred kinds of work that will be undertaken

column4: THESE AGENCIES THEREFORE WILL SIMPLY BE DOING ON A SOMEWHAT ENLARGED SCALE THE SAME SORT OF THINGS THAT THEY HAVE BEEN DOING
column5: these agencies therefore will simply be doing on a somewhat enlarged scale the same sort of things that they have been doing

column4: THIS WILL MAKE CERTAIN THAT THE LARGEST POSSIBLE PORTION OF THE FUNDS ALLOTTED
column5: this will make certain that the largest possible portion of the funds allotted

column4: WILL BE SPENT FOR ACTUALLY CREATING NEW WORK AND NOT FOR BUILDING UP EXPENSIVE OVERHEAD ORGANIZATIONS HERE IN WASHINGTON
column5: will be spent for actually creating new work and not for building up expensive overhead organizations here in washington

column4: FOR MANY MONTHS PREPARATIONS HAVE BEEN UNDER WAY
column5: for many months preparations have been under way

column4: THE ALLOTMENT OF FUNDS FOR DESIRABLE PROJECTS HAS ALREADY BEGUN
column5: the allotment of funds for desirable projects has already begun

column4: THE KEY MEN FOR THE MAJOR RESPONSIBILITIES OF THIS GREAT TASK ALREADY HAVE BEEN SELECTED
column5: the key men for the major responsibilities of this great task already have been selected

column4: I WELL REALIZE THAT THE COUNTRY IS EXPECTING BEFORE THIS YEAR IS OUT TO SEE THE DIRT FLY AS THEY SAY IN CARRYING ON THE WORK
column5: i well realize that the country is expecting before this year is out to see the dirt fly as they say in carrying on the work

column4: AND I ASSURE MY FELLOW CITIZENS THAT NO ENERGY WILL BE SPARED IN USING THESE FUNDS EFFECTIVELY
column5: and i assure my fellow citizens that no energy will be spared in using these funds effectively

column4: TO MAKE A MAJOR ATTACK UPON THE PROBLEM OF UNEMPLOYMENT
column5: to make a major attack upon the problem of unemployment

column4: OUR RESPONSIBILITY IS TO ALL OF THE PEOPLE IN THIS COUNTRY
column5: our responsibility is to all of the people in this country

column4: THIS IS A GREAT NATIONAL CRUSADE TO DESTROY ENFORCED IDLENESS WHICH IS AN ENEMY OF THE HUMAN SPIRIT
column5: this is a great national crusade to destroy enforced idleness which is an enemy of the human spirit

column4: GENERATED BY THIS DEPRESSION
column5: generated by this depression

column4: OUR ATTACK UPON THESE ENEMIES MUST BE WITHOUT STINT AND WITHOUT DISCRIMINATION
column5: our attack upon these enemies must be without stint and without discrimination

column4: NO SECTIONAL NO POLITICAL DISTINCTIONS CAN BE PERMITTED
column5: no sectional no political distinctions can be permitted

column4: IT MUST HOWEVER BE RECOGNIZED THAT WHEN AN ENTERPRISE OF THIS CHARACTER IS EXTENDED OVER MORE THAN THREE THOUSAND COUNTIES THROUGHOUT THE NATION
column5: it must however be recognized that when an enterprise of this character is extended over more than three thousand counties throughout the nation

column4: THERE MAY BE OCCASIONAL INSTANCES OF INEFFICIENCY BAD MANAGEMENT OR MISUSE OF FUNDS
column5: there may be occasional instances of inefficiency bad management or misuse of funds

column4: WHEN CASES OF THIS KIND OCCUR
column5: when cases of this kind occur

column4: THERE WILL BE THOSE OF COURSE WHO WILL TRY TO TELL YOU THAT THE EXCEPTIONAL FAILURE IS CHARACTERISTIC OF THE ENTIRE ENDEAVOR
column5: there will be those of course who will try to tell you that the exceptional failure is characteristic of the entire endeavor

column4: IT SHOULD BE REMEMBERED THAT IN EVERY BIG JOB THERE ARE SOME IMPERFECTIONS
column5: it should be remembered that in every big job there are some imperfections

column4: THERE ARE CHISELERS IN EVERY WALK OF LIFE THERE ARE THOSE IN EVERY INDUSTRY WHO ARE GUILTY OF UNFAIR PRACTICES
column5: there are chiselers in every walk of life there are those in every industry who are guilty of unfair practices

column4: EVERY PROFESSION HAS ITS BLACK SHEEP BUT LONG EXPERIENCE IN GOVERNMENT HAS TAUGHT ME
column5: every profession has its black sheep but long experience in government has taught me

column4: THAT THE EXCEPTIONAL INSTANCES OF WRONGDOING IN GOVERNMENT ARE PROBABLY LESS NUMEROUS THAN IN ALMOST EVERY OTHER LINE OF ENDEAVOR
column5: that the exceptional instances of wrongdoing in government are probably less numerous than in almost every other line of endeavor

column4: THE MOST EFFECTIVE MEANS OF PREVENTING SUCH EVILS IN THIS WORKS RELIEF PROGRAM WILL BE THE ETERNAL VIGILANCE OF THE AMERICAN PEOPLE THEMSELVES
column5: the most effective means of preventing such evils in this works relief program will be the eternal vigilance of the american people themselves

column4: I CALL UPON MY FELLOW CITIZENS EVERYWHERE TO COOPERATE WITH ME
column5: i call upon my fellow citizens everywhere to cooperate with me

column4: IN MAKING THIS THE MOST EFFICIENT AND THE CLEANEST EXAMPLE OF PUBLIC ENTERPRISE THE WORLD HAS EVER SEEN
column5: in making this the most efficient and the cleanest example of public enterprise the world has ever seen

column4: IT IS TIME TO PROVIDE A SMASHING ANSWER FOR THOSE CYNICAL MEN WHO SAY THAT A DEMOCRACY CANNOT BE HONEST AND EFFICIENT
column5: it is time to provide a smashing answer for those cynical men who say that a democracy cannot be honest and efficient

column4: IF YOU WILL HELP THIS CAN BE DONE
column5: if you will help this can be done

column4: I THEREFORE HOPE YOU WILL WATCH THE WORK IN EVERY CORNER OF THIS NATION
column5: i therefore hope you will watch the work in every corner of this nation

column4: FEEL FREE TO CRITICIZE TELL ME OF INSTANCES WHERE WORK CAN BE DONE BETTER OR WHERE IMPROPER PRACTICES PREVAIL
column5: feel free to criticize tell me of instances where work can be done better or where improper practices prevail

column4: NEITHER YOU NOR I WANT CRITICISM CONCEIVED IN A PURELY FAULTFINDING OR PARTISAN SPIRIT
column5: neither you nor i want criticism conceived in a purely faultfinding or partisan spirit

column4: BUT I AM JEALOUS OF THE RIGHT OF EVERY CITIZEN TO CALL TO THE ATTENTION OF HIS OR HER GOVERNMENT
column5: but i am jealous of the right of every citizen to call to the attention of his or her government

column4: EXAMPLES OF HOW THE PUBLIC MONEY CAN BE MORE EFFECTIVELY SPENT FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE AMERICAN PEOPLE
column5: examples of how the public money can be more effectively spent for the benefit of the american people

column4: I NOW COME MY FRIENDS TO A PART OF THE REMAINING BUSINESS BEFORE THE CONGRESS
column5: i now come my friends to a part of the remaining business before the congress

column4: IT HAS UNDER CONSIDERATION MANY MEASURES WHICH PROVIDE FOR THE ROUNDING OUT OF THE PROGRAM OF ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL RECONSTRUCTION
column5: it has under consideration many measures which provide for the rounding out of the program of economic and social reconstruction

column4: WITH WHICH WE HAVE BEEN CONCERNED FOR TWO YEARS
column5: with which we have been concerned for two years

column4: I CAN MENTION ONLY A FEW OF THEM TONIGHT BUT I DO NOT WANT MY MENTION OF SPECIFIC MEASURES
column5: i can mention only a few of them tonight but i do not want my mention of specific measures

column4: TO BE INTERPRETED AS LACK OF INTEREST IN OR DISAPPROVAL OF MANY OTHER IMPORTANT PROPOSALS THAT ARE PENDING
column5: to be interpreted as lack of interest in or disapproval of many other important proposals that are pending

column4: THE NATIONAL INDUSTRIAL RECOVERY ACT EXPIRES ON THE SIXTEENTH OF JUNE
column5: the national industrial recovery act expires on the sixteenth of june

column4: AFTER CAREFUL CONSIDERATION I HAVE ASKED THE CONGRESS TO EXTEND THE LIFE OF THIS USEFUL AGENCY OF GOVERNMENT
column5: after careful consideration i have asked the congress to extend the life of this useful agency of government

column4: AS WE HAVE PROCEEDED WITH THE ADMINISTRATION OF THIS ACT
column5: as we have proceeded with the administration of this act

column4: WE HAVE FOUND FROM TIME TO TIME MORE AND MORE USEFUL WAYS OF PROMOTING ITS PURPOSES
column5: we have found from time to time more and more useful ways of promoting its purposes

column4: NO REASONABLE PERSON WANTS TO ABANDON OUR PRESENT GAINS
column5: no reasonable person wants to abandon our present gains

column4: WE MUST CONTINUE TO PROTECT CHILDREN
column5: we must continue to protect children

column4: TO ENFORCE MINIMUM WAGES TO PREVENT EXCESSIVE HOURS
column5: to enforce minimum wages to prevent excessive hours

column4: TO SAFEGUARD DEFINE AND ENFORCE COLLECTIVE BARGAINING AND WHILE RETAINING FAIR COMPETITION
column5: to safeguard define and enforce collective bargaining and while retaining fair competition

column4: TO ELIMINATE SO FAR AS HUMANLY POSSIBLE THE KINDS OF UNFAIR PRACTICES BY SELFISH MINORITIES WHICH UNFORTUNATELY
column5: to eliminate so far as humanly possible the kinds of unfair practices by selfish minorities which unfortunately

column4: DID MORE THAN ANYTHING ELSE TO BRING ABOUT THE RECENT COLLAPSE OF INDUSTRIES
column5: did more than anything else to bring about the recent collapse of industries

column4: THERE IS LIKEWISE PENDING BEFORE THE CONGRESS
column5: there is likewise pending before the congress

column4: LEGISLATION TO PROVIDE FOR THE ELIMINATION OF UNNECESSARY HOLDING COMPANIES IN THE PUBLIC UTILITY FIELD
column5: legislation to provide for the elimination of unnecessary holding companies in the public utility field

column4: I CONSIDER THIS LEGISLATION A POSITIVE RECOVERY MEASURE
column5: i consider this legislation a positive recovery measure

column4: POWER PRODUCTION IN THIS COUNTRY IS VIRTUALLY BACK TO THE NINETEEN TWENTYNINE PEAK
column5: power production in this country is virtually back to the nineteen twentynine peak

column4: THE OPERATING COMPANIES IN THE GAS AND ELECTRIC UTILITY FIELD ARE BY AND LARGE IN GOOD CONDITION BUT
column5: the operating companies in the gas and electric utility field are by and large in good condition but

column4: UNDER HOLDING COMPANY DOMINATION THE UTILITY INDUSTRY HAS LONG BEEN HOPELESSLY AT WAR WITHIN ITSELF AND WITH PUBLIC SENTIMENT
column5: under holding company domination the utility industry has long been hopelessly at war within itself and with public sentiment

column4: BY FAR THE GREATER PART OF THE GENERAL DECLINE IN UTILITY SECURITIES HAD OCCURRED BEFORE I WAS INAUGURATED
column5: by far the greater part of the general decline in utility securities had occurred before i was inaugurated

column4: THE ABSENTEE MANAGEMENT OF UNNECESSARY HOLDING COMPANY CONTROL
column5: the absentee management of unnecessary holding company control

column4: HAS LOST TOUCH WITH AND HAS LOST THE SYMPATHY OF THE COMMUNITIES IT PRETENDS TO SERVE
column5: has lost touch with and has lost the sympathy of the communities it pretends to serve

column4: EVEN MORE SIGNIFICANTLY IT HAS GIVEN THE COUNTRY AS A WHOLE AN UNEASY APPREHENSION OF OVERCONCENTRATED ECONOMIC POWER
column5: even more significantly it has given the country as a whole an uneasy apprehension of overconcentrated economic power

column4: A BUSINESS THAT LOSES THE CONFIDENCE OF ITS CUSTOMERS AND THE GOODWILL OF THE PUBLIC CANNOT LONG CONTINUE TO BE A GOOD RISK FOR THE INVESTOR
column5: a business that loses the confidence of its customers and the goodwill of the public cannot long continue to be a good risk for the investor

column4: THIS LEGISLATION WILL SERVE THE INVESTOR BY ENDING THE CONDITIONS WHICH HAVE CAUSED THAT LACK OF CONFIDENCE AND GOODWILL
column5: this legislation will serve the investor by ending the conditions which have caused that lack of confidence and goodwill

column4: IT WILL PUT THE PUBLIC UTILITY OPERATING INDUSTRY ON A SOUND BASIS FOR THE FUTURE
column5: it will put the public utility operating industry on a sound basis for the future

column4: BOTH IN ITS PUBLIC RELATIONS AND IN ITS INTERNAL RELATIONS
column5: both in its public relations and in its internal relations

column4: THIS LEGISLATION WILL NOT ONLY IN THE LONG RUN RESULT IN PROVIDING LOWER ELECTRIC AND GAS RATES TO THE CONSUMER
column5: this legislation will not only in the long run result in providing lower electric and gas rates to the consumer

column4: BUT IT WILL PROTECT THE ACTUAL VALUE AND EARNING POWER OF PROPERTIES NOW OWNED BY THOUSANDS OF INVESTORS
column5: but it will protect the actual value and earning power of properties now owned by thousands of investors

column4: WHO HAVE LITTLE PROTECTION UNDER THE OLD LAWS AGAINST WHAT USED TO BE CALLED FRENZIED FINANCE
column5: who have little protection under the old laws against what used to be called frenzied finance

column4: IT WILL NOT DESTROY VALUES
column5: it will not destroy values

column4: NOT ONLY BUSINESS RECOVERY BUT THE GENERAL ECONOMIC RECOVERY OF THE NATION WILL BE GREATLY STIMULATED BY THE ENACTMENT OF LEGISLATION
column5: not only business recovery but the general economic recovery of the nation will be greatly stimulated by the enactment of legislation

column4: DESIGNED TO IMPROVE THE STATUS OF OUR TRANSPORTATION AGENCIES
column5: designed to improve the status of our transportation agencies

column4: THERE IS NEED FOR LEGISLATION PROVIDING FOR THE REGULATION OF INTERSTATE TRANSPORTATION BY BUSES AND TRUCKS
column5: there is need for legislation providing for the regulation of interstate transportation by buses and trucks

column4: FOR THE REGULATION OF TRANSPORTATION BY WATER FOR THE STRENGTHENING OF OUR MERCHANT MARINE AND AIR TRANSPORT
column5: for the regulation of transportation by water for the strengthening of our merchant marine and air transport

column4: FOR THE STRENGTHENING OF THE INTERSTATE COMMERCE COMMISSION TO ENABLE IT TO CARRY OUT A ROUNDED CONCEPTION OF THE NATIONAL TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM
column5: for the strengthening of the interstate commerce commission to enable it to carry out a rounded conception of the national transportation system

column4: IN WHICH THE BENEFITS OF PRIVATE OWNERSHIP ARE RETAINED WHILE THE PUBLIC STAKE IN THESE IMPORTANT SERVICES IS PROTECTED BY THE PUBLIC'S GOVERNMENT
column5: in which the benefits of private ownership are retained while the public stake in these important services is protected by the public's government

column4: FINALLY THE REESTABLISHMENT OF PUBLIC CONFIDENCE IN THE BANKS OF THE NATION
column5: finally the reestablishment of public confidence in the banks of the nation

column4: IS ONE OF THE MOST HOPEFUL RESULTS OF OUR EFFORTS AS A NATION TO REESTABLISH PUBLIC CONFIDENCE IN PRIVATE BANKING
column5: is one of the most hopeful results of our efforts as a nation to reestablish public confidence in private banking

column4: WE ALL KNOW THAT PRIVATE BANKING ACTUALLY EXISTS BY VIRTUE OF THE PERMISSION OF AND REGULATION BY THE PEOPLE AS A WHOLE
column5: we all know that private banking actually exists by virtue of the permission of and regulation by the people as a whole

column4: SPEAKING THROUGH THEIR GOVERNMENT
column5: speaking through their government

column4: WISE PUBLIC POLICY HOWEVER REQUIRES NOT ONLY THAT BANKING BE SAFE
column5: wise public policy however requires not only that banking be safe

column4: BUT THAT ITS RESOURCES BE MOST FULLY UTILIZED IN THE ECONOMIC LIFE OF THE COUNTRY
column5: but that its resources be most fully utilized in the economic life of the country

column4: TO THIS END IT WAS DECIDED MORE THAN TWENTY YEARS AGO
column5: to this end it was decided more than twenty years ago

column4: THAT THE GOVERNMENT SHOULD ASSUME THE RESPONSIBILITY OF PROVIDING A MEANS BY WHICH THE CREDIT OF THE NATION MIGHT BE CONTROLLED
column5: that the government should assume the responsibility of providing a means by which the credit of the nation might be controlled

column4: NOT BY A FEW PRIVATE BANKING INSTITUTIONS BUT BY A BODY WITH PUBLIC PRESTIGE AND AUTHORITY
column5: not by a few private banking institutions but by a body with public prestige and authority

column4: THE ANSWER TO THIS DEMAND WAS THE FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM
column5: the answer to this demand was the federal reserve system

column4: TWENTY YEARS OF EXPERIENCE WITH THIS SYSTEM HAVE JUSTIFIED THE EFFORTS MADE TO CREATE IT
column5: twenty years of experience with this system have justified the efforts made to create it

column4: BUT THESE TWENTY YEARS HAVE SHOWN BY EXPERIENCE DEFINITE POSSIBILITIES FOR IMPROVEMENT
column5: but these twenty years have shown by experience definite possibilities for improvement

column4: CERTAIN PROPOSALS MADE TO AMEND THE FEDERAL RESERVE ACT DESERVE PROMPT AND FAVORABLE ACTION BY THE CONGRESS
column5: certain proposals made to amend the federal reserve act deserve prompt and favorable action by the congress

column4: THEY ARE A MINIMUM OF WISE READJUSTMENTS OF OUR FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM IN THE LIGHT OF PAST EXPERIENCE AND PRESENT NEEDS
column5: they are a minimum of wise readjustments of our federal reserve system in the light of past experience and present needs

column4: THESE MEASURES I HAVE MENTIONED ARE IN LARGE PART THE PROGRAM WHICH UNDER MY CONSTITUTIONAL DUTY I HAVE RECOMMENDED TO THE CONGRESS
column5: these measures i have mentioned are in large part the program which under my constitutional duty i have recommended to the congress

column4: THEY ARE ESSENTIAL FACTORS IN A ROUNDED PROGRAM FOR NATIONAL RECOVERY
column5: they are essential factors in a rounded program for national recovery

column4: THEY CONTEMPLATE THE ENRICHMENT OF OUR NATIONAL LIFE
column5: they contemplate the enrichment of our national life

column4: BY A SOUND AND RATIONAL ORDERING OF ITS VARIOUS ELEMENTS AND WISE PROVISIONS FOR THE PROTECTION OF THE WEAK AGAINST THE STRONG
column5: by a sound and rational ordering of its various elements and wise provisions for the protection of the weak against the strong

column4: NEVER SINCE MY INAUGURATION IN MARCH NINETEEN THIRTYTHREE HAVE I FELT SO UNMISTAKABLY THE ATMOSPHERE OF RECOVERY
column5: never since my inauguration in march nineteen thirtythree have i felt so unmistakably the atmosphere of recovery

column4: BUT IT IS MORE THAN THE RECOVERY OF THE MATERIAL BASIS OF OUR INDIVIDUAL LIVES
column5: but it is more than the recovery of the material basis of our individual lives

column4: IT IS THE RECOVERY OF CONFIDENCE IN OUR DEMOCRATIC PROCESSES AND INSTITUTIONS
column5: it is the recovery of confidence in our democratic processes and institutions

column4: WE HAVE SURVIVED ALL OF THE ARDUOUS BURDENS AND THE THREATENING DANGERS OF A GREAT ECONOMIC CALAMITY
column5: we have survived all of the arduous burdens and the threatening dangers of a great economic calamity

column4: WE HAVE IN THE DARKEST MOMENTS OF OUR NATIONAL TRIALS RETAINED OUR FAITH IN OUR OWN ABILITY TO MASTER OUR DESTINY
column5: we have in the darkest moments of our national trials retained our faith in our own ability to master our destiny

column4: FEAR IS VANISHING AND CONFIDENCE IS GROWING ON EVERY SIDE
column5: fear is vanishing and confidence is growing on every side

column4: RENEWED FAITH IN THE VAST POSSIBILITIES OF HUMAN BEINGS TO IMPROVE THEIR MATERIAL AND SPIRITUAL STATUS
column5: renewed faith in the vast possibilities of human beings to improve their material and spiritual status

column4: THROUGH THE INSTRUMENTALITY OF THE DEMOCRATIC FORM OF GOVERNMENT
column5: through the instrumentality of the democratic form of government

column4: THAT FAITH IS RECEIVING ITS JUST REWARD
column5: that faith is receiving its just reward

column4: FOR THAT WE CAN BE THANKFUL TO THE GOD WHO WATCHES OVER AMERICA
column5: for that we can be thankful to the god who watches over america

column4: THE FIRESIDE CHATS OF FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT BY FRANKLIN D ROOSEVELT SECTION NINE
column5: the fireside chats of franklin delano roosevelt by franklin d roosevelt section nine

column4: MARCH NINE NINETEEN THIRTYSEVEN PART ONE
column5: march nine nineteen thirtyseven part one

column4: LAST THURSDAY I DESCRIBED IN DETAIL CERTAIN ECONOMIC PROBLEMS WHICH EVERYONE ADMITS NOW FACE THE NATION
column5: last thursday i described in detail certain economic problems which everyone admits now face the nation

column4: FOR THE MANY MESSAGES WHICH HAVE COME TO ME AFTER THAT SPEECH AND WHICH IT IS PHYSICALLY IMPOSSIBLE TO ANSWER INDIVIDUALLY
column5: for the many messages which have come to me after that speech and which it is physically impossible to answer individually

column4: I TAKE THIS MEANS OF SAYING THANK YOU
column5: i take this means of saying thank you

column4: TONIGHT SITTING AT MY DESK IN THE WHITE HOUSE I MAKE MY FIRST RADIO REPORT TO THE PEOPLE IN MY SECOND TERM OF OFFICE
column5: tonight sitting at my desk in the white house i make my first radio report to the people in my second term of office

column4: I AM REMINDED OF THAT EVENING IN MARCH FOUR YEARS AGO WHEN I MADE MY FIRST RADIO REPORT TO YOU
column5: i am reminded of that evening in march four years ago when i made my first radio report to you

column4: WE WERE THEN IN THE MIDST OF THE GREAT BANKING CRISIS
column5: we were then in the midst of the great banking crisis

column4: SOON AFTER WITH THE AUTHORITY OF THE CONGRESS
column5: soon after with the authority of the congress

column4: WE ASKED THE NATION TO TURN OVER ALL OF ITS PRIVATELY HELD GOLD DOLLAR FOR DOLLAR TO THE GOVERNMENT OF THE UNITED STATES
column5: we asked the nation to turn over all of its privately held gold dollar for dollar to the government of the united states

column4: TODAY'S RECOVERY PROVES HOW RIGHT THAT POLICY WAS
column5: today's recovery proves how right that policy was

column4: BUT WHEN ALMOST TWO YEARS LATER IT CAME BEFORE THE SUPREME COURT ITS CONSTITUTIONALITY WAS UPHELD ONLY BY A FIVETOFOUR VOTE
column5: but when almost two years later it came before the supreme court its constitutionality was upheld only by a fivetofour vote

column4: THE CHANGE OF ONE VOTE WOULD HAVE THROWN ALL THE AFFAIRS OF THIS GREAT NATION BACK INTO HOPELESS CHAOS
column5: the change of one vote would have thrown all the affairs of this great nation back into hopeless chaos

column4: IN EFFECT FOUR JUSTICES RULED THAT THE RIGHT UNDER A PRIVATE CONTRACT
column5: in effect four justices ruled that the right under a private contract

column4: TO EXACT A POUND OF FLESH WAS MORE SACRED THAN THE MAIN OBJECTIVES OF THE CONSTITUTION TO ESTABLISH AN ENDURING NATION
column5: to exact a pound of flesh was more sacred than the main objectives of the constitution to establish an enduring nation

column4: IN NINETEEN THIRTYTHREE YOU AND I KNEW THAT WE MUST NEVER LET OUR ECONOMIC SYSTEM GET COMPLETELY OUT OF JOINT AGAIN
column5: in nineteen thirtythree you and i knew that we must never let our economic system get completely out of joint again

column4: THAT WE COULD NOT AFFORD TO TAKE THE RISK OF ANOTHER GREAT DEPRESSION
column5: that we could not afford to take the risk of another great depression

column4: WE ALSO BECAME CONVINCED THAT THE ONLY WAY TO AVOID A REPETITION OF THOSE DARK DAYS WAS TO HAVE A GOVERNMENT WITH POWER TO PREVENT
column5: we also became convinced that the only way to avoid a repetition of those dark days was to have a government with power to prevent

column4: AND TO CURE THE ABUSES AND THE INEQUALITIES WHICH HAD THROWN THAT SYSTEM OUT OF JOINT
column5: and to cure the abuses and the inequalities which had thrown that system out of joint

column4: WE THEN BEGAN A PROGRAM OF REMEDYING THOSE ABUSES AND INEQUALITIES  TO GIVE BALANCE AND STABILITY TO OUR ECONOMIC SYSTEM
column5: we then began a program of remedying those abuses and inequalities  to give balance and stability to our economic system

column4: TO MAKE IT BOMBPROOF AGAINST THE CAUSES OF NINETEEN TWENTYNINE
column5: to make it bombproof against the causes of nineteen twentynine

column4: TODAY WE ARE ONLY PARTWAY THROUGH THAT PROGRAM
column5: today we are only partway through that program

column4: AND RECOVERY IS SPEEDING UP TO A POINT WHERE THE DANGERS OF NINETEEN TWENTYNINE ARE AGAIN BECOMING POSSIBLE
column5: and recovery is speeding up to a point where the dangers of nineteen twentynine are again becoming possible

column4: NOT THIS WEEK OR MONTH PERHAPS BUT WITHIN A YEAR OR TWO
column5: not this week or month perhaps but within a year or two

column4: NATIONAL LAWS ARE NEEDED TO COMPLETE THAT PROGRAM
column5: national laws are needed to complete that program

column4: INDIVIDUAL OR LOCAL OR STATE EFFORT ALONE CANNOT PROTECT US IN NINETEEN THIRTYSEVEN ANY BETTER THAN TEN YEARS AGO
column5: individual or local or state effort alone cannot protect us in nineteen thirtyseven any better than ten years ago

column4: IT WILL TAKE TIME  AND PLENTY OF TIME  TO WORK OUT OUR REMEDIES ADMINISTRATIVELY EVEN AFTER LEGISLATION IS PASSED
column5: it will take time  and plenty of time  to work out our remedies administratively even after legislation is passed

column4: TO COMPLETE OUR PROGRAM OF PROTECTION IN TIME THEREFORE
column5: to complete our program of protection in time therefore

column4: WE CANNOT DELAY ONE MOMENT IN MAKING CERTAIN THAT OUR NATIONAL GOVERNMENT HAS POWER TO CARRY THROUGH
column5: we cannot delay one moment in making certain that our national government has power to carry through

column4: FOUR YEARS AGO ACTION DID NOT COME UNTIL THE ELEVENTH HOUR
column5: four years ago action did not come until the eleventh hour

column4: IT WAS ALMOST TOO LATE
column5: it was almost too late

column4: IF WE LEARNED ANYTHING FROM THE DEPRESSION
column5: if we learned anything from the depression

column4: WE WILL NOT ALLOW OURSELVES TO RUN AROUND IN NEW CIRCLES OF FUTILE DISCUSSION AND DEBATE ALWAYS POSTPONING THE DAY OF DECISION
column5: we will not allow ourselves to run around in new circles of futile discussion and debate always postponing the day of decision

column4: THE AMERICAN PEOPLE HAVE LEARNED FROM THE DEPRESSION
column5: the american people have learned from the depression

column4: FOR IN THE LAST THREE NATIONAL ELECTIONS
column5: for in the last three national elections

column4: AN OVERWHELMING MAJORITY OF THEM VOTED A MANDATE THAT THE CONGRESS AND THE PRESIDENT BEGIN THE TASK OF PROVIDING THAT PROTECTION
column5: an overwhelming majority of them voted a mandate that the congress and the president begin the task of providing that protection

column4: NOT AFTER LONG YEARS OF DEBATE BUT NOW
column5: not after long years of debate but now

column4: THE COURTS HOWEVER HAVE CAST DOUBTS ON THE ABILITY OF THE ELECTED CONGRESS TO PROTECT US AGAINST CATASTROPHE
column5: the courts however have cast doubts on the ability of the elected congress to protect us against catastrophe

column4: BY MEETING SQUARELY OUR MODERN SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC CONDITIONS
column5: by meeting squarely our modern social and economic conditions

column4: WE ARE AT A CRISIS IN OUR ABILITY TO PROCEED WITH THAT PROTECTION
column5: we are at a crisis in our ability to proceed with that protection

column4: IT IS A QUIET CRISIS THERE ARE NO LINES OF DEPOSITORS OUTSIDE CLOSED BANKS
column5: it is a quiet crisis there are no lines of depositors outside closed banks

column4: BUT TO THE FARSIGHTED IT IS FARREACHING IN ITS POSSIBILITIES OF INJURY TO AMERICA
column5: but to the farsighted it is farreaching in its possibilities of injury to america

column4: I WANT TO TALK WITH YOU VERY SIMPLY ABOUT THE NEED FOR PRESENT ACTION IN THIS CRISIS
column5: i want to talk with you very simply about the need for present action in this crisis

column4: THE NEED TO MEET THE UNANSWERED CHALLENGE OF ONETHIRD OF A NATION ILLNOURISHED ILLCLAD ILLHOUSED
column5: the need to meet the unanswered challenge of onethird of a nation illnourished illclad illhoused

column4: LAST THURSDAY I DESCRIBED THE AMERICAN FORM OF GOVERNMENT AS A THREE HORSE TEAM PROVIDED BY THE CONSTITUTION TO THE AMERICAN PEOPLE
column5: last thursday i described the american form of government as a three horse team provided by the constitution to the american people

column4: SO THAT THEIR FIELD MIGHT BE PLOWED
column5: so that their field might be plowed

column4: THE THREE HORSES ARE OF COURSE THE THREE BRANCHES OF GOVERNMENT  THE CONGRESS THE EXECUTIVE AND THE COURTS
column5: the three horses are of course the three branches of government  the congress the executive and the courts

column4: TWO OF THE HORSES ARE PULLING IN UNISON TODAY THE THIRD IS NOT
column5: two of the horses are pulling in unison today the third is not

column4: THOSE WHO HAVE INTIMATED THAT THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES IS TRYING TO DRIVE THAT TEAM
column5: those who have intimated that the president of the united states is trying to drive that team

column4: OVERLOOK THE SIMPLE FACT THAT THE PRESIDENT AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE IS HIMSELF ONE OF THE THREE HORSES
column5: overlook the simple fact that the president as chief executive is himself one of the three horses

column4: IT IS THE AMERICAN PEOPLE THEMSELVES WHO ARE IN THE DRIVER'S SEAT
column5: it is the american people themselves who are in the driver's seat

column4: IT IS THE AMERICAN PEOPLE THEMSELVES WHO WANT THE FURROW PLOWED
column5: it is the american people themselves who want the furrow plowed

column4: IT IS THE AMERICAN PEOPLE THEMSELVES WHO EXPECT THE THIRD HORSE TO PULL IN UNISON WITH THE OTHER TWO
column5: it is the american people themselves who expect the third horse to pull in unison with the other two

column4: I HOPE THAT YOU HAVE REREAD THE CONSTITUTION OF THE UNITED STATES IN THESE PAST FEW WEEKS
column5: i hope that you have reread the constitution of the united states in these past few weeks

column4: LIKE THE BIBLE IT OUGHT TO BE READ AGAIN AND AGAIN
column5: like the bible it ought to be read again and again

column4: IT IS AN EASY DOCUMENT TO UNDERSTAND WHEN YOU REMEMBER THAT IT WAS CALLED INTO BEING
column5: it is an easy document to understand when you remember that it was called into being

column4: BECAUSE THE ARTICLES OF CONFEDERATION UNDER WHICH THE ORIGINAL THIRTEEN STATES TRIED TO OPERATE AFTER THE REVOLUTION
column5: because the articles of confederation under which the original thirteen states tried to operate after the revolution

column4: SHOWED THE NEED OF A NATIONAL GOVERNMENT WITH POWER ENOUGH TO HANDLE NATIONAL PROBLEMS
column5: showed the need of a national government with power enough to handle national problems

column4: IN ITS PREAMBLE THE CONSTITUTION STATES THAT IT WAS INTENDED TO FORM A MORE PERFECT UNION AND PROMOTE THE GENERAL WELFARE
column5: in its preamble the constitution states that it was intended to form a more perfect union and promote the general welfare

column4: AND THE POWERS GIVEN TO THE CONGRESS TO CARRY OUT THOSE PURPOSES CAN BE BEST DESCRIBED BY SAYING
column5: and the powers given to the congress to carry out those purposes can be best described by saying

column4: THAT THEY WERE ALL THE POWERS NEEDED TO MEET EACH AND EVERY PROBLEM WHICH THEN HAD A NATIONAL CHARACTER
column5: that they were all the powers needed to meet each and every problem which then had a national character

column4: AND WHICH COULD NOT BE MET BY MERELY LOCAL ACTION
column5: and which could not be met by merely local action

column4: BUT THE FRAMERS WENT FURTHER
column5: but the framers went further

column4: HAVING IN MIND THAT IN SUCCEEDING GENERATIONS MANY OTHER PROBLEMS THEN UNDREAMED OF WOULD BECOME NATIONAL PROBLEMS
column5: having in mind that in succeeding generations many other problems then undreamed of would become national problems

column4: THEY GAVE TO THE CONGRESS THE AMPLE BROAD POWERS TO LEVY TAXES
column5: they gave to the congress the ample broad powers to levy taxes

column4: AND PROVIDE FOR THE COMMON DEFENSE AND GENERAL WELFARE OF THE UNITED STATES
column5: and provide for the common defense and general welfare of the united states

column4: THAT MY FRIENDS IS WHAT I HONESTLY BELIEVE
column5: that my friends is what i honestly believe

column4: TO HAVE BEEN THE CLEAR AND UNDERLYING PURPOSE OF THE PATRIOTS WHO WROTE A FEDERAL CONSTITUTION TO CREATE A NATIONAL GOVERNMENT
column5: to have been the clear and underlying purpose of the patriots who wrote a federal constitution to create a national government

column4: WITH NATIONAL POWER INTENDED AS THEY SAID TO FORM A MORE PERFECT UNION
column5: with national power intended as they said to form a more perfect union

column4: FOR OURSELVES AND OUR POSTERITY
column5: for ourselves and our posterity

column4: FOR NEARLY TWENTY YEARS THERE WAS NO CONFLICT BETWEEN THE CONGRESS AND THE COURT
column5: for nearly twenty years there was no conflict between the congress and the court

column4: CONGRESS PASSED A STATUTE WHICH IN EIGHTEEN OH THREE THE COURT SAID VIOLATED AN EXPRESS PROVISION OF THE CONSTITUTION
column5: congress passed a statute which in eighteen oh three the court said violated an express provision of the constitution

column4: THE COURT CLAIMED THE POWER TO DECLARE IT UNCONSTITUTIONAL AND DID SO DECLARE IT
column5: the court claimed the power to declare it unconstitutional and did so declare it

column4: BUT A LITTLE LATER THE COURT ITSELF ADMITTED
column5: but a little later the court itself admitted

column4: THAT IT WAS AN EXTRAORDINARY POWER TO EXERCISE AND THROUGH MR JUSTICE WASHINGTON LAID DOWN THIS LIMITATION UPON IT
column5: that it was an extraordinary power to exercise and through mr justice washington laid down this limitation upon it

column4: IT IS BUT A DECENT RESPECT DUE TO THE WISDOM THE INTEGRITY AND THE PATRIOTISM OF THE LEGISLATIVE BODY
column5: it is but a decent respect due to the wisdom the integrity and the patriotism of the legislative body

column4: BY WHICH ANY LAW IS PASSED
column5: by which any law is passed

column4: TO PRESUME IN FAVOR OF ITS VALIDITY UNTIL ITS VIOLATION OF THE CONSTITUTION IS PROVED BEYOND ALL REASONABLE DOUBT
column5: to presume in favor of its validity until its violation of the constitution is proved beyond all reasonable doubt

column4: BUT SINCE THE RISE OF THE MODERN MOVEMENT FOR SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC PROGRESS THROUGH LEGISLATION
column5: but since the rise of the modern movement for social and economic progress through legislation

column4: THE COURT HAS MORE AND MORE OFTEN AND MORE AND MORE BOLDLY
column5: the court has more and more often and more and more boldly

column4: ASSERTED A POWER TO VETO LAWS PASSED BY THE CONGRESS AND STATE LEGISLATURES IN COMPLETE DISREGARD OF THIS ORIGINAL LIMITATION
column5: asserted a power to veto laws passed by the congress and state legislatures in complete disregard of this original limitation

column4: IN THE LAST FOUR YEARS THE SOUND RULE OF GIVING STATUTES THE BENEFIT OF ALL REASONABLE DOUBT HAS BEEN CAST ASIDE
column5: in the last four years the sound rule of giving statutes the benefit of all reasonable doubt has been cast aside

column4: THE COURT HAS BEEN ACTING NOT AS A JUDICIAL BODY BUT AS A POLICYMAKING BODY
column5: the court has been acting not as a judicial body but as a policymaking body

column4: WHEN THE CONGRESS HAS SOUGHT TO STABILIZE NATIONAL AGRICULTURE TO IMPROVE THE CONDITIONS OF LABOR
column5: when the congress has sought to stabilize national agriculture to improve the conditions of labor

column4: TO SAFEGUARD BUSINESS AGAINST UNFAIR COMPETITION
column5: to safeguard business against unfair competition

column4: TO PROTECT OUR NATIONAL RESOURCES AND IN MANY OTHER WAYS TO SERVE OUR CLEARLY NATIONAL NEEDS
column5: to protect our national resources and in many other ways to serve our clearly national needs

column4: THE MAJORITY OF THE COURT HAS BEEN ASSUMING THE POWER TO PASS ON THE WISDOM OF THESE ACTS OF THE CONGRESS
column5: the majority of the court has been assuming the power to pass on the wisdom of these acts of the congress

column4: AND TO APPROVE OR DISAPPROVE THE PUBLIC POLICY WRITTEN INTO THESE LAWS
column5: and to approve or disapprove the public policy written into these laws

column4: THAT IS NOT ONLY MY ACCUSATION
column5: that is not only my accusation

column4: IT IS THE ACCUSATION OF MOST DISTINGUISHED JUSTICES OF THE PRESENT SUPREME COURT
column5: it is the accusation of most distinguished justices of the present supreme court

column4: I HAVE NOT THE TIME TO QUOTE TO YOU ALL THE LANGUAGE USED BY DISSENTING JUSTICES IN MANY OF THESE CASES
column5: i have not the time to quote to you all the language used by dissenting justices in many of these cases

column4: BUT IN THE CASE HOLDING THE RAILROAD RETIREMENT ACT UNCONSTITUTIONAL FOR INSTANCE
column5: but in the case holding the railroad retirement act unconstitutional for instance

column4: CHIEF JUSTICE HUGHES SAID IN A DISSENTING OPINION THAT THE MAJORITY OPINION WAS A DEPARTURE FROM SOUND PRINCIPLES
column5: chief justice hughes said in a dissenting opinion that the majority opinion was a departure from sound principles

column4: AND PLACED AN UNWARRANTED LIMITATION UPON THE COMMERCE CLAUSE
column5: and placed an unwarranted limitation upon the commerce clause

column4: AND THREE OTHER JUSTICES AGREED WITH HIM
column5: and three other justices agreed with him

column4: IN THE CASE OF HOLDING THE AAA UNCONSTITUTIONAL
column5: in the case of holding the aaa unconstitutional

column4: JUSTICE STONE SAID OF THE MAJORITY OPINION THAT IT WAS A TORTURED CONSTRUCTION OF THE CONSTITUTION
column5: justice stone said of the majority opinion that it was a tortured construction of the constitution

column4: AND TWO OTHER JUSTICES AGREED WITH HIM
column5: and two other justices agreed with him

column4: IN THE CASE HOLDING THE NEW YORK MINIMUM WAGE LAW UNCONSTITUTIONAL JUSTICE STONE SAID
column5: in the case holding the new york minimum wage law unconstitutional justice stone said

column4: THAT THE MAJORITY WERE ACTUALLY READING INTO THE CONSTITUTION THEIR OWN PERSONAL ECONOMIC PREDILECTIONS AND THAT
column5: that the majority were actually reading into the constitution their own personal economic predilections and that

column4: IF THE LEGISLATIVE POWER IS NOT LEFT FREE TO CHOOSE THE METHODS OF SOLVING THE PROBLEMS OF POVERTY
column5: if the legislative power is not left free to choose the methods of solving the problems of poverty

column4: SUBSISTENCE AND HEALTH OF LARGE NUMBERS IN THE COMMUNITY THEN
column5: subsistence and health of large numbers in the community then

column4: GOVERNMENT IS TO BE RENDERED IMPOTENT
column5: government is to be rendered impotent

column4: AND TWO OTHER JUSTICES AGREED WITH HIM
column5: and two other justices agreed with him

column4: IN THE FACE OF THESE DISSENTING OPINIONS THERE IS NO BASIS FOR THE CLAIM MADE BY SOME MEMBERS OF THE COURT
column5: in the face of these dissenting opinions there is no basis for the claim made by some members of the court

column4: THAT SOMETHING IN THE CONSTITUTION HAS COMPELLED THEM REGRETFULLY TO THWART THE WILL OF THE PEOPLE
column5: that something in the constitution has compelled them regretfully to thwart the will of the people

column4: IN THE FACE OF SUCH DISSENTING OPINIONS IT IS PERFECTLY CLEAR THAT AS CHIEF JUSTICE HUGHES HAS SAID
column5: in the face of such dissenting opinions it is perfectly clear that as chief justice hughes has said

column4: WE ARE UNDER A CONSTITUTION BUT THE CONSTITUTION IS WHAT THE JUDGES SAY IT IS
column5: we are under a constitution but the constitution is what the judges say it is

column4: THE COURT IN ADDITION TO THE PROPER USE OF ITS JUDICIAL FUNCTIONS HAS IMPROPERLY SET ITSELF UP AS A THIRD HOUSE OF THE CONGRESS
column5: the court in addition to the proper use of its judicial functions has improperly set itself up as a third house of the congress

column4: A SUPERLEGISLATURE AS ONE OF THE JUSTICES HAS CALLED IT
column5: a superlegislature as one of the justices has called it

column4: READING INTO THE CONSTITUTION WORDS AND IMPLICATIONS WHICH ARE NOT THERE AND WHICH WERE NEVER INTENDED TO BE THERE
column5: reading into the constitution words and implications which are not there and which were never intended to be there

column4: WE HAVE THEREFORE
column5: we have therefore

column4: REACHED THE POINT AS A NATION WHERE WE MUST TAKE ACTION TO SAVE THE CONSTITUTION FROM THE COURT AND THE COURT FROM ITSELF
column5: reached the point as a nation where we must take action to save the constitution from the court and the court from itself

column4: WE MUST FIND A WAY TO TAKE AN APPEAL FROM THE SUPREME COURT TO THE CONSTITUTION ITSELF
column5: we must find a way to take an appeal from the supreme court to the constitution itself

column4: WE WANT A SUPREME COURT WHICH WILL DO JUSTICE UNDER THE CONSTITUTION  NOT OVER IT
column5: we want a supreme court which will do justice under the constitution  not over it

column4: IN OUR COURTS WE WANT A GOVERNMENT OF LAWS AND NOT OF MEN
column5: in our courts we want a government of laws and not of men

column4: I WANT  AS ALL AMERICANS WANT  AN INDEPENDENT JUDICIARY AS PROPOSED BY THE FRAMERS OF THE CONSTITUTION
column5: i want  as all americans want  an independent judiciary as proposed by the framers of the constitution

column4: THAT MEANS A SUPREME COURT THAT WILL ENFORCE THE CONSTITUTION AS WRITTEN
column5: that means a supreme court that will enforce the constitution as written

column4: THAT WILL REFUSE TO AMEND THE CONSTITUTION BY THE ARBITRARY EXERCISE OF JUDICIAL POWER  AMENDED BY JUDICIAL SAYSO
column5: that will refuse to amend the constitution by the arbitrary exercise of judicial power  amended by judicial sayso

column4: IT DOES NOT MEAN A JUDICIARY SO INDEPENDENT THAT IT CAN DENY THE EXISTENCE OF FACTS WHICH ARE UNIVERSALLY RECOGNIZED
column5: it does not mean a judiciary so independent that it can deny the existence of facts which are universally recognized

column4: HOW THEN COULD WE PROCEED TO PERFORM THE MANDATE GIVEN US
column5: how then could we proceed to perform the mandate given us

column4: IT WAS SAID IN LAST YEAR'S DEMOCRATIC PLATFORM
column5: it was said in last year's democratic platform

column4: IF THESE PROBLEMS CANNOT BE EFFECTIVELY SOLVED WITHIN THE CONSTITUTION
column5: if these problems cannot be effectively solved within the constitution

column4: WE SHALL SEEK SUCH CLARIFYING AMENDMENT AS WILL ASSURE THE POWER TO ENACT THOSE LAWS
column5: we shall seek such clarifying amendment as will assure the power to enact those laws

column4: ADEQUATELY TO REGULATE COMMERCE PROTECT PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY AND SAFEGUARD ECONOMIC SECURITY
column5: adequately to regulate commerce protect public health and safety and safeguard economic security

column4: IN OTHER WORDS WE SAID WE WOULD SEEK AN AMENDMENT ONLY IF EVERY OTHER POSSIBLE MEANS BY LEGISLATION WERE TO FAIL
column5: in other words we said we would seek an amendment only if every other possible means by legislation were to fail

column4: WHEN I COMMENCED TO REVIEW THE SITUATION WITH THE PROBLEM SQUARELY BEFORE ME
column5: when i commenced to review the situation with the problem squarely before me

column4: I CAME BY A PROCESS OF ELIMINATION TO THE CONCLUSION THAT SHORT OF AMENDMENTS
column5: i came by a process of elimination to the conclusion that short of amendments

column4: THE ONLY METHOD WHICH WAS CLEARLY CONSTITUTIONAL AND WOULD AT THE SAME TIME CARRY OUT OTHER MUCH NEEDED REFORMS
column5: the only method which was clearly constitutional and would at the same time carry out other much needed reforms

column4: WAS TO INFUSE NEW BLOOD INTO ALL OUR COURTS
column5: was to infuse new blood into all our courts

column4: WE MUST HAVE MEN WORTHY AND EQUIPPED TO CARRY OUT IMPARTIAL JUSTICE
column5: we must have men worthy and equipped to carry out impartial justice

column4: BUT AT THE SAME TIME WE MUST HAVE JUDGES WHO WILL BRING TO THE COURTS A PRESENTDAY SENSE OF THE CONSTITUTION
column5: but at the same time we must have judges who will bring to the courts a presentday sense of the constitution

column4: JUDGES WHO WILL RETAIN IN THE COURTS THE JUDICIAL FUNCTIONS OF A COURT
column5: judges who will retain in the courts the judicial functions of a court

column4: AND REJECT THE LEGISLATIVE POWERS WHICH THE COURTS HAVE TODAY ASSUMED
column5: and reject the legislative powers which the courts have today assumed

column4: IN FORTYFIVE OUT OF THE FORTYEIGHT STATES OF THE UNION JUDGES ARE CHOSEN NOT FOR LIFE BUT FOR A PERIOD OF YEARS
column5: in fortyfive out of the fortyeight states of the union judges are chosen not for life but for a period of years

column4: IN MANY STATES JUDGES MUST RETIRE AT THE AGE OF SEVENTY
column5: in many states judges must retire at the age of seventy

column4: CONGRESS HAS PROVIDED FINANCIAL SECURITY
column5: congress has provided financial security

column4: BY OFFERING LIFE PENSIONS AT FULL PAY FOR FEDERAL JUDGES ON ALL COURTS WHO ARE WILLING TO RETIRE AT SEVENTY
column5: by offering life pensions at full pay for federal judges on all courts who are willing to retire at seventy

column4: IN THE CASE OF SUPREME COURT JUSTICES THAT PENSION IS TWENTY THOUSAND DOLLARS A YEAR
column5: in the case of supreme court justices that pension is twenty thousand dollars a year

column4: BUT ALL FEDERAL JUDGES ONCE APPOINTED
column5: but all federal judges once appointed

column4: CAN IF THEY CHOOSE HOLD OFFICE FOR LIFE NO MATTER HOW OLD THEY MAY GET TO BE
column5: can if they choose hold office for life no matter how old they may get to be

column4: THE FIRESIDE CHATS OF FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT BY FRANKLIN D ROOSEVELT
column5: the fireside chats of franklin delano roosevelt by franklin d roosevelt

column4: SECTION TEN MARCH NINE NINETEEN THIRTYSEVEN PART TWO
column5: section ten march nine nineteen thirtyseven part two

column4: WHAT IS MY PROPOSAL
column5: what is my proposal

column4: IT IS SIMPLY THIS WHENEVER A JUDGE OR JUSTICE OF ANY FEDERAL COURT
column5: it is simply this whenever a judge or justice of any federal court

column4: HAS REACHED THE AGE OF SEVENTY AND DOES NOT AVAIL HIMSELF OF THE OPPORTUNITY TO RETIRE ON A PENSION
column5: has reached the age of seventy and does not avail himself of the opportunity to retire on a pension

column4: A NEW MEMBER SHALL BE APPOINTED BY THE PRESIDENT THEN IN OFFICE
column5: a new member shall be appointed by the president then in office

column4: WITH THE APPROVAL AS REQUIRED BY THE CONSTITUTION OF THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES
column5: with the approval as required by the constitution of the senate of the united states

column4: THAT PLAN HAS TWO CHIEF PURPOSES
column5: that plan has two chief purposes

column4: BY BRINGING INTO THE JUDICIAL SYSTEM A STEADY AND CONTINUING STREAM OF NEW AND YOUNGER BLOOD I HOPE FIRST
column5: by bringing into the judicial system a steady and continuing stream of new and younger blood i hope first

column4: TO MAKE THE ADMINISTRATION OF ALL FEDERAL JUSTICE SPEEDIER AND THEREFORE LESS COSTLY
column5: to make the administration of all federal justice speedier and therefore less costly

column4: SECONDLY TO BRING TO THE DECISION OF SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC PROBLEMS YOUNGER MEN WHO HAVE HAD PERSONAL EXPERIENCE AND CONTACT
column5: secondly to bring to the decision of social and economic problems younger men who have had personal experience and contact

column4: WITH MODERN FACTS AND CIRCUMSTANCES UNDER WHICH AVERAGE MEN HAVE TO LIVE AND WORK
column5: with modern facts and circumstances under which average men have to live and work

column4: THIS PLAN WILL SAVE OUR NATIONAL CONSTITUTION FROM HARDENING OF THE JUDICIAL ARTERIES
column5: this plan will save our national constitution from hardening of the judicial arteries

column4: THE NUMBER OF JUDGES TO BE APPOINTED WOULD DEPEND WHOLLY ON THE DECISION OF PRESENT JUDGES NOW OVER SEVENTY

column4: ARE DIRECTLY OXIDIZED TO EXCRETIONS AND LACKING NITROGEN CANNOT SERVE FOR MAKING NEW ANIMAL PROTOPLASM
column5: are directly oxidized to excretions and lacking nitrogen cannot serve for making new animal protoplasm

column4: FAT AND CARBOHYDRATE FOODS THEN NEVER BECOME LIVING MATTER
column5: fat and carbohydrate foods then never become living matter

column4: THEY MAY BE STORED ESPECIALLY AS FAT UNTIL NEEDED FOR OXIDATION TO SUPPLY ENERGY
column5: they may be stored especially as fat until needed for oxidation to supply energy

column4: THE BUILDING UP OF THE PROTOPLASM FROM PROTEIDS IS ANABOLISM CONSTRUCTIVE METABOLISM
column5: the building up of the protoplasm from proteids is anabolism constructive metabolism

column4: THE DESTRUCTION OF PROTOPLASM EXCESS PROTEIDS OR THE FAT AND CARBOHYDRATE FOODS IS CATABOLISM DESTRUCTIVE METABOLISM
column5: the destruction of protoplasm excess proteids or the fat and carbohydrate foods is catabolism destructive metabolism

column4: CATABOLISM IS PROBABLY DUE TO ENZYME ACTION BUT THE FINAL RESULT IS CHIEFLY CARBON DIOXIDE AND WATER
column5: catabolism is probably due to enzyme action but the final result is chiefly carbon dioxide and water

column4: WHICH COULD BE DERIVED BY THE ORDINARY CHEMICAL EVOLUTION OF PROTOPLASM PROTEID SUGAR STARCH OR FATS
column5: which could be derived by the ordinary chemical evolution of protoplasm proteid sugar starch or fats

column4: IN THE PLANT STARCH AS HAS BEEN SEEN IS FIRST FORMED IN THE CHLOROPHYLLBODIES
column5: in the plant starch as has been seen is first formed in the chlorophyllbodies

column4: BUT THE FORMATION OF STARCH ALL IMPORTANT AS IT IS IS AFTER ALL ONLY THE MANUFACTURE OF FOOD
column5: but the formation of starch all important as it is is after all only the manufacture of food

column4: AS A PRELIMINARY TO THE REAL PROCESSES OF NUTRITION
column5: as a preliminary to the real processes of nutrition

column4: THESE PROCESSES MUST TAKE PLACE EVERYWHERE IN ORDINARY PROTOPLASM
column5: these processes must take place everywhere in ordinary protoplasm

column4: FOR IT IS HERE THAT OXIDATION OCCURS AND THE NEED FOR A RENEWAL OF MATTER AND ENERGY CONSEQUENTLY ARISES
column5: for it is here that oxidation occurs and the need for a renewal of matter and energy consequently arises

column4: SOONER OR LATER THE STARCH GRAINS ARE CHANGED INTO A KIND OF SUGAR GLUCOSE WHICH UNLIKE STARCH DISSOLVES IN THE SAP
column5: sooner or later the starch grains are changed into a kind of sugar glucose which unlike starch dissolves in the sap

column4: AND MAY THUS BE EASILY TRANSPORTED TO ALL PARTS OF THE PLANT
column5: and may thus be easily transported to all parts of the plant

column4: WHEREVER THERE IS NEED FOR NEW PROTOPLASM WHETHER TO REPAIR PREVIOUS WASTE OR TO SUPPLY MATERIALS FOR GROWTH
column5: wherever there is need for new protoplasm whether to repair previous waste or to supply materials for growth

column4: AFTER ABSORPTION INTO THE CELLS THE ELEMENTS OF THE STARCH OR GLUCOSE ARE BY THE LIVING PROTOPLASM IN SOME UNKNOWN WAY
column5: after absorption into the cells the elements of the starch or glucose are by the living protoplasm in some unknown way

column4: COMBINED WITH NITROGEN AND SULPHUR PROBABLY ALSO WITH SALTS WATER ETC TO FORM PROTEID MATTER
column5: combined with nitrogen and sulphur probably also with salts water etc to form proteid matter

column4: THE PARTICLES OF THIS NEWLY FORMED COMPOUND ARE INCORPORATED INTO THE PROTOPLASM
column5: the particles of this newly formed compound are incorporated into the protoplasm

column4: IF A LARGER QUANTITY OF STARCH IS FORMED IN THE CHLOROPHYLL BODIES THAN IS IMMEDIATELY NEEDED BY THE PROTOPLASM FOR PURPOSES OF REPAIR OR GROWTH
column5: if a larger quantity of starch is formed in the chlorophyll bodies than is immediately needed by the protoplasm for purposes of repair or growth

column4: IT MAY BE RECONVERTED INTO STARCH AFTER JOURNEYING AS GLUCOSE THROUGH THE PLANT
column5: it may be reconverted into starch after journeying as glucose through the plant

column4: AND BE LAID DOWN AS RESERVE STARCH IN THE CELLS OF ROOT OR STEM OR ELSEWHERE
column5: and be laid down as reserve starch in the cells of root or stem or elsewhere

column4: APPARENTLY WHEN THIS RESERVE SUPPLY IS FINALLY NEEDED AT ANY POINT IN THE PLANT IT IS AGAIN CHANGED TO GLUCOSE AND TRANSPORTED THITHER
column5: apparently when this reserve supply is finally needed at any point in the plant it is again changed to glucose and transported thither

column4: IT IS PROBABLE THAT NEW LEAVES AND NEW TISSUES GENERALLY ARE ALWAYS FORMED IN PART FROM THIS RESERVE STARCH
column5: it is probable that new leaves and new tissues generally are always formed in part from this reserve starch

column4: IN THE PLANT AS IN THE ANIMAL METABOLISM MUST CONSIST OF ANABOLIC AND CATABOLIC PROCESSES
column5: in the plant as in the animal metabolism must consist of anabolic and catabolic processes

column4: THE CONSTRUCTION IN THE CELLS OF NEW PROTEID FROM THE ABSORBED CARBOHYDRATE AND THE MATERIALS FROM THE SOIL IS TRUE ANABOLISM
column5: the construction in the cells of new proteid from the absorbed carbohydrate and the materials from the soil is true anabolism

column4: IT IS ALSO CLEAR THAT CATABOLISM OR OXIDATION FOR THE LIBERATION OF ENERGY OCCURS AS IN ANIMALS BUT THIS PROCESS IS SLOWER
column5: it is also clear that catabolism or oxidation for the liberation of energy occurs as in animals but this process is slower

column4: PROBABLY FOODS CONTAINING CARBON HYDROGEN AND OXYGEN ARE THE SOURCES OF ENERGY IN THE HIGHER PLANTS AS IN ANIMALS
column5: probably foods containing carbon hydrogen and oxygen are the sources of energy in the higher plants as in animals

column4: IN BOTH PLANTS AND ANIMALS SIMPLE WASTE SUBSTANCES RESULT FROM THE CATABOLIC PROCESSES IN THE CELLS
column5: in both plants and animals simple waste substances result from the catabolic processes in the cells

column4: IN THE ANIMAL CARBON DIOXIDE WATER AND NITROGEN COMPOUNDS ARE THE CHIEF EXCRETIONS
column5: in the animal carbon dioxide water and nitrogen compounds are the chief excretions

column4: THEY ARE ABSORBED BY THE CIRCULATING LIQUIDS AND CARRIED TO THE ELIMINATING ORGANS LUNGS AND KIDNEYS CHIEFLY FOR ELIMINATION
column5: they are absorbed by the circulating liquids and carried to the eliminating organs lungs and kidneys chiefly for elimination

column4: IN THE HIGHER PLANTS THE EXCRETIONS ARE CARBON DIOXIDE WHICH ESCAPES THROUGH THE EPIDERMIS OF ROOT STEM AND LEAF AND THROUGH THE STOMATA
column5: in the higher plants the excretions are carbon dioxide which escapes through the epidermis of root stem and leaf and through the stomata

column4: WATER WHICH IS LOST BY EVAPORATION ESPECIALLY FROM THE LEAF SURFACE THROUGH THE STOMATA
column5: water which is lost by evaporation especially from the leaf surface through the stomata

column4: EXCRETIONS WHICH ARE LOST BY OSMOSIS THROUGH THE ROOTS AND THE ACCUMULATED BUT USELESS MINERAL SUBSTANCES WHICH ARE ELIMINATED BY LEAF FALL
column5: excretions which are lost by osmosis through the roots and the accumulated but useless mineral substances which are eliminated by leaf fall

column4: IN BOTH ANIMALS AND PLANTS OXYGEN IS ESSENTIAL TO THE CATABOLIC PART OF METABOLISM
column5: in both animals and plants oxygen is essential to the catabolic part of metabolism

column4: HENCE OXYGEN MUST BE SUPPLIED TO THE CELLS
column5: hence oxygen must be supplied to the cells

column4: OXYGENATION IS THE TERM USED TO DENOTE THE OXYGENSUPPLYING PART OF RESPIRATION
column5: oxygenation is the term used to denote the oxygensupplying part of respiration

column4: THE OTHER PART OF RESPIRATION ELIMINATION OF CARBON DIOXIDE HAS BEEN TREATED UNDER EXCRETIONS
column5: the other part of respiration elimination of carbon dioxide has been treated under excretions

column4: IN THE ANIMAL OXYGEN IS ABSORBED BY THE BLOOD IN EXCESS BY THE HEMOGLOBIN OF THE RED CELLS OF THE BLOOD
column5: in the animal oxygen is absorbed by the blood in excess by the hemoglobin of the red cells of the blood

column4: AND LATER IS ABSORBED FROM THE BLOOD AND LYMPH BY ALL THE LIVING CELLS
column5: and later is absorbed from the blood and lymph by all the living cells

column4: IN THE PLANT ALSO OXYGEN IS ABSORBED THROUGH THE EPIDERMIS AND STOMATA FROM THE AIR
column5: in the plant also oxygen is absorbed through the epidermis and stomata from the air

column4: THIS PROCESS IS HOWEVER OBSCURED DURING THE DAY BECAUSE OF THE OXYGEN FREED IN THE MANUFACTURE OF STARCH WHICH GOES ON AT THAT TIME
column5: this process is however obscured during the day because of the oxygen freed in the manufacture of starch which goes on at that time

column4: PROBABLY THIS FREED OXYGEN IS USED FOR THE PURPOSE OF OXYGENATION BUT MORE IS FREED IN THE PHOTOSYNTHETIC PROCESS THAN IS NEEDED FOR OXYGENATION
column5: probably this freed oxygen is used for the purpose of oxygenation but more is freed in the photosynthetic process than is needed for oxygenation

column4: AND HENCE THE EXCESS OXYGEN IS ELIMINATED WHILE STARCH MANUFACTURE IS IN PROCESS
column5: and hence the excess oxygen is eliminated while starch manufacture is in process

column4: IN COMPARING A HIGHER ANIMAL AND A GREEN PLANT CONFUSION MUST BE AVOIDED REGARDING THE PART PLAYED BY OXYGEN AND CARBON DIOXIDE IN TRUE RESPIRATION
column5: in comparing a higher animal and a green plant confusion must be avoided regarding the part played by oxygen and carbon dioxide in true respiration

column4: WITH THE PART PLAYED BY THE SAME SUBSTANCES IN STARCH FORMATION PHOTOSYNTHESIS
column5: with the part played by the same substances in starch formation photosynthesis

column4: IN NONGREEN PLANTS LIKE THE INDIAN PIPE AND MUSHROOMS THE BREATHING OF OXYGEN AND THE EXCRETION OF CARBON DIOXIDE ARE AS IN THE ANIMAL
column5: in nongreen plants like the indian pipe and mushrooms the breathing of oxygen and the excretion of carbon dioxide are as in the animal

column4: THIS IS TRUE ALSO OF GREEN PLANTS IN DARKNESS AND EVEN IN THE LIGHT OF ALL PARTS OF GREEN PLANTS EXCEPT THE CHLOROPHYLLBODIES
column5: this is true also of green plants in darkness and even in the light of all parts of green plants except the chlorophyllbodies

column4: THESE CONSTITUTE A SORT OF EXTRA MECHANISM ENABLING GREEN PLANTS TO MAKE THEIR OWN CARBOHYDRATE FOOD
column5: these constitute a sort of extra mechanism enabling green plants to make their own carbohydrate food

column4: IMAGINE A HIGHER ANIMAL WITH AN ATTACHMENT FOR TURNING THE CARBON DIOXIDE AND WATER EXCRETED
column5: imagine a higher animal with an attachment for turning the carbon dioxide and water excreted

column4: BACK TO STARCH USABLE AS FOOD AND THE COMPARISON OF THE GREEN PLANT AND THE ANIMAL WOULD BE COMPLETE

column5: the facts of biology which admit of adequate explanation only in connection with the theory of descent

column5: there are numberless similarities and correlations and surprising uniformities

column5: the great variety of life as exhibited in the countless species of plants and animals has been referred to and yet great as this variety is

column5: there are after all only a few types of structure among all animals and plants some three or four or eight or ten general modes of development

column4: IT IS MOREOVER TRUE THAT ALL LIVING FORMS ARE BUT SERIES OF MODIFICATIONS AND EXTENSIONS OF ONE SINGLE PLAN OF STRUCTURE
column5: it is moreover true that all living forms are but series of modifications and extensions of one single plan of structure

column4: ALL HAVE THE SAME ULTIMATE SUBSTANCE
column5: all have the same ultimate substance

column5: the mysterious semifluid network of protoplasm which is so far as is known the physical basis of all life

column5: and the equally mysterious nuclear substance or chromatin

column4: WHICH IN SOME FASHION PRESIDES OVER ALL THE MOVEMENTS OF THE PROTOPLASM AND IS THE PHYSICAL BASIS OF THE PHENOMENA OF HEREDITY

column4: ALL ORGANISMS HAVE THE SAME NEED OF REPRODUCTION

column5: all are forced to make concession after concession to their surroundings and in these concessions all progress in life consists

column4: AND AT LAST EACH ORGANISM OR EACH ALLIANCE OF ORGANISMS MUST COME TO THE GREATEST CONCESSION OF ALL WHICH IS CALLED DEATH
column5: and at last each organism or each alliance of organisms must come to the greatest concession of all which is called death

column5: the unity in life then is not less a fact than is life's great diversity

column5: is the theory of descent  ie that similarities are due to blood relationship and that differences come from adaptive modifications

column5: first it must be noted that some structures are not nonadaptive that is do not change to fit changed habits or conditions of life

column5: such structures or organs are most often found internally

column4: BUT NOT IN ANY STRIKING WAY IS THERE CHANGE IN THE INTERNAL ORGANS
column5: but not in any striking way is there change in the internal organs

column5: internal organs may persist unchanged and hence they offer good guides to classification

column5: on the other hand external structures are likely to undergo adaptation when habits or conditions of life change

column5: hence as jordan has said the inside of an animal tells the real history of its ancestry the outside tells us only where its ancestors have been

column5: between the fin of a fish and the paddle of a whale

column4: BOTH ADAPTIVE SWIMMING ORGANS YET THE RESEMBLANCE IN THESE CASES DOES NOT GO DEEPER THAN THE SURFACE  IT IS ONE OF FUNCTION ONLY

column5: all such cases of resemblance in function but not in detailed plan of structure are called analogies

column5: and mean nothing more than similarity of environment

column5: careful study shows detailed internal as well as external similarities of structure such cases are homologies

column5: these principles of homology are essential to a correct interpretation of the facts of morphology

column5: since backboned animals are best known to most readers they may be taken as an illustration

column5: these therefore may well be called backboned animals

column5: for upon a barrelshaped cylinder of clay bearing a long inscription we have cyrus's account of his capture of babylon extracts from it are as follows

column5: marduk the great lord looking with joy on his pious works and upright heart

column5: commanded him cyrus to go forth to his city babylon and he went by his side as a friend and companion

column4: HIS MANY TROOPS WHOSE NUMBER LIKE THE WATERS OF THE RIVER COULD NOT BE COUNTED MARCHED IN FULL ARMOR AT HIS SIDE
column5: his many troops whose number like the waters of the river could not be counted marched in full armor at his side

column5: without a skirmish or a battle he permitted them to enter babylon and sparing the city he delivered the king nabonidus to him

column5: he certainly mentions details which neither nabonidus nor cyrus would care to have appear in their royal records his story is as follows

column5: the babylonians encamped without their walls awaited his coming

column5: whereupon they withdrew within their defenses

column5: here they shut themselves up and made light of his siege having laid in a store of provision for many years in preparation against this attack

column5: for when they saw cyrus conquering nation after nation they were convinced that he would never stop and their turn would come at last

column5: cyrus was now reduced to great perplexity as time went on and he made no progress against the place

column4: IN THIS DISTRESS EITHER SOMEONE MADE THIS SUGGESTION TO HIM OR HE BETHOUGHT HIMSELF OF A PLAN WHICH HE PROCEEDED TO PUT IN EXECUTION
column5: in this distress either someone made this suggestion to him or he bethought himself of a plan which he proceeded to put in execution

column5: on which the river sank to such an extent that the natural bed of the stream became fordable

column5: but as it was the persians came upon them by surprise and so took the city

column5: owing to the vast size of the place the inhabitants of the central parts as the residents of babylon declare

column5: only the king's son belshazzar was killed

column5: the people enjoying the greater freedom which cyrus permitted them were contented and life in babylon went on about as before

column5: then the babylonians secretly plotted to throw off the persian yoke

column5: that same year when darius hystaspes came to the persian throne the babylonians openly rebelled

column5: the following story from herodotus tells the results

column5: at last when the time came for rebelling openly they did as follows

column5: having first set apart their mothers each man chose besides out of his whole household one woman whomsoever he pleased

column5: these alone were allowed to live while all the rest were brought to one place and strangled

column5: when tidings reached darius of what had happened

column5: he drew together all his power and began the war by marching straight upon babylon and laying siege to the place

column5: mounting upon the battlements that crowned their walls they insulted and jeered at darius and his mighty host

column5: one even shouted to them and said why sit ye there persians why do ye not go back to your homes till mules foal ye will not take our city

column5: this was said by a babylonian who thought that a mule would never foal

column5: now when a year and seven months had passed darius and his army were quite wearied out finding that they could not anyhow take the city

column5: all stratagems and all arts had been used and yet the king could not prevail

column5: at last in the twentieth month

column5: one of his sumptermules gave birth to a foal

column5: zopyrus when they told him not thinking that it could be true went and saw the colt with his own eyes

column5: after which he commanded his servants to tell no one what had come to pass while he himself pondered the matter

column5: calling to mind then the words of the babylonian at the beginning of the siege

column5: till mules foal ye shall not take our city he thought as he reflected on this speech that babylon might now be taken

column4: FOR IT SEEMED TO HIM THAT THERE WAS A DIVINE PROVIDENCE IN THE MAN HAVING USED THE PHRASE AND THEN HIS MULE HAVING FOALED
column5: for it seemed to him that there was a divine providence in the man having used the phrase and then his mule having foaled

column5: as soon therefore as he felt within himself that babylon was fated to be taken he went to darius and asked him if he set a very high value on its conquest

column5: when he found that darius did indeed value it highly he considered further with himself how he might make the deed his own and be the man to take babylon

column4: NOBLE EXPLOITS IN PERSIA ARE EVER HIGHLY HONORED AND BRING THEIR AUTHORS TO GREATNESS
column5: noble exploits in persia are ever highly honored and bring their authors to greatness

column5: he therefore reviewed all ways of bringing the city under

column5: but found none by which he could hope to prevail unless he maimed himself and then went over to the enemy

column5: to do this seeming to him a light matter he mutilated himself in a way that was utterly without remedy

column5: for he cut off his own nose and ears and then clipping his hair close and flogging himself with a scourge

column4: HE CAME IN THIS PLIGHT BEFORE DARIUS
column5: he came in this plight before darius

column5: wrath stirred within the king at the sight of a man of his lofty rank in such a condition

column5: leaping down from his throne he exclaimed aloud and asked zopyrus who it was that had disfigured him and what he had done to be so treated

column5: zopyrus answered there is not a man in the world but thou o king that could reduce me to such a plight

column4: NO STRANGER'S HANDS HAVE WROUGHT THIS WORK ON ME BUT MY OWN ONLY
column5: no stranger's hands have wrought this work on me but my own only

column5: i maimed myself because i could not endure that the assyrians should laugh at the persians wretched man said darius

column4: THOU COVEREST THE FOULEST DEEDS WITH THE FAIREST POSSIBLE NAME WHEN THOU SAYEST THY MAIMING IS TO HELP OUR SIEGE FORWARD
column5: thou coverest the foulest deeds with the fairest possible name when thou sayest thy maiming is to help our siege forward
