column5: how will thy disfigurement thou simpleton induce the enemy to yield one day sooner

column4: SURELY THOU HADST GONE OUT OF THY MIND WHEN THOU DIDST SO MISUSE THYSELF
column5: surely thou hadst gone out of thy mind when thou didst so misuse thyself

column4: HAD I TOLD THEE REJOINED THE OTHER WHAT I WAS BENT ON DOING THOU WOULDST NOT HAVE SUFFERED IT
column5: had i told thee rejoined the other what i was bent on doing thou wouldst not have suffered it

column4: AS IT IS I KEPT MY OWN COUNSEL AND SO ACCOMPLISHED MY PLANS
column5: as it is i kept my own counsel and so accomplished my plans

column4: NOW THEREFORE IF THERE BE NO FAILURE ON THY PART WE SHALL TAKE BABYLON
column5: now therefore if there be no failure on thy part we shall take babylon

column5: i will desert to the enemy as i am and when i get into their city i will tell them that it is by thee that i have been thus treated

column4: I THINK THEY WILL BELIEVE MY WORDS AND ENTRUST ME WITH A COMMAND OF TROOPS THOU ON THY PART MUST WAIT
column5: i think they will believe my words and entrust me with a command of troops thou on thy part must wait

column4: TILL THE TENTH DAY AFTER I AM ENTERED WITHIN THE TOWN AND THEN PLACE NEAR TO THE GATES OF SEMIRAMIS A DETACHMENT OF THY ARMY
column5: till the tenth day after i am entered within the town and then place near to the gates of semiramis a detachment of thy army

column4: TROOPS FOR WHOSE LOSS THOU WILT CARE LITTLE A THOUSAND MEN
column5: troops for whose loss thou wilt care little a thousand men

column4: WAIT AFTER THAT SEVEN DAYS AND POST ME ANOTHER DETACHMENT TWO THOUSAND STRONG AT THE NINEVEH GATES
column5: wait after that seven days and post me another detachment two thousand strong at the nineveh gates

column4: THEN LET TWENTY DAYS PASS AND AT THE END OF THAT TIME STATION NEAR THE CHALDASAN GATES A BODY OF FOUR THOUSAND

column5: let neither these nor the former troops be armed with any weapons but their swords those thou mayest leave them

column4: ONE AT THE BELIAN THE OTHER AT THE CISSIAN GATES FOR I EXPECT THAT ON ACCOUNT OF MY SUCCESSES

column5: having left these instructions zopyrus fled towards the gates of the town often looking back to give himself the air of a deserter

column5: he replied that he was zopyrus and deserted to them from the persians

column5: introduced into their assembly he began to bewail his misfortunes telling them that

column5: the babylonians seeing a persian of such exalted rank in so grievous a plight his nose and ears cut off

column5: the first physician to see the president at parkland hospital was dr charles j carrico a resident in general surgery

column5: approximately two minutes later dr carrico saw the president on his back being wheeled into the emergency area

column4: HE NOTED THAT THE PRESIDENT WAS BLUEWHITE OR ASHEN IN COLOR HAD SLOW SPASMODIC AGONAL RESPIRATION WITHOUT ANY COORDINATION
column5: he noted that the president was bluewhite or ashen in color had slow spasmodic agonal respiration without any coordination

column4: MADE NO VOLUNTARY MOVEMENTS HAD HIS EYES OPEN WITH THE PUPILS DILATED WITHOUT ANY REACTION TO LIGHT
column5: made no voluntary movements had his eyes open with the pupils dilated without any reaction to light

column4: EVIDENCED NO PALPABLE PULSE AND HAD A FEW CHEST SOUNDS WHICH WERE THOUGHT TO BE HEARTBEATS
column5: evidenced no palpable pulse and had a few chest sounds which were thought to be heartbeats

column4: ON THE BASIS OF THESE FINDINGS DR CARRICO CONCLUDED THAT PRESIDENT KENNEDY WAS STILL ALIVE

column5: dr carrico noted two wounds a small bullet wound in the front lower neck

column4: AND AN EXTENSIVE WOUND IN THE PRESIDENT'S HEAD WHERE A SIZABLE PORTION OF THE SKULL WAS MISSING
column5: and an extensive wound in the president's head where a sizable portion of the skull was missing

column4: HE OBSERVED SHREDDED BRAIN TISSUE AND QUOTE CONSIDERABLE SLOW OOZING END QUOTE FROM THE LATTER WOUND

column4: FOLLOWED BY QUOTE MORE PROFUSE BLEEDING END QUOTE AFTER SOME CIRCULATION WAS ESTABLISHED
column5: followed by quote more profuse bleeding end quote after some circulation was established

column5: observing the serious problems presented by the head wound and inadequate respiration dr carrico directed his attention to improving the president's breathing

column4: AND ALSO RAGGED TISSUE WHICH INDICATED A TRACHEAL INJURY
column5: and also ragged tissue which indicated a tracheal injury

column5: dr carrico treated the president's known adrenal insufficiency by administering hydrocortisone

column5: he made the official determination because the ultimate cause of death the severe head injury was within his sphere of specialization

column5: the time was fixed at one pm as an approximation since it was impossible to determine the precise moment when life left the president

column5: when asked why he did not turn the president over dr carrico testified as follows

column4: THIS MAN WAS IN OBVIOUS EXTREME DISTRESS AND ANY MORE THOROUGH INSPECTION WOULD HAVE INVOLVED SEVERAL MINUTES  WELL SEVERAL
column5: this man was in obvious extreme distress and any more thorough inspection would have involved several minutes  well several

column4: CONSIDERABLE TIME WHICH AT THIS JUNCTURE WAS NOT AVAILABLE
column5: considerable time which at this juncture was not available

column4: A THOROUGH INSPECTION WOULD HAVE INVOLVED WASHING AND CLEANSING THE BACK AND THIS IS NOT PRACTICAL IN TREATING AN ACUTELY INJURED PATIENT
column5: a thorough inspection would have involved washing and cleansing the back and this is not practical in treating an acutely injured patient

column4: YOU HAVE TO DETERMINE WHICH THINGS WHICH ARE IMMEDIATELY LIFE THREATENING AND COPE WITH THEM BEFORE ATTEMPTING TO EVALUATE THE FULL EXTENT OF THE INJURIES
column5: you have to determine which things which are immediately life threatening and cope with them before attempting to evaluate the full extent of the injuries

column4: DID YOU EVER HAVE OCCASION TO LOOK AT THE PRESIDENT'S BACK
column5: did you ever have occasion to look at the president's back

column4: ANSWER NO SIR BEFORE  WELL IN TRYING TO TREAT AN ACUTELY INJURED PATIENT YOU HAVE TO ESTABLISH AN AIRWAY ADEQUATE VENTILATION
column5: answer no sir before  well in trying to treat an acutely injured patient you have to establish an airway adequate ventilation

column4: AND YOU HAVE TO ESTABLISH ADEQUATE CIRCULATION
column5: and you have to establish adequate circulation

column4: BEFORE THIS WAS ACCOMPLISHED THE PRESIDENT'S CARDIAC ACTIVITY HAD CEASED AND CLOSED CARDIAC MASSAGE WAS INSTITUTED WHICH MADE IT IMPOSSIBLE TO INSPECT HIS BACK
column5: before this was accomplished the president's cardiac activity had ceased and closed cardiac massage was instituted which made it impossible to inspect his back

column4: QUESTION WAS ANY EFFORT MADE TO INSPECT THE PRESIDENT'S BACK AFTER HE HAD EXPIRED ANSWER NO SIR

column4: QUESTION AND WHY WAS NO EFFORT MADE AT THAT TIME TO INSPECT HIS BACK ANSWER

column4: I SUPPOSE NOBODY REALLY HAD THE HEART TO DO IT

column5: were clean they had good color to them there was no grease on them and they were not fragmented they looked as if they had just been picked up end quote

column5: in an apparent effort to determine by means of a scientific test whether oswald had recently fired a weapon

column4: THE RESULTS WERE POSITIVE FOR THE HANDS AND NEGATIVE FOR THE RIGHT CHEEK
column5: the results were positive for the hands and negative for the right cheek

column4: EXPERT TESTIMONY BEFORE THE COMMISSION

column4: WAS TO THE EFFECT THAT THE PARAFFIN TEST WAS UNRELIABLE IN DETERMINING WHETHER OR NOT A PERSON HAS FIRED A RIFLE OR REVOLVER

column5: the commission has therefore placed no reliance on the paraffin tests administered by the dallas police

column5: he does not appear to have been able to establish meaningful relationships with other people he was perpetually discontented with the world around him

column4: IS TO COLLECT PROCESS AND EVALUATE INFORMATION ABOUT PERSONS OR GROUPS WHO MAY BE A DANGER TO THE PRESIDENT
column5: is to collect process and evaluate information about persons or groups who may be a danger to the president

column4: IN ADDITION TO THIS FUNCTION PRS IS RESPONSIBLE FOR SUCH TASKS
column5: in addition to this function prs is responsible for such tasks

column4: AS OBTAINING CLEARANCE OF SOME CATEGORIES OF WHITE HOUSE EMPLOYEES AND ALL TRADESMEN WHO SERVICE THE WHITE HOUSE
column5: as obtaining clearance of some categories of white house employees and all tradesmen who service the white house

column4: THE SECURITY PROCESSING OF GIFTS SENT TO THE PRESIDENT AND TECHNICAL INSPECTIONS AGAINST COVERT LISTENING DEVICES
column5: the security processing of gifts sent to the president and technical inspections against covert listening devices

column4: AT THE TIME OF THE ASSASSINATION PRS WAS A VERY SMALL GROUP COMPRISED OF TWELVE SPECIALISTS AND THREE CLERKS
column5: at the time of the assassination prs was a very small group comprised of twelve specialists and three clerks

column4: MANY PERSONS CALL THEMSELVES TO THE ATTENTION OF PRS BY ATTEMPTING TO VISIT THE PRESIDENT
column5: many persons call themselves to the attention of prs by attempting to visit the president

column4: FOR BIZARRE REASONS OR BY WRITING OR IN SOME OTHER WAY ATTEMPTING TO COMMUNICATE WITH HIM IN A THREATENING OR ABUSIVE MANNER
column5: for bizarre reasons or by writing or in some other way attempting to communicate with him in a threatening or abusive manner

column4: OR WITH UNDUE PERSISTENCE
column5: or with undue persistence

column4: ROBERT I BOUCK SPECIAL AGENT IN CHARGE OF PRS
column5: robert i bouck special agent in charge of prs

column4: ESTIMATED THAT MOST OF THE MATERIAL RECEIVED BY HIS OFFICE ORIGINATED IN THIS FASHION
column5: estimated that most of the material received by his office originated in this fashion

column4: OR FROM THE OCCASIONAL INVESTIGATIONS INITIATED BY THE SECRET SERVICE
column5: or from the occasional investigations initiated by the secret service

column4: WHILE THE BALANCE WAS FURNISHED TO PRS BY OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES WITH PRIMARY SOURCE BEING THE FBI
column5: while the balance was furnished to prs by other federal agencies with primary source being the fbi

column4: THE TOTAL VOLUME OF INFORMATION RECEIVED BY PRS HAS RISEN STEADILY
column5: the total volume of information received by prs has risen steadily

column4: IN NINETEEN FORTYTHREE PRS RECEIVED APPROXIMATELY NINE THOUSAND ITEMS OF INFORMATION
column5: in nineteen fortythree prs received approximately nine thousand items of information

column4: IN NINETEEN FIFTYTHREE THIS HAD INCREASED TO MORE THAN SEVENTEEN THOUSAND ITEMS
column5: in nineteen fiftythree this had increased to more than seventeen thousand items

column4: IN NINETEEN SIXTYTHREE THE TOTAL EXCEEDED THIRTYTWO THOUSAND ITEMS
column5: in nineteen sixtythree the total exceeded thirtytwo thousand items

column4: SINCE MANY ITEMS MAY PERTAIN TO A SINGLE CASE THESE FIGURES DO NOT SHOW THE CASELOAD
column5: since many items may pertain to a single case these figures do not show the caseload

column4: IN THE PERIOD FROM NOVEMBER NINETEEN SIXTYONE TO NOVEMBER NINETEEN SIXTYTHREE
column5: in the period from november nineteen sixtyone to november nineteen sixtythree

column4: PRS RECEIVED ITEMS IN EIGHT THOUSAND SEVEN HUNDRED NINE CASES
column5: prs received items in eight thousand seven hundred nine cases

column4: BEFORE THE ASSASSINATION OF PRESIDENT KENNEDY
column5: before the assassination of president kennedy

column4: PRS EXPRESSED ITS INTEREST IN RECEIVING INFORMATION ON SUSPECTS IN VERY GENERAL TERMS FOR EXAMPLE
column5: prs expressed its interest in receiving information on suspects in very general terms for example

column4: PRS INSTRUCTED THE WHITE HOUSE MAILROOM A SOURCE OF MUCH PRS DATA
column5: prs instructed the white house mailroom a source of much prs data

column4: TO REFER ALL COMMUNICATIONS ON IDENTIFIED EXISTING CASES AND IN ADDITION
column5: to refer all communications on identified existing cases and in addition

column4: ANY COMMUNICATION QUOTE THAT IN ANY WAY INDICATES ANYONE MAY HAVE POSSIBLE INTENTION OF HARMING THE PRESIDENT END QUOTE
column5: any communication quote that in any way indicates anyone may have possible intention of harming the president end quote

column4: SLIGHTLY MORE SPECIFIC CRITERIA WERE ESTABLISHED FOR PRS PERSONNEL PROCESSING WHITE HOUSE MAIL REFERRED BY THE WHITE HOUSE MAILROOM
column5: slightly more specific criteria were established for prs personnel processing white house mail referred by the white house mailroom

column4: BUT AGAIN THE STANDARDS WERE VERY GENERAL
column5: but again the standards were very general

column4: THESE INSTRUCTIONS TO PRS PERSONNEL APPEAR TO BE THE ONLY INSTANCE WHERE AN EFFORT WAS MADE TO REDUCE THE CRITERIA TO WRITING
column5: these instructions to prs personnel appear to be the only instance where an effort was made to reduce the criteria to writing

column4: WHEN REQUESTED TO PROVIDE A SPECIFIC STATEMENT OF THE STANDARDS EMPLOYED BY PRS IN DECIDING WHAT INFORMATION TO SEEK AND RETAIN
column5: when requested to provide a specific statement of the standards employed by prs in deciding what information to seek and retain

column4: THE SECRET SERVICE RESPONDED QUOTE
column5: the secret service responded quote

column4: THE CRITERIA IN EFFECT PRIOR TO NOVEMBER TWENTYTWO NINETEEN SIXTYTHREE FOR DETERMINING WHETHER TO ACCEPT MATERIAL FOR THE PRS GENERAL FILES
column5: the criteria in effect prior to november twentytwo nineteen sixtythree for determining whether to accept material for the prs general files

column4: WERE BROAD AND FLEXIBLE ALL MATERIAL IS AND WAS DESIRED ACCEPTED AND FILED IF IT INDICATED OR TENDED TO INDICATE
column5: were broad and flexible all material is and was desired accepted and filed if it indicated or tended to indicate

column4: THAT THE SAFETY OF THE PRESIDENT IS OR MIGHT BE IN DANGER EITHER AT THE PRESENT OR IN THE FUTURE
column5: that the safety of the president is or might be in danger either at the present or in the future

column4: THERE ARE MANY ACTIONS SITUATIONS AND INCIDENTS THAT MAY INDICATE SUCH POTENTIAL DANGER SOME ARE SPECIFIC SUCH AS THREATS
column5: there are many actions situations and incidents that may indicate such potential danger some are specific such as threats

column4: DANGER MAY BE IMPLIED FROM OTHERS SUCH AS MEMBERSHIP OR ACTIVITY IN AN ORGANIZATION WHICH BELIEVES IN ASSASSINATION AS A POLITICAL WEAPON
column5: danger may be implied from others such as membership or activity in an organization which believes in assassination as a political weapon

column4: ALL MATERIAL RECEIVED BY PRS WAS SEPARATELY SCREENED
column5: all material received by prs was separately screened

column4: AND A DETERMINATION MADE AS TO WHETHER THE INFORMATION MIGHT INDICATE POSSIBLE HARM TO THE PRESIDENT
column5: and a determination made as to whether the information might indicate possible harm to the president

column4: IF THE MATERIAL WAS EVALUATED
column5: if the material was evaluated

column4: AS INDICATING SOME POTENTIAL DANGER TO THE PRESIDENT  NO MATTER HOW SMALL  IT WAS INDEXED IN THE GENERAL PRS FILES
column5: as indicating some potential danger to the president  no matter how small  it was indexed in the general prs files

column4: UNDER THE NAME OF THE INDIVIDUAL OR GROUP OF INDIVIDUALS TO WHOM THAT MATERIAL RELATED END QUOTE
column5: under the name of the individual or group of individuals to whom that material related end quote

column4: THE GENERAL FILES OF PRS CONSIST OF FOLDERS ON INDIVIDUALS CARD INDEXED BY NAME
column5: the general files of prs consist of folders on individuals card indexed by name

column4: THE FILES ARE MANUALLY MAINTAINED WITHOUT USE OF ANY AUTOMATIC DATAPROCESSING TECHNIQUES
column5: the files are manually maintained without use of any automatic dataprocessing techniques

column4: AT THE TIME OF THE ASSASSINATION THE ACTIVE PRS GENERAL FILES CONTAINED APPROXIMATELY FIFTY THOUSAND CASES
column5: at the time of the assassination the active prs general files contained approximately fifty thousand cases

column4: ACCUMULATED OVER A TWENTYYEAR PERIOD SOME OF WHICH INCLUDED MORE THAN ONE INDIVIDUAL
column5: accumulated over a twentyyear period some of which included more than one individual

column4: A CASE FILE WAS ESTABLISHED IF THE INFORMATION AVAILABLE SUGGESTED THAT THE SUBJECT MIGHT BE A DANGER TO THE PRESIDENT
column5: a case file was established if the information available suggested that the subject might be a danger to the president

column4: MANY OF THESE CASES WERE NOT INVESTIGATED BY PRS
column5: many of these cases were not investigated by prs

column4: THE CASE FILE SERVED MERELY AS A REPOSITORY FOR INFORMATION UNTIL ENOUGH HAD ACCUMULATED TO WARRANT AN INVESTIGATION
column5: the case file served merely as a repository for information until enough had accumulated to warrant an investigation

column4: DURING THE PERIOD NOVEMBER NINETEEN SIXTYONE TO NOVEMBER NINETEEN SIXTYTHREE
column5: during the period november nineteen sixtyone to november nineteen sixtythree

column4: PRS INVESTIGATED THIRTYFOUR NEWLY ESTABLISHED OR REACTIVATED CASES CONCERNING RESIDENTS OF TEXAS
column5: prs investigated thirtyfour newly established or reactivated cases concerning residents of texas

column4: MOST OF THESE CASES INVOLVED PERSONS WHO USED THREATENING LANGUAGE IN COMMUNICATIONS TO OR ABOUT THE PRESIDENT
column5: most of these cases involved persons who used threatening language in communications to or about the president

column4: AN ADDITIONAL ONE HUNDRED FIFTEEN CASES CONCERNING TEXAS RESIDENTS WERE ESTABLISHED BUT NOT INVESTIGATED
column5: an additional one hundred fifteen cases concerning texas residents were established but not investigated

column4: WHEN PRS LEARNS OF AN INDIVIDUAL WHOSE CONDUCT WARRANTS SCRUTINY IT REQUESTS AN INVESTIGATION BY THE CLOSEST SECRET SERVICE FIELD OFFICE
column5: when prs learns of an individual whose conduct warrants scrutiny it requests an investigation by the closest secret service field office

column4: OF WHICH THERE ARE SIXTYFIVE THROUGHOUT THE COUNTRY
column5: of which there are sixtyfive throughout the country

column4: IF THE FIELD OFFICE DETERMINES THAT THE CASE SHOULD BE SUBJECT TO CONTINUING REVIEW PRS ESTABLISHES A FILE
column5: if the field office determines that the case should be subject to continuing review prs establishes a file

column4: WHICH REQUIRES A CHECKUP AT LEAST EVERY SIX MONTHS
column5: which requires a checkup at least every six months

column4: THIS MIGHT INVOLVE A PERSONAL INTERVIEW OR INTERVIEWS WITH MEMBERS OF THE PERSON'S HOUSEHOLD WHEREVER POSSIBLE
column5: this might involve a personal interview or interviews with members of the person's household wherever possible

column4: THE SECRET SERVICE ARRANGES FOR THE FAMILY AND FRIENDS OF THE INDIVIDUAL AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS
column5: the secret service arranges for the family and friends of the individual and local law enforcement officials

column4: TO ADVISE THE FIELD OFFICE IF THE SUBJECT DISPLAYS SIGNS OF INCREASED DANGER OR PLANS TO LEAVE HIS HOME AREA
column5: to advise the field office if the subject displays signs of increased danger or plans to leave his home area

column4: AT THE TIME OF THE ASSASSINATION THERE WERE APPROXIMATELY FOUR HUNDRED PERSONS THROUGHOUT THE COUNTRY WHO WERE SUBJECT TO PERIODIC REVIEW
column5: at the time of the assassination there were approximately four hundred persons throughout the country who were subject to periodic review

column4: IF PRS CONCLUDES AFTER INVESTIGATION
column5: if prs concludes after investigation

column4: THAT AN INDIVIDUAL PRESENTS A SIGNIFICANT DANGER TO THE LIFE OF THE PRESIDENT HIS NAME IS PLACED IN A TRIP INDEX FILE
column5: that an individual presents a significant danger to the life of the president his name is placed in a trip index file

column4: WHICH IS MAINTAINED ON A GEOGRAPHICAL FIELD OFFICE BASIS
column5: which is maintained on a geographical field office basis

column4: AT THE TIME OF THE ASSASSINATION THE NAMES OF ABOUT ONE HUNDRED PERSONS WERE IN THIS INDEX ALL OF WHOM WERE INCLUDED IN THE GROUP OF FOUR HUNDRED
column5: at the time of the assassination the names of about one hundred persons were in this index all of whom were included in the group of four hundred

column4: BEING REVIEWED REGULARLY
column5: being reviewed regularly

column4: PRS ALSO MAINTAINS AN ALBUM OF PHOTOGRAPHS AND DESCRIPTIONS OF ABOUT TWELVE TO FIFTEEN INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE REGARDED AS CLEAR RISKS TO THE PRESIDENT
column5: prs also maintains an album of photographs and descriptions of about twelve to fifteen individuals who are regarded as clear risks to the president

column4: AND WHO DO NOT HAVE A FIXED PLACE OF RESIDENCE MEMBERS OF THE WHITE HOUSE DETAIL OF THE SECRET SERVICE HAVE COPIES OF THIS ALBUM
column5: and who do not have a fixed place of residence members of the white house detail of the secret service have copies of this album

column4: INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE REGARDED AS DANGEROUS TO THE PRESIDENT
column5: individuals who are regarded as dangerous to the president

column4: AND WHO ARE IN PENAL OR HOSPITAL CUSTODY ARE LISTED ONLY IN THE GENERAL FILES OF PRS
column5: and who are in penal or hospital custody are listed only in the general files of prs

column4: BUT THERE IS A SYSTEM FOR THE IMMEDIATE NOTIFICATION OF THE SECRET SERVICE BY THE CONFINING INSTITUTION WHEN A SUBJECT IS RELEASED OR ESCAPES
column5: but there is a system for the immediate notification of the secret service by the confining institution when a subject is released or escapes

column4: PRS ATTEMPTS TO ELIMINATE SERIOUS RISKS BY HOSPITALIZATION OR WHERE NECESSARY
column5: prs attempts to eliminate serious risks by hospitalization or where necessary

column4: THE PROSECUTION OF PERSONS WHO HAVE COMMITTED AN OFFENSE SUCH AS THREATENING THE PRESIDENT
column5: the prosecution of persons who have committed an offense such as threatening the president

column4: IN JUNE NINETEEN SIXTYFOUR PRS HAD ARRANGEMENTS TO BE NOTIFIED ABOUT THE RELEASE OR ESCAPE OF APPROXIMATELY ONE THOUSAND PERSONS
column5: in june nineteen sixtyfour prs had arrangements to be notified about the release or escape of approximately one thousand persons

column4: IN SUMMARY AT THE TIME OF THE ASSASSINATION
column5: in summary at the time of the assassination

column4: PRS HAD RECEIVED OVER A TWENTYYEAR PERIOD BASIC INFORMATION ON SOME FIFTY THOUSAND CASES
column5: prs had received over a twentyyear period basic information on some fifty thousand cases

column4: IT HAD ARRANGEMENTS TO BE NOTIFIED ABOUT RELEASE FROM CONFINEMENT IN ROUGHLY ONE THOUSAND CASES
column5: it had arrangements to be notified about release from confinement in roughly one thousand cases

column4: IT HAD ESTABLISHED PERIODIC REGULAR REVIEW OF THE STATUS OF FOUR HUNDRED INDIVIDUALS
column5: it had established periodic regular review of the status of four hundred individuals

column4: IT REGARDED APPROXIMATELY ONE HUNDRED OF THESE FOUR HUNDRED CASES AS SERIOUS RISKS
column5: it regarded approximately one hundred of these four hundred cases as serious risks

column4: AND TWELVE TO FIFTEEN OF THESE CASES AS HIGHLY DANGEROUS RISKS
column5: and twelve to fifteen of these cases as highly dangerous risks

column4: MEMBERS OF THE WHITE HOUSE DETAIL WERE EXPECTED TO FAMILIARIZE THEMSELVES WITH THE DESCRIPTIONS AND PHOTOGRAPHS OF THE HIGHEST RISK CASES
column5: members of the white house detail were expected to familiarize themselves with the descriptions and photographs of the highest risk cases

column4: THE CASES SUBJECT TO PERIODIC REVIEW AND THE ONE HUNDRED OR SO CASES IN THE HIGHER RISK CATEGORY
column5: the cases subject to periodic review and the one hundred or so cases in the higher risk category

column4: WERE FILED ON A GEOGRAPHIC BASIS AND COULD CONVENIENTLY BE REVIEWED BY A SECRET SERVICE AGENT PREPARING FOR A PRESIDENTIAL TRIP
column5: were filed on a geographic basis and could conveniently be reviewed by a secret service agent preparing for a presidential trip

column4: TO A PARTICULAR PART OF THE COUNTRY THESE WERE THE FILES REVIEWED BY PRS ON NOVEMBER EIGHT NINETEEN SIXTYTHREE
column5: to a particular part of the country these were the files reviewed by prs on november eight nineteen sixtythree

column4: AT THE REQUEST OF SPECIAL AGENT LAWSON ADVANCE AGENT FOR PRESIDENT KENNEDY'S TRIP TO DALLAS
column5: at the request of special agent lawson advance agent for president kennedy's trip to dallas

column4: THE GENERAL FILES OF PRS WERE NOT INDEXED BY GEOGRAPHIC LOCATION AND WERE OF LITTLE USE IN PREPARING FOR A PRESIDENTIAL VISIT TO A SPECIFIC LOCALITY
column5: the general files of prs were not indexed by geographic location and were of little use in preparing for a presidential visit to a specific locality

column4: SECRET SERVICE REQUESTS TO OTHER AGENCIES FOR INTELLIGENCE INFORMATION
column5: secret service requests to other agencies for intelligence information

column4: WERE NO MORE SPECIFIC THAN THE BROAD AND GENERAL INSTRUCTIONS ITS OWN AGENTS AND THE WHITE HOUSE MAILROOM
column5: were no more specific than the broad and general instructions its own agents and the white house mailroom

column4: THE HEAD OF PRS TESTIFIED THAT THE SECRET SERVICE REQUESTED OTHER AGENCIES TO PROVIDE QUOTE
column5: the head of prs testified that the secret service requested other agencies to provide quote

column4: ANY AND ALL INFORMATION THAT THEY MAY COME IN CONTACT WITH THAT WOULD INDICATE DANGER TO THE PRESIDENT END QUOTE
column5: any and all information that they may come in contact with that would indicate danger to the president end quote

column4: THESE REQUESTS WERE COMMUNICATED IN WRITING BY THE SECRET SERVICE RATHER THE SERVICE DEPENDED ON THE PERSONAL LIAISON MAINTAINED BY PRS
column5: these requests were communicated in writing by the secret service rather the service depended on the personal liaison maintained by prs

column4: WITH THE HEADQUARTERS OF THE FEDERAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES PARTICULARLY THE FBI
column5: with the headquarters of the federal intelligence agencies particularly the fbi

column4: AND AT THE WORKING LEVEL WITH PERSONNEL OF THE FIELD OFFICES OF THE VARIOUS AGENCIES THE SERVICE FREQUENTLY PARTICIPATED
column5: and at the working level with personnel of the field offices of the various agencies the service frequently participated

column4: IN THE TRAINING PROGRAMS OF OTHER LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES AND AGENTS FROM OTHER AGENCIES ATTENDED THE REGULAR SECRET SERVICE TRAINING SCHOOLS
column5: in the training programs of other law enforcement agencies and agents from other agencies attended the regular secret service training schools

column4: PRESIDENTIAL PROTECTION WAS AN IMPORTANT TOPIC IN THESE TRAINING PROGRAMS
column5: presidential protection was an important topic in these training programs

column4: IN THE ABSENCE OF MORE SPECIFIC INSTRUCTIONS OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES INTERPRETED THE SECRET SERVICE'S INFORMAL REQUESTS
column5: in the absence of more specific instructions other federal agencies interpreted the secret service's informal requests

column4: TO RELATE PRINCIPALLY TO OVERT THREATS TO HARM THE PRESIDENT OR OTHER SPECIFIC MANIFESTATIONS OF HOSTILITY
column5: to relate principally to overt threats to harm the president or other specific manifestations of hostility

column4: FOR EXAMPLE AT THE TIME OF THE ASSASSINATION THE FBI HANDBOOK WHICH IS IN THE POSSESSION OF EVERY BUREAU SPECIAL AGENT PROVIDED QUOTE
column5: for example at the time of the assassination the fbi handbook which is in the possession of every bureau special agent provided quote

column4: THREATS AGAINST THE PRESIDENT OF THE US
column5: threats against the president of the us

column4: MEMBERS OF HIS IMMEDIATE FAMILY THE PRESIDENTELECT AND THE VICEPRESIDENT INVESTIGATION OF THREATS AGAINST THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
column5: members of his immediate family the presidentelect and the vicepresident investigation of threats against the president of the united states

column4: MEMBERS OF HIS IMMEDIATE FAMILY THE PRESIDENTELECT AND THE VICEPRESIDENT IS WITHIN THE EXCLUSIVE JURISDICTION OF THE US SECRET SERVICE
column5: members of his immediate family the presidentelect and the vicepresident is within the exclusive jurisdiction of the us secret service

column4: ANY INFORMATION INDICATING THE POSSIBILITY OF AN ATTEMPT AGAINST THE PERSON OR SAFETY OF THE PRESIDENT
column5: any information indicating the possibility of an attempt against the person or safety of the president

column4: MEMBERS OF THE IMMEDIATE FAMILY OF THE PRESIDENT THE PRESIDENTELECT OR THE VICEPRESIDENT
column5: members of the immediate family of the president the presidentelect or the vicepresident

column4: MUST BE REFERRED IMMEDIATELY BY THE MOST EXPEDITIOUS MEANS OF COMMUNICATION TO THE NEAREST OFFICE OF THE US SECRET SERVICE
column5: must be referred immediately by the most expeditious means of communication to the nearest office of the us secret service

column4: ADVISE THE BUREAU AT THE SAME TIME BY TELETYPE OF THE INFORMATION SO FURNISHED TO THE SECRET SERVICE AND THE FACT THAT IT HAS BEEN SO DISSEMINATED
column5: advise the bureau at the same time by teletype of the information so furnished to the secret service and the fact that it has been so disseminated

column4: THE ABOVE ACTION SHOULD BE TAKEN WITHOUT DELAY IN ORDER TO ATTEMPT TO VERIFY THE INFORMATION AND NO EVALUATION OF THE INFORMATION SHOULD BE ATTEMPTED
column5: the above action should be taken without delay in order to attempt to verify the information and no evaluation of the information should be attempted

column4: WHEN THE THREAT IS IN THE FORM OF A WRITTEN COMMUNICATION GIVE A COPY TO LOCAL SECRET SERVICE AND FORWARD THE ORIGINAL TO THE BUREAU
column5: when the threat is in the form of a written communication give a copy to local secret service and forward the original to the bureau

column4: WHERE IT WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE TO SECRET SERVICE HEADQUARTERS IN WASHINGTON
column5: where it will be made available to secret service headquarters in washington

column4: THE REFERRAL OF THE COPY TO LOCAL SECRET SERVICE SHOULD NOT DELAY THE IMMEDIATE REFERRAL OF THE INFORMATION BY THE FASTEST AVAILABLE MEANS OF COMMUNICATION
column5: the referral of the copy to local secret service should not delay the immediate referral of the information by the fastest available means of communication

column4: TO SECRET SERVICE LOCALLY END QUOTE
column5: to secret service locally end quote

column4: THE STATE DEPARTMENT ADVISED THE SECRET SERVICE OF ALL CRANK AND THREAT LETTER MAIL
column5: the state department advised the secret service of all crank and threat letter mail

column4: OR CRANK VISITORS AND FURNISHED REPORTS CONCERNING ANY ASSASSINATION OR ATTEMPTED ASSASSINATION OF A RULER OR OTHER MAJOR OFFICIAL ANYWHERE IN THE WORLD
column5: or crank visitors and furnished reports concerning any assassination or attempted assassination of a ruler or other major official anywhere in the world

column4: THE SEVERAL MILITARY INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES REPORTED CRANK MAIL AND SIMILAR THREATS INVOLVING THE PRESIDENT
column5: the several military intelligence agencies reported crank mail and similar threats involving the president

column4: ACCORDING TO SPECIAL AGENT IN CHARGE BOUCK
column5: according to special agent in charge bouck

column4: THE SECRET SERVICE HAD NO STANDARD PROCEDURE FOR THE SYSTEMATIC REVIEW OF ITS REQUESTS FOR AND RECEIPT OF INFORMATION FROM OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES
column5: the secret service had no standard procedure for the systematic review of its requests for and receipt of information from other federal agencies

column4: THE COMMISSION BELIEVES THAT THE FACILITIES AND PROCEDURES OF THE PROTECTIVE RESEARCH SECTION OF THE SECRET SERVICE
column5: the commission believes that the facilities and procedures of the protective research section of the secret service

column4: PRIOR TO NOVEMBER TWENTYTWO NINETEEN SIXTYTHREE WERE INADEQUATE
column5: prior to november twentytwo nineteen sixtythree were inadequate

column4: ITS EFFORTS APPEAR TO HAVE BEEN TOO LARGELY DIRECTED AT THE CRANK THREAT
column5: its efforts appear to have been too largely directed at the crank threat

column4: ALTHOUGH THE SERVICE RECOGNIZED THAT ITS ADVANCE PREVENTIVE MEASURES MUST ENCOMPASS MORE THAN THESE MOST OBVIOUS DANGERS
column5: although the service recognized that its advance preventive measures must encompass more than these most obvious dangers

column4: IT MADE LITTLE EFFORT TO IDENTIFY FACTORS IN THE ACTIVITIES OF AN INDIVIDUAL
column5: it made little effort to identify factors in the activities of an individual

column4: OR AN ORGANIZED GROUP OTHER THAN SPECIFIC THREATS WHICH SUGGESTED A SOURCE OF DANGER AGAINST WHICH TIMELY PRECAUTIONS COULD BE TAKEN
column5: or an organized group other than specific threats which suggested a source of danger against which timely precautions could be taken

column4: EXCEPT FOR ITS SPECIAL TRIP INDEX FILE OF FOUR HUNDRED NAMES
column5: except for its special trip index file of four hundred names

column4: NONE OF THE CASES IN THE PRS GENERAL FILES WAS AVAILABLE FOR SYSTEMATIC REVIEW ON A GEOGRAPHIC BASIS WHEN THE PRESIDENT PLANNED A PARTICULAR TRIP
column5: none of the cases in the prs general files was available for systematic review on a geographic basis when the president planned a particular trip

column4: AS REPORTED IN CHAPTER TWO WHEN THE SPECIAL FILE WAS REVIEWED ON NOVEMBER EIGHT
column5: as reported in chapter two when the special file was reviewed on november eight

column4: IT CONTAINED THE NAMES OF NO PERSONS FROM THE ENTIRE DALLASFORT WORTH AREA
column5: it contained the names of no persons from the entire dallasfort worth area

column4: NOTWITHSTANDING THE FACT THAT AMBASSADOR STEVENSON HAD BEEN ABUSED BY PICKETS IN DALLAS LESS THAN A MONTH BEFORE
column5: notwithstanding the fact that ambassador stevenson had been abused by pickets in dallas less than a month before

column4: BOUCK EXPLAINED THE FAILURE TO TRY TO IDENTIFY THE INDIVIDUALS INVOLVED IN THE STEVENSON INCIDENT AFTER IT OCCURRED ON THE GROUND THAT
column5: bouck explained the failure to try to identify the individuals involved in the stevenson incident after it occurred on the ground that

column4: PRS REQUIRED A MORE DIRECT INDICATION OF A THREAT TO THE PRESIDENT AND THAT THERE WAS NO SUCH INDICATION UNTIL THE PRESIDENT'S SCHEDULED VISIT TO THAT AREA BECAME KNOWN
column5: prs required a more direct indication of a threat to the president and that there was no such indication until the president's scheduled visit to that area became known

column4: SUCH AN APPROACH SERIOUSLY UNDERMINES THE PRECAUTIONARY NATURE OF PRS WORK
column5: such an approach seriously undermines the precautionary nature of prs work

column4: IF THE PRESENCE IN DALLAS OF THE STEVENSON PICKETS MIGHT HAVE CREATED A DANGER FOR THE PRESIDENT ON A VISIT TO THAT CITY
column5: if the presence in dallas of the stevenson pickets might have created a danger for the president on a visit to that city

column4: PRS SHOULD HAVE INVESTIGATED AND BEEN PREPARED TO GUARD AGAINST IT
column5: prs should have investigated and been prepared to guard against it

column5: other agencies occasionally provided information to the secret service concerning potentially dangerous political groups

column5: however the vague requests for information which the secret service made

column5: to federal intelligence and law enforcement agencies were not well designed to elicit information from them

column4: ABOUT PERSONS OTHER THAN THOSE WHO WERE OBVIOUS THREATS TO THE PRESIDENT
column5: about persons other than those who were obvious threats to the president

column5: the requests shifted the responsibility for evaluating difficult cases from the service the agency most responsible for performing that task

column5: to the other agencies no specific guidance was provided

column5: it had no written specification of intelligence information collected by cia abroad which was desired by the secret service

column5: the special agent is officially employed and should not use liquor until the completion of all of his official duties for the day

column4: AFTER WHICH TIME A VERY MODERATE USE OF LIQUOR WILL NOT BE CONSIDERED A VIOLATION HOWEVER ALL MEMBERS OF THE WHITE HOUSE DETAIL
column5: after which time a very moderate use of liquor will not be considered a violation however all members of the white house detail

column4: AND SPECIAL AGENTS COOPERATING WITH THEM ON PRESIDENTIAL AND SIMILAR PROTECTIVE ASSIGNMENTS ARE CONSIDERED TO BE SUBJECT TO CALL FOR OFFICIAL DUTY
column5: and special agents cooperating with them on presidential and similar protective assignments are considered to be subject to call for official duty

column4: AT ANY TIME WHILE IN TRAVEL STATUS
column5: at any time while in travel status

column4: THEREFORE THE USE OF INTOXICATING LIQUOR OF ANY KIND INCLUDING BEER AND WINE BY MEMBERS OF THE WHITE HOUSE DETAIL
column5: therefore the use of intoxicating liquor of any kind including beer and wine by members of the white house detail

column4: AND SPECIAL AGENTS COOPERATING WITH THEM OR BY SPECIAL AGENTS ON SIMILAR ASSIGNMENTS WHILE THEY ARE IN A TRAVEL STATUS IS PROHIBITED END QUOTE
column5: and special agents cooperating with them or by special agents on similar assignments while they are in a travel status is prohibited end quote

column4: THE REGULATIONS PROVIDE FURTHER THAT QUOTE VIOLATION OR SLIGHT DISREGARD END QUOTE OF THESE PROVISIONS QUOTE
column5: the regulations provide further that quote violation or slight disregard end quote of these provisions quote

column4: WILL BE CAUSE FOR REMOVAL FROM THE SERVICE END QUOTE
column5: will be cause for removal from the service end quote

column4: CHIEF ROWLEY TESTIFIED
column5: chief rowley testified

column4: THAT UNDER ORDINARY CIRCUMSTANCES HE WOULD HAVE TAKEN DISCIPLINARY ACTION AGAINST THOSE AGENTS WHO HAD BEEN DRINKING IN CLEAR VIOLATION OF THE REGULATION
column5: that under ordinary circumstances he would have taken disciplinary action against those agents who had been drinking in clear violation of the regulation

column4: HOWEVER HE FELT THAT ANY DISCIPLINARY ACTION MIGHT HAVE GIVEN RISE
column5: however he felt that any disciplinary action might have given rise

column4: TO AN INFERENCE THAT THE VIOLATION OF THE REGULATION HAD CONTRIBUTED TO THE TRAGIC EVENTS OF NOVEMBER TWENTYTWO
column5: to an inference that the violation of the regulation had contributed to the tragic events of november twentytwo

column4: SINCE HE WAS CONVINCED THAT THIS WAS NOT THE CASE HE BELIEVED THAT IT WOULD BE UNFAIR TO THE AGENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES TO TAKE EXPLICIT DISCIPLINARY MEASURES
column5: since he was convinced that this was not the case he believed that it would be unfair to the agents and their families to take explicit disciplinary measures

column4: HE FELT THAT EACH AGENT RECOGNIZED THE SERIOUSNESS OF THE INFRACTION AND THAT THERE WAS NO DANGER OF A REPETITION
column5: he felt that each agent recognized the seriousness of the infraction and that there was no danger of a repetition

column4: THE COMMISSION RECOGNIZES THAT THE RESPONSIBILITIES OF MEMBERS OF THE WHITE HOUSE DETAIL OF THE SECRET SERVICE ARE ARDUOUS
column5: the commission recognizes that the responsibilities of members of the white house detail of the secret service are arduous

column4: THEY WORK LONG HARD HOURS UNDER VERY GREAT STRAIN AND MUST TRAVEL FREQUENTLY
column5: they work long hard hours under very great strain and must travel frequently

column4: IT MIGHT SEEM HARSH TO CIRCUMSCRIBE THEIR OPPORTUNITIES FOR RELAXATION
column5: it might seem harsh to circumscribe their opportunities for relaxation

column4: YET THEIR ROLE OF PROTECTING THE PRESIDENT IS SO IMPORTANT TO THE WELLBEING OF THE COUNTRY
column5: yet their role of protecting the president is so important to the wellbeing of the country

column4: THAT IT IS REASONABLE TO EXPECT THEM TO MEET VERY HIGH STANDARDS OF PERSONAL CONDUCT
column5: that it is reasonable to expect them to meet very high standards of personal conduct

column4: SO THAT NOTHING CAN INTERFERE WITH THEIR BRINGING TO THEIR TASK THE FINEST QUALITIES AND MAXIMUM RESOURCES OF MIND AND BODY
column5: so that nothing can interfere with their bringing to their task the finest qualities and maximum resources of mind and body

column4: THIS IS THE SALUTARY GOAL TO WHICH THE SECRET SERVICE REGULATION IS DIRECTED
column5: this is the salutary goal to which the secret service regulation is directed

column4: WHEN IT ABSOLUTELY FORBIDS DRINKING BY ANY AGENT ACCOMPANYING THE PRESIDENT ON A TRIP
column5: when it absolutely forbids drinking by any agent accompanying the president on a trip

column4: NOR IS THIS GOAL SERVED WHEN AGENTS REMAIN OUT UNTIL EARLY MORNING HOURS AND LOSE THE OPPORTUNITY TO GET A REASONABLE AMOUNT OF SLEEP
column5: nor is this goal served when agents remain out until early morning hours and lose the opportunity to get a reasonable amount of sleep

column5: it is conceivable that those men who had little sleep and who had consumed alcoholic beverages even in limited quantities

column5: however there is no evidence that these men failed to take any action in dallas within their power that would have averted the tragedy

column5: stationing police on the rooftops of all buildings overlooking the reception area

column5: when president and mrs kennedy shook hands with members of the public along the fences surrounding the reception area they were closely guarded by secret service agents

column5: at these stops agents from the presidential followup car stood between the president and the public

column5: the commission regards such impromptu stops as presenting an unnecessary danger

column4: BUT FINDS THAT THE SECRET SERVICE AGENTS DID ALL THAT COULD HAVE BEEN DONE TO TAKE PROTECTIVE MEASURES
column5: but finds that the secret service agents did all that could have been done to take protective measures

column5: the limousine used by president kennedy in dallas was a convertible with a detachable rigid plastic bubble top

column4: WHICH WAS NEITHER BULLETPROOF NOR BULLET RESISTANT
column5: which was neither bulletproof nor bullet resistant

column5: the last presidential vehicle with any protection against smallarms fire left the white house in nineteen fiftythree

column4: IT WAS NOT THEN REPLACED BECAUSE THE STATE OF THE ART DID NOT PERMIT THE DEVELOPMENT OF A BULLETPROOF TOP OF SUFFICIENTLY LIGHT WEIGHT
column5: it was not then replaced because the state of the art did not permit the development of a bulletproof top of sufficiently light weight

column4: TO PERMIT ITS REMOVAL ON THOSE OCCASIONS WHEN THE PRESIDENT WISHED TO RIDE IN AN OPEN CAR
column5: to permit its removal on those occasions when the president wished to ride in an open car

column5: the secret service believed that it was very doubtful that any president would ride regularly in a vehicle with a fixed top even though transparent

column5: since the assassination the secret service with the assistance of other federal agencies and of private industry

column5: the secret service has therefore suggested this practice only on extraordinary occasions

column5: to move into the passenger section without hindrance or delay had the vehicle been so designed it is possible that an agent riding in the front seat

column5: could have reached the president in time to protect him from the second and fatal shot to hit the president

column4: HOWEVER SUCH ACCESS TO THE PRESIDENT WAS INTERFERED WITH BOTH BY THE METAL BAR SOME FIFTEEN INCHES ABOVE THE BACK OF THE FRONT SEAT

column5: and by the passengers in the jump seats

column5: in contrast the vice presidential vehicle although not specially designed for that purpose

column5: had no passenger in a jump seat between agent youngblood and vice president johnson to interfere with agent youngblood's ability

column4: TO TAKE A PROTECTIVE POSITION IN THE PASSENGER COMPARTMENT BEFORE THE THIRD SHOT WAS FIRED
column5: to take a protective position in the passenger compartment before the third shot was fired

column4: THE ASSASSINATION SUGGESTS THAT IT WOULD HAVE BEEN OF PRIME IMPORTANCE
column5: the assassination suggests that it would have been of prime importance

column5: at that time the agents on the framing boards of the followup car were expected to perform such a function

column5: even if the car is traveling more slowly the delay involved in reaching the president may be crucial

column5: it is clear that at the time of the shots in dallas agent clinton j hill leaped to the president's rescue as quickly as humanly possible

column5: even so analysis of the motion picture films taken by amateur photographer zapruder

column4: REVEALS THAT HILL FIRST PLACED HIS HAND ON THE PRESIDENTIAL CAR AT FRAME THREE FORTYTHREE THIRTY FRAMES
column5: reveals that hill first placed his hand on the presidential car at frame three fortythree thirty frames

column4: AND THEREFORE APPROXIMATELY ONE POINT SIX SECONDS AFTER THE PRESIDENT WAS SHOT IN THE HEAD

column4: PLANNING FOR MOTORCADE CONTINGENCIES
column5: planning for motorcade contingencies

column4: IN RESPONSE TO INQUIRY BY THE COMMISSION REGARDING THE INSTRUCTIONS TO AGENTS IN A MOTORCADE
column5: in response to inquiry by the commission regarding the instructions to agents in a motorcade

column4: OF EMERGENCY PROCEDURES TO BE TAKEN IN A CONTINGENCY SUCH AS THAT WHICH ACTUALLY OCCURRED THE SECRET SERVICE RESPONDED QUOTE
column5: of emergency procedures to be taken in a contingency such as that which actually occurred the secret service responded quote

column4: THE SECRET SERVICE HAS CONSISTENTLY FOLLOWED TWO GENERAL PRINCIPLES IN EMERGENCIES INVOLVING THE PRESIDENT
column5: the secret service has consistently followed two general principles in emergencies involving the president

column4: ALL AGENTS ARE SO INSTRUCTED
column5: all agents are so instructed

column4: THE FIRST DUTY OF THE AGENTS IN THE MOTORCADE IS TO ATTEMPT TO COVER THE PRESIDENT AS CLOSELY AS POSSIBLE AND PRACTICABLE
column5: the first duty of the agents in the motorcade is to attempt to cover the president as closely as possible and practicable

column4: AND TO SHIELD HIM BY ATTEMPTING TO PLACE THEMSELVES BETWEEN THE PRESIDENT AND ANY SOURCE OF DANGER
column5: and to shield him by attempting to place themselves between the president and any source of danger

column4: SECONDLY AGENTS ARE INSTRUCTED TO REMOVE THE PRESIDENT AS QUICKLY AS POSSIBLE FROM KNOWN OR IMPENDING DANGER
column5: secondly agents are instructed to remove the president as quickly as possible from known or impending danger

column4: AGENTS ARE INSTRUCTED THAT IT IS NOT THEIR RESPONSIBILITY TO INVESTIGATE OR EVALUATE A PRESENT DANGER
column5: agents are instructed that it is not their responsibility to investigate or evaluate a present danger

column4: BUT TO CONSIDER ANY UNTOWARD CIRCUMSTANCES AS SERIOUS AND TO AFFORD THE PRESIDENT MAXIMUM PROTECTION AT ALL TIMES
column5: but to consider any untoward circumstances as serious and to afford the president maximum protection at all times

column4: NO RESPONSIBILITY RESTS UPON THOSE AGENTS NEAR THE PRESIDENT FOR THE IDENTIFICATION OR ARREST OF ANY ASSASSIN OR AN ATTACKER
column5: no responsibility rests upon those agents near the president for the identification or arrest of any assassin or an attacker

column4: THEIR PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY IS TO STAY WITH AND PROTECT THE PRESIDENT
column5: their primary responsibility is to stay with and protect the president

column4: BEYOND THESE TWO PRINCIPLES THE SECRET SERVICE BELIEVES A DETAILED CONTINGENCY OR EMERGENCY PLAN IS NOT FEASIBLE
column5: beyond these two principles the secret service believes a detailed contingency or emergency plan is not feasible

column4: BECAUSE THE VARIATIONS POSSIBLE PRECLUDE EFFECTIVE PLANNING
column5: because the variations possible preclude effective planning

column4: A NUMBER OF STEPS ARE TAKEN HOWEVER TO PERMIT APPROPRIATE STEPS TO BE TAKEN IN AN EMERGENCY
column5: a number of steps are taken however to permit appropriate steps to be taken in an emergency

column4: FOR INSTANCE THE LEAD CAR ALWAYS IS MANNED BY SECRET SERVICE AGENTS FAMILIAR WITH THE AREA AND WITH LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS
column5: for instance the lead car always is manned by secret service agents familiar with the area and with local law enforcement officials

column4: THE RADIO NET IN USE IN MOTORCADES IS ELABORATE AND PERMITS A NUMBER OF DIFFERENT MEANS OF COMMUNICATION WITH VARIOUS LOCAL POINTS
column5: the radio net in use in motorcades is elaborate and permits a number of different means of communication with various local points

column4: A DOCTOR IS IN THE MOTORCADE
column5: a doctor is in the motorcade

column4: THIS BASIC APPROACH TO THE PROBLEM OF PLANNING FOR EMERGENCIES IS SOUND
column5: this basic approach to the problem of planning for emergencies is sound

column4: ANY EFFORT TO PREPARE DETAILED CONTINGENCY PLANS MIGHT WELL HAVE THE UNDESIRABLE EFFECT OF INHIBITING QUICK AND IMAGINATIVE RESPONSES
column5: any effort to prepare detailed contingency plans might well have the undesirable effect of inhibiting quick and imaginative responses

column4: IF THE ADVANCE PREPARATION IS THOROUGH AND THE PROTECTIVE DEVICES AND TECHNIQUES EMPLOYED ARE SOUND
column5: if the advance preparation is thorough and the protective devices and techniques employed are sound

column4: THOSE IN COMMAND SHOULD BE ABLE TO DIRECT THE RESPONSE APPROPRIATE TO THE EMERGENCY THE COMMISSION FINDS THAT THE SECRET SERVICE AGENTS IN THE MOTORCADE
column5: those in command should be able to direct the response appropriate to the emergency the commission finds that the secret service agents in the motorcade

column4: WHO WERE IMMEDIATELY RESPONSIBLE FOR THE PRESIDENT'S SAFETY REACTED PROMPTLY AT THE TIME THE SHOTS WERE FIRED
column5: who were immediately responsible for the president's safety reacted promptly at the time the shots were fired

column4: THEIR ACTIONS DEMONSTRATE THAT THE PRESIDENT AND THE NATION CAN EXPECT COURAGE AND DEVOTION TO DUTY FROM THE AGENTS OF THE SECRET SERVICE
column5: their actions demonstrate that the president and the nation can expect courage and devotion to duty from the agents of the secret service

column5: recommendations

column5: the commission's review of the provisions for presidential protection at the time of president kennedy's trip to dallas demonstrates the need for substantial improvements

column5: since the assassination the secret service and the department of the treasury

column4: HAVE PROPERLY TAKEN THE INITIATIVE IN REEXAMINING MAJOR ASPECTS OF PRESIDENTIAL PROTECTION
column5: have properly taken the initiative in reexamining major aspects of presidential protection

column5: many changes have already been made and others are contemplated some of them in response to the commission's questions and informal suggestions

column4: ASSASSINATION A FEDERAL CRIME
column5: assassination a federal crime

column4: THERE WAS NO FEDERAL CRIMINAL JURISDICTION OVER THE ASSASSINATION OF PRESIDENT KENNEDY
column5: there was no federal criminal jurisdiction over the assassination of president kennedy

column4: HAD THERE BEEN REASON TO BELIEVE THAT THE ASSASSINATION WAS THE RESULT OF A CONSPIRACY FEDERAL JURISDICTION COULD HAVE BEEN ASSERTED
column5: had there been reason to believe that the assassination was the result of a conspiracy federal jurisdiction could have been asserted

column4: IT HAS LONG BEEN A FEDERAL CRIME TO CONSPIRE TO INJURE ANY FEDERAL OFFICER ON ACCOUNT OF OR WHILE HE IS ENGAGED IN THE LAWFUL DISCHARGE OF THE DUTIES OF HIS OFFICE
column5: it has long been a federal crime to conspire to injure any federal officer on account of or while he is engaged in the lawful discharge of the duties of his office

column4: MURDER OF THE PRESIDENT HAS NEVER BEEN COVERED BY FEDERAL LAW HOWEVER SO THAT ONCE IT BECAME REASONABLY CLEAR THAT THE KILLING WAS THE ACT OF A SINGLE PERSON
column5: murder of the president has never been covered by federal law however so that once it became reasonably clear that the killing was the act of a single person

column4: THE STATE OF TEXAS HAD EXCLUSIVE JURISDICTION
column5: the state of texas had exclusive jurisdiction

column4: IT IS ANOMALOUS THAT CONGRESS HAS LEGISLATED IN OTHER WAYS TOUCHING UPON THE SAFETY OF THE CHIEF EXECUTIVE OR OTHER FEDERAL OFFICERS
column5: it is anomalous that congress has legislated in other ways touching upon the safety of the chief executive or other federal officers

column4: WITHOUT MAKING AN ATTACK ON THE PRESIDENT A CRIME THREATENING HARM TO THE PRESIDENT IS A FEDERAL OFFENSE
column5: without making an attack on the president a crime threatening harm to the president is a federal offense

column4: AS IS ADVOCACY OF THE OVERTHROW OF THE GOVERNMENT BY THE ASSASSINATION OF ANY OF ITS OFFICERS
column5: as is advocacy of the overthrow of the government by the assassination of any of its officers

column4: THE MURDER OF FEDERAL JUDGES US ATTORNEYS AND MARSHALS AND A NUMBER OF OTHER SPECIFICALLY DESIGNATED
column5: the murder of federal judges us attorneys and marshals and a number of other specifically designated

column4: FEDERAL LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS IS A FEDERAL CRIME
column5: federal law enforcement officers is a federal crime

column4: EQUALLY ANOMALOUS ARE STATUTORY PROVISIONS WHICH SPECIFICALLY AUTHORIZE THE SECRET SERVICE TO PROTECT THE PRESIDENT
column5: equally anomalous are statutory provisions which specifically authorize the secret service to protect the president

column4: WITHOUT AUTHORIZING IT TO ARREST ANYONE WHO HARMS HIM THE SAME PROVISIONS AUTHORIZE THE SERVICE TO ARREST WITHOUT WARRANT
column5: without authorizing it to arrest anyone who harms him the same provisions authorize the service to arrest without warrant

column4: PERSONS COMMITTING CERTAIN OFFENSES INCLUDING COUNTERFEITING AND CERTAIN FRAUDS INVOLVING FEDERAL CHECKS OR SECURITIES
column5: persons committing certain offenses including counterfeiting and certain frauds involving federal checks or securities

column4: THE COMMISSION AGREES WITH THE SECRET SERVICE THAT IT SHOULD BE AUTHORIZED TO MAKE ARRESTS WITHOUT WARRANT
column5: the commission agrees with the secret service that it should be authorized to make arrests without warrant

column4: FOR ALL OFFENSES WITHIN ITS JURISDICTION AS ARE FBI AGENTS AND FEDERAL MARSHALS
column5: for all offenses within its jurisdiction as are fbi agents and federal marshals

column4: THERE HAVE BEEN A NUMBER OF EFFORTS TO MAKE ASSASSINATION A FEDERAL CRIME PARTICULARLY AFTER THE ASSASSINATION OF PRESIDENT MCKINLEY
column5: there have been a number of efforts to make assassination a federal crime particularly after the assassination of president mckinley

column4: AND THE ATTEMPT ON THE LIFE OF PRESIDENTELECT FRANKLIN D ROOSEVELT
column5: and the attempt on the life of presidentelect franklin d roosevelt

column4: IN NINETEEN OH TWO BILLS PASSED BOTH HOUSES OF CONGRESS BUT FAILED OF ENACTMENT WHEN THE SENATE REFUSED TO ACCEPT THE CONFERENCE REPORT
column5: in nineteen oh two bills passed both houses of congress but failed of enactment when the senate refused to accept the conference report

column4: A NUMBER OF BILLS WERE INTRODUCED IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING THE ASSASSINATION OF PRESIDENT KENNEDY
column5: a number of bills were introduced immediately following the assassination of president kennedy

column5: the commission recommends to the congress that it adopt legislation which would

column5: punish the murder or manslaughter of attempt or conspiracy to murder kidnaping of and assault upon

column5: the president vice president or other officer next in the order of succession to the office of president the presidentelect and the vicepresidentelect

column4: WHETHER OR NOT THE ACT IS COMMITTED WHILE THE VICTIM IS IN THE PERFORMANCE OF HIS OFFICIAL DUTIES OR ON ACCOUNT OF SUCH PERFORMANCE
column5: whether or not the act is committed while the victim is in the performance of his official duties or on account of such performance

column4: SUCH A STATUTE WOULD COVER THE PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENT OR IN THE ABSENCE OF A VICE PRESIDENT THE PERSON NEXT IN ORDER OF SUCCESSION
column5: such a statute would cover the president and vice president or in the absence of a vice president the person next in order of succession

column4: DURING THE PERIOD BETWEEN ELECTION AND INAUGURATION THE PRESIDENTELECT AND VICEPRESIDENTELECT WOULD ALSO BE COVERED
column5: during the period between election and inauguration the presidentelect and vicepresidentelect would also be covered

column4: RESTRICTING THE COVERAGE IN THIS WAY WOULD AVOID UNNECESSARY CONTROVERSY OVER THE INCLUSION OR EXCLUSION OF OTHER OFFICIALS WHO ARE IN THE ORDER OF SUCCESSION
column5: restricting the coverage in this way would avoid unnecessary controversy over the inclusion or exclusion of other officials who are in the order of succession

column5: or who hold important governmental posts
